Title: Ecto - adenosine triphosphatase activity at the cholinergic nerve endings of the torpedo electric organ
Affiliations: Fachbereich Biologie der Universität Oldenburg, 2900 Oldenburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Keller, F., Fachbereich Biologie der Universität Oldenburg, 2900 Oldenburg, Germany; Zimmermann, H., Fachbereich Biologie der Universität Oldenburg, 2900 Oldenburg, Germany
Abstract: Synaptosomes isolated from the electric organ of Torpedo marmorata contain activity of an ATPase which is located at the extracellular face of the plasma membrane. Ecto-ATPase activity can be stimulated independently and to a similar extent by either Ca-2+ or Mg-2+ Apparent Km-values for ATP are 79 μM and 53 μM for Ca-2+ and Mg-2+ respectively. Apparent Km-values for Ca-2+ and Mg-2+ at 1 mM ATP are 0.71 mM and 0.61 mM respectively. The enzyme is also activated by Mn-2+ and GTP can replace ATP as a substrate. Presence of 5′-nucleotidase activity suggests that adenosine is the final hydrolysis product. Thus hydrolysis of nucleotides released during exocytosis of synaptic vesicle contents and purine salvage may be a major role of this ecto-enzyme. We furthermore suggest that the ecto-ATPase may provide the key to understanding the storage of the high energy compound ATP in cholinergic synaptic vesicles. On depolarization of the nerve terminal and exocytosis, ATP represents the signal for activating the ATPase whereby concentrations of Ca-2+ and Mg-2+ are already saturating. Following depolarization induced Ca-2+ influx, a possible function of the ATPase may be the outward transport of Ca-2+ from the nerve terminal. © 1983.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphatase; calcium; animal cell; cholinergic nerve; electric organ; invertebrate; nerve ending; nervous system; nonhuman; synaptosome; Adenosine Monophosphate; Adenosine Triphosphate; Adenosinetriphosphatase; Animal; Ca(2+) Mg(2+)-ATPase; Ca(2+)-Transporting ATPase; Electric Organ; Glycerophosphates; Guanosine Triphosphate; Hydrolysis; In Vitro; Kinetics; Receptors, Cholinergic; Synaptosomes; Torpedo

Title: Energy conservation by underground heat storage examples from the swedish energy programme
Source title: Advances in Tunnelling Technology and Subsurface Use
Affiliations: Swedish Rock Engineering Research Foundation-BeFo, Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Bjurström, S., Swedish Rock Engineering Research Foundation-BeFo, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: A large part of world energy consumption is used for heating and cooling. In this sector, storage can make a considerable contribution to energy savings by levelling out the discrepancy between energy available and need. Often the larger quantities of available energy have low temperature, i.e. have a low energy density. The un derground has great potential for economical storage of large volumes of low energy density and for substituting prime energy with "new energy" extracted from the near subsurface. This has been increasingly recognized and confirmed in recent years in the Swedish Energy Programme, which has several hundred projects for research and development with connection to the ground and energy. Examples of most important underground storage concepts are reviewed in the paper. Limiting factors and potentials are briefly discussed. The paper concludes that underground storage is technically well suited for small systems for single houses and for incorporation into large district heating systems. In connection with the increasing number of heat pumps now being introduced in Sweden (including very large ones of 10-15 MW), subsurface systems are expected to contribute up to 10% of the Swedish energy supply for heating before the end of the 1980s. © 1983.

Title: Dinorwic and energy storage
Source title: Advances in Tunnelling Technology and Subsurface Use
Affiliations: Central Electricity Generating Board, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hannah, I.W., Central Electricity Generating Board, United Kingdom
Abstract: Providing really efficient methods for storing large quantities of electricity has long presented major technical challenges to engineers; challenges that have recently been heightened by the escalations of fuel costs and by fears of early exhaustion of oil and gas supplies. Throughout these dramatic times the CEGB has actively considered a wide range of storage alternatives, including compressed air, batteries, fuel calls and pumped storage. Concurrently a major pumped storage scheme at Dinorwic in North Wales has been ordered and virtually completed, involving major civil engineering and tunnelling contributions. This paper reviews the overall options and problems in large scale power storage, largely by reference to the design and construction of Dinorwic. © 1983.

Title: The use of underground caverns for storage and disposal
Source title: Advances in Tunnelling Technology and Subsurface Use
Affiliations: Department of the Environment, Minerals Planning Division, rm C7/08A, 2 Marsham Street, London, SW1P 3EB, United Kingdom; Dames and Moore, Consulting Engineers in the Environmental and Applied Earth Sciences, The Limes, 123 Mortlake High Street, London, SW14 8SN, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Brook, D., Department of the Environment, Minerals Planning Division, rm C7/08A, 2 Marsham Street, London, SW1P 3EB, United Kingdom; Day, C.J., Dames and Moore, Consulting Engineers in the Environmental and Applied Earth Sciences, The Limes, 123 Mortlake High Street, London, SW14 8SN, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper briefly describes the research programme on underground storage commissioned by the United Kingdom Department of the Environment and presents an interim report on some of the findings. The use of underground space has become more attractive with the increasingly intensive use of the land surface and rising land values in developed countries. It enables multiple use of the land and it can produce significant energy savings because of the insulating effect of the ground itself. Large caverns have been mined for storage in a number of countries but there is as yet little experience in the UK. Because of its interests in the fields of land use, conservation and pollution control, the Department of the Environment sought to inform itself on an area of possible future policy interest by determining the advantages, disadvantages, potential and implications of underground cavern storage in the UK. Therefore, in November 1981, the Department commissioned Dames & Moore to undertake research on the use of underground caverns for storage and disposal. © 1983.

Authors: Auston D.H., Freeman R.R., Smith P.R., Mills D.M., Siemann R.H.
Title: High-speed x-ray sensitive photoconducting detector
Affiliations: Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974; Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853; Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853
Authors with affiliations: Auston, D.H., Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974; Freeman, R.R., Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974; Smith, P.R., Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974; Mills, D.M., Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853; Siemann, R.H., Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853
Abstract: A novel photoconducting detector for time-resolved measurements in the x-ray region of the spectrum has been constructed. Time resolution of better than 40 ps at energies between 3 and 10 keV has been demonstrated in bunch length measurements on the Cornell Electron Storage Ring. At high beam currents, dramatic instabilities and a breakup of the electron bunch were directly observed with this detector.

Authors: Jipson V.B., Lynt H.N., Graczyk J.F.
Title: Laser writing of discontinuous metal films
Affiliations: IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jipson, V.B., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Lynt, H.N., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Graczyk, J.F., IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Abstract: Discontinuous films of noble metals formed by thin-film nucleation demonstrate attractive properties for optical storage applications. Writing energies lower than those for more conventional tellurium based systems have been achieved using 2.0-3.0-nm gold layers in a trilayer configuration. The discontinuous nature of the film is shown to greatly influence the writing characteristics of these films. This is due to the fact that written spots are now formed through laser induced sintering of the small metallic islands, rather than by film ablation that occurs for continuous films.

Title: High-energy particle accelerators
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Crowley-Milling, M.C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The reasons why high-energy particle accelerators are needed for sub-nuclear physics are briefly given, followed by a short history of the development of the different types of accelerators, describing their basic principles. The main accelerators and storage rings in service today are described, and the parameters of those under construction or projected are given. Finally, the physical factors limiting the performance of the various types of accelerator are discussed, together with proposals for overcoming them by the application of new techniques.

Title: Transfer and storage of chemical and radiation potential
Source title: Journal of the Chemical Society, Faraday Transactions 2: Molecular and Chemical Physics
Affiliations: Davy Faraday Research Laboratory, Royal Institution, 21 Albemarle Street, London W1X 4BS
Authors with affiliations: Porter, G., Davy Faraday Research Laboratory, Royal Institution, 21 Albemarle Street, London W1X 4BS
Abstract: The change in potential which accompanies any spontaneous process is given by RT In [1 - (j/J)], where j is the net forward flux and J is the forward flux at the same reactant potential but in the absence of products. This equation is applied to thermal and photochemical reactions. For the latter, we introduce and evaluate the quantities 'radiation potential' and 'scattered radiation potential' in analogy with 'chemical potential'. 'Storage' of energy is defined and shown to be a two-stage process. Thermodynamic losses are relatively small provided the rather stringent requirements of geometry and transport kinetics can be met. The influences of these several factors on the efficiency of solar-energy collection and storage are evaluated.

Title: THERMAL CYCLING EFFECT ON MECHANICAL PROPERTIES OF RP/C.
Affiliations: State Univ of New York-Buffalo,, Amherst, NY, USA, State Univ of New York-Buffalo, Amherst, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Han, K.S., State Univ of New York-Buffalo,, Amherst, NY, USA, State Univ of New York-Buffalo, Amherst, NY, USA; Ishikawa, T., State Univ of New York-Buffalo,, Amherst, NY, USA, State Univ of New York-Buffalo, Amherst, NY, USA
Abstract: RP/C materials are widely used in the structural applications. One of the potential applications is the strut system in an Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage, which requires high strength-to-weight ratio and low thermal conductivity. In the cryogenic applications of RP/C such as Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage, systems, the thermal cycling effect on the mechanical performances of composites is as important as the cryogenic performance of RP/C itself. This study deals with the cryogenic cycling effects on compressive strength, modulus, fracture toughness and failure studies of short glass fiber polyester laminate and glass fiber cloth epoxy composite rod. It is concluded that thermal cycling causes delamination in glass polyester laminates which degrades compressive strength.
Index Keywords: COMPOSITE MATERIALS - Fiber Reinforced; CRYOGENICS; EPOXY RESINS - Laminating; POLYESTERS - Laminating; STRUCTURAL DESIGN; DEGRADATION; DELAMINATION; FRACTURE TOUGHNESS; THERMAL CYCLING; PLASTICS, REINFORCED

Title: In-situ studies on deep-sea amphipods and their intestinal microflora
Affiliations: Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Woods Hole, 02543, Massachusetts, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wirsen, C.O., Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Woods Hole, 02543, Massachusetts, United States; Jannasch, H.W., Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Woods Hole, 02543, Massachusetts, United States
Abstract: Amphipods, trapped at depths of 1 410 to 5 330 m and incubated in situ in the presence of a radiolabeled protein as a food source, were fractionated to measure the distribution of label in the major biochemical constituents: low molecular pools, ethanol and base soluble proteins, lipids, polysaccharides and nucleic acids. The results suggest lipid energy storage and enhanced microbial growth within the amphipod guts as compared to growth on the uningested food material. The merits and limitations of this general approach are critically evaluated. © 1983 Springer-Verlag.

Title: PHOTOCHEMICAL CONVERSIONS.
Abstract: Direct quantum conversion processes for the production of either fuel or chemical compounds of high value represent a domain of very active research. They are a major theme of this conference proceedings on 'Photochemical Conversions. ' Eight plenary lecturers at the conference discussed basic principles of photobiological and photochemical, and photophysical conversion mechanisms, particularly in relation to their applications to fuel production, photovoltaic cells, solar energy harvesting, and the chemistry and physics of both synthetic materials and the living cells.

Title: EFFICIENCY LIMITATIONS IN PHOTOCHEMICAL CONVERSION.
Affiliations: Royal Inst of Great Britain, Davy, Faraday Research Lab, London, Engl, Royal Inst of Great Britain, Davy Faraday Research Lab, London, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Porter, George, Royal Inst of Great Britain, Davy, Faraday Research Lab, London, Engl, Royal Inst of Great Britain, Davy Faraday Research Lab, London, Engl
Abstract: The minimum theoretical losses in the conversion of light energy into chemical potential are evaluated. The concepts of radiation potential and scattered radiation potential are introduced and a simple general expression is derived for the maximum efficiency of power extraction. A brief comparison is made between efficiencies of water photolysis so far attained and those theoretically attainable with sensitizers commonly used.

Title: MEASURED TOTAL PERFORMANCE OF A SOLAR HOME USING CONCRETE MASONRY.
Affiliations: Natl Concrete Masonry Assoc,, Technical Services Div, Herndon, VA,, USA, Natl Concrete Masonry Assoc, Technical Services Div, Herndon, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Howard, Bion D., Natl Concrete Masonry Assoc,, Technical Services Div, Herndon, VA,, USA, Natl Concrete Masonry Assoc, Technical Services Div, Herndon, VA, USA
Abstract: The Roberts Home (Sundance I), located in Reston, Virginia, is a 214 square meter (2300 square foot) three level passive-hybird solar residence using a single glazed, 62 m**2 (663 ft**2 ) Trombe wall with automated movable insulation and a 9. 1 m**2 (98 ft**2 ) single sloped glazed sunspace. Concrete masonry comprises an inner core thermal mass, including an air-core hybrid storage system. The winter building heat load was met by 52% passive solar heating, 12% auxiliary backup and 36% internal heat generation. The internal gains were high compared to other monitored buildings. The auxiliary heating thermal integrity was a low 17. 77 kJ/ m**2 / HDD (0. 86 Btu/ ft**2 /HDD). Summer natural cooling using building design removed 99% of the measured sensible cooling load. The auxiliary heat pumps performed only 1% of the sensible cooling. (Edited author abstract. )
Index Keywords: MASONRY MATERIALS - Applications; SOLAR ENERGY - Applications; COLLECTION AND THERMAL STORAGE; SPACE COOLING THERMAL PERFORMANCE; SPACE HEATING THERMAL PERFORMANCE; WINTER BUILDING HEAT LOAD; HOUSES

Title: ANNUAL THERMAL UTILITY OF INTERNAL GAINS.
Affiliations: Ecotope Inc, Seattle, WA, USA, Ecotope Inc, Seattle, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Palmiter, Larry, Ecotope Inc, Seattle, WA, USA, Ecotope Inc, Seattle, WA, USA; Kennedy, Mike, Ecotope Inc, Seattle, WA, USA, Ecotope Inc, Seattle, WA, USA
Abstract: This paper presents an analysis of the impact of internal gains on thermal loads. Two designs were considered: a standard design with windows equally distributed and low thermal storage and a passive solar design with mostly south glass and high thermal storage. In each case, the level of internal gains was cut in half, and the resulting change in thermal loads was noted. The ratio of the change in annual thermal loads to the change in annual internal gains was defined as the utility of the gains. The utility was found to correlate well with the annual space heat. The results are presented both graphically and in a form suitable for use on a pocket calculator. (Edited author abstract. )

Title: COST SAVINGS THROUGH FIRST COST REDUCTION.
Affiliations: TVA, USA, TVA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Burrows, David L., TVA, USA, TVA, USA; Ira, Stephen R., TVA, USA, TVA, USA
Abstract: Eleven Commercial and Industrial (C&I) solar projects are reported on from TVA's C&I solar water heating project. Three basic design approaches are discussed: drainback, glycol, and shallow solar pond. Collector types include: flat plate, parabolic, evacuated tube, and pond. Cost breakdowns are described by nine categories including: collectors, support structures, storage, piping, energy transport, insulation, and electrical/ controls.

Abstract: In hot climates where it is cool at night, buildings can be kept comfortable during hot days by storing cool in the building-structure. This is a common technique used throughout the world. This paper describes how to analyze this method. (Author abstract. ) Refs.

Title: 'MABATHOANA HOUSE IN QOALING: A TRANSITIONAL MODERN DESIGN IN LESOTHO.
Affiliations: Associates in Rural Development Inc, Maseru, Lesotho, Associates in Rural Development Inc, Maseru, Lesotho
Authors with affiliations: Klein, Gary A., Associates in Rural Development Inc, Maseru, Lesotho, Associates in Rural Development Inc, Maseru, Lesotho
Abstract: This paper concerns the design, construction and performance of a thermal storage wall and direct gain house in the lowlands of Lesotho. Infrastructural self-reliance was integral to the design in that the demand for water has been minimized, and the need for grid-supplied electricity eliminated. Alternative, on-site systems provide for very comfortable living at low personal and societal costs. Coupled with the use of locally available, 'modern' building materials, this house represents another step in the transition from existing practice to environmentally wise architecture. (Author abstract. )

Authors: van Dijk H.A.L., van Galen E., Hensen J., de Wit M.
Title: HIGH PERFORMANCE PASSIVE SOLAR HEATING SYSTEM WITH HEAT PIPE ENERGY TRANSFER AND LATENT HEAT STORAGE.
Affiliations: TNO, Inst of Applied Physics, Delft,, Neth, TNO, Inst of Applied Physics, Delft, Neth
Authors with affiliations: van Dijk, H.A.L., TNO, Inst of Applied Physics, Delft,, Neth, TNO, Inst of Applied Physics, Delft, Neth; van Galen, E., TNO, Inst of Applied Physics, Delft,, Neth, TNO, Inst of Applied Physics, Delft, Neth; Hensen, J., TNO, Inst of Applied Physics, Delft,, Neth, TNO, Inst of Applied Physics, Delft, Neth; de Wit, M., TNO, Inst of Applied Physics, Delft,, Neth, TNO, Inst of Applied Physics, Delft, Neth
Abstract: Preliminary results are reported from a current project on the development of a high performance passive solar heating system. Two special components are introduced: a. A heat pipe as a thermal diode tube for the efficient transfer of collected solar heat from the absorber plate to behind an insulation layer. b. A latent heat storage section with high storage capacity at moderate operating temperatures. Additional advantageous characteristics: the maintenance costs are negligible, and the performance is highly insensitive to inadequate control of the system by the inhabitants. A first global design of the system showed significantly higher predicted gains than a conventional storage wall at however still high manufacturing costs, although the cost-benefit ratio was already competitive with a similar active solar system. (Edited author abstract. )

Title: USE OF VISIBLE LIGHT PHOTOREACTIONS IN CHEMICAL SYNTHESIS AND APPLICATION.
Affiliations: RWTH, Inst of Organic Chemistry,, Aachen, West Ger, RWTH, Inst of Organic Chemistry, Aachen, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Scharf, H.-D., RWTH, Inst of Organic Chemistry,, Aachen, West Ger, RWTH, Inst of Organic Chemistry, Aachen, West Ger; Leismann, H., RWTH, Inst of Organic Chemistry,, Aachen, West Ger, RWTH, Inst of Organic Chemistry, Aachen, West Ger; Koch, H., RWTH, Inst of Organic Chemistry,, Aachen, West Ger, RWTH, Inst of Organic Chemistry, Aachen, West Ger
Abstract: The early applications of visible light photoreactions were induced by solar radiation containing wavelengths down to the UV-region. In modern photochemistry the sun has been substituted by better manageable but at the same time energy consuming artificial light sources. In times of imminent shortage of primary energies, people remembered that the sun delivers 100 to 400 watts per square meter to the earth's surface. The paper reconsiders and investigates the possible uses of this economic energy source in photochemistry.

Title: COMMON ERRORS IN DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF PASSIVE SOLAR HOMES: RESULTS OF A REVIEW OF NMSEI TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS.
Affiliations: New Mexico State Univ, New Mexico, Solar Energy Inst, Las Cruces, NM,, USA, New Mexico State Univ, New Mexico Solar Energy Inst, Las Cruces, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Selinfreund, Martin, New Mexico State Univ, New Mexico, Solar Energy Inst, Las Cruces, NM,, USA, New Mexico State Univ, New Mexico Solar Energy Inst, Las Cruces, NM, USA; Farrer, Roger, New Mexico State Univ, New Mexico, Solar Energy Inst, Las Cruces, NM,, USA, New Mexico State Univ, New Mexico Solar Energy Inst, Las Cruces, NM, USA
Abstract: One of the state-funded programs of the New Mexico Solar Energy Institute (NMSEI) at New Mexico State University provides citizens of New Mexico with a limited amount of free technical advice on the design, construction, and operation of solar systems. Requests for assistance are now averaging 40 to 50 per month in the solar thermal field alone. Experience in the technical assistance program has identified common areas in which help is needed and identified common errors made in the design and construction of solar homes. Common errors will be discussed, such as incorrect orientation of houses (this can have some surprising effects) and inappropriate use of what would otherwise be adequate insulation. Proposed methods of providing information to designers and builders to counteract these (and other) common errors will be described. (Edited author abstract. )

Abstract: The paper presents a description and analysis of a passive solar residence with double, southeast and southwest, orientation. Abstract: The proposed system will utilize winter climate as an annual source of cooling by taking advantage of natural ambient temperatures to freeze ice as a source for cooling. A passive freon heat pipe and ice storage system will provide the necessary cooling for refrigeration. The Refrigeration/Economic Loads Optimization Program, or RELOP, explores the various proportions of ice storage and superinsulation to discover the economically-optimized combinations of the two. Abstract: The primary objective of the DOE Passive Solar Class A Peformance Evaluation Program is to collect, analyze, and archive detailed test data for the rigorous validation of analysis/design tools used for passive solar research and design. This paper presents results of the analysis and qualification of several one- and two-week data sets taken at three Class A test sites for the purpose of validating envelope and thermal-storage-energy-transfer processes in passive solar analysis/design tools. Analysis of the data sets consists of editing the measured data and comparing these data with simulated performance results using public-domain, passive solar analysis tools and a standard reporting format developed for the Class A program. Comparisons of the measured data with results using the DOE-2 computer program are presented. (Author abstract. )
Index Keywords: TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; DIRECT-GAIN TEST CELL; PASSIVE SOLAR ANALYSIS/DESIGN TOOLS; PREDICTED VS. PRESSURED SPACE-AIR TEMPERATURES; SOLAR CLASS A PERFORMANCE EVALUATION PROGRAM; TEST DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS; THERMAL-STORAGE-ENERGY TRANSFER PROCESSES; SOLAR ENERGY

Abstract: This paper presents a new method for predicting the annual auxiliary space heating requirements of passively heated solar houses in the United States. It features closed-form, analytical expressions for solar system performance that are amenable to use by architects, engineers, or home-builders with the aid of an inexpensive, programmable calculator. The method is applicable to direct gain, water storage wall, or mass storage (Trombe) wall passive solar heating systems and is general in practice in that it does not restrict the user to a particular 'reference' system. It permits the rapid assessment of the performance effects of variations in such system features as south glazing, thermal storage, or movable insulation. (Edited author abstract. )

Abstract: The interaction of solar and auxiliary resources in passive/hybrid solar commercial buildings calls for special care in the design and selection of mechanical systems controls. The author reports difficulties experienced with HVAC controls for an otherwise highly successful project, and offers observations which may help other designers avoid such problems. (Author abstract. )

Title: PERFORMANCE OF THREE AIR ENVELOPE RESIDENCES IN IOWA USING MASS FLOOR STORAGE.

Authors with affiliations: Hadley, Roger D., CHANGE, Solar & Enviromental, Design, Cedar Rapids, IA, USA, CHANGE, Solar & Enviromental Design, Cedar Rapids, IA, USA
Abstract: Since the introduction of 'air envelope' structures as a concept in energy conscious design, a continual controversy has evolved questioning nearly every aspect of their construction and performance. This author agrees with the general concept of air envelope structures, but very much disagrees with the concepts of using earth as a storage media, using concrete culverts as a means of natural cooling, using double vapor barriers in the envelope walls. This paper describes the performance of three homes that differ markedly from those that have gained more notoriety, without the problems of moisture condensation, or large temperature swings. (Author abstract. )

Title: TRANSFORMATIONS: THE DESIGN PROCESS IN RESIDENTIAL RETROFIT ACTIVE HAND/PASSIVE DESIGN.
Affiliations: Sunstone Design, Hopewell, NJ, USA, Sunstone Design, Hopewell, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lawrence, Vinton, Sunstone Design, Hopewell, NJ, USA, Sunstone Design, Hopewell, NJ, USA; Katzenbach Jr., C.B., Sunstone Design, Hopewell, NJ, USA, Sunstone Design, Hopewell, NJ, USA
Abstract: The author's experience as owner, designer, and builder in the architectural and energy renovation of an early 1800s farmstead in Central New Jersey. Innovative passive design concepts were carefully integrated with the traditional features of an old field-stone farmhouse to achieve an 85% reduction in the non-renewable energy use. The study documents the processes and quantitative effects of the energy conserving strategies employed, from insulation and caulking to the addition of a two-story 'sunspace' which utilizes the stone mass of the structure as an integral heat storage medium. Emphasis is placed upon the integration of the 'new' with the 'old' and the importance of user/client involvement in the design choices made. In addition to design and details, cost and performance data are presented where appropriate. (Author abstract. )

Title: WOOD FRAME SUPPORTED THERMAL MASS FLOORS.
Affiliations: Sunstructures Inc, Ann Arbor, MI,, USA, Sunstructures Inc, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kelly Jr., Edward J., Sunstructures Inc, Ann Arbor, MI,, USA, Sunstructures Inc, Ann Arbor, MI, USA
Abstract: The direct gain passive solar concept employing a mass floor is quite common and easily constructed in slab-on-grade residences. Often, however, certain design decisions or constraints may require an above grade solution to thermal mass floors for optimum solar performance. Above grade, wood frame supported, thermal mass floors, which can be low-cost, low maintenance, and attractive, have been developed in two residences designed and constructed by SUNSTRUCTURES. The finished result is a mass floor with a dark color added to the concrete with a tile pattern of oak strips set in the floor in one house and a dark slate tile finish in the other. Both of these floors will have good passive thermal storage and sound control characteristics. They are relatively simple to build and are amazingly effective when the need arises to utilize them in the upper story of wood framed residences. (Author abstract. )

Abstract: In this paper we discuss the performance of phase-change materials (PCMs) as thermal storage in passive solar heating systems. We discuss factors, other than material properties, that affect storage performance and optimization. We also briefly describe solid-state phase-change materials (SSPCMs) and list typical material properties. We give results from a parametric analysis of PCM Trombe walls and discuss the factors that limit performance. We present configurations for enhanced PCM performance and give simulation results for an idealized case. (Author abstract. )

Abstract: Chilled water systems are one of the major energy consumers in industrial, commercial, and institutional complexes. The centralization of chilled water systems has considerable advantages, namely: simplified controls, the installed capacity is reduced due to diversity, consolidated maintenance and operation, etc. With central chilled water systems, the following areas present potential energy and cost savings: Chilled Water Reset; Condenser Water Reset; Sequencing of the Chillers; Chilled Water Storage; Variable Chilled Water Pumping. In this paper the feasibility aspect of each of the above items will be discussed.

Title: GLASS FIBER REINFORCED EPOXY LEAF SPRING DESIGN.
Affiliations: Shell Development Co, Houston, TX,, USA, Shell Development Co, Houston, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gottenberg, W.G., Shell Development Co, Houston, TX,, USA, Shell Development Co, Houston, TX, USA; Lo, K.H., Shell Development Co, Houston, TX,, USA, Shell Development Co, Houston, TX, USA
Abstract: This paper reviews the function of a spring as an energy storage device. It examines in detail the influence on that function of the material of construction (unidirectional glass fibers in epoxy versus steel) and of spring geometry. The design latitudes afforded by the variable thickness/width options are illustrated. Finally, the significance of shear stress components in planes containing the fibers is examined, particularly as it relates to the selection of the thermoset resin matrix. Complete knowledge of shear stresses is not important in a steel part undergoing flexure while with a reinforced resin part shear stresses rather than normal stress components may control the design. Procedures are presented for evaluation of design stresses due to simple flexure as well as such secondary loads as axle windup.

Abstract: Through the initiative of the U. S. DOE management is currently reactivating production facilities of the waste management program which will result in quantity production of byproduct heat sources. Additionally, DOE is currently designing a 500 Watt(e), strontium-90 fueled demonstration RTG which will be assembled, tested and prepared for fueling in 1984.

Abstract: The purpose of this analysis is to provide information on the nature, value, and importance of known and potential mineral resources within the Hanford, Washington, nuclear site and vicinity. The work is part of a larger program being conducted by the U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) to evaluate suitability of various areas within the conterminous United States as sites for construction of repositories for terminal storage of high-level commercial nuclear-reactor waste. Geologic data supporting this work were collected and interpreted. Economic data were collected and analyzed. Current and past mineral resource production data was compiled and projected to the year 2005 for an area within 100 km of the candidate site and for the remainder of the Columbia Plateau. The 25-yr projection is considered to be the maximum foreseeable forecast period for analysis of economic data.

Authors with affiliations: Gardner, D.A., Cygna Energy Services, Solana Beach,, CA, USA, Cygna Energy Services, Solana Beach, CA, USA; Dombek, F.S., Cygna Energy Services, Solana Beach,, CA, USA, Cygna Energy Services, Solana Beach, CA, USA; Reeser, H.G., Cygna Energy Services, Solana Beach,, CA, USA, Cygna Energy Services, Solana Beach, CA, USA
Abstract: In response to the perceived utility need for interim storage facilities for low-level nuclear waste, Cygna Energy Services has developed a Modular Interim Waste Storage Building (IWSB) design which emphasizes low cost, design simplicity, commercial construction techniques, rapid construction time and licensability. The IWSB is modular and easily expanded. The base module includes a truck bay, storage bay with vaults, remote-control over-head bridge crane and a separate control room. The facility design basis and features are described. Waste storage and shielding requirements are optimized through the use of a computerized inventory control system. Cost of the Cygna Modular IWSB is on the order of 4 million for a five year capacity facility and a construction period of about 12 to 14 months.

Title: BEAM ACCUMULATION AND MOMENTUM COOLING AT TARN.
Affiliations: Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Noda, A., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Chida, K., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Hattori, T., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Kadota, S., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Katayama, T., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Mizobuchi, A., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Takanaka, M., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Tokuda, N., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Watanabe, S., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Yonehara, H., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Yoshizawa, M., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn; Hirao, Y., Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: TARN is a storage ring of low energy ions with kinetic energies around 10 Mev per nucleon, which aims at beam accumulation into both longitudinal and transverse phase spaces. It has already accumulated beams of proton, molecular hydrogen (H//2** plus ), alpha and **3He** plus . Intensity increase of twenty times has been attained by multi-turn injection into horizontal transverse phase space of the area of 153 pi mm multiplied by (times) mrad. RF stacking into the longitudinal phase space has been performed with the repetition rate of 30 Hz, and intensity increase of 15 times has been achieved resulting in the fractional momentum spread of 2. 2%. A system for stochastic momentum cooling has been installed into TARN. Schottky signal of stacked beam has been seen clearly with use of a new pickup of traveling wave type. With Schottky scan, the effect of the fifth order resonance on the stacked beam has been observed.

Title: BULK SOLID STORAGE AND FLOW CONSIDERATIONS FOR COAL PREPARATION PLANT.
Affiliations: Univ of Wollongong, Wollongong, Aust, Univ of Wollongong, Wollongong, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Arnold, P.C., Univ of Wollongong, Wollongong, Aust, Univ of Wollongong, Wollongong, Aust; McLean, A.G., Univ of Wollongong, Wollongong, Aust, Univ of Wollongong, Wollongong, Aust; Moore, B.A., Univ of Wollongong, Wollongong, Aust, Univ of Wollongong, Wollongong, Aust
Abstract: Modern coal preparation plant operation requires reliable and uniform flow of bulk solids without the use of expensive and energy consuming flow promotion devices. A brief outline of the necessary design procedure and flow property test procedures will highlight that in the design of coal preparation plants considerable attention to the flow of bulk solids is necessary due to the adverse flow properties of the bulk solids handled. It will be emphasised that, due to the heterogeneous nature of coal, material flow problems should be examined for each individual situation.

Title: NEGATIVE HYDROGEN ION SOURCES.
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Authors with affiliations: Prelec, K., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA, Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, NY, USA
Abstract: There are two main areas of negative hydrogen ion applications: injection into high energy accelerators and production of beams of energetic hydrogen atoms for fusion devices. In both cases, the ease with which the charge state of negative ions can be changed by either single or double electron stripping is the reason that made their application attractive. In tandem accelerators, the final energy of H** plus ions is twice as high as it would correspond to the terminal voltage, in circular accelerators (synchrotrons, storage rings) injection of H** plus ions by full stripping of H** minus ions in a foil inside the ring is not limited by the Liouville's theorem and results in a higher phase space density than achieved by direct H** plus injection. Finally, beams of hydrogen atoms at energies above 100 keV, which will be required for plasma heating and current drive in future fusion devices, can efficiently be produced only by acceleration of negative ions and their subsequent neutralization. Various H** minus sources are discussed.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS; ELECTRONS; HYDROGEN; PLASMAS - Heating; METAL VAPORS; NEGATIVE HYDROGEN ION APPLICATIONS; PENNING SOURCES; ION SOURCES

Title: PLANNING AHEAD FOR ENERGY EMERGENCIES: WHOSE JOB IS IT ANYWAY? .
Source title: Special Report - National Research Council, Transportation Research Board
Affiliations: US DOE, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Winkler, Ronald L., US DOE, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: Storage of oil in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR) was increased, and a number of other general energy and economic measures were instituted which provided incentives for sound development and conservation of energy. The overriding goals of the energy emergency preparedness program are to reduce the nation's vulnerability to energy supply disruptions and to alleviate their impacts on the nation. Previous policies of oil allocation, price controls, and mandatory demand-restraint measures have been abandoned because in some instances they were found to create adverse economic and social impacts and were, therefore, counterproductive. In the past the government attempted to allocate petroleum rather than rely on market forces during supply disruptions. Some of the consequences were energy shortages and lines for gasoline at service stations. The best way to ensure that petroleum is allocated where it is needed is to rely on the marketplace.
Index Keywords: ENERGY POLICY; ENERGY CONSERVATION INCENTIVES; ENERGY SUPPLY DISRUPTIONS; ENERGY/ECONOMIC MEASURES; OIL STORAGE; STRATEGIC PETROLEUM RESERVE; ENERGY MANAGEMENT

Abstract: The March 1979 TMI-2 accident and cleanup activities to date have generated some radioactive wastes that are not typical of those wastes produced by normal light-water reactor operations. The U. S. Department of Energy, through its subcontractor, EG&G Idaho, is conducting research and development activities to effectively deal with the unique technical problems associated with safe handling, shipping, storage, and disposal of these special wastes. The conference is divided into six sessions which cover major areas such as materials handling, density separation, fine coal processing, tailings treatment, instrumentation and control, plant design and computer simulation. Title: HYBRID SOLAR THERMAL-PHOTOVOLTAIC SYSTEMS DEMONSTRATION - PHASE I AND II.
Source title: U.S. Department of Energy Conservation and Solar Applications (Report) CS
Affiliations: Brown Univ, Providence, RI, USA, Brown Univ, Providence, RI, USA
Authors with affiliations: Loferski, Joseph J., Brown Univ, Providence, RI, USA, Brown Univ, Providence, RI, USA
Abstract: A system based on combined photovoltaic/thermal (PV/T) panels for conversion of sunlight into the forms (thermal and electric energy) needed to supply the energy needs of a small single family residence is described. It uses PV/T panels which utilize air as the heat transfer medium. Optimization of thermal performance was accomplished by attaching metal fins to the back surface of each cell which significantly increased the heat transfer coefficient from the solar cells to the air stream. The other major components of the selected system are an air-to-air heat pump, a rock thermal energy storage bin, a synchronous dc-to-ac converter, a microprocessor to control the system, a heat exchanger for the domestic hot water system and the building itself. Twenty collectors, containing 2860 four inch diameter solar cells, were constructed and installed on the building. Performance of the system was simulated using a TRNSYS-derived program.

Title: INVESTIGATIONS AND REPORT ON NATURAL HEAT RESOURCES AND STORAGE OF HEAT.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Affiliations: VIAK AB, Goteborg, Swed, VIAK AB, Goteborg, Swed
Authors with affiliations: Hard, Stig, VIAK AB, Goteborg, Swed, VIAK AB, Goteborg, Swed
Abstract: The Swedish Parliament has ruled that energy consumption must be reduced. For this purpose the replenishment of low temperature natural heat sources will be utilized among other measures. The development of heat-pump systems in combination with natural heat sources therefore has increased in recent years. Integrated planning is necessary for a successful introduction of this new technology.

Authors: Haji-Sheikh A., Eftekhar J., Lou D.Y.S.
Title: SOME THERMOPHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF PARAFFIN WAX AS A THERMAL STORAGE MEDIUM.
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at Arlington,, Mechanical Engineering Dep,, Arlington, TX, USA, Univ of Texas at Arlington, Mechanical Engineering Dep, Arlington, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Haji-Sheikh, A., Univ of Texas at Arlington,, Mechanical Engineering Dep,, Arlington, TX, USA, Univ of Texas at Arlington, Mechanical Engineering Dep, Arlington, TX, USA; Eftekhar, J., Univ of Texas at Arlington,, Mechanical Engineering Dep,, Arlington, TX, USA, Univ of Texas at Arlington, Mechanical Engineering Dep, Arlington, TX, USA; Lou, D.Y.S., Univ of Texas at Arlington,, Mechanical Engineering Dep,, Arlington, TX, USA, Univ of Texas at Arlington, Mechanical Engineering Dep, Arlington, TX, USA
Abstract: An experimental study is conducted to determine the suitability of paraffin wax SUNTECH P116 as a phase change material for storage of thermal energy. Certain temperature-dependent thermophysical properties in the neighborhood of the melting point useful for this study, but not adequately available in the literature, are measured. They include thermal conductivity, density, thermal expansion coefficient, and viscosity. It is observed that the thermal conductivity of paraffin wax, in solid phase, is not a monotonic function of temperature as reported in the literature. Other thermophysical properties of the liquid phase measured vary monotonically with temperature.
Index Keywords: PARAFFINS - Applications; PARAFFIN WAX; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; SPACECRAFT

Authors: Smith K.J., Leatherwood J.M., Eisen E.J.
Title: Effects of preweaning and postweaning feed restriction on the development of polygenic obese mice
Affiliations: Dep. Anim. Sc., North Carolina State Univ., Raleigh, NC 27650, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, K.J., Dep. Anim. Sc., North Carolina State Univ., Raleigh, NC 27650, United States; Leatherwood, J.M., Dep. Anim. Sc., North Carolina State Univ., Raleigh, NC 27650, United States; Eisen, E.J., Dep. Anim. Sc., North Carolina State Univ., Raleigh, NC 27650, United States
Abstract: Polygenic obese (M16) and control (ICR) mice were raised in litters of 8 (N8) or preweaning restricted in litters of 14 (N14). Mice were fed either ad libitum or postweaning restricted by automatic feeders from 4 to 10 weeks of age. All mice were fed ad libitum from 10 to 16 weeks. Preweaning restriction (N14) resulted in mice at 4 weeks with smaller body weights, fat percent, subcutaneous fat depot and adipocyte diameter than N8 mice. Most of the effects of preweaning restriction were overcome by 10 weeks. Obese mice, at 10 and 16 weeks, were heavier and had higher fat percent and larger fat depots with more and larger adipocytes than control mice. Postweaning restriction resulted in mice at 10 weeks with smaller body weight but greater fat percent, especially in the control line. Postweaning restriction of obese mice resulted in a higher percent of fat at 16 weeks. The change in eating pattern, stress or other factors associated with postweaning restriction, as imposed in this study, resulted in an altered metabolism that distributed a greater proportion of energy to fat storage than in the ad libitum fed mice. Ultimate body size and adipose tissue characteristics were determined primarily by genotype, whereas most effects of nutritional restriction were temporary.
Index Keywords: adipocyte; animal experiment; animal model; caloric restriction; heredity; infant; mouse; nonhuman; obesity; polygeny; postnatal development; subcutaneous tissue; Adipose Tissue; Aging; Animal; Body Weight; Comparative Study; Diet; Energy Intake; Feeding Behavior; Mice; Mice, Obese; Obesity; Support, U.S. Gov't, P.H.S.; Weaning

Authors: Thomson A.D., Ryle P.R., Shaw G.K.
Title: Ethanol, thiamine and brain damage
Affiliations: Department of Gastroenterology, Greenwich District Hospital, London SE10, United Kingdom; Bexley Hospital, Kent,Bexley, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Thomson, A.D., Department of Gastroenterology, Greenwich District Hospital, London SE10, United Kingdom; Ryle, P.R., Department of Gastroenterology, Greenwich District Hospital, London SE10, United Kingdom; Shaw, G.K., Department of Gastroenterology, Greenwich District Hospital, London SE10, United Kingdom, Bexley Hospital, Kent,Bexley, United Kingdom
Abstract: In this paper an attempt has been made to identify important factors governing the supply of thiamine and to examine the relative roles of thiamine and ethanol in the pathogenesis of alcoholic brain damage.Thiamine depletion occurs in alcoholics principally through decreased intake, impaired absorp tion and reduced hepatic storage. The kinetics of thiamine uptake and turnover in brain are such that any fall in circulating levels of the vitamin may significantly impair the supply to the brain.The brain depends on an adequate supply of glucose both as an energy source and as a donor of carbon fragments for protein and lipid biosynthesis. Glucose utilisation is, however, thiamine dependent and it is likely that this is a major factor in the production of thiamine deficient brain damage.Ethanol alone can cause a number of structural alterations in brain tissue and these lesions may be found in alcoholics either in association with or in the absence of thiamine deficient lesions. It is also probable that ethanol and thiamine deficiency act synergistically to produce structural damage.Recurrent deficiences of many different kinds also play a part in the production of cumulative brain damage in the alcoholic. © 1983 Medical Council on Alcoholism.
Index Keywords: alcohol; cyanocobalamin; glucose; nicotinic acid; pyridoxine; thiamine; alcoholism; brain atrophy; brain injury; central nervous system; computer analysis; computer assisted tomography; diagnosis; etiology; human; intoxication; nervous system; neurotoxicity

Authors: Hogman C.F., De Verdier C.-H., Ericson A.
Title: Cell shape and total adenylate concentration as important factors for posttransfusion survival of erythrocytes
Affiliations: The Blood Center, University Hospital, S-751 85 Uppsala, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Hogman, C.F., The Blood Center, University Hospital, S-751 85 Uppsala, Sweden; De Verdier, C.-H., The Blood Center, University Hospital, S-751 85 Uppsala, Sweden; Ericson, A., The Blood Center, University Hospital, S-751 85 Uppsala, Sweden
Abstract: Red cells were stored for 42 days in a CPD/SAGM plastic bag system and then rejuvenated with bicarbonate, pyruvate and slow addition of adenosine. The reversibility and the time dependence of metabolic and morphologic changes were compared with autologous, posttransfusion survival. Total adenylates correlated better (r = 0.88) than ATP with viability in vivo. ATP was better maintained when the blood was stored under anaerobic than aerobic conditions. A high correlation between morphology and viability was found in rejuvenated cells (r = 0.95). It is suggested that the time needed for reversal of changes is essential for viability.
Index Keywords: adenosine phosphate; adenosine triphosphate; blood and hemopoietic system; blood storage; cell shape; erythrocyte; human; human cell; Adenine Nucleotides; Blood Preservation; Blood Transfusion; Cell Survival; Energy Metabolism; Erythrocytes; Human; Spleen; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't

Authors: Frankenfeld J.W., Taylor W.F., Brinkman D.W.
Title: Storage Stability of Synfuels from Oil Shale. 1. General Features of Sediment Formation in Model Fuel Systems
Source title: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Product Research and Development
Affiliations: Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Products Research Division, Linden, New Jersey 07036, United States; Bartlesville Energy Technology Center, U.S. Department of Energy, Bartlesville, Oklahoma 74003, United States
Authors with affiliations: Frankenfeld, J.W., Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Products Research Division, Linden, New Jersey 07036, United States; Taylor, W.F., Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Products Research Division, Linden, New Jersey 07036, United States; Brinkman, D.W., Bartlesville Energy Technology Center, U.S. Department of Energy, Bartlesville, Oklahoma 74003, United States
Abstract: The general features of sediment formation in middle distillate fuels were investigated. The effect of nitrogen compounds on sediment formation was determined by using pure nitrogen compounds in model petroleum-derived fuel systems. The rate of sediment formation was dependent on the presence of nitrogen compounds, the nature of the diluent employed, and the storage conditions. Detailed studies of the effects of reaction conditions were carried out with 2,5-dimethylpyrrole (DMP) as the model. Air, increased temperature, dissolved oxygen, and light all strongly accelerated the sediment forming reaction while moisture had a variable effect. The initial reaction rate was approximately first order in nitrogen concentration. The reaction has a low apparent activation energy and appears to involve a free-radical oxidative self-condensation of the nitrogen compound. © 1983, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: AIR; FUELS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; OIL SHALE; OXYGEN; SYNTHETIC FUELS

Title: INTERNATIONAL PLUTONIUM STORAGE - STATUS AND OPTIONS.
Affiliations: US Arms Control & Disarmament, Agency, Washington, DC, USA, US Arms Control & Disarmament Agency, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Turrentine, Archelaus R., US Arms Control & Disarmament, Agency, Washington, DC, USA, US Arms Control & Disarmament Agency, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: In 1978 the Director General of the IAEA established an Expert Group to prepare proposals for the international management and storage of plutonium. The Expert Group included representatives from most countries with advanced nuclear programs. After working on a single approach, some participants broke ranks and pressed for an alternative approach. In its final report to the Director General in late 1982, the Expert Group provided three alternative approaches to international plutonium storage (IPS). The question is how to keep alive the concept of IPS and to develop a viable mechanism which is attractive to countries holding separated plutonium.

Title: IMPROVED PERFORMANCE OF SOLAR STILLS.
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Tripoli, Libya, Faculty of Engineering, Tripoli, Libya
Authors with affiliations: Zaki, G.M., Faculty of Engineering, Tripoli, Libya, Faculty of Engineering, Tripoli, Libya; El-Shafiey, M., Faculty of Engineering, Tripoli, Libya, Faculty of Engineering, Tripoli, Libya
Abstract: Experimental investigation has been conducted to study the different parameters affecting solar still performance. Full size prototype stills, of the simple basin-single slope type, have been operated with particular interest in developments for improving their yield. The use of a layer of black stones inside the stills to prolong the mass transfer period has been tested and 33% productivity increase has been reported. Coupling solar stills with solar collectors for brine preheating has been also investigated. Combined brine preheating and cover external cooling raised the yield of the stills by an average of 49%.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; EVAPORATION; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Utilization; WATER TREATMENT - Salt Removal; BRINE DEPTH; EXPERIMENTAL STILLS; HEAT STORING ROCKS; PRODUCTIVITY; SOLAR COLLECTORS; DISTILLATION

Title: SOLAR DISTILLATION - STATE OF THE ART AND FUTURE PROSPECTS.
Affiliations: CSIRO, Div of Energy Technology,, Highett, Aust, CSIRO, Div of Energy Technology, Highett, Aust
Authors with affiliations: Cooper, P.I., CSIRO, Div of Energy Technology,, Highett, Aust, CSIRO, Div of Energy Technology, Highett, Aust
Abstract: This paper reviews the state of the art of solar distillation, with particular reference to single effect basin type solar stills. These are the most common form of solar still and the only type which have been installed in any significant size. The equations describing the internal heat and mass transfer in a solar still are presented and used as a basis for indicating the conditions which lead to high outputs from solar stills. It is shown that the potential for increasing the efficiency of solar stills is not large. A number of the more successful materials which have been used for the cover, basin liner, structure, basin insulation and seals are presented, with comment on their advantages and disadvantages. The operational problems and ways of overcoming them are given and areas identified where field experience is still required. A method for approximately sizing solar still area and the required water storage volume is presented, with some comment on storage features. There is some scope in the future for increasing the unit area output of solar stills by the use of dyes and supplementary waste heat.
Index Keywords: DESALINATION; DISTILLATION; RESERVOIRS; SEAWATER - Salt Removal; WATER TREATMENT - Salt Removal; CONSTRUCTIONAL MATERIALS; MULTIPLE EFFECT STILLS; OPERATIONAL PROBLEMS; SOLAR DISTILLATION; SOLAR STILLS; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Flow Properties of Ethylene-Propylene Terpolymer Filled with Silica Modified by Silane Coupling Agents
Source title: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Product Research and Development
Affiliations: School of Chemical Engineering, Cornell University, New York 14853, Ithaca, United States; International Business Machines Corporation, Endicott, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Daley, L.R., School of Chemical Engineering, Cornell University, New York 14853, Ithaca, United States, International Business Machines Corporation, Endicott, NY, United States; Rodriguez, F., School of Chemical Engineering, Cornell University, New York 14853, Ithaca, United States
Abstract: When some polymers are extruded, pulsating flow can occur. This is associated with land fracture where the elastic energy storage capacity of the flowing polymer is exceeded periodically near the wall. In the usual shear stress-rate-of-shear diagram, such behavior can be seen as a hysteresis loop. The commercial rubber, based on ethylene-propylene-diene monomer (EPDM) exhibits this behavior. A reinforcing filler, finely divided silica, when added to the EPDM, increases the loop size. On the other hand, treatment of the EPDM-silica mixture with a silane coupling agent can decrease the size of the loop. Two other measures of energy-storing capacity are the Bagley end correction (stored shear strain) and die swell, Both of these are affected somewhat by the filler-coupling agent combination. © 1983, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: MONOMERS; POLYMERS - Extrusion; ETHYLENE-PROPYLENE TERPOLYMER; TERPOLYMERS

Authors: Philippopouios C., Economou D., Economou C., Marangozis J.
Title: Norbornadiene-Quadricyclane System in the Photochemical Conversion and Storage of Solar Energy
Source title: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Product Research and Development
Affiliations: Laboratory of Chemical Process Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Philippopouios, C., Laboratory of Chemical Process Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece; Economou, D., Laboratory of Chemical Process Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece; Economou, C., Laboratory of Chemical Process Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece; Marangozis, J., Laboratory of Chemical Process Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece
Abstract: Experimental data are presented on the photochemical conversion of norbornadiene to quadricyclane. Parameters examined in the efficiency and kinetics of conversion were concentration effects and the presence of solvents and photosensitizers. A model of a flat-plate, batch, photochemical solar collector was evaluated with the experimental data and insolation information. Process analysis and preliminary economic evaluation of the system are presented which point to the conclusion that the system is technically feasible but economically noncompetitive at present. © 1983, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Butler Paul C., Freese James M., Miller David W., Price Gary D., Carlson Jack N.
Title: SMALL WIND TURBINE WITH BATTERY STORAGE STAND-ALONE EXPERIMENT.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Butler, Paul C., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Freese, James M., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Miller, David W., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Price, Gary D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA; Carlson, Jack N., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: An experiment to evaluate battery storage with a stand-alone wind generator system is being pursued jointly by Sandia National Laboratories (SNL) and the Rocky Flats Small ( less than 100 kW) Wind Systems Test Facility (Rockwell International). The goal of the experiment is to evaluate the performance, life, and maintenance requirements of batteries in a stand-alone environment. Also, the operating characteristics and life of the wind turbine are being evaluated. This paper discusses in detail the system components and instrumentation as well as the initial battery capacity testing and load cycle testing. Partial results from the first four months of data are presented.

Title: MANAGEMENT AND DISPOSAL OF USED NUCLEAR FUEL AND REPROCESSING WASTES.
Source title: Uranium and Nuclear Energy, Proceedings of the International Symposium held by the Uranium Institu
Affiliations: Natl Cooperative for the Disposal of, Radioactive Wastes, Switz, Natl Cooperative for the Disposal of Radioactive Wastes, Switz
Authors with affiliations: Rometsch, Rudolf, Natl Cooperative for the Disposal of, Radioactive Wastes, Switz, Natl Cooperative for the Disposal of Radioactive Wastes, Switz
Abstract: After presenting the historical and technical backgrounds of used nuclear fuel disposal, the international consensus on the principles of final disposal is outlined. The existing waste management practices are briefly reviewed. It is concluded that the technologies required for safely handling used nuclear fuel and reprocessing wastes are well-established and proven, and are currently in commercial operation; as a result of the considerable amount of research and development work already completed, there is now sufficient knowledge to demonstrate that both used fuel and reprocessing wastes can be finally disposed of safely - meaning that future generations can be free of the need to care for them.

Title: PRODUCT RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AT NUOVO PIGNONE.
Affiliations: Nuovo Pignone, Technological, Research & Development Dep,, Florence, Italy, Nuovo Pignone, Technological Research & Development Dep, Florence, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Esposito, G., Nuovo Pignone, Technological, Research & Development Dep,, Florence, Italy, Nuovo Pignone, Technological Research & Development Dep, Florence, Italy
Abstract: Nuovo Pignone mainly operates in an energy market which, as is well known, is characterized by continuous technological development and fierce international competition. Moreover, in the past few years, this market has undergone rapid and often unpredictable changes in trend and stability. The company has been established in natural gas services (such as treatment, transport, storage and reinjection), fertilizers (ammonia and urea), methanol and polyethylene production, and oil refining, and more recently in nuclear power and energy recovery and some electronic applications, and has focused its attention on some requirements stemming from the increasing importance of off-shore oil discoveries. The company has also been keeping a watchful eye on processes involving coal, such as gasification, slurry transportation, and liquefaction.

Authors: Bennett W.S., Gilbert K.V., Lowrey R.Y.
Title: LONG TERM MANAGEMENT OF USDOE TRANSURANIC WASTE.
Affiliations: Rockwell Int, Rocky Flats Plant,, Golden, CO, USA, Rockwell Int, Rocky Flats Plant, Golden, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bennett, W.S., Rockwell Int, Rocky Flats Plant,, Golden, CO, USA, Rockwell Int, Rocky Flats Plant, Golden, CO, USA; Gilbert, K.V., Rockwell Int, Rocky Flats Plant,, Golden, CO, USA, Rockwell Int, Rocky Flats Plant, Golden, CO, USA; Lowrey, R.Y., Rockwell Int, Rocky Flats Plant,, Golden, CO, USA, Rockwell Int, Rocky Flats Plant, Golden, CO, USA
Abstract: Operations of the US Department of Energy (USDOE) and its predecessor agencies have generated large quantities of waste materials contaminated with transuranic (TRU) elements. These wastes were originally managed by shallow land burial. In 1970 a change in policy occurred which required that wastes contaminated with TRU elements above 10 nCi/gm be placed in retrievable storage pending development of a permanent isolation method. The concentration limit of 10 nCi/gm was selected to be no higher than the upper range of radium-226 occurring naturally in the earth's crust. Plutonium-239, the principal isotope in TRU waste, and radium-226 are comparable in half life and radiotoxicity. It was reasoned that since man had lived in the vicinity of such alpha activity levels without apparent ill effects, placing materials with such contamination levels in carefully selected near surface disposal sites would present no significant hazard. It is now felt, based on discrimination factors, relative biological effectiveness and pathway analyses, that this concentration limit was overly conservative, and will likely be raised to 100 nCi/gm in the near future.
Index Keywords: INDUSTRIAL WASTES - Treatment; WASTE DISPOSAL - Management; ALPHA ACTIVITY LEVELS; LONG-TERM MANAGEMENT; NEAR SURFACE DISPOSAL SITES; RADIOTOXICITY; RETRIEVABLE STORAGE; TRANSURANIC WASTES; TRANSURANIUM ELEMENTS

Title: GEOTHERMAL ALTERNATE ENERGY - EXPANDING OPTIONS.
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Earth &, Space Sciences Div, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Earth & Space Sciences Div, Los Alamos, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Pettitt, Roland, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Earth &, Space Sciences Div, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Earth & Space Sciences Div, Los Alamos, NM, USA; White, Anthony A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Earth &, Space Sciences Div, Los Alamos, NM,, USA, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Earth & Space Sciences Div, Los Alamos, NM, USA
Abstract: The energy that can be derived from extracting heat from the hot, dry rock of the earth is immense and available almost anywhere at accessible depths. High grade HDR heat sources may be used for generation of electricity or high-temperature direct process uses, while the lower grade (or shallower) heat sources will be exploited for use in a variety of ways that will alleviate the inefficient burning of the petroleum resources. Production temperatures of HDR systems can be closely tailored to fit the temperature requirements of the intended end use. By using the experience gained from the hydraulic fracturing of crystalline basement rock, a number of feasible options are now possible for storage of solar and waste industrial heat.

Title: KALAUPAPA, MOLOKAI, HAWAII WIND TURBINE AND BATTERY STORAGE ANALYSIS USING THE SOLSTOR II COMPUTER CODE.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: Murphy, Kevin D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: The feasibility of a wind turbine collector and battery storage system on the island of Molokai, Hawaii, was investigated using the SOLSTOR II optimizing computer code. Three system configurations were evaluated: utility-connected, stand-alone with generator backup, and stand-alone without generator backup. The utility-connected version considered both sell-back of energy to the utility and no sell-back. Major analysis conclusions are: the wind regime used in the simulation is extremely good, the annualized specific energy costs for all simulation cases are considerably lower than the current utility electric rate, and moderate battery storage capacity is economically attractive on the island of Molokai.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; BATTERY STORAGE SYSTEM; ENERGY SELL-BACK; GENERATOR BACKUP; SOLSTOR II OPTIMIZING COMPUTER CODE; WIND TURBINE COLLECTOR; WIND TURBINES

Title: DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY COMMERCIAL NUCLEAR WASTE MANAGEMENT POLICY.
Affiliations: US DOE, Nuclear Waste Policy Act, Project Office, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Nuclear Waste Policy Act Project Office, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hanrahan, Edward J., US DOE, Nuclear Waste Policy Act, Project Office, Washington, DC, USA, US DOE, Nuclear Waste Policy Act Project Office, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 establishes a step-by-step process governing the siting, construction, and operation of a high-level nuclear waste repository. As one of the first steps, DOE is required by the Act to identify states having potentially acceptable sites for a waste repository. Based on the information acquired thus far, Secretary Hodel has formally notified the governors and legislative leaders of the states of Louisiana, Texas, Utah, Mississippi, Nevada and Washington that each state contains a potentially acceptable site for a repository. The Act also requires that the DOE issue guidelines for the recommendation of sites for a repository within 180 days of enactment. The proposed guidelines were published in the Federal Register for public review and comment on February 7, 1983. These guidelines will be used to identify and nominate sites for characterization and eventually to determine the suitability of a site for development as a repository. The next steps under the Act are DOE'S initial nomination of five locations suitable for site characterization, based on a consideration of the guidelines and the environmental assessments to be prepared for each of the five nominated sites, followed by a recommendation of three candidate sites to the President for his approval.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR INDUSTRY - Legislation; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; HIGH-LEVEL RADIOACTIVE WASTE; MONITORED RETRIEVABLE STORAGE; NUCLEAR WASTE MANAGEMENT; NUCLEAR WASTE POLICY ACT; REPOSITORY SITE RECOMMENDATION; SPENT FUEL STORAGE; NUCLEAR FUELS

Title: PENALTY-FINITE ELEMENT METHODS IN CONDUCTION AND CONVECTION HEAT TRANSFER.
Affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Inst &, State Univ, Dep of Engineering, Science & Mechanics, Blacksburg,, Virginia Polytechnic Inst & State Univ, Dep of Engineering Science & Mechanics, Blacksburg,
Authors with affiliations: Reddy, J.N., Virginia Polytechnic Inst &, State Univ, Dep of Engineering, Science & Mechanics, Blacksburg,, Virginia Polytechnic Inst & State Univ, Dep of Engineering Science & Mechanics, Blacksburg,
Abstract: A finite element analysis based on the penalty function method is presented for the solution of the Navier-Stokes equations and the energy equation governing steady laminar motion of a viscous incompressible fluid. Numerical results are presented for the two-dimensional window cavity (R//A equals 10**3, 10**4, 10**5, 10**6) and three-dimensional window cavity (R//A equals 10**3 and 10**4) problems and a concentric cylindrical annulus problem. From the three-dimensional simulation of the flows, it is concluded that the fixed wall in the three-dimensional cavity has the (kinematic as well as thermal) effect of reducing the strength of the flow field. Due to the lack of quantitative results on the three-dimensional window cavity problem in the open literature, comparison of the results to assess the quality is not possible. However, it is noted that the global behaviour of solutions predicted by the penalty finite element model is very accurate despite the use of coarse meshes. In order to analyse higher Rayleigh number flows, mesh refinements must be made. Toward this end it is more practical to use out-of-core solution methods to meet the storage demands.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Element Method; RINGS; WINDOWS; CYLINDRICAL ANNULUS; ENERGY EQUATION; HEAT CONDUCTION; PENALTY FUNCTION METHOD; WINDOW CAVITY PROBLEMS; HEAT TRANSFER

Title: LATENT HEAT STORAGE WALL FOR AIR CONDITIONING.
Affiliations: Commission of the European, Communities, Joint Research Cent,, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Joint Research Cent, Ispra, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Colombo, R., Commission of the European, Communities, Joint Research Cent,, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Joint Research Cent, Ispra, Italy; Pellegrini, G., Commission of the European, Communities, Joint Research Cent,, Ispra, Italy, Commission of the European Communities, Joint Research Cent, Ispra, Italy
Abstract: The characteristics and the design of a latent heat storage curtain wall for space conditioning integrated in a hybrid solar building are presented and discussed from the point of view of the local climatological data and the energy saving potential. The wall combines in a single technological module the functions of collecting, storing and releasing heat at ambient temperature through a fan-assisted air circulation. The module is dimensioned in a way so as to meet the daily energy demand for climatization during the summer and to supply part of the space heating requirements during the winter.

Authors: Klingbeil W.W., Hong S.W., Kienle R.N., Witt H.W.H.
Title: THEORETICAL AND EXPERIMENTAL ANALYSIS OF DUAL-COMPOUND TREAD DESIGNS FOR REDUCED ROLLING RESISTANCE.
Affiliations: Uniroyal Inc Corporate Research, Cent, Middlebury, CT, USA, Uniroyal Inc Corporate Research Cent, Middlebury, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Klingbeil, W.W., Uniroyal Inc Corporate Research, Cent, Middlebury, CT, USA, Uniroyal Inc Corporate Research Cent, Middlebury, CT, USA; Hong, S.W., Uniroyal Inc Corporate Research, Cent, Middlebury, CT, USA, Uniroyal Inc Corporate Research Cent, Middlebury, CT, USA; Kienle, R.N., Uniroyal Inc Corporate Research, Cent, Middlebury, CT, USA, Uniroyal Inc Corporate Research Cent, Middlebury, CT, USA; Witt, H.W.H., Uniroyal Inc Corporate Research, Cent, Middlebury, CT, USA, Uniroyal Inc Corporate Research Cent, Middlebury, CT, USA
Abstract: A deflected tire/rolling resistance computer model to simulate free-rolling of a belted radial automobile tire is reviewed. Composite theory needed to compute model stiffness parameters and energy loss factors from details of the tread-band design is then summarized and applied to establish a reference model based on a regular production P195/75R14 steel-belted tire. The analysis of tread compound effects on rolling resistance proceeds from the reference model through variations in the elastic storage modulus and the hysteresis loss factor of the tread compound. Theoretical predictions are examined with respect to various rolling loss mechanisms underlying the model, as well as net rolling resistance trends. Experimental data confirming the theoretical model are provided for both unit-compound and dual-compound treads.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; BELTED RADIAL TIRES; CAP/BASE MODULI; DUAL-COMPOUND TREAD DESIGN; ELASTIC STORAGE MODULUS; HYSTERESIS LOSS FACTOR; TIRE ROLLING RESISTANCE; TIRES

Authors: Whitaker R.B., Craven S.M., Etter D.E., Jendrek E.F., Nease A.B.
Title: Characterization of Radiation-Cross-linked, High-Density Polyethylene for Thermal Energy Storage
Source title: Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Product Research and Development
Affiliations: MRC-Mound, Monsanto Research Corporation, Miamlsburg, Ohio 45342, United States
Authors with affiliations: Whitaker, R.B., MRC-Mound, Monsanto Research Corporation, Miamlsburg, Ohio 45342, United States; Craven, S.M., MRC-Mound, Monsanto Research Corporation, Miamlsburg, Ohio 45342, United States; Etter, D.E., MRC-Mound, Monsanto Research Corporation, Miamlsburg, Ohio 45342, United States; Jendrek, E.F., MRC-Mound, Monsanto Research Corporation, Miamlsburg, Ohio 45342, United States; Nease, A.B., MRC-Mound, Monsanto Research Corporation, Miamlsburg, Ohio 45342, United States
Abstract: Electron beam cross-linked high-density polyethylene (HDPE) pellets (DuPont Alathon, 0.93 MI) have been characterized for potential utility in thermal energy storage applications, before and after up to 500 melt-freeze cycles in ethylene glycol. Up to 95% of the HDPE'S initial DSC ΔWf value (44.7 cal/g) (at 1.25 °C/min cooling rates) was retained up to 9.0 Mrad radiation dosage. Form-stability after 500 melt-freeze cycles was very good at this dosage level. X-ray diffraction measurements showed little difference between irradiated HDPE's and the unirradiated control, indicating that cross-linking occurred primarily in the amorphous regions. FTIR spectroscopy showed the pellets to be uniformly reacted. The ratios of the 965-cm-1 absorption band (trans RCH=CRH′) to the 909-cm-1 band (RCH=CH2) increased with increasing radiation dosage, up to 18 Mrad. Gel contents reached a maximum of 75% at the 13.5 Mrad dosage, indicating that other reactions, in addition to cross-linking, occurred at the highest (18 Mrad) dosage level. © 1983, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; POLYETHYLENES

Title: CESA-I SIMULATION.
Affiliations: Univ Politecnica de Madrid,, Electronic Engineering Dep, Madrid,, Spain, Univ Politecnica de Madrid, Electronic Engineering Dep, Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Martinez, P., Univ Politecnica de Madrid,, Electronic Engineering Dep, Madrid,, Spain, Univ Politecnica de Madrid, Electronic Engineering Dep, Madrid, Spain; Munoz, M., Univ Politecnica de Madrid,, Electronic Engineering Dep, Madrid,, Spain, Univ Politecnica de Madrid, Electronic Engineering Dep, Madrid, Spain; Peire, J., Univ Politecnica de Madrid,, Electronic Engineering Dep, Madrid,, Spain, Univ Politecnica de Madrid, Electronic Engineering Dep, Madrid, Spain; Prieto, J., Univ Politecnica de Madrid,, Electronic Engineering Dep, Madrid,, Spain, Univ Politecnica de Madrid, Electronic Engineering Dep, Madrid, Spain; Castro, M., Univ Politecnica de Madrid,, Electronic Engineering Dep, Madrid,, Spain, Univ Politecnica de Madrid, Electronic Engineering Dep, Madrid, Spain
Abstract: The CESA-I simulation program allows study of a solar power plant in every possible situation. The CESA-I project (Central Electrosolar de Almeria) is a 1. 2 MWe solar facility located near Tabernas, Almeria, in south-eastern Spain. A detailed mathematical model for every plant component has been developed and successfully tested. The simulation program is built up from these models. The structure of the simulation program has three sections: the INPUT program asks the operator for the information needed to define the operating conditions in an interactive procedure; the CALCULUS program carries out the required calculation process; the OUTPUT program allows the operator to select the desired data output format, ranging from graphics to the plant's Data Acquisition System output.
