Authors: Moustafa S., Zewen H., Jarrar D., Ramadan M., El-Mansy H.
Title: TWO YEARS EXPERIENCE WITH KUWAIT'S COGENERATION SOLAR POWER PLANT.
Affiliations: Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research,, Sulaibiya Solar Program, Safat,, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Sulaibiya Solar Program, Safat, Kuwait
Authors with affiliations: Moustafa, S., Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research,, Sulaibiya Solar Program, Safat,, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Sulaibiya Solar Program, Safat, Kuwait; Zewen, H., Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research,, Sulaibiya Solar Program, Safat,, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Sulaibiya Solar Program, Safat, Kuwait; Jarrar, D., Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research,, Sulaibiya Solar Program, Safat,, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Sulaibiya Solar Program, Safat, Kuwait; Ramadan, M., Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research,, Sulaibiya Solar Program, Safat,, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Sulaibiya Solar Program, Safat, Kuwait; El-Mansy, H., Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research,, Sulaibiya Solar Program, Safat,, Kuwait, Kuwait Inst for Scientific Research, Sulaibiya Solar Program, Safat, Kuwait
Abstract: The world's first cogeneration solar power plant utilizing point focusing parabolic dishes was commissioned at the Sulaibiya Solar Complex of Kuwait in March 1981. During two years of operation, considerable experience was gained in system operation and maintenance, performance evaluation, system optimization and identification of critical technical components. Activities included evaluation of the solar collector field performance, thermal optimization of the collector field, pipeline network, collector reflective surface quality and receivers absorptance, as affected by sand storms, cleaning frequency, and aging. Other activities included the evaluation of performance of the energy conversion system (ECS). This included the thermodynamic cycle, the turbine performance under full and partial loading, and the overall power budget for various levels of incident solar radiation.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; POWER GENERATION - Solar Energy; SOLAR ENERGY - Energy Utilization; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; SOLAR RADIATION - Concentrators; ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEM; IRRIGATION GREENHOUSES; PARABOLIC DISHES; REFLECTIVE SURFACE QUALITY; THERMODYNAMIC CYCLE; TURBINE PERFORMANCE; COGENERATION PLANTS

Title: SOLAR PONDS: PERFORMANCE OF BOTTOM-INSULATION AND PERFORMANCE OF ABOVE-GROUND AND UNDER-GROUND THERMAL STORAGE.
Affiliations: Northern Arizona Univ, Coll of, Engineering & Technology,, Flagstaff, AZ, USA, Northern Arizona Univ, Coll of Engineering & Technology, Flagstaff, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Davis, B.W., Northern Arizona Univ, Coll of, Engineering & Technology,, Flagstaff, AZ, USA, Northern Arizona Univ, Coll of Engineering & Technology, Flagstaff, AZ, USA
Abstract: Two computer codes, which were developed for the purpose of modeling the performance of shallow solar ponds as well as thermal storage, are described. The models are used to specifically investigate the performance of bottom-insulation relative to reducing earth-coupled losses in ponds. Model results show that as much as 20% of the incident solar flow may be lost due to conductive earth coupling, unless the bottom is insulated. Results from a second model focused on the performance of solar thermal storage. Specifically, above-ground storage, with several different insulation thicknesses, was compared with underground storage performance; environmental conditions similar to those expected in Kuwait were imposed on the model. Results show that a modest amount of insulation on storage tanks stationed above-ground can be as efficient as underground storage. Further, small storage tanks need more insulation than large tanks: the insulation thickness required to produce equal performance in three typical tank sizes is quantified. One-fifth as much insulation is required on typically large tanks as is required for the same performance in typically small tanks.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SIMULATION; HEAT INSULATING MATERIALS; HOT WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RESERVOIRS - Energy Storage; HEAT STORAGE TANKS; INSULATION THICKNESS; MICROCOMPUTERS; SOLAR PONDS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; UNDERGROUND STORAGE; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: CONTROL OF THE PUMP STATION WORK TO COUNTRY WATERWORKS - THE METHOD OF PREPARING DISPECHERS PLANS.
Affiliations: Akad Rolnicza, Inst Budownictwa, Rolniczego, Wroclaw, Pol, Akad Rolnicza, Inst Budownictwa Rolniczego, Wroclaw, Pol
Authors with affiliations: Alberski, Z., Akad Rolnicza, Inst Budownictwa, Rolniczego, Wroclaw, Pol, Akad Rolnicza, Inst Budownictwa Rolniczego, Wroclaw, Pol
Abstract: The paper discusses a study that was based on energy conservation in water supply systems, and that was limited to analyzing the costs of electric power used for pumping water. The costs during the 1-th stage of control of the waterwork are the function of the decision concerning the quantity of water pumped to the system and of the quantity of distributed water which took place in that period. The quantity of distributed water in each interval is a random variable, thus the obtained effects of control (costs) in any period of time will result from the accuracy of prediction of the water pumped. An analytical approach is developed that allows an optimal control decision table to be prepared for all possible states of water storage in the reservoir in the time interval of the control process.
Index Keywords: FLOW OF WATER - Control; HYDRAULICS; ANALYTICAL APPROACH; CONTROL PROCESS; OPTIMAL CONTROL DECISION TABLE; PUMPED WATER QUANTITY; TIME INTERVALS; WATER QUANTITY DISTRIBUTED; PUMPING PLANTS

Title: OVERVIEW OF WASTE-HANDLING REQUIREMENTS FOR A NUCLEAR WASTE REPOSITORY IN BASALT.
Affiliations: Rockwell Hanford Operations, Basalt, Waste Isolation Project, Richland,, WA, USA, Rockwell Hanford Operations, Basalt Waste Isolation Project, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Gimera, R.J., Rockwell Hanford Operations, Basalt, Waste Isolation Project, Richland,, WA, USA, Rockwell Hanford Operations, Basalt Waste Isolation Project, Richland, WA, USA; Davis, J.M., Rockwell Hanford Operations, Basalt, Waste Isolation Project, Richland,, WA, USA, Rockwell Hanford Operations, Basalt Waste Isolation Project, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: Early in 1976, the U. S. Energy Research and Development Administration established the National Waste Terminal Storage (NWTS) Program. The Basalt Waste Isolation Project (BWIP) is one of the components of this program and is chartered with the responsibility of assessing the feasibility of using the deep basalts beneath the Hanford Site as a medium for the disposal of nuclear waste. The BWIP has used a systems approach to integrate the major program elements which affect the basic NWTS Program goal to provide permanent, environmentally safe, and secure underground storage of nuclear waste. These elements include: conducting geologic and hydrologic studies which will lead to the selection of an acceptable site for a possible repository; developing technical criteria for the design of waste packages; designing a nuclear waste repository in basalt (NWRB). This paper discusses the following waste-handling requirements for an NWRB: waste-handling building, receiving facilities, hot cell, transfer cask, transfer-cask transporter, and radwaste management.
Index Keywords: BASALT; MATERIALS HANDLING; BASALT WASTE ISOLATION PROJECT; COMMERCIAL WASTE DISPOSAL; GEOLOGIC REPOSITORIES; NATIONAL WASTE TERMINAL STORAGE PROGRAM; WASTE HANDLING REQUIREMENTS; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS

Title: WIND SYSTEM VALUE ASSESSMENT FOR ELECTRIC UTILITIES.
Affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Inst &, State Univ, Electrical Engineering, Dep, Blacksburg, VA, USA, Virginia Polytechnic Inst & State Univ, Electrical Engineering Dep, Blacksburg, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rahman, S., Virginia Polytechnic Inst &, State Univ, Electrical Engineering, Dep, Blacksburg, VA, USA, Virginia Polytechnic Inst & State Univ, Electrical Engineering Dep, Blacksburg, VA, USA; Matheny, B., Virginia Polytechnic Inst &, State Univ, Electrical Engineering, Dep, Blacksburg, VA, USA, Virginia Polytechnic Inst & State Univ, Electrical Engineering Dep, Blacksburg, VA, USA
Abstract: The factors that influence the value of the Wind Energy Conversion System (WECS) to different utilities are discussed. There are a number of articles which have examined this issue from the point of view of one or a few of these factors. This paper however, is meant to provide a comprehensive review of a number of factors that influence the value of the WECS. The factors discussed in this paper include capacity and energy credits, the downwind effect of clusters, array effects, environmental credit, and storage. Finally the authors discuss how these factors can be integrated to get a value assessment tool for wind energy systems.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC UTILITIES; ARRAY EFFECTS; CAPACITY AVAILABILITY; CLUSTER DOWNWIND EFFECTS; ENERGY CREDITS; WIND ENERGY SYSTEM VALUE; WIND POWER

Title: STRATEGIES OF SOLAR ENERGY APPLICATIONS IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES.
Affiliations: Asiatic Oxygen Ltd, Int Solar Energy, Soc, Maharashtra, India, Asiatic Oxygen Ltd, Int Solar Energy Soc, Maharashtra, India
Authors with affiliations: Datta, R.L., Asiatic Oxygen Ltd, Int Solar Energy, Soc, Maharashtra, India, Asiatic Oxygen Ltd, Int Solar Energy Soc, Maharashtra, India
Abstract: The peoples of the developing countries consisting mainly of rural population require the basic needs of life to be provided with. The sun and sun-based sources of energy with well planned and adequate technological developments, when applied judiciously, can contribute substantially towards meeting such needs. The strategies, therefore, required to be adopted should comprise the following components: socio-economical - relating the uses of such energy sources for basic needs of life; technological - developmental investigations of collection, storage, and efficient conversion of these sources, and of materials of construction; and organisational - setting up national commissions of solar energy.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURE; ENERGY RESOURCES; ENERGY UTILIZATION; NATURAL GAS; PEAT; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; INDIA; PHOTOVOLTAICS; RURAL PEOPLE; SUN BASED ENERGY SOURCES; THERMAL CONVERSION; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Fuller T., Finn M., Minogue P., Carroll D.
Title: INVESTIGATION OF THE PERFORMANCE OF VARIOUS HEATING SYSTEMS IN A MATCHED PAIR OF HOUSES - EXPERIMENTAL ARRANGEMENT AND INITIAL RESULTS.
Affiliations: An Foras Forbartha, Dublin, Irel, An Foras Forbartha, Dublin, Irel

Abstract: A description is given of a research project, the purpose of which was to investigate the ability of a group of conventional heating systems to meet a variety of heating regimes and the overall efficiency achieved, with a view to introducing innovations in control and heat storage to improve their performance. A pair of adjacent identical semi-detached houses were fitted with instrumentation for monitoring internal conditions and energy consumptions, and for simulating occupancy. A weather monitoring station was also installed at the site. The data logging and control functions were performed by a microcomputer.

Title: SOLAREX PV SOLAR BREEDER.
Affiliations: Solarex Corp, Rockville, MD, USA, Solarex Corp, Rockville, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Simms, W.J., Solarex Corp, Rockville, MD, USA, Solarex Corp, Rockville, MD, USA
Abstract: The Solarex Photovoltaic Solar Breeder is the first full scale industrial manufacturing facility to be completely powered by the sun. The Solarex Breeder is not connected to the utility grid. The Solarex Breeder will serve as the prototype for a wide variety of large scale, fully independent solar powered facilities in the future. The photovoltaic system for the Solarex Breeder consists of five major subsystems providing the functions of energy conversion, power regulation and inversion, energy storage, operation and control, and power distribution. A 200 kWp rooftop photovoltaic array converts sunlight directly into electricity. This array is composed of more than 3000 Solarex PowerLine Series photovoltaic panels. Each panel has 72 solar cells manufactured with Solarex' patented semicrystalline silicon-based technology. Thus, the Breeder array has nearly one-quarter million 10 multiplied by 10 cm solar cells.
Index Keywords: ARCHITECTURE; ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING - Solar; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS - Power Supply; SOLAR CELLS - Arrays; ECONOMICS; INDUSTRIAL MANUFACTURING FACILITY; POWER REGULATION; SELF-SUFFICIENT BUILDING; SOLAREX PHOTOVOLTAIC SOLAR BREEDER; TERRESTRIAL PHOTOVOLTAICS; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS

Title: OUR EFFORT IN SOLUTION OF ENERGY CONSERVATION OF AIR CONDITIONING SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Chinese Acad of Building Research, Inst of Air Conditioning, China, Chinese Acad of Building Research, Inst of Air Conditioning, China
Authors with affiliations: Wu, Yuanwei, Chinese Acad of Building Research, Inst of Air Conditioning, China, Chinese Acad of Building Research, Inst of Air Conditioning, China
Abstract: Energy consevation is the problem of the world concern. In China, the energy consumption on air coditioning has been rapidly increased. To reduce the energy consumption, some measures have been developed by my colleagues. One is to calculate design cooling load with a new method which takes the heat storage property of building envelope into consideration. The other is to give vertically zoned air conditioning only to working area in high-ceiling industrial buildings. The third one is to use heat recovery in packaged air conditioner, i. e. to take condensed heat as the reheat source.

Title: COUPLED HEAT AND GROUNDWATER FLOW IN POROUS ROCK.
Affiliations: AERE, Harwell, Engl, AERE, Harwell, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Rae, J., AERE, Harwell, Engl, AERE, Harwell, Engl; Robinson, P.C., AERE, Harwell, Engl, AERE, Harwell, Engl; Wickens, L.M., AERE, Harwell, Engl, AERE, Harwell, Engl
Abstract: Coupled heat and flow problems that occur for water in porous rock are considered with particular reference to the possible disposal underground of high-level radioactive waste. Other areas of interest are the storage and retrieval of hot water in underground reservoirs, the attempt to extract useful geothermal energy by pumping water into fracture systems in hot rock, and some thermal methods to extract oil from tight reservoirs. A finite element program, NAMMU, for coupled heat and groundwater flow problems is used for the examples considered.

Authors: Cardwell R.G., Younkin J.M., Swindle Jr. D.W.
Title: GAS-PHASE SAMPLING OF UF6 CYLINDERS IN INTERNATIONAL SAFEGUARDS.
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Gaseous Diffusion Plant,, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Gaseous Diffusion Plant, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cardwell, R.G., Oak Ridge Gaseous Diffusion Plant,, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Gaseous Diffusion Plant, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Younkin, J.M., Oak Ridge Gaseous Diffusion Plant,, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Gaseous Diffusion Plant, Oak Ridge, TN, USA; Swindle Jr., D.W., Oak Ridge Gaseous Diffusion Plant,, Oak Ridge, TN, USA, Oak Ridge Gaseous Diffusion Plant, Oak Ridge, TN, USA
Abstract: This paper describes a method taking gas-phase or, equivalently, vapor-phase samples from cylinders containing solid or liquid UF//6 for routine IAEA verification of UF//6 enrichment and purity, and recommends it as a general replacement for routine liquid sampling of UF//6 cylinders performed during IAEA verification inspections. Described is the vapor sampling method and the associated equipment used at United States gaseous diffusion enrichment facilities. Using data from field test experiments at the Oak Ridge and Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plants, liquid-phase and vapor-phase UF//6 sampling methods are compared to statistically validate the vapor-phase sampling method in determining **2**3**5U enrichment. Savings in cost, time, and sample storage and transportation are shown, as well as a large decrease in the amount of necessary sample inventory indefinitely held out of the process. In addition, a portable gas-phase sampling cart that can be used in both process and field sampling is described.
Index Keywords: GASES - Analysis; URANIUM COMPOUNDS; GAS-PHASE SAMPLING; INTERNATIONAL ATOMIC ENERGY AGENCY; NUCLEAR SAFEGUARDS; URANIUM HEXAFLUORIDE; NUCLEAR FUELS

Authors: Boese F.K., Floss B., Kostrzewa S., Wehowsky P.
Title: TOWER PROJECTS ALMERIA AND GAST AS STEPS TOWARDS THE COMMERCIAL HIGH TEMPERATURE UTILIZATION OF SOLAR ENERGY.
Affiliations: INTERATOM GmbH, Bergisch Gladbach, West Ger, INTERATOM GmbH, Bergisch Gladbach, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Boese, F.K., INTERATOM GmbH, Bergisch Gladbach, West Ger, INTERATOM GmbH, Bergisch Gladbach, West Ger; Floss, B., INTERATOM GmbH, Bergisch Gladbach, West Ger, INTERATOM GmbH, Bergisch Gladbach, West Ger; Kostrzewa, S., INTERATOM GmbH, Bergisch Gladbach, West Ger, INTERATOM GmbH, Bergisch Gladbach, West Ger; Wehowsky, P., INTERATOM GmbH, Bergisch Gladbach, West Ger, INTERATOM GmbH, Bergisch Gladbach, West Ger
Abstract: Solar tower plants can generate heat on a very high temperature level. Therefore, there is a real technical possibility to gain the high energy content of solar energy. The first demonstration plants realize temperatures up to a level of about 500 degree C. The possibility of higher operating temperatures (up to a level of about 1300 degree C) has been demonstrated in test facilities. From the thermodynamic point of view temperatures of about 2000 degree C are optimum, depending on absortivity, emissivity and light concentration. In the paper, the design and experiences gained with the 500 kW solar plant in Almeria and the 20 MW plant GAST are discussed. For the future development the thermochemical cycles are of special interest. Some possible examples are discussed and it is shown that there are specific advantages when solar energy is applied compared to systems with conventional energy sources.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN FUELS - Manufacture; POWER GENERATION - Solar Energy; SOLAR POWER PLANTS - Spain; SOLAR RADIATION - Heliostats; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION; COLD STORAGE TANK; DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEM; GAS COOLED SOLAR PLANT; THERMOCHEMICAL CYCLES; TOWER PLANTS; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Fetrow L.K., Allen R.P., McCoy M.W.
Title: SECTIONING TECHNIQUES FOR PLUTONIUM CONTAMINATED GLOVE BOXES.
Affiliations: Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab,, Richland, WA, USA, Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Fetrow, L.K., Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab,, Richland, WA, USA, Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; Allen, R.P., Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab,, Richland, WA, USA, Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA; McCoy, M.W., Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab,, Richland, WA, USA, Battelle, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: The size reduction of plutonium-contaminated glove boxes can substantially reduce storage and disposal volumes and is essential to prepare material for decontamination by advanced techniques such as vibratory finishing or electropolishing. Several industrial sectioning techniques have been evaluated at Pacific Northwest Laboratory under U. S. Department of Energy sponsorship for the size reduction of plutonium-contaminated glove-boxes. The techniques evaluated include plasma arc torch cutting, mechanical sawing and nibbling, abrasive cutting, and hydraulic shearing and punching. These demonstration studies show that plutonium-contaminated glove boxes can be sectioned safely, efficiently, and with minimal secondary waste generation for size reduction or decontamination purposes using an appropriate combination of available industrial metal cutting techniques.
Index Keywords: RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Waste Disposal; GLOVE BOXES; HYDRAULIC SHEARING AND PUNCHING; MECHANICAL SAWING AND NIBBLING; PLASMA ARC TORCH CUTTING, ABRASIVE CUTTING; SECTIONING TECHNIQUES; VOLUME REDUCTION; PLUTONIUM AND ALLOYS

Title: WEST VALLEY DEMONSTRATION PROJECT - STRATEGY FOR AN ACHIEVABLE BUT CHALLENGING PROJECT.
Affiliations: DOE, Idaho Operations Office, Idaho, Falls, ID, USA, DOE, Idaho Operations Office, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hamric, J.P., DOE, Idaho Operations Office, Idaho, Falls, ID, USA, DOE, Idaho Operations Office, Idaho Falls, ID, USA
Abstract: The West Valley facility, a shutdown reprocessing plant, has been kept in a safe condition by Nuclear Fuel Services, Inc. (NFS). The West Valley Nuclear Services Co. , Inc. (WVNS), a subsidiary of Westinghouse Electric Corporation, took over site operations from NFS for the Department of Energy's West Valley Project Office. In the strictest sense, the engineering arm of WVNS is now working toward bringing the multitude of project tasks into focus. They are developing logic pathways to identify all the links needed in the chain to accomplish solidification, storage, and shipment of the high level waste (HLW). In addition to efforts directly supporting the demonstration portion of the project, operational activities were stepped up upon site takeover. Beneficial changes have already been made in security, radiation monitoring and control, emergency planning and drills, and administrative controls.
Index Keywords: INDUSTRIAL WASTES - Treatment; NUCLEAR FUELS - Reprocessing; CLOSED REPROCESSING PLANT; DECONTAMINATION; HIGH-LEVEL RADIOACTIVE WASTES; OPERATIONAL ACTIVITIES; WEST VALLEY DEMONSTRATION PROJECT; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS

Title: TROGLODYTE COMMUNITIES IN FRANCE.
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, Sch of, Architecture, MD, USA, Univ of Maryland, Sch of Architecture, MD, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lord, David, Univ of Maryland, Sch of, Architecture, MD, USA, Univ of Maryland, Sch of Architecture, MD, USA
Abstract: The definition of a troglodyte comes from the Greek, troglodytes, 'One who creeps into holes; cave dweller. ' The expression refers to any of the prehistoric people who lived in caves or to those who choose to live alone in seclusion. Far from these definitions is the richness of life and culture of the underground dwellers of central France who live in the maisons troglodytes. The people who live here are the modern French who have inherited centuries-old homes which require very little energy or maintenance to keep them comfortable. The adjustment to increased costs of imported goods including energy has been taking place quietly in the French countryside for many years as Frenchmen have re-discovered the homes of their ancestors.
Index Keywords: ARCHITECTURE; HEATING - Heat Storage; CARVED OUT SHELTERS; LOIRE VALLEY DWELLINGS; QUARRIED CAVES; SUBTERRANEAN SHELTERS; UNDERGROUND HOUSING; BUILDINGS

Title: DESIGN DESCRIPTION AND OPERATIONAL EXPERIENCE WITH A CONCENTRATING PHOTOVOLTAIC TOTAL ENERGY SYSTEM IN HAWAII.
Affiliations: Acurex Corp, Mountain View, CA, USA, Acurex Corp, Mountain View, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rafinejad, D., Acurex Corp, Mountain View, CA, USA, Acurex Corp, Mountain View, CA, USA
Abstract: Wilcox Hospital photovoltaic (PV) system is rated at 35 kW of direct current electrical power and 200 kW of thermal energy at the design condition of 1,000 W/m**2 of direct normal insolation and 50 degree C cell temperature. The PV system is designed to supply electricity to the hospital grid, and heat for domestic hot water. The electricity is generated from PV cells along the focal line of the parabolic trough concentrators. The resulting electrical power is converted and conditioned by the power conditioning system to supply alternating current electricity at 480V, three phase to the hospital, eliminating the necessity for electrical storage. The thermal energy and cell cooling system consists of a closed-loop coolant circuit; a storage tank with an immersion-type heat exchanger for heating the hospital portable water. The power conditioning unit (PCU) has two distinct functions. The first is to hold the field at its peak power point, and the second is to produce alternating current power compatible with the utility. Operation of the field is fully automatic.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; HOSPITALS - Hawaii; POWER GENERATION - Solar Energy; SOLAR POWER PLANTS - Design; SOLAR RADIATION - Concentrators; CONCENTRATING PHOTOVOLTAIC TOTAL ENERGY SYSTEM; CONTROL CABINET; ELECTRIC GRID; IMMERSION TYPE HEAT EXCHANGER; POWER CONDITIONING UNIT; STORAGE TANK; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS

Authors with affiliations: Birchard, G.F., US Nuclear Regulatory Commission,, Washington, DC, USA, US Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Washington, DC, USA; Alexander, D.H., US Nuclear Regulatory Commission,, Washington, DC, USA, US Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: The US Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) must evaluate the sites and designs for high-level waste (HLW) repositories proposed by the US Department of Energy (DOE) against NRC and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) standards. This evaluation will require the use of complex numerical models for comparison with standards. Because the NRC needs to develop models based upon a correct understanding of natural processes in order to verify models used by applicants in the licensing process, a number of analogues are being investigated.

Title: Dynamics of latent heat storage in fixed beds a non-linear equilibrium model— the analogy with chromatography
Affiliations: Laboratoire Des Sciences Du Génie Chimique, CNRS-ENSIC, 1 Rue Grandville, 54042 Nancy Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Chapotard, C., Laboratoire Des Sciences Du Génie Chimique, CNRS-ENSIC, 1 Rue Grandville, 54042 Nancy Cedex, France; Tondeur, D., Laboratoire Des Sciences Du Génie Chimique, CNRS-ENSIC, 1 Rue Grandville, 54042 Nancy Cedex, France
Abstract: This paper investigates theoretically the dynamics of a latent heat storage system consisting of a fixed bed operating close to thermal equilibrium with a percolating fluid. The model used is an idealized one, which emphasizes the role of the heat capacity factor, but neglects heat transfer resistances, losses, and hydrodynamic non-idealities. The approach is shown to resemble that used classicaly in non-linear adsorption, and analogous concepts, such as shock waves and dispersive waves are introduced. The shapes and propagation characteristics of the temperature profiles generated during loading and unloading of the bed are discussed, for various fusible materials, operating temperatures, initial and boundary conditions, and flow direction. The non-linear dependence of the enthalpy of the storage material on temperature is shown to play a central role in determining the qualitative features of these profiles. The aims of the article are mainly qualitative, conceptual and didactic. © 1983, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: CHROMATOGRAPHIC ANALYSIS; THERMODYNAMICS; DEVAULT EQUATION; ENTHALPY; EQUILIBRIUM MODEL; GOLDEN'S STRING RULE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: DESIGN OF STAND-ALONE WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEMS WITH ENERGY STORAGE.
Affiliations: Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of, Electrical & Computer, Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of Electrical & Computer Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ashenayi, K., Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of, Electrical & Computer, Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of Electrical & Computer Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA; Ramakumar, R., Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of, Electrical & Computer, Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA, Oklahoma State Univ, Sch of Electrical & Computer Engineering, Stillwater, OK, USA
Abstract: This paper discusses the application of the Loss of Power Supply Probability (LPSP) method to the design of stand-alone wind energy conversion systems (WECS) with energy storage. The entire output of the WECS is assumed to be processed through the storage and the wind resource is modeled using a Weibull distribution. The WECS power output characteristic is approximated in terms of two straight line segments and the load is assumed to have a uniform distribution. Equations and assumptions related to the modeling and design are documented in the paper. Representative numerical results for typical wind regimes and for different combinations of system parameters are presented and discussed.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; OUTPUT STORAGE PROCESSING; POWER SUPPLY PROBABILITY LOSS; STAND-ALONE SYSTEMS; TYPICAL WIND REGIMES; UNIFORM DISTRIBUTION LOAD; WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEM/WECS; WIND TURBINES

Abstract: Article XII. A. 5 of the IAEA Statutes is discussed. Title: VENTILATION OF AGRICULTURAL STRUCTURES.
Abstract: The objective of this book is to provide the basic fundamentals of ventilation of agricultural structures. The focus is toward ventilation as it relates to environmental modification for livestock buildings and plant growth and storage facilities. The intention is to present the 'state-of-the-art' of ventilation of livestock and plant structures from the basic fundamentals of ventilation through the application of these fundamentals to design and management, while taking into consideration the economic and energy use characteristics of specific systems. This necessarily includes consideration of the physiological responses of livestock and plants to the environment, since these responses are essential to the design and performance of ventilation systems. Refs.

Title: PROPOSED ALTERNATIVES FOR INTERNATIONAL PLUTONIUM STORAGE.
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Authors with affiliations: de Montmollin, J.M., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM,, USA, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
Abstract: The IAEA Director General convened an Expert Group in December 1978, to study proposals for implementing some form of IPS. The Group labored for three years, developing details of a single proposed concept. In early 1982 a group of developing countries proposed a different and less-restrictive scheme, which was labeled Alternative B. In response, three other countries proposed a scheme more restrictive than the original Alternative A. The Expert Group forwarded all three alternatives to the Board of Governors, without recommendation, in its final report. In this paper the features that distinguish each of the alternatives are described.
Index Keywords: LEGISLATION; NUCLEAR FUELS - Protection; INTERNATIONAL ATOMIC ENERGY AGENCY; INTERNATIONAL PLUTONIUM STORAGE; NUCLEAR SAFEGUARDS; PLUTONIUM AND ALLOYS

Title: UNDERGROUND STORAGE OF OIL AND GAS: TECHNICAL DEVELOPMENT AND COST ASPECTS.
Affiliations: Itasca Consulting Group Inc,, Minneapolis, MN, USA, Itasca Consulting Group Inc, Minneapolis, MN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Bergman, S.Magnus, Itasca Consulting Group Inc,, Minneapolis, MN, USA, Itasca Consulting Group Inc, Minneapolis, MN, USA
Abstract: In the transportation chain, storage is a very important factor. Storage is not an aim in itself but a way to obtain a higher degree of utilization of pipelines and terminal space as well as to overcome potential cut off from supply sources. Often the production of different oil and gas products from refineries and suppliers will remain at a constant level, while the consumption demand varies from week to week throughout the year, thus requiring the suppliers to stockpile oil and gas to even out the supply capacity and optimize the function of the system. This paper will briefly describe different storage applications of oil and gas on the surface as well as underground, then concentrate on the cavern storage application and describe technical developments within this field.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; GAS STORAGE - Underground; AQUIFER STORAGE; COST-COMPARISON OF STORAGE METHODS; SALT DOME STORAGE FACILITY; STORAGE IN ROCK CAVERNS; PETROLEUM, CRUDE

Title: CHP/DH SYSTEMS AND THE OUTLOOK FOR THE INNER CITIES.
Affiliations: Atkins Research & Development, UK, Atkins Research & Development, UK
Authors with affiliations: Murphy, T.F., Atkins Research & Development, UK, Atkins Research & Development, UK
Abstract: The lead city feasibility studies have shown that there is a close relationship between the outlook for urban areas and the prospects for CHP/DH systems. Trends in population movements, housing renewal and economic activity in the inner city areas of the UK are reviewed and their effect on the prospects for CHP/DH systems as a whole and on the development of schemes are explored.
Index Keywords: HEATING - District; URBAN PLANNING - Heating; CHP/DH SYSTEMS; COMBINED HEAT AND POWER; ENERGY SAVING; HEAT LOADS; HEAT STORAGE SYSTEMS; RESIDENTIAL HOUSES; COGENERATION PLANTS

Title: ADDITIONAL PEAK LOAD SET FOR COMBINED CYCLE POWER PLANT OPERATING ON GAS FROM COAL.
Authors with affiliations: Miller, A.; Lewandowski, J.
Abstract: One of the essential trends of further power engineering development in countries with large coal reserves seems to be at present building of combined gas-steam power plants operating on gas from coal gasification. To improve load following capability and to increase power system advantages of the combined cycle plant the possibility to add a peak load unit to the base configuration of power plant has been analysed. General concept of such additional peak load unit consists in storage of some fuel gas from gasification process in suitable reservoir at the night-time and burning it in peak load gas turbine during the day-time. The main problems occuring, namely, the selection of a gas storage method, reasonable from the technical and economical point of view, and the choice of the gas turbine arrangement are discussed. The results of the analysis indicate technical reality of application of the proposed peak-load set. Estimated costs of peak energy obtained from discussed set are slightly higher than corresponding costs of a hydraulic pumped storage power plant in Polish circumstances.
Index Keywords: COAL GASIFICATION; GAS STORAGE; GAS TURBINES; COMBINE CYCLE POWER PLANTS; COMBINED GAS-STEAM POWER PLANTS; COMPARISON WITH HYDRAULIC PUMPED STORAGE POWER PLANTS.; COUNTRIES WITH LARGE COAL RESERVES; PEAK-LOAD SET; POWER PLANTS

Title: REGIONAL HEAT GRIDS AND HEAT STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Affiliations: Kernforschungsanlage Juelich, Inst, of Reactor Components, Juelich, West, Ger, Kernforschungsanlage Juelich, Inst of Reactor Components, Juelich, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Scholz, F., Kernforschungsanlage Juelich, Inst, of Reactor Components, Juelich, West, Ger, Kernforschungsanlage Juelich, Inst of Reactor Components, Juelich, West Ger
Abstract: From the point of view of saving primary energy in general and finding substitutes for oil in particular, the provision of district heat on the basis of combined heat and power (CHP) and the utilization of waste heat is superior to all other heating processes. Heat reservoirs also make a contribution to reducing energy and oil consumption since they enable the incidence of and demand for heat to be uncoupled as far as time is concerned. An economically favorable solution is presented by large pressureless heating water reservoirs.
Index Keywords: COGENERATION PLANTS - Planning; URBAN PLANNING - Heating; CHP/DH SYSTEMS; COMBINED HEATING AND POWER (CHP); DISTRICT HEATING (DH); FEASIBILITY STUDY; HEATING NETWORKS; WASTE HEAT; HEATING

Title: STATUS OF PHOTOVOLTAIC CONVERSION.
Affiliations: Arizona State Univ, Coll of, Engineering & Applied Sciences,, Tempe, AZ, USA, Arizona State Univ, Coll of Engineering & Applied Sciences, Tempe, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Backus, C.E., Arizona State Univ, Coll of, Engineering & Applied Sciences,, Tempe, AZ, USA, Arizona State Univ, Coll of Engineering & Applied Sciences, Tempe, AZ, USA
Abstract: The field of photovoltaics has made tremendous strides over the last ten years toward becoming a viable economical power source to meet human needs. The price of photovoltaic modules for terrestrial applications has decreased by more than a factor of 10 over that time period to a level of 5/peak watt (U. S. ) at the manufacturer's dock. This price level makes them more attractive than many other power sources, such as diesel generators, for remote sites. This can be especially true for many of the applications in the Middle Eastern countries of the world. The technology is in such a state of development that it is reasonable to assume that the price of photovoltaic modules will decrease about another factor of 10 in the next 10 years. At that price photovoltaics becomes economically attractive for most parts of the world.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Energy Resources; SEMICONDUCTOR MATERIALS; SOLAR CELLS - Efficiency; SOLAR ENERGY; SPACECRAFT - Power Supply; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; FLAT PLATE SOLAR ARRAYS; PHOTOVOLTAIC MODULES AND SYSTEMS; SATELLITES; SILICON; STORAGE BATTERIES; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS

Authors with affiliations: Akinoglu, B.G, Middle East Technical Univ, Physics, Dep, Ankara, Turk, Middle East Technical Univ, Physics Dep, Ankara, Turk; Kunc, S., Middle East Technical Univ, Physics, Dep, Ankara, Turk, Middle East Technical Univ, Physics Dep, Ankara, Turk; Ogelman, H., Middle East Technical Univ, Physics, Dep, Ankara, Turk, Middle East Technical Univ, Physics Dep, Ankara, Turk; Yegingil, I., Middle East Technical Univ, Physics, Dep, Ankara, Turk, Middle East Technical Univ, Physics Dep, Ankara, Turk
Abstract: A passive solar house using thermal storage walls has been in operation since spring of 1981 in Adana, Turkey. Two of the rooms of this residential building have been constructed identically, except one has a roof pond. During the summer of 1982 the roof pond was operated with a thin layer of light floating perlite on the water; no additional movable covers were employed. The comparison of the two rooms indicates that 5 degree C of cooling, corresponding to 16 w/m**2 average daily energy removal from the pond, can be achieved. The results and the thermal analysis of the system are discussed.

Title: SPENT FUEL STORAGE AND REPROCESSING.
Affiliations: Allied Corp, USA, Allied Corp, USA
Authors with affiliations: Forrow, Brian D., Allied Corp, USA, Allied Corp, USA
Abstract: The author reports on the current status of the Barnwell Nuclear Fuel Reprocessng Plant in South Carolina. The plant was designed and constructed to reprocess spent fuel from commercial power reactors utilizing the basic solvent extraction technology ('Purex Process') for chemical separation which has been successfully employed for more than 380 plant-years of world operation. However, no spent nuclear fuel has thus far been stored or processed at the Barnwell Plant, owing to a Government prohibition against reprocessing by the plant's private owners. The most important result achieved at Barnwell has been the demonstration of advanced safeguards for reprocessing plants to prevent nuclear proliferation. The owners remain hopeful that it will be possible for the Plant to operate under new ownership (presumably the Government), but it is imperative that a solution be provided before the funding ceases in order to preserve and fully utilize this valuable national asset.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR INDUSTRY - Energy Policy; NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS - Waste Disposal; COMMERCIAL POWER REACTORS; FUEL REPROCESSING PLANTS; NUCLEAR PROLIFERATION SAFEGUARDS; SOLVENT EXTRACTION TECHNOLOGY; SPENT NUCLEAR FUEL; NUCLEAR FUELS

Authors: Kline W.H., Lahey T.J., Moe H.J.
Title: DECOMMISSIONING A PLUTONIUM FABRICATION FACILITY.
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kline, W.H., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA; Lahey, T.J., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA; Moe, H.J., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA, Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, IL, USA
Abstract: In 1973, Argonne National Laboratory began consolidating and upgrading its plutonium-handling operations with the result that a research fuel-fabrication facility was shut down and declared surplus. Sixteen of the twenty-three gloveboxes which comprised the system were dismantled and relocated for reuse or placed into controlled storage during 1974 but, due to funding constraints, full-scale decommissioning did not start until 1978. Since that time the fourteen remaining contaminated gloveboxes, including all internal and external equipment as well as the associated ventilation systems, have been assayed for radioactive content, dissassembled, size reduced to fit acceptable packaging and sent to a U. S. Department of Energy transuranic (TRU) retrievable-storage repository or to a low-level nuclear burial site. The project required 4 1/2 years to complete, 30 man years of effort, produced some 560 m**3 (20,000 ft**3) of radioactive waste of which 70% was TRU, and cost around 2. 2 million dollars.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR FUELS - Processing; DECONTAMINATION; GLOVEBOXES; PLUTONIUM FABRICATION FACILITIES; TRANSURANIUM WASTES; RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS

Abstract: The recovery and reuse of industrial waste heat may be limited if an energy source cannot be utilized in an otherwise available but out of phase or unequal capacity end-use process. Authors with affiliations: Allen, C.C., Rockwell Hanford Operations, Basalt, Waste Isolation Project, Richland,, WA, USA, Rockwell Hanford Operations, Basalt Waste Isolation Project, Richland, WA, USA; Strope, M.B., Rockwell Hanford Operations, Basalt, Waste Isolation Project, Richland,, WA, USA, Rockwell Hanford Operations, Basalt Waste Isolation Project, Richland, WA, USA
Abstract: The National Waste Terminal Storage Program of the US Department of Energy is assessing a number of rock types to determine their suitability for the disposal of nuclear waste. As a part of this effort, the Basalt Waste Isolation Project (BWIP) is investigating the Pasco Basin in southwestern Washington State as the possible site of a nuclear waste repository in basalt (NWRB). The microcharacterization work described results in an identification of the minerals and other phase assemblages that provide the basis for a determination of the environment that acts to control geochemical conditions in an NWRB. Interactions between the basalt, groundwater, and proposed waste packages are studied to insure that the final repository and waste package designs meet all requirements for safety and isolation.

Abstract: The economic preconditions of applying solar energy to drying can be fulfilled by optimization using a simulation model and procedure of the solar system and its controlling strategy. By the simulation procedure the time functions of the state of material to be dried have to be determined on the basis of arbitrary time function of the input parameters of the solar system. The solar convective dryer is a compound thermal system. Its simulation model consists of the part-models of the solar collectors, of the heat storage, of the heat exchangers, of the flow system, of the dryer and of the controlling system. As an example of application the numerical analysis of a solar lucerne bed dryer is performed.

Title: ECONOMICS OF ENERGY STORAGE DEVICES IN INTERCONNECTED SYSTEMS - A NEW APPROACH.

Authors with affiliations: Rau, Narayan S., Natl Energy Board, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Natl Energy Board, Ottawa, Ont, Can; Necsulescu, Christina M., Natl Energy Board, Ottawa, Ont, Can, Natl Energy Board, Ottawa, Ont, Can
Abstract: The simulation of energy storage devices in power systems for economic analysis has generally been attempted as a linear program formulation. This report suggests a new method that includes the effect of machine outage and nonlinear nature of cost of production of energy. The probability density function (PDF) of hourly loads is the starting point of the method. The method has proposed the concepts of shifting the PDF to a 'target' to honor the energy constraints and has shown that the modifications to the PDF can be easily obtained from the cumulative distribution function (CDF). The method has been used for the analysis of operational economics of any storage device in two interconnected systems.

Title: FUEL SAVINGS THROUGH PROPER CONTROL OF STEAM STORAGE CAPACITIES OF AN INDUSTRIAL POWER PLANT.
Affiliations: Ekono Inc, Bellevue, WA, USA, Ekono Inc, Bellevue, WA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Immonen, Pekka J., Ekono Inc, Bellevue, WA, USA, Ekono Inc, Bellevue, WA, USA; Damen, Henrik, Ekono Inc, Bellevue, WA, USA, Ekono Inc, Bellevue, WA, USA
Abstract: Considerable savings in fuel costs, and operational advantages as well, can be achieved by proper utilization of existing steam storage capacities to smooth variations of the steam loads of individual boilers. The payback times of such investments have typically been less than a year. The Metsaliiton Teollisuus Oy Mill at Kirkniemi, Finland, is an example of the successful application of such a system. In spite of the need to simultaneously control two boilers and several thermal storages, it was possible to implement the system using standard control hardware, without using a centralized computer. Dynamic simulation was successfully applied to determine the optimum control strategy and the controller tuning parameters.

Title: Measurements on ablative hole formation process in thin tellurium-selenium alloy films
Affiliations: Philips Laboratories, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10562, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lou, D.Y., Philips Laboratories, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10562, United States; Blom, G.M., Philips Laboratories, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10562, United States
Abstract: We report on real time measurements of the hole formation process in Te-Se alloy films. The results tend to support a three-step model. First, there is an initiation stage. Energy is absorbed in advance of hole formation. The precise mechanism for hole initiation depend quite sensitively on writing conditions. In some situations the evidence supports a blister formation model. After the hole is initiated, its boundary then propagates out, driven by interfacial energies. Finally, in the terminal phase of hole opening, the continued propagation of the hole boundary becomes limited by the propagation of the melt boundary, until the film material solidifies.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL; LASERS - Applications; TELLURIUM SELENIUM ALLOYS

Title: A theoretical analysis of the dynamics of hot water underground stores of general shape
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: Inst. of Theoretical Phys., Goteborg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Brander, O., Inst. of Theoretical Phys., Goteborg, Sweden; Rehbinder, G., Inst. of Theoretical Phys., Goteborg, Sweden
Abstract: In 1969, Waterman introduced the so-called T-matrix method to solve the problem of the scattering of an acoustic wave from a body of general shape. Since then, this method has been extended in different directions and used to solve many different scattering problems. The authors show here that it can also be used to determine the temperature field in the rock around a cavern of general shape, filled with hot water of arbitrarily varying temperature. This problem is of interest for the storage of surplus heat for later use, an increasingly important technical problem. They modify the T-matrix formalism to be applicable to this problem, and show that it works for the simple case of a spherical cavity. They discuss some general properties of the temperature field, as well as some practical problems connected to the accuracy of the mathematical model and to the numerical convergence of the solution. Numerical calculations for non-spherical cases are postponed to later publications. The problem with several cavities is discussed, and a method to determine the influence of a plane ground surface is presented.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SOLAR ENERGY; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; UNDERGROUND STORAGE; HEATING

Title: Ablative optical recording using organic dye-in-polymer thin films: Some mechanistic aspects
Affiliations: Xerox Webster Research Center, Webster, NY 14580, United States
Authors with affiliations: Law, K.-Y., Xerox Webster Research Center, Webster, NY 14580, United States; Johnson, G.E., Xerox Webster Research Center, Webster, NY 14580, United States
Abstract: The influence of a number of materials properties and device structure variations on the energy threshold for laser marking of organic dye-in-polymer films has been investigated. Our results indicate that the write-sensitivity of these organic dye-in-polymer optical recording media is strongly dependent on the absorption efficiency of the recording film, the quantum efficiency of generation of thermal energy by the dye and the recording film thickness for films >100 nm. The write-sensitivity is however, not dependent on the glass transition temperature, the surface tension or the melt viscosity of the polymer binder. This independence is attributed to the very rapid nature of the mark formation process. The technological implications of the present work are discussed.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: Two-dimensional numerical simulation of an inductively driven imploding foil plasma

Abstract: A 1.9-MJ capacitor bank with intermediate inductive energy storage for pulse shortening has been used to implode a thin cylindrical sheath in a z-pinch geometry. Theoretical investigations of two-dimensional axisymmetric effects in the r-z plane, which lead to a thickening of the sheath, have been made using a two-dimensional magnetohydrodynamics code. The results of several calculations are presented which demonstrate how imperfections in the initial sheath geometry affect development of the acceleration-driven magnetohydrodynamic Rayleigh-Taylor instability.

Abstract: Limits on the yield of photochemical devices have been always analysed in standard atmospheric conditions: generally air mass, 0, 1, 1.2. In this paper the authors analyse limits of thermodynamical efficiency in realistic weather conditions. They give a general method which allows one to calculate the long-term value of limit efficiency in the case of systems with internal storage. They discuss how the threshold wavelength at which conversion efficiency is maximum depends on the climate and on the energy losses in storage.

Authors: Smy P.R., Clements R.M., Dale J.D., Simeoni D., Topham D.R.
Title: Efficiency and erosion characteristics of plasma jet igniters
Source title: Journal of Physics D: Applied Physics
Affiliations: Faculty of Engng., Univ. of Alberta, Edmonton, Alta., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Smy, P.R., Faculty of Engng., Univ. of Alberta, Edmonton, Alta., Canada; Clements, R.M., Faculty of Engng., Univ. of Alberta, Edmonton, Alta., Canada; Dale, J.D., Faculty of Engng., Univ. of Alberta, Edmonton, Alta., Canada; Simeoni, D., Faculty of Engng., Univ. of Alberta, Edmonton, Alta., Canada; Topham, D.R., Faculty of Engng., Univ. of Alberta, Edmonton, Alta., Canada
Abstract: The rate of erosion of both ceramic and metal in a typical plasma jet igniter has been monitored as a function of various experimental parameters. Even under the most favorable conditions it appears that working lifetimes may be limited to the order of ten hours-a figure in line with previous measurements of arc erosion. Direct measurements of the thermal energy delivered by the igniter to the adjacent gas reveal that overall efficiencies approximately 10% are attained. In order to minimise erosion while maintaining a given delivery of thermal energy it is found essential to work with low initial voltages on the energy storage capacitor.

Abstract: A dichroic dye was added to smectic A liquid crystals as an absorber of laser energy to eliminate the need to conduct heat from an external absorber to the liquid crystal layer. Title: Control of Ca2+ in rod outer segment disks by light and cyclic GMP
Affiliations: Laboratory of Chemical Physics, NIADDK, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD 20205, United States
Authors with affiliations: George, J.S., Laboratory of Chemical Physics, NIADDK, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD 20205, United States; Hagins, W.A., Laboratory of Chemical Physics, NIADDK, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD 20205, United States
Abstract: Photons absorbed in vertebrate rods and cones probably cause electrochemical changes at the photoreceptor plasma membrane by changing the cytoplasmic concentration of a diffusible transmitter substance, reducing the Na+ current flowing into the outer segment of the cell in the dark, to produce the observed membrane hyperpolarization that is the initial excitatory response1-4. Cyclic GMP has been proposed as the transmitter because a light-activated cyclic GMP phosphodiesterase (PDE) has been found in rod disk membranes5,6 and because intracellularly injected cyclic GMP7 reduces rod membrane potentials. Free Ca 2+ has also been proposed because increasing external [Ca 2+] quickly and reversibly reduces the dark current and divalent cationophores increase the Ca2+ sensitivity8. Ca 2+ efflux from rod outer segments (ROS) of intact retinas occurs simultaneously with light responses9,10. Vesicles prepared from ROS disk membranes become more permeable on illumination, releasing trapped ions or molecules11-13, but intact outer segment disks have not previously been found to store sufficient Ca2+ in darkness and to release enough in light to meet the theoretical requirements for control of the dark current by varying cytoplasmic Ca2+ (refs 14-18). We now report experiments that show the required Ca2+ storage and release from rod disk membranes suspended in media containing high-energy phosphate esters and electrolytes approximating the cytoplasmic composition of live rod cells. Cyclic GMP stimulates Ca2+ uptake by ROS disks in such media. © 1983 Nature Publishing Group.
Index Keywords: calcium; calcium 45; cyclic gmp; radioisotope; calcium; cyclic GMP; animal cell; calcium transport; drug efficacy; light; nonhuman; photon; retina; retina rod outer segment; visual system; active transport; animal; article; frog; intracellular membrane; light; metabolism; mitochondrion; photoreceptor; physiology; retina rod outer segment; vision; Animal; Biological Transport, Active; Calcium; Cyclic GMP; Intracellular Membranes; Light; Mitochondria; Photoreceptors; Rana catesbeiana; Rod Outer Segments; Vision

Authors: Smith S.J., MacDermott A.B., Weight F.F.
Title: Detection of intracellular Ca2+ transients in sympathetic neurones using arsenazo III
Affiliations: Laboratory of Preclinical Studies, National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, Rockville, MD 20852, United States; Department of Physiology, Yale University, School of Medicine, New Haven, CT 06510, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, S.J., Laboratory of Preclinical Studies, National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, Rockville, MD 20852, United States, Department of Physiology, Yale University, School of Medicine, New Haven, CT 06510, United States; MacDermott, A.B., Laboratory of Preclinical Studies, National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, Rockville, MD 20852, United States; Weight, F.F., Laboratory of Preclinical Studies, National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, Rockville, MD 20852, United States
Abstract: Changes in cytosolic calcium ion concentration ([Ca2+] i) have been implicated in a wide variety of cellular stimulus-transduction roles1-3. In nerve cells, it is believed that electrical activity raises [Ca2+]i, by allowing influx of Ca2+ through voltage-dependent channels in the surface membrane 4,5. Elevation of neuronal [Ca2+]i may also occur due to release of Ca2+ from intracellular storage sites 6-8. Transient increases in [Ca2+]i are thought to trigger neurotransmitter release9, and to modulate axonal transport10, energy metabolism11 and growth cone movement12. Intracellular Ca2+ also appears to regulate membrane potassium channels and thereby to regulate electrical excitability 13. Although [Ca2+]i transients have been measured in a few giant invertebrate neurones14, detection of such transients in a vertebrate neurone has not been previously reported. We have measured [Ca2+]i in bullfrog sympathetic neurones by photometry of a microinjected calcium indicator dye, arsenazo III (refs 14-16), and report here that action potentials and voltage-clamped depolarizations cause long-lasting increases in [Ca2+]i. Also, exposure to the drug theophylline can cause spontaneous periodic increases in [Ca 2+]i. Comparisons of [Ca2+]i signals with simultaneous intracellular recordings of membrane potential suggest that the kinetics of the post-tetanic hyperpolarization (PTH) following a series of action potentials or the spontaneous hyperpolarizations induced by theophylline directly reflect the kinetics of the [Ca2+]i, transient. © 1983 Nature Publishing Group.

Authors: Van Der Zaag D.E., Horton D.
Title: Potato production and utilization in world perspective with special reference to the tropics and sub-tropics
Affiliations: Directorate for Agricultural Research (DLO), Wageningen, Netherlands; International Potato Center (CIP), Lima, Peru
Authors with affiliations: Van Der Zaag, D.E., Directorate for Agricultural Research (DLO), Wageningen, Netherlands; Horton, D., International Potato Center (CIP), Lima, Peru
Abstract: Potato production is increasing rapidly in the tropics and sub-tropics and is declining gradually in the temperate zone. It is not expected that in the near future potato production for ethanol production will become important or that the production for starch or stock feed will increase. Consumption per capita is more or less stable in Western Europe and North America but is increasing in Africa and Asia. On average, energy and protein from potatoes cost the developing-country consumer at least three times as much as from wheat or rice. Better application by farmers of existing and newly developed technologies - including better adapted cultivars, healthy seed tubers, botanical seed and low-cost storage and processing - can reduce costs per unit of output substantially, mainly by increasing yield. Doubling the yield without considerable increases in production costs per hectare would allow the potato to become a cheap vegetable in many tropical or sub-tropical areas and to become a staple food in others with favourable growing conditions. © 1983 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: developing countries; energy; food consumption; food prices; production costs; starch; stock feed; technology

Authors: Meger R.A., Commisso R.J., Cooperstein G., Goldstein S.A.
Title: Vacuum inductive store/pulse compression experiments on a high power accelerator using plasma opening switches
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375
Authors with affiliations: Meger, R.A., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375; Commisso, R.J., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375; Cooperstein, G., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375; Goldstein, S.A., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375
Abstract: The first results of experiments using plasma opening switches for inductive energy storage are described. The switch has been shown to conduct up to 200-kA current for ∼50 ns then to open in <10 ns, transferring the current to an electron beam load. Inductive energy storage, pulse compression, and power multiplication are demonstrated. A simple model explaining the switch operation is presented.

Authors: Danilov M., Hasemann H., Kim P., Michel E., Nagovizin V., Schmidt-Parzefall W., Wurth R.
Title: The ARGUS drift chamber
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: DESY, Hamburg, Germany; ITEP, Moscow, Russian Federation; University of Toronto, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Danilov, M., ITEP, Moscow, Russian Federation; Hasemann, H., DESY, Hamburg, Germany; Kim, P., University of Toronto, Canada; Michel, E., DESY, Hamburg, Germany; Nagovizin, V., ITEP, Moscow, Russian Federation; Schmidt-Parzefall, W., DESY, Hamburg, Germany; Wurth, R., DESY, Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: The ARGUS detector came into operation at the DORIS-II e+e- storage ring at the end of 1982. Its two meter long drift chamber contains 5940 sense and 24588 field wires organized in uniform 18 × 18.8 mm2 drift cells filling the whole volume. These cells form 36 layers, 18 of which provide stereo views. Each sense wire is equipped with a single hit TDC and ADC for coordinate and dE/dx measurements. The chamber is operated with propane to improve momentum and dE/dx resolution. The drift chamber design and initial performance are presented. With a very crude space-time relation approximation and without all the necessary corrections applied, a spatial resolution of about 200 ≃m was obtained for half of the drift cell volume. Further corrections should improve this result. An intrinsic dE/dx resolution of 4.2% and an actual resolution of 5% were obtained for cosmic muons and also for Bhabha scattered electrons. An actual dE/dx resolution of 5.6% was obtained for pions from e+e- annihilation data with almost no track selection. A relativistic rise of 30% was observed in good agreement with theory. The long-term stability is still to be investigated. © 1983.
Index Keywords: PHYSICS - High Energy; PARTICLE DETECTORS

Authors: Bénichou J.L., Flegel W., Friend B., Gildemeister O., Girard C., Hauviller C., Hervé A., King A., Lecoq P., Panman J., Winter K.
Title: Design study of a large cylindrical drift chamber
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Bénichou, J.L., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Flegel, W., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Friend, B., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Gildemeister, O., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Girard, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Hauviller, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Hervé, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; King, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Lecoq, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Panman, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Winter, K., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: A design study of a large cylindrical drift chamber of 4.5 m length and 3.4 m diameter for an experiment at a large e+e- storage ring is presented. Measurements of the electrostatic stability of the wiresand of the pulse propagation along the wires are reported. The mechanical design, minimizing the amount of material traversed by particles, is discussed. © 1983.
Index Keywords: PHYSICS - High Energy; DRIFT CHAMBERS; PARTICLE DETECTORS

Authors: Arai R., Boerner H., Ishihara N., Kohriki T., Kondo T., Nakamura S., Watase Y., Suekane F.
Title: Development of a large cylindrical drift chamber for the venus detector at tristan
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: KEK, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Oho-Machi, Tsukuba-Gun, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1 Ohokayama, Meguro-Ku, Tokyo, 152, Japan

Abstract: A large cylindrical drift chamber is being built for the VENUS detector at the e+-e- storage ring TRISTAN at KEK. A total of 7104 drift cells is arranged in twenty-nine concentrical layers. The twenty axial layers are combined into double layers to simplify the task of the pattern recognition software. A spatial resolution of 150 ≃m is aimed at. © 1983.
Index Keywords: PHYSICS - High Energy; DRIFT CHAMBERS; PARTICLE DETECTORS

Title: Digital disk optics
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Kodak Apparatus Division, 901 Elmgrove Road, Rochester, NY, 14624, United States
Authors with affiliations: Foster, G.G., Kodak Apparatus Division, 901 Elmgrove Road, Rochester, NY, 14624, United States
Abstract: The KAD Digital Information Systems Laboratory As developed diode laser record and play-back equipment for use with Kodak Laser Write/Read (LWR) optical disks which have been described in previous sessions. The Digital Disk Breadboard (DDB) in operation for several years and the Advanced Optical Disk Demonstration Unit (AODDU) completed this year both offer convincing demonstrations of the excellent performance achievable with small light-weight apparatus. All our diode laser equipment utilizes lenses and optical assemblies of our own design and fabrication. © 1983 SPIE.
Index Keywords: ADVANCED OPTICAL DISK DEMONSTRATION UNIT; DIGITAL DISK BREADBOARD; DIGITAL DISK OPTICS; ENCIRCLED ENERGY FUNCTION; IMAGING LENS DESIGN CONCEPT; OBJECTIVE LENS DESIGN; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: The writing mechanism for discontinuous metal films
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: IBM Thomas J Watson Research Center, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY, 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jipson, V.B., IBM Thomas J Watson Research Center, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY, 10598, United States
Abstract: Discontinuous metal films have been recently proposed as a potential archival optical storage material. This class of materials exhibits a unique writing mechanism that yields relatively low writing energies even when materials with high melting points are used. Here, the physics of this writing mechanism are examined. Transmission electron micrographs of exposed areas clearly indicate that the writing mechanism is laser induced coalescence of the metal particles resulting in a dramatic change in optical properties. It is shown that the observed coalescence mechanism is consistent with a theoretical analysis for the sintering of small particles. Calculations based on this mechanism indicate that writing can occur at temperatures well below the melting point of the bulk material. However, detailed thermal modeling of the writing process coupled with measured threshold energies, indicates that melting almost certainly occurs. Furthermore, experimental results indicate a sharp threshold to the writing process. This is inconsistent with the theory of particle coalescence, but a necessary characteristic for a practical optical storage material. This threshold can be attributed to the necessity of bringing the metal particles into physical contact before coalescence can proceed. © 1983 SPIE.
Index Keywords: ARCHIVAL OPTICAL STORAGE MATERIAL; LOW WRITING ENERGIES; OPTICAL CONTRAST; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE OF WRITING MECHANISM; TRANSMISSION ELECTRON MICROGRAPHS; WRITING THRESHOLD; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Authors: Yoshida T., Ohta T., Sato I., Ohara S.
Title: An optical digital memory using tellurium sub-oxide thin film disc
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Central Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd., 3-15, Yagumo-Nakamachi, Moriguchi, Osaka, 570, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yoshida, T., Central Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd., 3-15, Yagumo-Nakamachi, Moriguchi, Osaka, 570, Japan; Ohta, T., Central Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd., 3-15, Yagumo-Nakamachi, Moriguchi, Osaka, 570, Japan; Sato, I., Central Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd., 3-15, Yagumo-Nakamachi, Moriguchi, Osaka, 570, Japan; Ohara, S., Central Research Laboratories, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. Ltd., 3-15, Yagumo-Nakamachi, Moriguchi, Osaka, 570, Japan
Abstract: A practical optical digital memory using Tellurium sub-oxide [TeOx (x = 1)] thin film disc has been developed for document and digital image storage. In the recording mode, the reflectivity of TeOx thin film recording layer evaporated on a pregrooved PMMA substrate is changed by the absorption of the irradiated thermal energy of focused recording laser beam and the signal is recorded on the disc in the form of a chain of micron-sized flat and non-deformed dots. The optical memory using a laser diode as a light source is capable of storing up to 700 MBytes in user data on one side of a preformatted and pregrooved disc, 200 mm in diameter with an access time below 0.5 seconds. Input NRZ digital data are converted to 4/5 MNRZ code which has less DC component and recorded on the optical disc rotating at 900 rpm. Recording data speed on the disc is 6.8 Mbps and the length of the shortest bits is 0.8 μm The error rate of less than 10-8 has been achieved by the implementation of an error correction scheme with 5.4 % redundancy. © 1983, SPIE.
Index Keywords: OPTICAL DIGITAL MEMORY; SPECTRAL CHARACTERISTICS OF PLAYBACK SIGNAL; TELLURIUM SUB-OXIDE THIN FILM; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Authors: Case W.E., Smith J.L., Eden D.D.
Title: An examination of vanadium dioxide thin film as an erasable/reuseable medium for optical recording
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Research, Vought Corporation, P. 0. Box 225907, Dallas, TX, 75265, United States
Authors with affiliations: Case, W.E., Department of Research, Vought Corporation, P. 0. Box 225907, Dallas, TX, 75265, United States; Smith, J.L., Department of Research, Vought Corporation, P. 0. Box 225907, Dallas, TX, 75265, United States; Eden, D.D., Department of Research, Vought Corporation, P. 0. Box 225907, Dallas, TX, 75265, United States
Abstract: Vanadium dioxide undergoes a thermally induced first order phase change from semiconductor to metal near 67°C. In thin-film form, significant optical contrast can be produced at visible wavelengths on switching from low to high temperature phases. If the film is locally heated (e.g. by means of a laser) so that the temperature is driven above the transition point, the color or reflectance is changed only in that local region. Upon removal of the heat source the temperature returns to equilibrium. The local contrast, however, is either removed (dynamic operation), or stored indefinitely (memory operation) depending on the equilibrium or "bias" temperature. This storage option is possible because the material deposited as a thin film exhibits hysteresis, e., the curve describing the state of the film vs. temperature is double valued in the transition region. In order to erase information from a film region, that region must be lowered in temperature to a level below the onset of hysteresis. The general properties of vanadium dioxide thin film suggest a material suitable for recording optical information in a high density, digital format allowing erasure and reuse. Practical feasibility has been examined at Vought during the past year by a series of performance measurements. For example, laser writing of one micron diameter spots in less than 50 nanoseconds has been accomplished, and the amount of energy required for writing is compatible with laser diodes. These measurement results and data on contrast, storage time, and film surface morphology will be presented. The size of individual crystallites comprising the vanadium dioxide film is expected to fix ultimate spatial resolution. © 1983 SPIE.
Index Keywords: DIELECTRIC SPACERS; GENERIC MULTILAYER CONFIGURATION FOR RECORDING; THERMALLY INDUCED FIRST ORDER PHASE CHANGE; THIN-FILM FORM PROPERTIES; VANADIUM DIOXIDE REFLECTANCE HYSTERESIS LOOP; VIDEO RECORDING

Authors: Reichman B., Chessex P., Verellen G., Putet G., Smith J.M., Heim T., Swyer P.R.
Title: Dietary composition and macronutrient storage in preterm infants
Affiliations: Div. Clin. Nutr., Hosp. Sick Child., Toronto, Ont. M5G 1X8, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Reichman, B., Div. Clin. Nutr., Hosp. Sick Child., Toronto, Ont. M5G 1X8, Canada; Chessex, P., Div. Clin. Nutr., Hosp. Sick Child., Toronto, Ont. M5G 1X8, Canada; Verellen, G., Div. Clin. Nutr., Hosp. Sick Child., Toronto, Ont. M5G 1X8, Canada; Putet, G.; Smith, J.M.; Heim, T.; Swyer, P.R.
Abstract: A comparison has been made of the influence of feeding own mother's milk and formula on the oxidation and accretion of energy and macronutrients in the growing preterm infant of very low birth weight (<1,300 g) by using the combined techniques of nutrient balance and computerized indirect calorimetry. There were 22 studies in formula-fed infants and 15 studies in premature infants fed own mother's milk. Despite their lower metabolizable energy intake, the infants fed own mother's milk grew in weight, length, and head circumference at a rate approximating those of the formula-fed group. The metabolic rate was significantly lower in the infants fed own mother's milk (56.0 ± 0.9 v 62.6 ± 0.8 kcal/kg/d; P < .001). The protein intake, oxidation, and accretion were similar in the two groups. The infants fed own mother's milk had a significantly lower fat intake (P < .001), higher fat oxidation (P < .025) and consequently lower fat accretion (P < .001) than the formula-fed infants. The proportional fat content of the daily weight gain was lower in the infants fed own mother's milk (16% v 33%; P < .001) but protein content was similar (13% v 12%). The accretion of energy, fat, and protein correlated with the respective metabolizable intakes in both groups (r = .81 to .98; P < .001), suggesting that accretion rates and hence composition of weight gain are dependent on levels of energy and macronutrient intake.
Index Keywords: fat; protein; article; breast; breast milk; calorimetry; clinical article; computer analysis; diagnosis; energy; fetus; fetus growth; human; human experiment; infant; metabolism; normal human; normal value; prematurity; weight gain; Animals; Body Weight; Calorimetry, Indirect; Cattle; Dietary Carbohydrates; Dietary Fats; Dietary Proteins; Energy Intake; Energy Metabolism; Food, Formulated; Humans; Infant; Infant, Low Birth Weight; Infant, Newborn; Infant, Premature; Milk; Milk, Human

Abstract: Exclusive production of proton-antiproton pairs by two photon scattering at CM energies between 2.0 GeV and 3.1 GeV has been measured with the TASSO detector at the e+e- storage ring PETRA. The angular distribution is flat within the accepted CM angular range |cos Θ*|≤0.7. The integrated cross section (|cos Θ*|≤0.6) drops from about 4 nb at 2 GeV to less than 0.5 nb above 3 GeV. For the two-photon production of the ηc(2984) and its subsequent decay into proton-antiproton the upper limit Γ(ηc→γγ)·B(ηc→pp)<0.32 keV (95% CL) is found. © 1983.

Authors: Basile M., Bonvicini G., Romeo G.C., Cifarelli L., Contin A., Curatolo M., D'Alí G., Del Papa C., Esposito B., Giusti P., Massam T., Nania R., Palmonari F., Sartorelli G., Susinno G., Votano L., Zichichi A.
Title: The leading effect explains the forward-backward multiplicity correlations in hadronic interactions

Votano, L., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università, Bologna, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Frascati, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Bologna, Italy; Zichichi, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Università, Bologna, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Frascati, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Bologna, Italy
Abstract: The multiplicity correlations between forward and backward hemispheres observed since a long time in (pp) interactions at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings (ISR), are shown to be due to the leading effect. These multiplicity correlations are reproduced following our method of classifying each (pp) interaction in terms of the effective hadronic energy available. It is this energy, and not the long-range correlation, which produces low or high multiplicities in both hemispheres of a (pp) collision. The (log s)-dependence of the correlation strength follows from the energy dependence of the multiplicity. The (log s)-dependence is shown to follow our prediction from FNAL and SPS, to ISR, and up to Collider energies. © 1983 Società Italiana di Fisica.
Author Keywords: Other topics in specific reactions and phenomenology of elementary particles
