Authors: Nikitin S.A., Saldin E.L., Yurkov M.V.
Title: Calculation of the depolarizing effect of the field imperfections in electron-positron storage rings
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk 90, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Nikitin, S.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk 90, Russian Federation; Saldin, E.L., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk 90, Russian Federation; Yurkov, M.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk 90, Russian Federation
Abstract: The radiative kinetics of polarization is calculated for the magnetic structures of the actual storage rings at high [VEPP-4, 5 GeV] and ultra-high [LEP, 50 GeV] energies taking into account the limited accuracy of the mounting of the focusing elements. Methods for the spin-orbital coupling parameter calculation are presented in a form convenient for computing. The possibility of compensating for the influence of the parasitic spin-orbital coupling is also investigated. © 1983.
Index Keywords: CHARGED PARTICLES - Magnetic Field Effects; ACCELERATORS

Title: Laser-induced optical recording in thin films - Modelling of the hole opening and experiments with organic sublayers
Source title: Applied Physics A Solids and Surfaces
Affiliations: Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Broer, D.J., Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Vriens, L., Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: A model is presented to describe the hole opening in ablative optical recording. The model accounts for changes in geometry of the sensitive film, for adhesion of the film to the substrate, for surface tension gradients in the sensitive film and for evaporation or sublimation at the film-substrate interface. The changes in geometry during hole opening are shown to be responsible for an energy barrier Fact=10-16 to 10-15 J, corresponding to 1.5-6J/cm3 which is much too large to make thermal activation of hole opening possible. Fact is reduced by surface tension gradients in the liquid film and/or evaporation at the filmsubstrate interface. The predictions of the model are compared with laser recording experiments performed with Te-alloy films on various polymer sublayers. Experiments and model show that the threshold energy Eth for hole opening (and Fact) can be reduced by (i) lowering the surface tension and/or polarity of the polymer sublayer, (ii) reducing the dynamic work of adhesion, e.g. by decreasing the crosslink density or the mean molecular weight of the sublayer, and (iii) increasing the concentration of low molecular weight material in the sublayer, which reduces the adhesion of the film and stimulates evaporation at the interface. © 1983 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: Maximization of recording density obtainable in te-alloys
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, 5600 JA, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Schouhamer Immink, K.A., Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, 5600 JA, Netherlands; Aarts, R.M., Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, 5600 JA, Netherlands
Abstract: We report on high density recording experiments of digital information in Te alloys on pregrooved discs. The recording and reading of information is done on a recorder fitted with an AlGaAs laser. We describe experiments with modulation systems using pit-length modulation based on runlength-limited codes. Runlength-limited sequences were adopted as a modulator output because of the fact that this class of restricted sequences has a great impact in magnetic and optical recording.State-of-the-art high power solid-state lasers can emit a light pulse of sufficient energy for only a limited time and can therefore only be used in a pulsed mode. Pit-length modulation is achieved by adjusting the rotational velocity of the disc and laser pulse write frequency in such a way that oblong pits of overlapping monoholes result.We demonstrate the feasibility of recording densities of up to 1 Mbit/mm^ with the application of pit-length modulation schemes. Ó 1983 SPIE. © 1983 SPIE.
Index Keywords: HIGH DENSITY OPTICAL RECORDING; INFORMATION DENSITY MAXIMIZATION; LASER RECORDER; PREGROOVED DISKS; RUNLENGTH-LIMITED BINARY SEQUENCES; TELLURIUM ALLOY RECORDING LAYER; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: The stability of thin tellurium and tellurium alloy films for optical data storage: II
Affiliations: IBM Research Laboratory, San Jose, CA 95193, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, W.-Y., IBM Research Laboratory, San Jose, CA 95193, United States
Abstract: The chemical and physical degradation and the effects of the substrate and a low surface energy subbing layer on the stability of thin tellurium and tellurium alloy films for optical data storage are reported. Chemically, thin tellurium films degrade mainly through the uniform oxidation of tellurium to TeO2. In addition, localized degradation occurs at regions where initial defects on the substrate are present. Thin tellurium and tellurium alloy films can also degrade physically through crystal growth for an initially polycrystalline film and phase transformation for an initially amorphous film. While no significant difference in the uniform degradation rate is observed between films deposited onto poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) and those deposited onto glass substrates, more localized degradation is detected for the films deposited onto PMMA substrates because of the higher initial defects of the substrate. The presence of a low surface energy subbing layer tends to degrade both the chemical and physical stability of these films. The degradation in the chemical stability is attributed to the change in the microstructure or thickness of the film due to the presence of the low surface energy subbing layer. © 1983.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL; TELLURIUM

Authors: Mazzeo N.J., Ahn K.Y., Jipson V.B., Lynt H.N.
Title: Fabrication and testing of trilayers with a high deposition rate plasma-polymerized spacer
Affiliations: IBM T.J. Watson Research Center, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mazzeo, N.J., IBM T.J. Watson Research Center, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Ahn, K.Y., IBM T.J. Watson Research Center, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Jipson, V.B., IBM T.J. Watson Research Center, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Lynt, H.N., IBM T.J. Watson Research Center, P.O. Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Abstract: A great deal of effort has recently been directed toward the development of digital optical storage systems using Ga-Al-As lasers for both reading and writing. The relatively low output power of these devices necessitates sensitive optical storage media if reasonable data rates are to be achieved. At the same time, it is desirable that the material exhibit archival properties. One method of reducing the writing energy for a wide variety of materials is to incorporate them within an optical structure that improves the optical efficiency. In particular, trilayer structures consisting of an aluminum layer 30 nm thick, a spacer layer about 100 nm thick and a thin storage layer offer the potential of improved sensitivity for a wide range of active materials, but their use requires the fabrication of a low thermal conductivity optically clear spacer layer approximately one-quarter wave thick. Because of manufacturing considerations, it is desirable that this layer be deposited at relatively high rates in an inexpensive process. Here we describe the investigation of the plasma polymerization of various monomers for this purpose. It has been found that stable films of perfluoro-2-butene can be deposited at rates greater than 1 nm s-1. Trilayer structures using this material as the spacer layer are compared with more conventional materials. © 1983.
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL; PLASMAS; POLYMERIZATION; FILMS

Authors: Stams F.J.M., Veenhuis M., Weenk G.H., Hansen T.A.
Title: Occurrence of polyglucose as a storage polymer in Desulfovibrio species and Desulfobulbus propionicus
Affiliations: Department of Microbiology, University of Groningen, Kerklaan 30, Haren, NL-9751 NN, Netherlands; Department of Electron Microscopy, University of Groningen, Kerklann 30, Haren, NL-9751 NN, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Stams, F.J.M., Department of Microbiology, University of Groningen, Kerklaan 30, Haren, NL-9751 NN, Netherlands; Veenhuis, M., Department of Electron Microscopy, University of Groningen, Kerklann 30, Haren, NL-9751 NN, Netherlands; Weenk, G.H., Department of Microbiology, University of Groningen, Kerklaan 30, Haren, NL-9751 NN, Netherlands; Hansen, T.A., Department of Microbiology, University of Groningen, Kerklaan 30, Haren, NL-9751 NN, Netherlands
Abstract: The occurrence of organic storage compounds in six strains of sulfate-reducing bacteria was investigated. In Desulfovibrio HL21 and Desulfovibrio vulgaris NCIB 8303 accumulation of polyglucose was brought about by limiting the Fe2+ or NH4+concentration in the growth medium. Desulfobulbus propionicus 1pr3 and especially Desulfovibrio gigas NCIB 9332 already synthesized large amounts of polyglucose in normal media, whereas the synthesis of polyglucose in two strains of Desulfovibrio desulfuricans was far less pronounced. Suspensions of Desulfovibrio HL21 cells in media without an energy source and sulfate degraded the polyglucose to acetate, hydrogen and small amounts of ethanol and succinate; Desulfobulbus propionicus formed acetate, propionate and some hydrogen under these conditions. In the presence of sulfate both strains produced acetate and corresponding amounts of sulfide. None of the strains synthesized PHB as a storage polymer. © 1983 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Desulfobulbus propionicus; Desulfovibrio; Polyglucose; Storage compounds; Sulfate-reducing bacteria
Index Keywords: glucose polymer; polysaccharide; desulfovibrio; nonhuman

Title: Validating criticality codes for spent fuel casks
Affiliations: Nuclear Safety Division of the OECD Nuclear Energy Agency, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Kovan, R., Nuclear Safety Division of the OECD Nuclear Energy Agency, Paris, France; Stephens, M., Nuclear Safety Division of the OECD Nuclear Energy Agency, Paris, France
Abstract: As a step toward establishing universally acceptable techniques for spent-fuel cask criticality calculations, the OECD Nuclear Energy Agency devised a set of standard problems which were then solved by fourteen different groups using their own codes and approaches. On the whole, the exercise demonstrated that the Monte Carlo and other methods used to solve the transport equations can give satisfactory results, while methods based on diffusion theory must be used with great care for such calculations.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR FUELS - Standards; Nuclear reactors; radioisotope; container; nonhuman; nuclear power plant; prevention; radioactive waste storage

Authors: Amos N., Block M.M., Bobbink G.J., Botje M., Favart D., Leroy C., Linde F., Lipnik P., Matheys J.-P., Miller D., Potter K., Shukla S., Velde-Wilquet C.V., Zucchelli S.
Title: Comparison of small-angle pp̄ and pp elastic scattering at the CERN intersecting storage rings
Affiliations: Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; State University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Amos, N., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Block, M.M., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Bobbink, G.J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Botje, M., State University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Favart, D., Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Leroy, C., Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Linde, F., State University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Lipnik, P., Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Matheys, J.-P., Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Miller, D., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Potter, K., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Shukla, S., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Velde-Wilquet, C.V., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Zucchelli, S., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States
Abstract: Antiproton-proton and proton-proton small-angle elastic scattering have been measured for centre-of-mass energies √s = 30.7 and 62.5 GeV at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings (ISR). Antiproton-proton and proton-proton total cross sections are obtained using the optical theorem. The measurement of the Coulomb scattering and its interference with the nuclear scattering allows a determination of the ratio of the real-to-imaginary part of the forward nuclear scattering amplitude. Also presented are measurements for the nuclear slope parameter at √s = 62.5 GeV. Our new results reinforce the conclusions drawn recently from our measurements at √s = 52.8 GeV. In particular, the pp̄ total cross section is rising at ISR energies and should continue to rise well beyond these energies. © 1983.

Authors: Musset P., Price M., Lohrmann E.
Title: Search for magnetic monopoles in electron-positron collisions at 34 GeV CM energy
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; II. Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Musset, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Price, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Lohrmann, E., II. Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: A search for heavily ionizing particles was carried out at the electron-positron storage ring PETRA with the help of Kapton detectors placed inside the vacuum pipe. The total integrated luminosity was 90 pb-1 at CM energies above 34 GeV. The search was sensitive to particles with magnetic charge from 1 · 137 2 e to 5 · 137 2 e and with masses up to up to 10-16 GeV/c2. No such particle was found, leading to an upper limit of the production cross section of monopole-antimonopole pairs of 4 × 10-38 cm2 (95% CL). © 1983.

Authors: Giordano N., Cacciola G., Parmaliana A.
Title: CATALYTIC AND REACTION ENGINEERING ASPECTS IN THE STORAGE OF HYDROGEN THROUGH THE REVERSIBLE DEHYDROGENATION OF CYCLOHEXANE.
Affiliations: CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi, e Processi Chimici per la, Transformazione e l'Accumulo, CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi e Processi Chimici per la Transformazione e l'Accumulo dell'En
Authors with affiliations: Giordano, N., CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi, e Processi Chimici per la, Transformazione e l'Accumulo, CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi e Processi Chimici per la Transformazione e l'Accumulo dell'En; Cacciola, G., CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi, e Processi Chimici per la, Transformazione e l'Accumulo, CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi e Processi Chimici per la Transformazione e l'Accumulo dell'En; Parmaliana, A., CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi, e Processi Chimici per la, Transformazione e l'Accumulo, CNR, Istituto di Ricerche sui Metodi e Processi Chimici per la Transformazione e l'Accumulo dell'En
Abstract: Hydrogen as an energy carrier has several advantages, especiallyith regard to its storage and transmission possibilities. Present technology already offers proven ways for handling and storage (cryogenic, pressurized, hydrides, hollow spheres) but lacks suitable means for both storage and long-distance transportation. Reversible catalytic (de)hydrogenation reactions appear a possible solution to this problem. An obvious limitation is complete reversibility, a quality hard to achieve, unless selective catalysts are developed. Work carried out in authors institute has proven the (de) hydrogenation of cyclohexane to be best suited for that purpose and meeting the requirements of full reversibility taking advatnage of newly developed highly selective catalysts developed in this laboratory. Concepts underlying catalytic aspects of this specific catalyst, choice of reactor and process design engineering are outlined for a closed-loop cycle characterized by three phases: hydrogen storage (charge); cyclohexane transportation and release of hydrogen (discharge). Together with process design characteristics, an account is given of the results on catalyst characterization namely on the nature of active sites and the kinetical-diffusional behavior in fixed-bed operations (from micro-reactor experiments). Proven advantages of this novel class of catalysts are emphasized.
Index Keywords: CATALYSTS - Analysis; CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Dehydrogenation; CYCLOHEXANE; HYDROGEN FUELS

Title: On the storage of high-energy protons in the solar corona: The cyclotron instability
Affiliations: Institute of Applied Geophysics, the USSR State Committee for Hydrometeorology and Control of the Natural Environment, 20-B, Glebovskaya ul., Moscow, 107258, Russia
Authors with affiliations: Meerson, B.I., Institute of Applied Geophysics, the USSR State Committee for Hydrometeorology and Control of the Natural Environment, 20-B, Glebovskaya ul., Moscow, 107258, Russia; Rogachevskii, I.V., Institute of Applied Geophysics, the USSR State Committee for Hydrometeorology and Control of the Natural Environment, 20-B, Glebovskaya ul., Moscow, 107258, Russia
Abstract: We consider the problem of long-time storage of high-energy protons, accelerated in the process of a flare, in coronal magnetic traps. From the viewpoint of the storage, one of the most important plasma instabilities is the kinetic cyclotron instability of the Alfvén waves. We carry out a detailed theoretical analysis of the instability for typical conditions of the solar corona. It is the refraction of the Alfvén waves in combination with a drastic decrease of the instability growth rate with an increase of the angle between the directions of the wave vector and the stationary magnetic field that leads to the possibility of the long-term storage of the flare protons. Sufficient conditions of the storage are determined. © 1983 D. Reidel Publishing Co.

Title: Elongational-flow predictions of the Leonov constitutive equation
Affiliations: Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, 07974, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Larson, R.G., Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, 07974, NJ, United States
Abstract: The basic thermodynamic ideas from rubber-elasticity theory which Leonov employed to derive his constitutive model are herein summarized. Predictions of the single-mode version are presented for homogeneous elongational flows including stress growth following start-up of steady flow, stress decay following sudden stretching and following cessation of steady flow, elastic recovery following cessation of steady flow, energy storage in steady-state flow, and the velocity profile in constantforce spinning. Using parameters of the multiple-mode version which fit the linearviscoelastic data, the Leonov-model predictions of elongational stress growth during, and elastic recovery following, steady elongation are calculated numerically and compared to the experimental results for Melt I and to the Wagner model. It is found that the Leonov model, as originally formulated, agrees qualitatively with the data, but not quantitatively; the Wagner model gives quantitative agreement, but requires much nonlinear data with which to fit model parameters. Quantitative agreement can be obtained with the Leonov model, if the nonequilibrium potential which relates recoverable strain to strain rate is adjusted empirically. This can most simply be done by making each relaxation time dependent upon the recoverable strain. The Leonov model, unlike the Wagner model, is derived from an entropic constitutive equation, which is advantageous for calculating stored elastic energy or viscous dissipation. The Leonov model also has an appealingly simple differential form, similar to the upper-convected Maxwell model, which, in numerical calculations, may be an important advantage over the integral Wagner model. © 1983 Steinkopff.
Author Keywords: elongational flow; Leonov constitutive model; Melt I; nonequilibrium potential; Wagner model

Authors: Smart D., Reilly R., Wells B.
Title: Laser Targeting Considerations in Redundant Memory Repair
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Teradyne Inc, 183 Essex Street, Boston, MA, 02111, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smart, D., Teradyne Inc, 183 Essex Street, Boston, MA, 02111, United States; Reilly, R., Teradyne Inc, 183 Essex Street, Boston, MA, 02111, United States; Wells, B., Teradyne Inc, 183 Essex Street, Boston, MA, 02111, United States
Abstract: Selection of alignment targets for memory redundancy repair is a design step that critically affects the yield of the device repair process. Assuming accurate laser beam positioning and energy density control, the ability of the system to reliably identify a reference on each die will result in a high fix-to-attempt ratio on repairable memories. © 1983, SPIE.
Index Keywords: ALIGNMENT TARGET SELECTION; LASER EYE SCHEME; LASER TARGETING; PHOTOREFLECTIVE TECHNIQUE; REDUNDANT MEMORY REPAIR; SITE ALIGNMENT; DATA STORAGE, SEMICONDUCTOR

Title: MIRINE, a mini-nuclear reactor for neutronography—data and applications [Le mini-réacteur pour neutronographie MIRENE—Performances et applications]
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Commissariat à l’Energie Atomique, Centre d’Etudes de Valduc DSN/SEESNC, B.P. 21, 21120, Is/Tille, France
Authors with affiliations: Houelle, M., Commissariat à l’Energie Atomique, Centre d’Etudes de Valduc DSN/SEESNC, B.P. 21, 21120, Is/Tille, France; Gerberon, J.M., Commissariat à l’Energie Atomique, Centre d’Etudes de Valduc DSN/SEESNC, B.P. 21, 21120, Is/Tille, France
Abstract: MIRENE is a MIni nuclear REactor for NEutronography. In the first part of this paper MIRENE is described and its characteristics are given. The core uses only 1 kg of enriched uranium in solution state. It works in a self-limited pulse mode. The neutron pulses are collimated in two beams which cross the concrete pro-tection walls surrounding the reactor. The main characteristics are : • peak power : 161 kW, • exponential rise time : .87 sec, • overall energy in a pulse : 2.9 MJ (6.8 × 1016 fissions), • axial beam : – exposure aera : 30 cm × 30 cm, – useful fluence per pulse : thermal neutrons : 9 × 108 n/cm2 ; γ-rays : 22 rads (Cd ratio on gold detector : 2), • lateral beam : – exposure aera : 18 cm × 24 cm, – useful fluence per pulse : thermal neutrons : 2.6 × 108 n/cm2 ; γ-rays : . 7 rad (Cd ratio : 9). In the second part of the paper, many applications of MIRENE in much different fields are indicated. The results we have obtained since MIRENE started to operate, in 1977, are shown : – In nuclear engineering : • testing of first neutron reactor fuel-pins, • control of “neutrophage screens” used in transport and storage of nuclear-fuel materials to secure the criticity-safety, • observation of irradiated-oxyde samples in order to determine the Equation of State of the fuel used in fast-neutron reactors .observation of UO2–H2O mixing conditions in the field of cri-ticity experiments, – In engineering, MIRENE has a large field of applications, two examples are given : • the control of the sealing of an electric isolator, • the visualization of the bonding layer between two high density metals, – Finally we show an original application in agronomy which has given very good results : the observation of the in-situ-growth of a corn-root. All these results prove that MIRENE as well as similar reactors can bring about an important contribution as Non-Destructive-Testing stools in the most large field of applications. Their simplicity of design and working connected to their intrinsic safety enabled them to have a high competitive performance/cost ratio. Users can take advantage of the own performances of nuclear reactors in neutronography while being relieved of a large part of the constraints associated to large-size ordinary reactor installation. © 1983, SPIE.
Index Keywords: CONCRETE PROTECTION WALLS CROSSING; ENRICHED URANIUM IN SOLUTION STATE; MINI NUCLEAR REACTOR FOR NEUTRONOGRAPHY (MIRENE); NEUTRON PULSES TWO BEAMS COLLIMATION; REACTOR FUEL PIN TESTING; SELF-LIMITED PULSE MODE; RADIOGRAPHY

Title: Electrochemical ways of tapping solar energy: an appraisal
Affiliations: Solid State and Structural Chemistry Unit, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560 012, India
Authors with affiliations: Shukla, A.K., Solid State and Structural Chemistry Unit, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560 012, India; Manoharan, R., Solid State and Structural Chemistry Unit, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560 012, India; Ramesh, K.V., Solid State and Structural Chemistry Unit, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore, 560 012, India
Abstract: In recent years, solar cell technology has advanced significantly and is nearing commercial viability. Practical solar cells that are capable of converting the solar radiation directly into electricity are now available. It is, however, imperative to couple them with appropriate power storage systems. This article is a brief review of the current status of electrochemical power systems such as storage batteries and fuel-electrolysis cell hybrids which could be successfully utilized to this end. © 1983 Indian Academy of Sciences.
Author Keywords: energy storage and conversion; fuel-electrolysis cells; Solar cell-batteries; storage batteries

Title: Suburban-rural energy balance comparisons for Vancouver, B.C.: An extreme case?
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, B.C., Canada; Department of Geography, Queen's University, Kingston, K7L 3N6, Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Oke, T.R., Department of Geography, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, V6T 1W5, B.C., Canada; McCaughey, J.H., Department of Geography, Queen's University, Kingston, K7L 3N6, Ontario, Canada
Abstract: Synchronous observations of the energy balances of a suburban and a rural area in the Vancouver region are used to investigate the impact of urbanization on energy exchange. Net radiation and rural soil heat flux density were directly measured, suburban heat storage was parameterized, and the turbulent heat flux densities were evaluated using the Bowen ratio-energy balance method. Most comparisons were conducted during a period of drying following an unusually wet early summer. These conditions produced atypical but very interesting results. With cloudless skies and high radiant input, suburban-rural differences of both net radiation and evapotranspiration were contrary to previous results and intuition. In both cases, suburban values were greater than their rural counterparts. In most respects the rural site behaved as expected, and the explanation for these findings is thought to be related to advective assistance of evapotranspiration from the suburban area. Under lesser radiant forcing the suburban budget acted in greater conformity with past experience and suburban-rural differences were similarly more in agreement with expectation. © 1983 D. Reidel Publishing Company.

Authors: Bethe H.A., Brown G.E., Cooperstein J., Wilson J.R.
Title: A simplified equation of state near nuclear density
Affiliations: W.K. Kellogg Radiation Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States; Physics Department, State University of New York, Stony Brook, NY 11794, United States; Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bethe, H.A., W.K. Kellogg Radiation Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, United States; Brown, G.E., Physics Department, State University of New York, Stony Brook, NY 11794, United States; Cooperstein, J., Physics Department, State University of New York, Stony Brook, NY 11794, United States; Wilson, J.R., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Abstract: The equation of state near nuclear density influences shock formation in stellar collapse Supernovae. The drop in the adiabatic index below 4 3 in this region, due to the negative nuclear pressure, disturbs the homology of the inner core and decreases its size. The initial shock energy and formation dynamics are particularly sensitive to matter in this regime. Only matter at low entropies (S ≤ 1.5) in the unshocked inner core approaches nuclear densities. We derive a simple equation of state for this material and find that nuclear properties are close to those at S = 0. The entropy associated with the nuclear surface can be absorbed into an "effective mass" which decreases towards one with increasing density, giving an accurate accounting for the storage of entropy in the excitation of the large nuclei. Such thermal excitation drains energy with little contribution to the pressure and thus may have important effects on the launching of the shock. Two phase transitions are considered. The first, from the heavy nucleus to the "bubble" phase, occurs at half nuclear matter density and is accomplished by use of simple expressions for the energy and pressure that include effects of the transition implicitly. The second, that to uniform nuclear matter, is done by requiring continuity of the pressure and entropy at the transition. The density at which this transition takes place is calculated and is found to decrease with entropy in a simple manner. With the use of suitable approximations, the equation of state is presented in a non-iterative form easily adapted for use in full hydrodynamical calculations of the supernovae process. Comparison with more detailed equations of state is made and the simplified one is found to represent well all important features. © 1983.

Authors: Schoutsen B., De Jong J.W., Harmsen E., De Tombe P.P., Achterberg P.W.
Title: Myocardial xanthine oxidase/dehydrogenase
Affiliations: Cardiochemical Laboratory, Thoraxcenter, Erasmus University Rotterdam, Postbus 1738, 3000 DR RotterdamThe, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Schoutsen, B., Cardiochemical Laboratory, Thoraxcenter, Erasmus University Rotterdam, Postbus 1738, 3000 DR RotterdamThe, Netherlands; De Jong, J.W., Cardiochemical Laboratory, Thoraxcenter, Erasmus University Rotterdam, Postbus 1738, 3000 DR RotterdamThe, Netherlands; Harmsen, E., Cardiochemical Laboratory, Thoraxcenter, Erasmus University Rotterdam, Postbus 1738, 3000 DR RotterdamThe, Netherlands; De Tombe, P.P., Cardiochemical Laboratory, Thoraxcenter, Erasmus University Rotterdam, Postbus 1738, 3000 DR RotterdamThe, Netherlands; Achterberg, P.W., Cardiochemical Laboratory, Thoraxcenter, Erasmus University Rotterdam, Postbus 1738, 3000 DR RotterdamThe, Netherlands
Abstract: High-energy phosphates in heart muscle deprived of oxygen are rapidly broken down to purine nucleosides and oxypurines. We studied the role of xanthine oxidase/dehydrogenase (EC 1.2.3.2/EC 1.2.1.37) in this process with novel high-pressure liquid chromatographic techniques. Under various conditions, including ischemia and anoxia, the isolated perfused rat heart released adenosine, inosine and hypoxanthine, and also substantial amounts of xanthine and urate. Allopurinol, an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase, greatly enhanced the release of hypoxanthine. From the purine release we calculated that the rat heart contained about 18 mU xanthine oxidase per g wet weight. Subsequently, we measured a xanthine oxidase activity of 9 mU/g wet wt. in rat-heart homogenate. When endogenous low molecular weight inhibitors were removed by gel filtration, the activity increased to 31 mU/g wet wt. Rat myocardial xanthine oxidase seems to be present mainly in the dehydrogenase form, which upon storage at -20°C is converted to the oxidase form. © 1983.
Author Keywords: (Rat heart); Adenosine catabolism; Anoxia; HPLC; Ischemia; Xanthine dehydrogenase; Xanthine oxidase
Index Keywords: adenosine; xanthine dehydrogenase; xanthine oxidase; animal cell; heart; nonhuman; rat; Animals; Coronary Disease; Coronary Vessels; Heart; Ketone Oxidoreductases; Male; Myocardium; Perfusion; Purine Nucleosides; Purines; Rats; Rats, Inbred Strains; Xanthine Dehydrogenase; Xanthine Oxidase; Animalia

Title: Energy storage in photosynthetic photophosphorylation: Lessons from the physical chemistry of the photographic latent image
Affiliations: Department of Plastics Research, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel; Department of Public Affairs, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Hoffman, A., Department of Plastics Research, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel; Tepper, E.L., Department of Public Affairs, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel
Abstract: Crystalline silver bromide in a gelatin matrix or in the form of a thin septum or membrane can be thermodynamically modified by exposure to light. The high-energy state created, known in the photographic literature as the latent image, enables reactants in contact with the membrane to form products that would otherwise be unfavored thermodynamically. Phenomenologically, the photosynthetic process shows certain similarities to the photographic process, the most obvious of which is that absorption of light by the chloroplast thylakoid membrane drives the reactants in contact with the membrane to form thermodynamically unfavorable products. The precise nature of the high-energy state of the photosynthetic membrane has yet to be clearly delineated. It is suggested here that, in analogy with the photographic state,,where the membrane is considered to host an electrochemically active redox couple, Ag+ Ag0, the membrane protein involved in phosphorylation (H+-ATP synthetase) is the site of an electrochemically active H+ H0 couple, whose thermodynamic state is determined by the number of electrons trapped by mobile protons in the form of stabilized atomic hydrogen, as well as the concentration of protons in the solution in contact with the membrane. The analysis leads to an energy storage mechanism in the thylakoid which is achieved by charging up a hydrogen electrode couple until the energy state of the membrane-protein/reactants system favors the conversion to products. The mechanism is hypothesized to involve a heterogeneous reaction on a metal-like hydrogen-electrode speck (comprising a few atoms of H0) whose size (area) determines the mixed or corrosion system potential. The resultant equations suggest some new experiments and predict their results. © 1983.

Authors: Walter C.W., Pauly J.A., Ausman R.K., Kundsin R.B., Holmes C.J.
Title: Microwave thawing of frozen parenteral solutions
Affiliations: Harvard Med. Sch., Boston, MA 02115, United States
Authors with affiliations: Walter, C.W., Harvard Med. Sch., Boston, MA 02115, United States; Pauly, J.A., Harvard Med. Sch., Boston, MA 02115, United States; Ausman, R.K., Harvard Med. Sch., Boston, MA 02115, United States; Kundsin, R.B.; Holmes, C.J.
Abstract: A commercially available microwave oven modified for use at medication stations throughout hospitals allows timely thawing of frozen parenteral solutions. The inherent problems of safety and uniform heating have been overcome, thus making possible the preparation, storage, and distribution of admixtures on a regional basis and ensuring the integrity of the product. Most parenteral medications are not degraded by microwave energy, and thawing by microwave energy permits timely administration and allows coordination of medication for a series of patients.
Index Keywords: MICROWAVE THAWING; PARENTERAL SOLUTIONS; SOLUTIONS - Freezing; OVENS, INDUSTRIAL; infusion fluid; parenteral solution; clinical article; methodology; microwave cooking; microwave radiation; nonhuman; preliminary communication; thawing; Equipment and Supplies, Hospital; Freezing; Infusions, Parenteral; Microwaves; Preservation, Biological

Title: The technology of the Li/BrCl in SOCl2 inorganic battery system: performance and self-discharge characteristics following long-term storage
Affiliations: Electrochem Industries Inc., 9990 Wehrle Drive, Clarence, 14031, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Krehl, P.W., Electrochem Industries Inc., 9990 Wehrle Drive, Clarence, 14031, New York, United States; Liang, C.C., Electrochem Industries Inc., 9990 Wehrle Drive, Clarence, 14031, New York, United States
Abstract: Investigations were conducted on Li/BrCl in SOCl2 cells to determine both the performance and shelf life characteristics after storage for a period of one year at various temperatures. Room temperature discharge test results indicate that there is little self-discharge in those cells stored at either room temperature or at -40° C. Even when the cells were subjected to elevated storage temperatures, the discharge results show that the cells exhibit a low self-discharge rate. However, cells stored at an elevated temperature do exhibit a decreased rate capability when compared to those results obtained from fresh cells. From the 56 ohm load discharge performance results, the self-discharge rate for cells stored at -40, 24, 50 and 72° C was calculated. Further, the activation energy over the temperature range was found to be 27.6±1.7 kJ. Also, the self-discharge rate was monitored under light load conditions. The results for Li/BrCl in SOCl2 D cells discharged under a current density of 2.38 to 0.016 mA cm-2, show that the operationally induced self-discharge rate reaches a maximum of 4.5 μA cm-2 for cells discharged under a current density of 0.034 mA cm-2 and decreases to 2.9 μA cm-2 as the discharge current density decreases to 0.016 mA cm-2. These data indicate that the self-discharge rate for cells discharged under very light loads may eventually approach that for cells stored under open circuit conditions. © 1983 Chapman and Hall Ltd.
Index Keywords: ELECTROLYTIC CELLS; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Authors: Angelis A.L.S., Basini G., Besch H.-J., Breedon R.E., Camilleri L., Chapin T.J., Cool R.L., Cox P.T., von Gagern C., Grosso-Pilcher C., Hanna D.S., Linnemann J.T., Newman C.B., Nickerson R.B., Phinney N., Pordes S.H., Powell K., Rusack R.W., Segar A.M., Tannenbaum M.J., Yelton J.M.
Title: Observation of jet structure in high transverse energy events at the CERN intersecting storage rings
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom; Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Angelis, A.L.S., Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom; Basini, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Besch, H.-J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Breedon, R.E., Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Camilleri, L., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Chapin, T.J., Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Cool, R.L., Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Cox, P.T., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; von Gagern, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Grosso-Pilcher, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Hanna, D.S., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Linnemann, J.T., Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Newman, C.B., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Nickerson, R.B., Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom; Phinney, N., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom; Pordes, S.H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland, Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Powell, K., Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom; Rusack, R.W., Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Segar, A.M., Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom; Tannenbaum, M.J., Rockefeller University, New York, NY, United States; Yelton, J.M., Oxford University, Oxford, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: The spectrum dN dET0 (ET0 = neutral transverse energy) has been measured with an electromagnetic calorimeter covering 90% of 2π in azimuth. The measurement, performed in pp collisions at s = 62 GeV, covered the ET0 range from 10 to 30 GeV. Evidence is presented that a large fraction of these events are jet-like, the fraction increasing with ET0. © 1983.

Title: On the role of memory effects for dissipation and diffusion in slow collective nuclear motion
Affiliations: Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Cassing, W., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Nörenberg, W., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: The energy dissipation in slow collective nuclear motion is viewed as a combined effect of a diabatic production of particle-hole excitations, leading to a conservative storage of collective energy, and a subsequent equilibration due to residual two-body collisions. The effective equation of motion for the collective degree of freedom turns out to be nonlocal in time due to the large mean free path of the nucleons and allows for a simultaneous description of two different attitudes of nuclear matter. The elastic response of heavy nuclei for "fast" collective motion switches over to pure friction for very slow collective motion. The time development of the fluctuations in the velocities may show oscillations for times comparable to the local equilibration time and hence, is qualitatively different from the classical limit. A first application of the diabatic dynamical approach is made for the quadrupole motion within a diabatic deformed harmonic oscillator basis. © 1983.

Title: Input and storage of benthic detritus in an Alaskan subarctic stream
Affiliations: Institute of Arctic Biology, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, 99701, AK, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cowan, C.A., Institute of Arctic Biology, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, 99701, AK, United States; Oswood, M.W., Institute of Arctic Biology, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, 99701, AK, United States
Abstract: Allochthonous leaf litter input and storage of benthic detritus were measured in Monument Creek, a second-order interior Alaskan stream. Litter input was very low, totaling 62.5 g ash-free dry weight (AFDW). m-2·y-2 in 1980. Peak input coincided with autumnal leaf fall. Benthic detritus storage was similarly low. CPOM (coarse particulate organic matter, > 1 mm) ranged from 2.8 to 28.9 g AFDW·m-2, peaking in mid-September. MPOM (medium particulate organic matter, 250 μm-1 mm) ranged from 3.7 to 10.9 g AFDW·m-2, peaking in May. SPOM (small particulate organic matter, 80-250 μm) ranged from 2.0 to 9.0 g AFDW·m-2 and also peaked in May. Compared to streams in temperate regions, Monument Creek is receiving and storing less energy from the surrounding forest. © 1983 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Parisi J., Huebener R.P., Mühlemeier B.
Title: Switching process between bistable positions of multiquantum flux tubes in a thin-film type I superconductor
Affiliations: Physikalisches Institut II, Universität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Parisi, J., Physikalisches Institut II, Universität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany; Huebener, R.P., Physikalisches Institut II, Universität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany; Mühlemeier, B., Physikalisches Institut II, Universität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany
Abstract: A superconducting memory device based on a bistable vortex position represents an interesting storage medium for future Josephson computers. In order to study the operational mode of such a single-flux quantum memory cell, we use as a model system multiquantum flux tubes in a thin-film type I superconductor (Pb). By employing high-resolution stroboscopic magnetooptical flux detection, we are able to globally visualize both spatial and temporal behavior of rapidly switching individual flux tubes. All experimental results agree reasonably well with theoretical model considerations of the energy balance during the elementary switching process. © 1983 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Index Keywords: SUPERCONDUCTING MATERIALS

Authors: Ehrlich R., Gentile T., Kubota Y., Stone S., Talman R., Wilcke R., Alam M.S., Csorna S., Hicks R.G., Panvini R., Poucher J.
Title: Particle identification by ionization measurements: Description of the CLEO dE dx system
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research

Authors with affiliations: Ehrlich, R., Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Gentile, T., Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Kubota, Y., Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Stone, S., Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Talman, R., Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Wilcke, R., Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Alam, M.S., Department of Physics and Astronomy, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Csorna, S., Department of Physics and Astronomy, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Hicks, R.G., Department of Physics and Astronomy, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Panvini, R., Department of Physics and Astronomy, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States; Poucher, J., Department of Physics and Astronomy, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37235, United States
Abstract: We describe the design, construction and performance of a pressurized proportional chamber system intended to identify particles by means of their energy loss in thin gas samples. The system is part of the CLEO detector at the Cornell Electron-Positron Storage Ring (CESR). © 1983.
Index Keywords: PROPORTIONAL COUNTERS; IONIZATION

Title: Volume and temperature in αp and αα collisions at very high energy
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Faessler, M.A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: Two special runs with a particles in the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings allowed the study of collisions of nuclei at the highest accelerator energies. The data obtained simultaneously by five experiments give an impression of the richness of this novel field. Results for elastic αp and αα scattering, for quasi-elastic interactions of nucleons, for hard scattering of constituents of nucleons, and for inelastic interactions are reported. The relevance of interaction volume and temperature is discussed. The modest increase of complexity of their interactions as compared to pp interactions compensates the small size of 4He nuclei. Collisions of ultrarelativistic light nuclei may thus provide a bridge between the well-explored field of high-energy pp collisions and the unexplored field of high-energy nucleus-nucleus collisions. © 1983.

Title: Hierarchies of irreversible energy conversion systems: A network thermodynamic approach. I. Linear steady state without storage
Affiliations: 23 Raydon Road, York, ME 03909, United States
Authors with affiliations: Peusner, L., 23 Raydon Road, York, ME 03909, United States
Abstract: Simple techniques of network thermodynamics are used to introduce new energy coupling parameter, Q, which serves as a measure of efficiency and stability in physical and biological energy conversion systems. Moreover, this parameter unifies various phenomenological equations, including hybrid descriptions. This is the first of three papers introducing ideas which generalize pioneering work of Kedem & Caplan (1965) and Caplan (1968) to the range of oscillatory, non-linear, non-reciprocal, energy storing phenomena. The Q parameter will be shown to reduce to simpler forms as the systems considered vary from the most general unstable forms to the simplest reversible versions; in particular, it leads to the familiar results of Onsager thermodynamics in the case of reciprocal systems. In addition to the powerful abstract results, these techniques relate thermodynamic energy conversion to a common engineering formalism, thus making available an armanentarium of graphical techniques and computer programs which should have wide applicability to biological systems. © 1983.

Title: Time resolved spectroscopy using synchrotron radiation
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Science and Engineering Research Council, Daresbury Laboratory, Daresbury, Warrington, WA4 4AD England, United Kingdom; Institut für Atom- und Festkörperphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimalle 14, 1 Berlin 33, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Munro, I.H., Science and Engineering Research Council, Daresbury Laboratory, Daresbury, Warrington, WA4 4AD England, United Kingdom; Schwentner, N., Institut für Atom- und Festkörperphysik, Freie Universität Berlin, Arnimalle 14, 1 Berlin 33, Germany
Abstract: Measurements have been carried out in the time domain by groups in Orsay, Stanford and Hamburg and the scientific significance of such experiments using synchrotron radiation has been considered in recent review articles [1-7]. At present, time resolved excitation and emission studies can be carried out routinely with a resolution of at least 1 ns, and measurements have been made on the fluorescence decay of individual vibronic levels of small molecules, on emission from low quantum yield vapours (∼10-4) at low pressure (∼1 Torr) and on quenching mechanisms in rigid matrices. Pure rare gas solids and mixtures have been studied extensively in an attempt to understand the kinetic processes associated with exciton formation. Also, for the first time, quantum coherence effects have been seen in rare gases. Using polarised light for excitation, orientated atomic states can be produced by photoselection and periodic fluorescence modulation can then be seen in the presence of an external applied field. The data give information about lifetimes, spins, multipolarities and "g" factors - even when the substates are unresolved in energy. Photoselection of an individual residue within a protein with pulsed, polarised light can, and has, led to an understanding of the microenvironment within the large molecule and has enabled initial estimates to be made of the flexibility of such large structures as well as of their overall size and shape. The best time resolution obtained so far using standard photon counting techniques is about ±50 ps and has been limited by the time response of the photodetector used. The narrow pulse width and the associated broad frequency spectrum (extending beyond 1 GHz) from storage ring sources has led to the study of phase shift and modulation techniques at a number of different frequencies. Preliminary results have revealed that in the frequency domain times of the order of a few ps can be measured. It is highly probable that, in the future, time domain measurements will be improved to give a resolution of about 1 ps and will be extended to include excitation over an extensive range of wavelengths in the VUV and X-ray regions. In this paper, a description of the actual time modulation of synchrotron radiation is followed by a comparison between several subnanosecond timing techniques which have been used at synchrotron radiation sources. The broad range of possible applications of these methods is illustrated by some slected examples. Finally a discussion is included on the prospects for reducing the bunch length into the picosecond region in future storage rings. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Storage Rings; Spectroscopy

Title: The Hefei Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (HESYRL): An 800 MeV electron storage ring and its synchrotron radiation experiment area
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhong-mou, B., University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China; Zhong-ling, X., University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei, China
Abstract: A group of physicists and engineers at the University of Science and Technology of China (USTC), to which we belong, is now planning a synchrotron radiation facility. The project has recently been authorized by the Chinese Academy of Science and is going to be put in to construction at Hefei, an East-China city, in a few months. The facility will be an intermediate-energy electron accelerator dedicated to synchrotron radiation research. It will be operated by a newly-established laboratory, to be called the Hefei Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, or HESYRL for short, and guided by the USTC. This is the first serious effort made by Chinese scientists to join the world in this flourishing and fruitful research field. © 1983.
Index Keywords: RESEARCH LABORATORIES - China; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Title: An instrument with very high energy resolution in X-ray scattering
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Institut Max Von Laue-Paul Langevin, 156 X, 38042 Grenoble Cédex, France; Sektion Physik der Universität München, D-8000 München 22, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dorner, B., Institut Max Von Laue-Paul Langevin, 156 X, 38042 Grenoble Cédex, France; Peisl, H., Sektion Physik der Universität München, D-8000 München 22, Germany
Abstract: The high intensity of X-rays emitted by synchrotons or storage rings provides the possibility of performing inelastic X-ray scattering with an energy resolution ΔE <10 meV (relative resolution ≈5 × 10-17). An instrument with nearly backscattering from perfect Si-crystals at monochromator and analyser is described. Focussing in space increases the transmitted intensity. Aspects which influence the resolution are discussed in detail. An energy scan at constant momentum transfer leaves all mechanical parts at rest and is performed by a variation of the temperature difference between monochromator and analyser crystals. The complementary to inelastic neutron scattering is outlined. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Beam Dynamics; Monochromators; X-rays

Title: Design considerations for an X-ray microprobe
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: NSLS Division, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Howells, M.R., NSLS Division, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, United States; Hastings, J.B., NSLS Division, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, United States
Abstract: The optical design of a fluorescent microprobe covering the X-ray region from 2 to 16 keV is considered for the NSLS X-ray ring. The limit on detectability is from total (photons/μm2) and several design choices are considered to match the optical system to the storage ring to maximize throughput. The tradeoffs in image quality and energy resolution of these designs have been considered and within these constraints two firm proposals are presented. © 1983.
Index Keywords: OPTICAL DEVICES - Design; MICROPROBES; Microscopes

Authors: Namioka T., Noda H., Goto K., Katayama T.
Title: Design studies of mirror-grating systems for use with an electron storage ring source at the photon factory
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Research Institute for Scientific Measurements, Tohoku University, Katahira, Sendai, 980, Japan; Institute of Applied Physics, University of Tsukuba, Sakura, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Department of Precision Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Shinshu University, Wakasato, Nagano, 380, Japan; Department of Mathematics and Physics, Defense Academy, Hashirimizu, Yokosuka, 239, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Namioka, T., Research Institute for Scientific Measurements, Tohoku University, Katahira, Sendai, 980, Japan; Noda, H., Institute of Applied Physics, University of Tsukuba, Sakura, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Goto, K., Department of Precision Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Shinshu University, Wakasato, Nagano, 380, Japan; Katayama, T., Department of Mathematics and Physics, Defense Academy, Hashirimizu, Yokosuka, 239, Japan
Abstract: The design method developed during the course of designing several grating instruments for use with a 2.5-GeV electron storage ring at the Photon Factory of the National Laboratory for High Energy Physics is described. The method is shown to be quite effective in designing complete optical trains which are tailored to maximize throughputs and resolution and to minimize aberrations, interference by unwanted wavelenghts and/or specific site-imposed constraints over limited wavelength ranges. The results obtained with this design method are given for the cases of 6.65-m off-plane Eagle type spectrograph/monochromator under construction and a planned 10-m grazing incidence monochromator. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Storage Rings; Mirrors; Monochromators

Title: X-ray microscopy
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: University of Göttingen, Geismarlandstr. 11, D-3400 Göttingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schmahl, G., University of Göttingen, Geismarlandstr. 11, D-3400 Göttingen, Germany
Abstract: X-ray photons in the wavelength range of about 1-10 nm are best suited for imaging and scanning X-ray microscopy. In this wavelength range the atomic cross sections are not considerably smaller than those for electrons in the energy range in which electron microscopy is performed. The absorption cross sections for soft X-rays are appropriate for the investigation of unstained and undried biological specimens, e.g. cell organelles or whole cells with high resolution. The attenuation of soft X-rays is dominated by photoelectric absorption leading to an absence of multiple scattering in the specimens. Microscopy with soft X-rays requires intense X-ray sources as well as high resolution X-ray lenses. Intense X-radiation is provided by the synchrotron radiation of electron storage rings whereas the most important parameter is the average spectral brilliance. In this paper the following topics will be discussed:. The development of high resolution X-ray optical elements, as zone plates and multilayered normal incidence mirrors, the development of imaging and scanning X-ray microscopes and the influence of the spectral brilliance of storage rings on the progress of X-ray microscopy. © 1983.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Synchrotron; Imaging techniques; Microscopes

Authors: Parr A.C., Southworth S.H., Dehmer J.L., Holland D.M.P.
Title: Photoelectron spectrometer for high resolution angular resolved studies
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Synchrotron Ultraviolet Radiation Facility, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States; Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Institute of Physical Science and Technology, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Authors with affiliations: Parr, A.C., Synchrotron Ultraviolet Radiation Facility, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States; Southworth, S.H., Synchrotron Ultraviolet Radiation Facility, National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States; Dehmer, J.L., Argonne National Laboratory, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Holland, D.M.P., Institute of Physical Science and Technology, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Abstract: We report on a new electron spectrometer system designed for use on storage ring light sources. The system features a large (76 cm diameter ×92 cm long) triply magnetically shielded vacuum chamber and two 10.2 cm mean radius hemispherical electron energy analyzers. One of the analyzers is fixed and the other is rotatable through about 150°. The chamber is pumped by a cryopump and a turbomolecular pump combination so as to enable experiments with a variety of gases under different conditions. The light detection includes both a direct beam monitor and polarization analyzer. The electron detection is accomplished with either a continuous channel electron multiplier or with multichannel arrays used as area detectors. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Storage Rings; Spectrometers

Title: Optimisation of a synchrotron radiation source
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Science and Engineering Research Council, Daresbury Laboratory, Daresbury, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, D.J., Science and Engineering Research Council, Daresbury Laboratory, Daresbury, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom
Abstract: In 1978 the European Science Foundation set up an ad hoc Committee on Synchrotron Radiation and since then the Committee's two sub-groups (Machine and Instrumentation) have been developing the idea of an optimised X-ray synchrotron radiation source for Europe. The properties of different types of source element (bending magnet or special insertion) have been analysed and a storage ring lattice developed which accomodates the requisite number of each. The resulting "Pluralistic Synchrotron Radiation Facility" is described and mention is made of a number of other important features of such a machine. © 1983.
Index Keywords: PHYSICS - High Energy; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Fedotov M.G., Kuper E.A., Litvinenko V.N., Panchenko V.E., Ushakov V.A.
Title: Measurement of the parameters of a linear CCD structure as a one-dimensional X-ray imaging detector
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk 90, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Fedotov, M.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk 90, Russian Federation; Kuper, E.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk 90, Russian Federation; Litvinenko, V.N., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk 90, Russian Federation; Panchenko, V.E., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk 90, Russian Federation; Ushakov, V.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk 90, Russian Federation
Abstract: The basic parameters of linear charge-coupled devices (CCD) as one-dimensional X-ray imaging detectors are measured in the 5.4-19.6 keV photon energy range. Within this range, the sensitivity-wavelength dependence is obtained. At the maximum of this dependence, the threshold flux density of photons for such a device attains 3×106 cm-2 s-1 for a storage time of ∼ 150 ms. This is equivalent to the incidence of single photons on a CCD cell with dimensions of 15 υm×15 υm during a storage time which varies from 120 μs-30 s. Within the photon energy range mentioned above, the sensitivity varies from 0.3 to 3 mV·photon-1·cell. The linearity of the dependence of signal amplitude on flux density of photons remains up to 7 × 108 cm-2 s-1 Any dependence of the sensitivity on the flux density of photons is not revealed. The spatial resolution is better than 100 μm and must be measured with micron accuracies. In addition to the photosensitive region, the shift register one is successfully tried. The ways of improving the CCD parameters for registration of X-rays are discussed. © 1983.
Index Keywords: Imaging techniques; X-RAYS - Measurements; X-ray apparatus

Authors: Makarov O.A., Sinyukov M.P., Gluskin E.S., Zakharov V.M.
Title: A station for studying solid state spectra using synchrotron radiation at the VEPP-2M storage ring
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Institute of Semiconductor Physics, the USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Institute of Nuclear Physics, the USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
