Abstract: An experimental station for reflection, transmission and luminescence experiments on solid samples in the photon energy range 3 to 40 eV is described. This allows data to be collected in a computer-controlled automatic mode. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Storage Rings; Monochromators; Solids

Authors: Wilcke H., Böhmer W., Haensel R., Schwentner N.
Title: High flux and high resolution VUV beam line for luminescence spectroscopy
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Kiel, D-2300 Kiel, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wilcke, H., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Kiel, D-2300 Kiel, Germany; Böhmer, W., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Kiel, D-2300 Kiel, Germany; Haensel, R., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Kiel, D-2300 Kiel, Germany; Schwentner, N., Institut für Experimentalphysik, Universität Kiel, D-2300 Kiel, Germany
Abstract: A high intensity and high resolution vacuum ultraviolet beam line for the wavelength range from 30 nm to 300 nm has been installed at the synchrotron radiation laboratory at the storage ring DORIS (HASYLAB). Sample chambers for luminescence spectroscopy on gaseous, liquid and solid samples and for photoelectron spectroscopy have been integrated. The light flux at the sample reaches 7×1012 photons·nm-1·s-1 at 8 eV photon energy for a current of 100 mA in the storage ring. A resolution of 0.007 nm has been obtained. © 1983.
Index Keywords: Luminescence; Spectroscopy; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Bruhn R., Schmidt E., Schröder H., Sonntag B., Thevenon A., Passereau G., Flamand J.
Title: An experimental station for photoelectron spectroscopy of atoms and molecules in the VUV
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: DESY, Hamburg, Germany; II. Institut für Experimentalphysik der Universität Hamburg, Germany; Jobin-Yvon, Division d'Instruments S.A., Longjumeau, France
Authors with affiliations: Bruhn, R., DESY, Hamburg, Germany; Schmidt, E., II. Institut für Experimentalphysik der Universität Hamburg, Germany; Schröder, H., II. Institut für Experimentalphysik der Universität Hamburg, Germany; Sonntag, B., II. Institut für Experimentalphysik der Universität Hamburg, Germany; Thevenon, A., Jobin-Yvon, Division d'Instruments S.A., Longjumeau, France; Passereau, G., Jobin-Yvon, Division d'Instruments S.A., Longjumeau, France; Flamand, J., Jobin-Yvon, Division d'Instruments S.A., Longjumeau, France
Abstract: We describe a new synchrotron radiation beam line from the DORIS storage ring to be used for atomic and molecular photoelectron spectroscopy in the proton energy range 30-250 eV. It is built around a 5.65 m total arm-length toroidal grating monochramator utilizing three interchangeable holographic gratings. The photon flux, resolution, higher-order contributions, and polarization are reported as determined by test measurements and in the course of atomic photoemission studies at the experimental station. © 1983.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Synchrotron; Photoemission; Spectroscopy

Authors: Hsieh H., Krinsky S., Luccio A., Pellegrini C., Van Steenbergen A.
Title: Wiggler, undulator and free electron laser radiation sources development at the national synchrotron light source
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hsieh, H., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Krinsky, S., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Luccio, A., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Pellegrini, C., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States; Van Steenbergen, A., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973, United States
Abstract: An overview is presented of the special radiation sources development at the NSLS for incorporation in a 2.5 GeV X-ray storage ring and a 700 MeV VUV storage ring. This includes a superconducting high field multipole wiggler, λc = 0.5 A ̊; a permanent magnet wiggler, λc = 2.0 A ̊; a maximum photon energy undulator (5-7 keV); an undulator for a soft X-ray line or "continuum" spectrum and a free electron laser source tunable in the 2500-4500 Å region. Source characteristics and status of development are given. In addition, the incorporation of a backscattered Compton photon source is being studied and relevant parameters are presented. © 1983.
Index Keywords: PHOTONS - Sources; RADIATION SOURCES; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Bilderback D.H., Lairson B.M., Barbee Jr. T.W., Ice G.E., Sparks Jr. C.J.
Title: Design of doubly focusing, tunable (5-30 keV), wide bandpass optics made from layered synthetic microstructures
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source and the School of Applied and Engineering Physics, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Metals and Ceramics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bilderback, D.H., Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source and the School of Applied and Engineering Physics, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Lairson, B.M., Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source and the School of Applied and Engineering Physics, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Barbee Jr., T.W., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Ice, G.E., Metals and Ceramics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States; Sparks Jr., C.J., Metals and Ceramics Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37830, United States
Abstract: Layered Synthetic Microstructures (LSMs) show great promise as focusing, high-throughput, hard X-ray monochromators. Experimental reflectivity vs. energy curves have been obtained on carbon-tungsten and carbon-molybdenum LSMs of up to 260 layers in thickness. Reflectivities for three flat LSMs with different bandppasses were 70% with ΔE E = 5.4%, 66% with ΔE E = 1.4%, and 19% with ΔE E = 0.6%. A new generation of variable bandwidth optics using two successive LSMs is proposed. The first element will be an LSM deposited on a substrate that can be water cooled as it intercepts direct radiation from a storage ring. It can be bent for vertical focusing. The bandpass can be adjusted by choosing interchangeable first elements from an assortment of LSMs with different bandpasses (for example, ΔE E = 0.005, 0.01, 0.02, 0.05, 0.1). The second LSM will consist of a multilayered structure with a 10% bandpass built onto a flexible substrate that can be bent for sagittal focusing. The result will be double focusing optics with an adjustable energy bandpass that are tunable from 5 to 30 keV. © 1983.
Index Keywords: Optics; Monochromators

Authors: Flank A.M., Fontaine A., Jucha A., Lemonnier M., Raoux D., Williams C.
Title: EXAFS in dispersive mode
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: LURE (CNRS), Bât 209C, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Flank, A.M., LURE (CNRS), Bât 209C, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Fontaine, A., LURE (CNRS), Bât 209C, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Jucha, A., LURE (CNRS), Bât 209C, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Lemonnier, M., LURE (CNRS), Bât 209C, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Raoux, D., LURE (CNRS), Bât 209C, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Williams, C., LURE (CNRS), Bât 209C, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Abstract: The new method of collecting EXAFS data in dispersive mode will be recalled. Polychromatic radiation is used so that data over the entire EXAFS spectrum can be recorded simultaneously. The improved efficiency in data collection opens up the possibility of kinetic studies in material science, chemistry and biophysics. The first data obtained with a self-scanned photodiode array manufactured by EG&G Reticon (RC 256 EC/17) working at room temperature show that XANES study at a few ms time-scale can be expected since only 1.3 ms were required to collect the XANES plot of elemental Ni, the D.C.I. storage ring running at a 1.72 GeV, 250 mA positron energy and current. © 1983.
Index Keywords: Spectrum analysis; X-rays

Authors: Friesel D.L., Flanders B.S., Pehl R.H.
Title: A variable geometry high-purity germanium detector telescope system for use with intermediate energy charged particles
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Milo B. Sampson Lane, Bloomington, IN 47401, United States; University of California, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Friesel, D.L., Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Milo B. Sampson Lane, Bloomington, IN 47401, United States; Flanders, B.S., Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Milo B. Sampson Lane, Bloomington, IN 47401, United States; Pehl, R.H., University of California, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: A versatile variable geometry detector telescope system consisting of silicon surface barrier and high-purity germanium planar detector has been developed and used at intermediate light ion energies at IUCF for several years. Detailed descriptions of the telescope system and its operational properties are given. The practical experiences of using detectors fabricated from both n- and p-type high-purity germanium for a variety of particles and energies are described along with details of the effects of long-term storage, radiation damage, and radiation damage annealing procedures on detector properties. Diffusion of the Li n+ contact after many radiation damage and anneal cycles is also discussed. © 1983.
Index Keywords: CHARGED PARTICLES - Measurements; RADIATION DAMAGE; RADIATION DETECTORS

Authors: Blum E.B., Siemann R.H., Auston D.H., Freeman R.R., Smith P., Mills D.M.
Title: Bunch length measurements in CESR using an X-ray sensitive photoconducting detector
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source (CHESS) and School of Applied and Engineering Physics, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blum, E.B., Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Siemann, R.H., Laboratory of Nuclear Studies, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States; Auston, D.H., Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Freeman, R.R., Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Smith, P., Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Mills, D.M., Cornell High Energy Synchrotron Source (CHESS) and School of Applied and Engineering Physics, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, United States
Abstract: A novel photoconducting detector has been used for bunch length measurements in CESR. The detector and measurements are described in detail. At 5.17 GeV beam energy no bunch lengthening was observed for beam currents up to 26.0 mA (4.2sx1011 electrons) in a single bunch. These results agree well with bunch lengthening calculations. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; RADIATION DETECTORS

Authors: Premaratne K., Dietz E.R., Henke B.L.
Title: The stability of cesium iodide X-ray photocathodes
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods In Physics Research
Affiliations: University of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States
Authors with affiliations: Premaratne, K., University of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States; Dietz, E.R., University of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States; Henke, B.L., University of Hawaii, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States
Abstract: For pulsed X-ray measurements as applied, for example, in high temperature plasma diagnostics, it has been established that the cesium iodide photocathode is very efficient for X-ray diode and streak camera applications. Its quantum yield (electrons/incident photon) is ten to one-hundred times higher than that for the gold photocathode in the 100-10 000 eV region. The width of its secondary electron energy distribution is appreciably less than that for gold, allowing time resolved, streak camera measurements to be extended into the picosecond region. In this note an experimental study is described which demonstrates that the cesium iodide photocathode quantum yield and secondary electron energy distribution can be stable under practical conditions of preparation, handling, storage and short period exposures to the atmosphere. © 1983.
Index Keywords: CESIUM COMPOUNDS; X-RAYS - Measurements; PHOTOCATHODES

Title: Information management data base for fusion target fabrication processes
Source title: Journal of Vacuum Science and Technology A: Vacuum, Surfaces and Films
Affiliations: Laboratory for Laser Energetics, University of Rochester, Rochester, New York 14623, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reynolds, J., Laboratory for Laser Energetics, University of Rochester, Rochester, New York 14623, United States
Abstract: A computer-based data management system has been developed to handle data associated with target fabrication processes including glass microballoon characterization, gas filling, materials coating, and storage locations. The system provides automatic data storage and computation, flexible data entry procedures, fast access, automated report generation, and secure data transfer. It resides on a CDC CYBER 175 computer and is compatible with the CDC data base language Query Update, but is based on custom fortran software interacting directly with the CYBER's file management system. The described data base maintains detailed, accurate, and readily available records of fusion targets information. © 1983, American Vacuum Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR ENERGY - Fusion Reactions; DATABASE SYSTEMS

Authors: Kan J.R., Akasofu S.-I., Lee L.C.
Title: A dynamo theory of solar flares
Affiliations: Geophysical Institute, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, Fairbanks, 99701, Alaska, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kan, J.R., Geophysical Institute, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, Fairbanks, 99701, Alaska, United States; Akasofu, S.-I., Geophysical Institute, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, Fairbanks, 99701, Alaska, United States; Lee, L.C., Geophysical Institute, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, Fairbanks, 99701, Alaska, United States
Abstract: It is proposed that the solar flare phenomenon can be understood as a manifestation of the electrodynamic coupling process of the photosphere-chromosphere-corona system as a whole. The system is coupled by electric currents, flowing along (both upward and downward) and across the magnetic field lines, powered by the dynamo process driven by the neutral wind in the photosphere and the lower chromosphere. A self-consistent formulation of the proposed coupling system is given. It is shown in particular that the coupling system can generate and dissipate the power of 1029 erg s#X2212;1 and the total energy of 1032 erg during a typical life time (103 s) of solar flares. The energy consumptions include Joule heat production, acceleration of current-carrying particles along field lines, magnetic energy storage and kinetic energy of plasma convection. The particle acceleration arises from the development of field-aligned potential drops of 10-150 kV due to the loss-cone constriction effect along the upward field-aligned currents, causing optical, X-ray and radio emissions. The total number of precipitating electrons during a flare is shown to be of order 1037-1038. © 1983 D. Reidel Publishing Co.

Title: Nuclear pumped O2(1Δ)-I2 laser
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: University of Illinois, 103 South Goodwin, Urbana, IL, 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miley, G.H., University of Illinois, 103 South Goodwin, Urbana, IL, 61801, United States; Zediker, M.S., University of Illinois, 103 South Goodwin, Urbana, IL, 61801, United States
Abstract: Neutrons from a pulsed Training Research Isotope Products General Atomics (TRIGA) research reactor are used to create nuclear reactions in a boron coating on the wall of an irradia-tiJn chamber that surrounds flowing oxygen. This generates high-energy ions that interact with the oxygen, producing the long-lived metastable, O2(1Δ). Current experiments use 1 to 5 Torr of O2 in 100 to 200 Torr of Ar carrier gas. The 1.27-μm emission from O2(1Δ) is monitored 8 meters from the excitation region and nearly 1 second after the reactor pulse (-10 msec wide). Results to date indicate O2(1Δ)/O2(3Σ) fractions obtained are well above the 17% required to invert iodine in a flowing transfer laser. The O2(1Δ)-I2 laser is of particular interest as a candidate driver for an inertial confinement fusion reactor. Since energy coupling between the pellet and driver occurs directly through neutrons, rela-tively high system efficiencies appear possible. Further, the long-lived O2(1Δ) state provides the energy storage time (fractions of a second) needed between pellet implosions. © 1983 SPIE.
Index Keywords: FLOWING TRANSFER LASER; GENERATION OF HIGH-ENERGY IONS; NUCLEAR PUMPING EXPERIMENTS; NUCLEAR REACTIONS IN BORON COATING; TIME DEPENDENT BEHAVIOR OF SPECIES; TRIGA REACTOR; LASERS, GAS

Woody, C., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY, United States, Queen Mary College, London, United Kingdom
Abstract: The differential cross section for production of jets in pp interactions at y = 0 and pT from 6-12 GeV/c has been measured at √s = 45 GeV at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings and compared with a previous measurement at √s = 63 GeV. The data were obtained using a 2.1 sr hadron calorimeter which was triggered on transverse energy. The energy dependence of the jet cross section is well described by (1-xT)mpT-n, with m = 10.6±1.0 and n = 5.3±0.2. The results are in good agreement with predictions obtained from a QCD-motivated model. © 1983.

Authors: Peatman W., Wolf F.-P., Unwin R.
Title: Threshold electron photoionisation study of D2: Vibration-rotation states of D+2(X2Σ+g
Affiliations: Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung mbH (BESSY)., D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany; Fritz-Haber-Institut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, D-1000 Berlin 33, Germany

Abstract: The measurement of the rotational energy levels of ordinary D+2 (X2Σ2g) for υ′ = 0-12 using threshold electron photo-ionisation spectroscopy at the BESSY storage ring is reported. The molecular constants ωe, ωeχe, ωeνe, Be, αe, γe, re and the ionisation potential (IP) are presented along with their respective standard deviations (measurement scatter). Values from the literature, theoretical and experimental, are reprinted here for comparison purposes. © 1983.

Title: A new tuneable and pulsed vacuum-ultraviolet and X-ray line source
Affiliations: Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Institut für Kernphysik, Karlsruhe, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Poth, H., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Institut für Kernphysik, Karlsruhe, Germany; Wolf, A., Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe, Institut für Kernphysik, Karlsruhe, Germany
Abstract: It is proposed to use the radiation emitted in electron capture by ions occurring in electron cooling of stored stable particle beams as a tuneable photon source for vacuum-ultraviolet (VUV) and X-ray spectroscopy. By choosing a suitable ion beam and storage energy, photon energies from the VUV to the X-ray region can be obtained. The photon line width can be made smaller than 0.2 eV and its energy can be turned in steps smaller than 10-4. The photon source can be continuous or pulsed with pulse duration of 100 ns and less and repetition rates of 1 MHz and more. With present electron cooling systems and storage-ring configurations, about 108-1012 photons can be produced into a 4π solid angle. The corresponding intensities for observation in a solid angle of 1 msr range from 104 in the VUV to more than 108 in the X-ray region. © 1983.

Title: Observational study on thermal flow and condensation of injecting steam from various submerged orifices
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: University of Tokyo, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Tokyo, 113, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kamei, S., University of Tokyo, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Tokyo, 113, Japan; Hirata, M., University of Tokyo, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Tokyo, 113, Japan
Abstract: It has been recognized that the steam accumulator plays an important role as one of thermal energy storage system and was used at hospitals, hotels and food factories in recent years. Experiments have been carried out to investigate direct contact condensation of saturated steam into a quiescent subcooled water environment. They were performed for subcooling from 20 - 70°C, for atmospheric pressure, and for various type of orifice (single-orifice, multi-orifice and porous-disc-orifice). The phenomena were observed by means of high speed shadowgraphy using a rotating prism camera. The phenomena were also visualized by techniques of liquid crystal using a still camera. The effect of bulk temperature in a water tank and the difference among a single-orifice, a multi-orifice and porous-disc-orifice were discussed and good predictive results for the visualization of thermal flow in a quiescent subcooled water environment were obtained. © 1983 SPIE.
Index Keywords: CONDENSATION; HIGH-SPEED SHADOWGRAPHY; STEAM ACCUMULATOR; STEAM INJECTION; SUBMERGED ORIFICES; THERMAL FLOW; PHOTOGRAPHY, HIGH SPEED

Title: Adaptation to overeating in lean and overweight men and women.
Authors with affiliations: Webb, P.; Annis, J.F.
Abstract: In groups of four, men and women in their 40s and 50s, some of them lean and some overweight, overate for 30 d by 1000 kcal/d (4186 kJ/d) more than they needed to maintain weight. On an average dietary mixture for Americans they gained a mean of 2.68 kg, and on a diet high in carbohydrate (60 per cent of energy) they gained 2.73 kg. However, on a diet high in protein and fat (70 per cent of energy), they gained significantly less, 1.75 kg. On all three diets the subjects should have gained 5 kg, if adipose tissue has an energy density of 6 kcal/g, and had there been no adaptation. There was adaptation, as evidenced by an average 7 per cent increase in thermogenesis, which was measured by 24-h direct and indirect calorimetry. Energy balances were calculated from: bomb calorimeter values for food and body waste; change in fuel stores from body composition measured by densitometry; and daily expenditure estimated from the net food intake needed to maintain body weight during a 30-d control period. During overeating, energy intake matched energy losses (including fuel storage) for the average diet and the high-carbohydrate diet, but on the diet high in protein and fat energy intake exceeded losses by more than 500 kcal/d (2093 kJ/d). Thus smaller than expected weight gains from overeating (luxuskonsumption) were largely explained by increased thermogenesis, except when the diet was high in protein and fat. Lean and overweight subjects did not differ in weight gain, loss of energy in urine and faeces, or thermogenesis from overeating.
Index Keywords: adaptation; adult; article; body constitution; body weight; caloric intake; calorimetry; carbohydrate diet; comparative study; diet; eating disorder; energy metabolism; fat intake; female; human; hyperphagia; male; metabolism; obesity; protein intake; Adaptation, Physiological; Adult; Body Constitution; Calorimetry; Comparative Study; Diet; Dietary Carbohydrates; Dietary Fats; Dietary Proteins; Eating Disorders; Energy Intake; Energy Metabolism; Female; Human; Hyperphagia; Male; Middle Age; Obesity; Support, U.S. Gov't, Non-P.H.S.; Thinness

Authors: Carling R.W., Bradshaw R.W., Mar R.W.
Title: Protective coatings for alloys in contact with molten drawsalt (NaNO3-KNO3)
Source title: Journal of Materials for Energy Systems
Affiliations: Exploratory Chemistry Division I, Sandia National Laboratories, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carling, R.W., Exploratory Chemistry Division I, Sandia National Laboratories, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Bradshaw, R.W., Exploratory Chemistry Division I, Sandia National Laboratories, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States; Mar, R.W., Exploratory Chemistry Division I, Sandia National Laboratories, Livermore, 94550, CA, United States
Abstract: Molten drawsalt (NaNO3-KNO3) is being considered as the energy transfer and storage medium for many solar central receiver applications. In an effort to reduce the cost of the containment material while maintaining corrosion resistance, alloys with aluminide coatings have been examined while in contact with molten drawsalt for more than 6000 hours at 600 °C. The alloys examined were 2.25 Cr-1 Mo, 5 Cr-0.5 Mo, and 9 Cr-1 Mo low-alloy steels, and 316 stainless steel. The results show a steady, albeit slow, net weight loss over the course of the experiment. The weight loss has been attributed to spoiling of Al2O3 from the surface (the occurrence of Al2O3 is a result of the aluminizing process) and dissolution of corrosion products NaAlO2 and/or NaFeO2 during post-immersion handling. Scanning electron micrographs of exposed surfaces revealed little or no corrosion of the base metal. It has been concluded that aluminide coated alloys could provide significant cost savings (~50 pct) relative to INCOLOY Alloy 800, and provide at least equivalent corrosion resistance. © 1983 American Society for Metals.
Index Keywords: SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; SOLAR RECEIVERS; STEEL CORROSION

Title: Hydrogen storage characteristics of Zr(BxB1-x′2, B = Fe, Co, B′ = Cr, Mn, andx = 0.4, 0.5, 0.6
Source title: Journal of Materials for Energy Systems
Affiliations: Department of Engineering Materials, University of Windsor, Windsor, N9B 3P4, Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Ivey, D.G., Department of Engineering Materials, University of Windsor, Windsor, N9B 3P4, Ontario, Canada; Northwood, D.O., Department of Engineering Materials, University of Windsor, Windsor, N9B 3P4, Ontario, Canada
Abstract: A number of zirconium pseudobinaries of the type Zr(BxB1-x′)2 demonstrate potential for application as hydrogen storage materials. Pseudobinaries of the above type with B = Fe, Co, B ′ = Mn, Cr, andx =0.4, 0.5, 0.6 have been investigated here and their hydrogen storage characteristics are reported. These alloys exhibit two-phase microstructures, identified as the cubic and hexagonal Laves phases. Hydrogen is absorbed into interstitial sites in the lattice with maximum capacities approaching 1.0 H-atoms per metal atom. Hydrogen capacities and hydride stabilities decrease with 'x'. Incomplete desorption has been observed in all instances. © 1983 American Society for Metals.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE

Title: A geoscience data evaluation and information system
Source title: Journal of the International Association for Mathematical Geology
Affiliations: Federal Institute for Geosciences and Natural Resources, Postfach 51 01 53, Hannover 51, 3000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gabert, G., Federal Institute for Geosciences and Natural Resources, Postfach 51 01 53, Hannover 51, 3000, Germany
Abstract: The exploration of mineral, energy, and water resources requires increasingly access to and usage of relevant up-to-date scientific technical, and economic information on relevant literature and factual data. At present, an Information Center on Mineral Resources and Geosciences is being established in the Federal Republic of Germany. The geoscience information center is responsible for the coordination of acquisition, storage, and dissemination of data on mineral and energy resources, water resources, and economic geology to inform public administration, relevant industry, research institutions, and universities by means of access to a variety of data bases. In the final stage, the information will be accessible on-line through a computer center at Karlsruhe (INKA). Available for the user are national data bases, comprising literature, and factual data on geoscience, mining, deposits, hydrogeology, ocean research, and marine technology, hydrology, oceanography, geodesy, and meteorology, as well as access to international literature and factual data bases. The relational retrieval system GRIPS-DIRS is in use for handling literature data bases at Karlsruhe (INKA), and the hierarchical storage and retrieval system ADABAS for handling factual data bases. The establishment of data-about-data-systems and the dissemination of publicly available evluated data in form of graphical displays of maps is envisaged. The geoscience information center cooperates intensely with similar centers of other disciplines in the Federal Republic of Germany. © 1983 Plenum Publishing Corporation.

Abstract: Metal hydrides, as energy storage media, are receiving considerable attention. The amount of literature concerning the properties of these materials has increased markedly over the past few years. In this paper, we conduct a review of the alloy groups which absorb large quantities of hydrogen. These alloy classes are designated as AB5, AB, AB2, AB3 and A2B7 and Mg-based compounds. These materials are discussed with emphasis placed on thermodynamic and kinetic properties, activation and deactivation, poisoning effects and storage capacity. © 1983 Chapman and Hall Ltd.

Title: Chloride accumulation in plant cells as a homeostatic system: Energy supply as a dependent variable
Affiliations: School of Biological Sciences (A12), University of Sydney, 2006, New South Wales, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Cram, W.J., School of Biological Sciences (A12), University of Sydney, 2006, New South Wales, Australia
Abstract: During the accumulation of KCl by excised tissue of the carrot storage root, Cl-, influx falls by 90% or more. The possibility that this reduction is caused by depletion of respiratory substrate and consequent limitation of Cl- influx by energy supply is disproved. If energy were limiting, then after accumulating KCl (i) the rate of O2 uptake would be less; (ii) the ATP content might be less; (iii) external glucose and/or sucrose would stimulate O2 uptake and Cl- influx; and (iv) respiratory uncouplers would stimulate O2 uptake less. In each case the opposite was found. The ratio of O2 uptake in KCl-loaded tissue to that in nonloaded tissue was 1.25±0.21 (7); the ATP concentration was the same after KCl loading; glucose did not stimulate O2 uptake (except indirectly in the same way as a nonmetabilized glucose analogue) nor did glucose or sucrose stimulate Cl- influx; and the maximal O2 uptake in the presence of the uncoupler ClCCP was the same after KCl loading. The decrease in Cl- influx must therefore be due to a negative feedback signal from internal Cl-, as previously suggested. It is pointed out that normal energy supply must be regarded not as an independent, controlling variable; but rather as a dependent variable of the KCl accumulation system. Conditions where energy supply is or becomes limiting are discussed. The distinction is drawn between pumps operating near equilibirium when energy supply may normally be a controlling factor (e.g., many H+-ATPases); and other pumps (possibly most of those for the uptake of nutrients and osmotica) which operate far from equilibrium and for which energy supply is a dependent variable. © 1983 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: chloride flux/accumulation; dependent/independent variables; energy supply; homeostasis; plant root cells; respiration; sugar levels
Index Keywords: carbohydrate; cell respiration; chloride transport; energy resource; higher plant; in vitro study; ion transport; nonhuman

Authors: MacKown C.T., Jackson W.A., Volk R.J.
Title: Partitioning of previously-accumulated nitrate to translocation, reduction, and efflux in corn roots
Affiliations: Agricultural Research Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture and Department of Agronomy, Lexington, 40546-0091, KY, United States; Soil Science Department, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, 27650, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: MacKown, C.T., Agricultural Research Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture and Department of Agronomy, Lexington, 40546-0091, KY, United States; Jackson, W.A., Soil Science Department, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, 27650, NC, United States; Volk, R.J., Soil Science Department, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, 27650, NC, United States
Abstract: The effect of nitrate uptake, or its absence, on the utilization of nitrate previously accumulated by dark-grown, decpitated maize (Zea mays L., cv. DeKalb XL-45) seedlings was examined. Five-d-old plants that had been pretreated with 50 mM 14NO3-for 20 h were exposed for 8 h to nutrient solutions containing either no nitrate or 50 mM 15NO3-, 98.7 atom % 15N. The ambient solution, xylem exudate, and plant tissue were analyzed to determine the quantities of previously-accumulated (endogenous) 14NO3-that were translocated to the xylem, lost to the solution, or reduced within the tissue during the 8-h period. Energy was continuously available to the roots from the attached endosperm. In the absence of incoming nitrate, appreciable reduction and translocation of the endogenous 14NO3-occurred, but efflux of 14NO3-to the external solution was minimal. In contrast, during 15NO3-uptake, there was considerable efflux of 14NO3-as well as translocation of 14NO3-to the xylem, but little 14NO3-was reduced. Thus there appeared to be an inverse relationship between 14NO3-efflux and reduction. The data are tentatively interpreted on the basis of a model which envisages (a) two storage locations within roots, one of which primarily supplies nitrate for translocation and the other of which primarily supplies nitrate for outward passage through plasmalemma, and (b) the majority of nitrate reduction as occurring during or immediately following influx across the plasmalemma, with endogenous 14NO3-initially moving outward being recycled inward and thereby being reduced. © 1983 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Nitrate translocation, reduction, efflux; Zea (NO3-partitioning)

Title: Preparation of VO2 thin film and its direct optical bit recording characteristics
Affiliations: NTT Public Corporation, Musashino Electrical Communication Laboratory, 3-9-11 Midoricho, Musashino-shi, Tokyo, 180, United States; NTT Public Corporation, Ibaraki Electrical Communication Laboratory, Tokai, Ibaraki, 319-11, Japan

Abstract: Vanadium dioxide (VO2) film which has nearly the same transition point as single crystal has been obtained by reactive evaporation of vanadium on glass and subsequent annealing in N2 gas. Relations between optical properties of VO2 film and its preparation conditions are presented. We made optical dirfect bit recording on VO2 film using a laser diode as the light source. The threshold recording energy and bit density are 2 mJ/cm?2 and 350 bits/mm, respectively. We also made tungsten doping to lower the VO2 film transition temperature. © 1983, Optical Society of America.

Title: Comparison of small-angle pp̄ and pp elastic scattering at 52.8 GeV center-of-mass energy at the CERN intersecting storage rings
Affiliations: Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; State University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Amos, N., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Block, M.M., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Bobbink, G.J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Botje, M., State University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Debaisieux, J., Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Favart, D., Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Leroy, C., Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Linde, F., State University, Utrecht, Netherlands; Lipnik, P., Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Matheys, J.-P., Université Catholique de Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Miller, D.H., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States; Potter, K., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Vander Velde-Wilquet, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Zucchelli, S., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, United States
Abstract: Proton-antiproton and proton-proton elastic scattering have been measured in the four-momentum transfer range 0.001≤|t|≤0.06 GeV2 for center-of-mass energy 52.8 GeV at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings (ISR). Using the known pp total cross section, a simultaneous fit to the pp̄ and pp differential cross sections yields the pp̄ total cross section; in addition, we obtain the ratio of the real-to-imaginary part of the forward nuclear-scattering amplitude and the nuclear-slope parameter for both pp̄ and pp. Our results show conclusively that the pp̄ total cross section is rising at ISR energies and lend support to conventional theories in which the difference between the pp̄ and pp total cross section vanishes at very high energy. © 1983.

Authors: Kanstad S.O., Cahen D., Malkin S.
Title: Simultaneous detection of photosynthetic energy storage and oxygen evolution in leaves by photothermal radiometry and photoacoustics
Affiliations: Laser and Applied Optics Laboratory, P.O. Box 303, Blindern, Oslo 3 Norway; Department of Structural Chemistry, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel; Department of Biochemistry, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kanstad, S.O., Laser and Applied Optics Laboratory, P.O. Box 303, Blindern, Oslo 3 Norway; Cahen, D., Department of Structural Chemistry, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel; Malkin, S., Department of Biochemistry, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel
Abstract: We have measured simultaneously the photothermal radiometry and the photoacoustic signals from intact leaves. We have confirmed that while the former senses that part of the modulated absorbed radiation not used in photosynthesis, but converted into heat, the latter, at low modulation frequencies, senses not only this heat but also the modulated oxygen evolution resulting from photosynthesis in the leaf. When photosynthetic activity is saturated upon additional excitation with strong non-modulated light, the photothermal radiometry signal increases (virtually all absorbed modulated light being converted into heat), while at the same time the photoacoustic signal decreases, because virtually no modulated oxygen evolution occurs any more. At higher modulation frequencies the behaviour of the photoacoustic signal closely follows that of the photothermal radiometry signal. We have used combined photothermal radiometry / photoacoustic measurements to estimate directly the yield of chemical energy storage in various plant species which applies for different times after excitation. Measurement of light saturation curves for wheat and Siberian pea bush leaves and of action spectra for the latter confirm the similarity between photothermal radiometry and high-frequency photoacoustic signals, and their difference from the low-frequency photoacoustic signal. Combined use of photothermal radiometry (or high-frequency photoacoustics) and low-frequency photoacoustics can thus provide more information than any one method alone. Experiments on intact chloroplasts and on a blue-green alga demonstrate that photothermal radiometry and photoacoustic methodologies can also be used for these tissues. © 1983.
Author Keywords: (Intact leaf); Oxygen evolution; Photoacoustic spectroscopy; Photosynthesis; Photothermal radiometry

Title: EARLY EXPERIENCE WITH SOLAR ELECTRIC GENERATING STATION 1 AT DAGGETT, CALIFORNIA.

Authors with affiliations: Kearney, D.W., Luz Engineering Corp, Westwood, CA,, USA, Luz Engineering Corp, Westwood, CA, USA
Abstract: The solar field comprised of 71,680 square meters of Luz parabolic trough line-focus solar collectors, supplies thermal energy at about 307 C (585 F) to the thermal storage tank. This energy is then used to generate saturated steam at 3. 79 MPa and 247 C (550 psia and 477 F), which passes through an independent natural gas-fired superheater and is brought to 416 C (780 F) superheat. The SEGS I solar electric plant is performing well in its startup year of operation. Placed in service on schedule in 1984, the plant is producing electricity with a high degree of reliability.

Abstract: This paper reviews the current state of solar water heating in the U. S. Active and passive water heating systems are covered. Topics discussed under active systems include collectors, storage tanks, controls, piping and freeze protection. Under passive systems, ICS and thermosiphon systems are covered. Domestic hot water testing and certification programs are briefly discussed as are recommendations for future research.

Affiliations: Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA, Ohio State Univ, Columbus, OH, USA

Abstract: This paper reviews world experience with salinity gradient solar ponds summarizing some of the results obtained, and it outlines basic site, construction, and operating requirements. It discusses difficulties encountered and errors made, and comments on some aspects of practical operating procedures and on research and operating experience still needed.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; OPERATING REQUIREMENTS; SALINITY GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS; SITE CONSTRUCTION; SOLAR POND TECHNOLOGY; Solar radiation

Title: ENGINEERING DESIGN OF SALT-GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS FOR THERMAL AND ELECTRIC ENERGY.
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso,, TX, USA, Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Reid, Robert L., Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso,, TX, USA, Univ of Texas at El Paso, El Paso, TX, USA
Abstract: Salt-gradient solar ponds hold much potential to provide thermal and electric energy to most areas of the world and have already been shown in applications to be both technically and economically feasible. However, too few large scale ponds have been constructed to develop standard, reliable design and construction practices. More research is needed on the validation of computational design methods, development of low cost containment systems, salt handing and dissolving, maintaining water clarity, design of diffusers and study of material behavior. More thermal and electric applications need to be constructed and evaluated to resolve design details and reduce costs. More efficient and less costly thermal electric generator systems are needed.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; ELECTRIC ENERGY; ENGINEERING DESIGN; SALT-GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS; THERMAL ENERGY; Solar radiation

Title: Wind energy.
Authors with affiliations: Pryde, P.R.
Abstract: Discusses siting and storage system aspects of wind power schemes. Examines economics of small wind machines, and outlines DOE studies on these for electricity generation in rural areas. Notes sail power studies. Large wind power machines are discussed, with emphasis on developments in the U.S.A. Lists the major wind turbine sites, existing and planned, and outlines some research on wind generators greater than 1 MW in size. Discusses environmental considerations (aesthetics, effects on bird life etc.) and notes difficulty of determining cost effectiveness of wind power systems. Outlines regions of greatest potential in the U.S.A. (C.J.U.)

Title: Finite element results of possible CAES tube to tubesheet joints.
Authors with affiliations: Lukas, H.; Montgomery, M.E.
Abstract: Recuperators are required to improve the thermal efficiency of compressed air energy storage (CAES) plants. The duty of these recuperators is severe from a thermal cycling standpoint. To determine relative life expectancies of standard and nonstandard tube to tubesheet joints, the Electric Power Researce Institute (EPRI) instituted a project to quantify the life. A finite element computer model was used to evaluate eight different tube to tubesheet joints under a variety of conditions. The study determined that successful tube to tubesheet joints can be made. (A)

Authors: Malachesky P.A., Bellows R.J., Einstein H.E., Grimes P.G., Newby K.R., Young A.R.
Title: Design of bipolar, flowing electrolyte zinc-bromine electric vehicle battery system
Affiliations: Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Linden, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Malachesky, P.A., Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Linden, NJ, United States; Bellows, R.J., Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Linden, NJ, United States; Einstein, H.E., Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Linden, NJ, United States; Grimes, P.G., Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Linden, NJ, United States; Newby, K.R., Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Linden, NJ, United States; Young, A.R., Exxon Research and Engineering Co., Linden, NJ, United States
Abstract: The integration of bipolar, flowing electrolyte zinc-bromine technology into a viable electric vehicle battery system requires careful analysis of the requirements placed on the battery system by the EV power train. An analysis of the influence of these factors on zinc-bromine EV battery system design has been carried out for two types of EV propulsion systems. The first of these is a nominal 100V dc system, while the second is a high voltage (200V dc) system as might be used with an advanced design ac propulsion system. Based on these studies, low profile, 12 dm2 bipolar cell components have been developed which are readily incorporated into a variety of motive power and stationary energy storage system designs.
Index Keywords: Bromine; Electric automobiles; Electrolytes; HVDC power transmission; Propulsion; Systems analysis; Zinc; AC propulsion; Advanced designs; Battery systems; Bipolar cells; Electric vehicle batteries; Flowing electrolytes; Propulsion system; Stationary energy storages; Secondary batteries

Title: Sorbent-containing storage systems for natural gas powered vehicles
Affiliations: Research Staff Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Golovoy, A., Research Staff Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, MI, United States
Abstract: Natural gas can be used as a vehicular fuel, but its low energy density is a significant drawback. The energy density can be increased by adsorption of the natural gas on high surface area sorbents. The adsorption of methane on activated carbons and molecular sieves was investigated at pressures up to 16 MPa (2300 psig). The improvement in methane storage capacity over empty cylinders is appreciable at low pressures but diminishes as the pressure increases. When adsorbed, for example, on 9LXC activated carbon at 3, 7, and 14 MPa the energy density increased by 245%, 100%, and 53%, respectively. Less improvement was observed with molecular sieves.
Index Keywords: Activated carbon; Methane; Molecular sieves; Natural gas; Sieves; Sorbents; Energy density; High surface area; Low pressures; Low-energy; Methane storage; Pressure increase; Storage systems; Vehicular fuel; Natural gas vehicles

Authors: Bechtoid R.L., Timbario T.J., Tison R.R., Sprafka R.J.
Title: The practical and economic considerations of converting highway vehicles to use natural gas as a fuel
Affiliations: Mueller Associates, Inc., United States; E:F Technology, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bechtoid, R.L., Mueller Associates, Inc., United States; Timbario, T.J., Mueller Associates, Inc., United States; Tison, R.R., E:F Technology, United States; Sprafka, R.J., E:F Technology, United States
Abstract: Natural gas provides a current, low-cost alternative to the use of gasoline and diesel fuel for highway transportation vehicles. However, due to the capital costs required to use natural gas as a transportation fuel in either compressed (CNG) or liquefied (LNG) forms, some applications are more advantageous than others. Generally, fleets provide the best opportunity for conversion because of the sheer volume of fuel required and because most vehicles return to a single location each day. The advent of small compressors may make conversion to natural gas feasible for private individuals. Presently, the most popular conversions are to CNG due to the limited availability of liquefiers to produce LNG. The available conversion kits favor vehicles with certain characteristics: vehicles should have spark-ignition engines, be large enough to support the weight of the CNG fuel cylinders, consume at least 5 gallons of gasoline each day on average and have sufficient storage volume so that the fuel cylinders do not infringe on required load-carrying volume. The ease of conversion depends greatly on the vehicle. Pickup trucks are usually easy to convert while subcompact cars can present formidable challenges due to space requirements and load-carrying capacity. The costs of converting to CNG include vehicle conversion costs, refueling station costs, and required operating and maintenance costs. These costs vary according to vehicles (how many storage tanks and how difficult the conversions are), the planned utilization of compressor capacity, whether the vehicles are refueled using slow-fill or fast-fill techniques and the refueling site preparation required. In this paper, these costs are explained and compiled for the conversion kits and refueling equipment presently available. A few case studies are explored to demonstrate what must be known to evaluate whether a fleet of vehicles has potential to save money using natural gas and how long it may take to see a return on the initial investment. Also discussed in the paper is an overview of CNG safety aspects, especially as related to road and operating restrictions that may exist in some local jurisdictions. Thus, in keeping with the intent of this paper to be a practical guide for decision-makers, reference is made to safety-related considerations and the restrictions which may be imposed by some states or municipalities on CNG vehicle operation.
Index Keywords: Compressed natural gas; Costs; Decision making; Diesel fuels; Energy resources; Engine cylinders; Fleet operations; Fuel storage; Gases; Gasoline; Highway engineering; Natural gas transportation; Trucks; Compressor capacity; Economic considerations; Fleet of vehicles; Highway vehicles; Maintenance cost; Space requirements; Transportation fuels; Transportation vehicles; Natural gas vehicles

Title: Particulate control systems for diesel engines using catalytically coated and uncoated traps with consideration of regeneration techniques
Affiliations: Volkswagenwerk AG, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Öser, P., Volkswagenwerk AG, Germany; Thorns, U., Volkswagenwerk AG, Germany
Abstract: Basic investigations of the particulate control system projects for VW and Audi diesel engines are summarized. A screening test procedure to evaluate the particulate concepts is developed and the significant assessment criteria are defined. The storage and regeneration characteristics as well as balance temperatures, introduced with this paper, are applied to various uncoated and catalytically coated filters. This paper discusses also the parameter studies for uncoated filters. A survey of regeneration techniques and individual regeneration methods is given with energy consideration and fuel consumption effects. After establishing the current stage, the priorities for further technical development work are set and the problem areas throughout the particulate control field are demonstrated. Cost-benefit in applicability for production use is considered. © Copyright 1983 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Cost benefit analysis; Testing; Assessment criteria; Balance temperatures; Coated filters; Energy considerations; Parameter studies; Particulate control; Screening tests; Technical development; Diesel engines

Title: Advanced electric and hybrid vehicle subsystem assessment
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hardy, K.S., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, United States; Langendoen, J.M., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, United States
Abstract: Various candidates for nonpetroleum electric and hybrid vehicle (EHV) subsystems have been evaluated as part of the Advanced Vehicle (AV) Assessment at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The subsystems include battery and power-peaking energy storage, heat engine and fuel cell energy conversion devices, motor/controller subsystems, transmissions, and vehicle subsystem (structure and body) technologies. The primary objective of this effort, was to project the mature capabilities of the various components in the 1990's for application in the systems evaluations in the next phase of this activity. This paper presents the basic characteristics of the subsystems and compares their capabilities with projected AV subsystem requirements. © Copyright 1983 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Energy conversion; Fuel cells; Fuel storage; Hybrid vehicles; Vehicle transmissions; Advanced vehicle; Basic characteristics; Electric and hybrid vehicles; Energy conversion devices; Jet Propulsion Laboratory; Power peaking; Primary objective; Systems evaluations; Fighter aircraft

Title: On-board storage and home refueling options for natural gas vehicles
Affiliations: Engineering and Research Staff, Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Golovoy, A., Engineering and Research Staff, Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, MI, United States; Braslaw, J., Engineering and Research Staff, Ford Motor Co., Dearborn, MI, United States
Abstract: In this paper options for on-board storage and home refueling of natural gas vehicles are presented and discussed. The on-board natural gas storage options considered are: storage at 2.2 MPa (300 psig) in activated carbon-filled cylinders, and 7.0 MPa (1000 psig) and 16.7 MPa (2400 psig) in hollow cylinders. Information is presented on small home refueling compressors designed to compress the natural gas to the above mentioned storage pressures. Also shown are data on the density and energy density of natural gas at pressures up to 21 MPa (3000 psig), It is found that to achieve a range of 160 km (100 miles), a 12.7 km/L (30 mpg) vehicle requires 232, 170 and 62 liters (8.2, 6.0 and 2.2 ft3), respectively, of natural gas storage volume at the three pressures considered. A preliminary comparison of the three storage options suggests that storage above 7.0 MPa is preferred. © Copyright 1983 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Activated carbon; Automobiles; Cylinders (shapes); Density of gases; Digital storage; Filling stations; Gas compressors; Gases; Natural gas; Energy density; Hollow cylinders; Natural gas storage; On board storage; Storage pressures; Natural gas vehicles

Title: Natural gas storage on activated carbon
Affiliations: Research Staff, Ford Motor Co.
Authors with affiliations: Golovoy, A., Research Staff, Ford Motor Co.; Blais, E.J., Research Staff, Ford Motor Co.
Abstract: Natural gas is a good fuel for internal combustion engines, but its low energy density is a significant drawback. The energy density can be increased by adsorption on a high surface area activated carbon. But with usage, some of the constituents in the natural gas composition accumulate on the carbon and reduce its adsorptivity. The adsorption-desorption of natural gas on 9LXC activated carbon was investigated to 100 cycles at 21°C and pressures of up to 12 MPa. The decrease in the capacity, G, as a function of the number of cycles, N, was found to follow the empirical correlation:G/Go = 1 - 0.085Log (N). Analysis of the activated carbon after 100 cycles showed accumulation of C 4. and higher hydrocarbons but not of C2 and C 3. For automotive applications, activated carbon appears practical in a narrow pressure range, centering around 7 MPa (1000 psig). The preferred storage is at a pressure of 17 MPa or higher, without the use of activated carbons. © Copyright 1983 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Internal combustion engines; Natural gas; Adsorption desorption; Automotive applications; Empirical correlations; High surface area activated carbon; Higher hydrocarbons; Natural gas composition; Natural gas storage; Number of cycles; Activated carbon

Title: An analysis and comparison of automotive propulsion systems
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Behrin, E., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States
Abstract: We analyze a number of existing and proposed automotive propulsion systems and compare their specific energy and specific peak power in terms of mechanical energy delivered from the propulsion system's energy-conversion device. The calculations account for losses due to the energy-conversion process and include the masses of both the fuel (or energy-storage device) and the energy-conversion components. Values used in the comparisons range from the current state of the art, or most-probable forecasts of characteristics to highly optimistic projections of device characteristics. On the basis of this analysis, we estimate the range and acceleration for passenger vehicles utilizing the various propulsion systems. We also examine power-boosted hybrid systems. © Copyright 1983 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Energy conversion; Fuel storage; Hybrid systems; Automotive propulsion; Conversion process; Device characteristics; Energy conversion devices; Mechanical energies; Passenger vehicles; Propulsion system; State of the art; Propulsion

Title: Elastomeric regenerative braking sysytems
Affiliations: Corporate Research Dept., Eaton Engineering and Research Center, Southfield, MI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hoppie, L.O., Corporate Research Dept., Eaton Engineering and Research Center, Southfield, MI, United States
Abstract: A theoretical and experimental investigation into the use of elastomers as the energy storage element of a regenerative braking system for urban vehicles is being carried out. This work has included the design and fabrication of full-scale elastomeric energy storage units which were tested to investigate energy density, efficiency and stress-relaxation. A complete small-scale system which simulates a vehicle was tested during transient speed conditions, and a complete full-scale system to be laboratory tested is under construction. © Copyright 1983 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

Authors: Bjurström S., Martna J., Rehbinder G., Röshoff K.
Title: Stability of a rock opening subjected to pulsating temperature
Affiliations: Swedish Rock Mechanics Research Foundation, Stockholm, Sweden; Swedish State Power Board, Vällingby, Sweden; Division of Rock Mechanics, University of Luleå, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Bjurström, S., Swedish Rock Mechanics Research Foundation, Stockholm, Sweden; Martna, J., Swedish State Power Board, Vällingby, Sweden; Rehbinder, G., Swedish Rock Mechanics Research Foundation, Stockholm, Sweden; Röshoff, K., Division of Rock Mechanics, University of Luleå, Sweden
Abstract: Large scale storage of heat is a vital part of the energy saving program being carried out in Sweden. In order to study the possibilities of storing heated water underground, a research rock cavern with a yolume of 15 000 m 2 has been built in Sweden. This cavern is filled with hot water and the temperature varies between 40 and 115°C. A research program will simulate the situation of seasonal heat storage and short term heat storage as well. In the cavern and in the surrounding rock a comprehensive instrumentation has been installed for the registration of, among other things, the stabilization process in the heated rock. This paper describes briefly the geological situation at the site and the selected method to measure the displacement in the heated rock. It also describes the preliminary results of the displacements in the rock due to the initial heating. © 5th ISRM Congress 1983. All rights reserved.

Title: Seasonal modeling using steady state techniques
Affiliations: Union Gas Limited, Chatham, ON, Canada
Authors with affiliations: James, W.G., Union Gas Limited, Chatham, ON, Canada
Abstract: A technique using a series of consecutive steady state analyses is used to perform seasonal analysis of natural gas storage and transmission systems. Daily system loads are varied over the time period using dimensionless profiles which allows the model to simulate storage draw-down and compressor operation. The operator may intervene at any point in time to change the system configuration. The simulation makes constraint interchanges where required and checks for situations requiring operator intervention. The system has applications for transmission, distribution, production and storage operation. © PSIG 1983.
Author Keywords: Compressor; Operation; Simulation; Steady-state; Storage

Title: Proceedings - SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition
Source title: Proceedings - SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition
Abstract: The proceedings contain 150 papers. The topics discussed include: 1982: a precipitous decline, the service company, bidding and integrity; acquisition and enhancement of mature producing properties: a case history; afterflow measurement and deconvolution in well test analysis; analysis of five field tests of steamdrive additives; an analysis of rate-sensitive skin in gas wells; application of electromagnetic propagation lagging in the Permian basin of west Texas; applying the principles of project financing to the independent oil and gas producer; binary surfactant mixtures for minimizing alcohol cosolvent requirements; case history: a multizone tight gas completion technique for the Blocker Cotton valley field, east Texas; a case study of retrograde behavior in a gas transmission network; cogeneration experience in steam EOR applications; comparison of uniaxial strain and hydrostatic stress porevolume compressibilities in the nugget sandstone; compressed air energy storage (CAES) in an aquifer - a case history; computer modeling of Katy Cockfield sands; conservative and nonconservative buckling of drillpipe; and critical design parameters to prevent gas invasion during cementing operations.

Authors: Istvan J.A., Crow C.V., Pereira J.C., Bakhtiari H.
Title: Compressed air energy storage (CAES) in an aquifer-A case history
Source title: Proceedings - SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: PB-KBB Inc., United States
Authors with affiliations: Istvan, J.A., PB-KBB Inc., United States; Crow, C.V., PB-KBB Inc., United States; Pereira, J.C., PB-KBB Inc., United States; Bakhtiari, H., PB-KBB Inc., United States
Abstract: The CAES aquifer experiment is a research project which draws its basic knowledge from natural gas storage in aquifers. It does however pose problems of a typical nature, namely the properties of the storage product which has a higher viscosity than natural gas, the need to cycle daily rather than seasonally and the higher temperature requirements. This paper summarizes the test activities that are being conducted at the Pittsfield Aquifer Test Site, concerning the field evaluation of a typical aquifer for storing and cycling compressed air under conditions approaching those existing in a full scale CAES operation. © 1983 Society of Petroleum Engineers (SPE).All right reserved.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Compressed air; Hydrogeology; Natural gas; Pressure vessels; Aquifer tests; Case history; Compressed air energy storages (CAES); Field evaluation; Natural gas storage; Compressed air energy storage

Title: Cyclic steam stimulation with formation parting
Affiliations: Universily of Alberta, Canada; Chevron Oil Field Research, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Farouq Ali, S.M., Universily of Alberta, Canada; Blunschi, J., Chevron Oil Field Research, Canada
Abstract: Cyclic steam stimulation in highly viscous oilbearing formations, such as those of Cold Lake, entails formation parting in many cases. This paper presents a numerical treatment of the phenomena involved in this process, viz. fluid flow in cyclic steam stimulation, formation parting, fracture propagation, and closure. The latter part of the model involves the calculation of stresses and strains in the formation as well as in the surrounding rocks, as a result of pressure and temperature changes, which are used to calculate the fracture length at various times. Fluid flow in the cyclic steam stimulation process is simulated hy a three-phase heat-fluid flow model, with implicit solution and and special procedures to minimize computational time. A coupled well model allows for six different well operation conditions, including fluid storage in the fracture. Rock stresses and strains were computed using a finite element model, developed for this study, which also gives the displacements and stresses at the fracture tip. Several fracture propagation criteria were tested, and as a consequence, all the pertinent criteria from the literature were rejected for the case pf non-isothermal fractures. Instead, it is postulated that for materials containing a propagating fracture, whose strain and/or surface energy is supplied by loading of. the fracture face and/or pore pressure or thermal expansion, the strain energy may not fully balance the imposed loads. A new criterion for fracture propagation and closure is offered that seems to reflect the reported behaviour in the field. © 1983 Petroleum Society of CIM.
Index Keywords: Elasticity; Fracture; Steam; Strain; Strain energy; Structural design; Thermal expansion; Computational time; Cyclic steam stimulations; Displacements and stress; Fracture propagation; Implicit solutions; Numerical treatments; Operation conditions; Pressure and temperature; Flow of fluids

Title: The effects of carbon cycle model error in calculating future atmospheric carbon dioxide levels
Affiliations: Division of Applied Mechanics, Stanford University, CA, 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Laurmann, J.A., Division of Applied Mechanics, Stanford University, CA, 94305, United States; Spreiter, J.R., Division of Applied Mechanics, Stanford University, CA, 94305, United States
Abstract: Empirical investigations have indicated that projections of future atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations of a quality quite adequate for practical questions regarding the environmental threat of anthropogenic carbon dioxide emissions and its relationship to energy use policy could be made with the simple assumption that a constant fraction of these emissions would be retained by the atmosphere. By analysis of the structural behavior of equations describing the transfer of carbon and carbon dioxide between their several reservoirs we have been able to demonstrate that this characteristic can be explained to result from approximately linear behavior and exponentially growing carbon dioxide release rates, combined with fitting of carbon cycle model parameters to the last twenty years of observed atmospheric carbon dioxide growth. These conclusions are independent of the details of carbon cycle model structure for projections up to 100 years into the future as long as the growth in atmospheric carbon dioxide release rates is sufficiently high, of the order of 1.5% per annum or more, as referenced to p re-industrial (steady state) conditions. At low rates of growth, when the longer response times of the carbon cycling system become important, for most energy use projections the resultant CO2 induced climate changes are small and the uncertainties in predicted atmospheric carbon dioxide level are thus not important. A possible exception to this condition occurs for scenarios of future fossil fuel use rates designed to avoid atmospheric CO2 levels exceeding a chosen threshold. In this instance details of carbon cycle model structure could significantly affect conclusions that might be drawn concerning future energy use policies; however, it is possible that such a result stems from inappropriate specification of a criterion for an environmental threat, rather than from inherent inadequacy of current carbon cycle models. Recent carbon cycle model developments postulate transfer processes of carbon into the deep ocean, large carbon storage reservoir at rates much higher than in the models we have analysed. If the existence of such mechanisms is confirmed, and they are found to be sufficiently rapid and large, some of our conclusions regarding the use of the constant fractional retention assumption may have to be modified. © 1983 D. Reidel Publishing Co.
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION - Environmental Impact; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METEOROLOGY - Climatology; CARBON DIOXIDE; carbon dioxide; climate; model; nonbiological model; nonhuman; theoretical study

Title: Areas of application for research into three-phase flow.
Authors with affiliations: Silvester, R.S.
Abstract: The engineering applications for a knowledge of the flow of solid liquid gas mixtures are reviewed. These are broadly categorised as as transport or process, the former including air lifted solids and the latter fluidised reactors. Most existing work on transport applications is centred around the mining of manganese nodules from the sea floor, though other applications include air lifting coal from deep land based shafts. A novel means of using injected air to reduce the friction of non Newtonian suspension flow is described. Three phase fluidised beds, suspensions of solid particles in a liquid by gas bubbling, are found in the process industry. A novel application for similar systems in the area of thermal energy storage is set forth. A final section is allocated to the theory of solid liquid gas flows, with emphasis upon the current state of the art. (A)

Title: Review of potential sail-assist applications to fisheries and influence of fishery operations on design.
Authors with affiliations: Sainsbury, J.C.
Abstract: The need to reduce fuel consumption of fishing vessels in order to work within economic boundaries of various fisheries has led to the introduction of sail assistance. Total power needs of fishing vessels are reviewed and the classification of fishing methods in terms of demands placed on the vessel is extended to a tentative ranking of fishing operations having potential for use of sail assist and alternate source power generation. The need for basic data concerning power use by fishing vessels in order to permit development of power budgets, and matching needs with available sources and storage facilities, is considered, together with some of the developments necessary before alternate power can make an effective contribution towards the total energy needs of larger fishing vessels. (A)

Title: Small hydroelectric development computer analysis.
Authors with affiliations: Soltys, P.W.
Abstract: Describes a computer model which was actual flow data for a period of record (e.g. USGS daily flow data) for determination of average annual energy output. Run of river and, pulsing (reservoir drawdown) operations can be studied. Illustrates the flow chart for small scale hydroelectric power station simulation and describes the input parameters. These include streamflow (continuous set of flow records) headwater and tailwater elevations, head losses (head loss vs turbine discharge curves) turbine discharge and environmental discharge. System efficiency and reservoir storage parameters are also considered. (C.J.U.)

Title: Relationship of regional water quality to aquifer thermal energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Allen, R.D.; Raymond, J.R.
Abstract: Modeling with the MINTEQ code showed three potential reactions: precipitation of calcium carbonate at raised temperature; solution of silica at raised temperature followed by precipitation at reduced temperature; and oxidation/precipitation of iron compounds. Ammeliorative chemical procedures are available. Low concentrations of solutes are generally favourable for ATES. Near-surface waters in high precipitation regions are low in salinity. Groundwater recharged from fresh surface waters also has reduced salinity.-from STAR, 22(14), 1984
Index Keywords: MINTEQ code; regional water quality; salinity; thermal energy storage

Title: Wind system value assessment for electric utilities.
Authors with affiliations: Rahman, S.; Matheny, B.
Abstract: The paper provides a review of a number of factors that influence the value of wind energy conversion sysems. The factors discussed include capacity and energy credits, the downwind effect of clusters, array effects, environmental credit, and storage. The integration of these factors to produce a value tool for wind energy systems is discussed. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Kalaupapa, Molokai, Hawaii wind turbine and battery storage analysis using the SOLSTOR II computer code.
Authors with affiliations: Murphy, K.D.
Abstract: The feasibility of a wind turbine collector and battery storage system on the island of Molokai, Hawaii, was investigated using the SOLSTOR II optimizing computer code. Three system configurations were evaluated: utility connected, stand alone with generator backup, and stand alone without generator back up. The utility connected version considered both sell back of energy to the utility and no sell back. Major analysis conclusions are: the wind regime used in the simulation is extremely good, the annualized specific energy costs for all simulation cases are considerably lower than the current utility electric rate, and moderate battery storage capacity is economically attractive on the island of Molokai. (A)

Authors: Neill D.R., Takahashi P.K., Brown N.E.
Title: Report on wind energy applications research and development programs in Hawaii.
Authors with affiliations: Neill, D.R.; Takahashi, P.K.; Brown, N.E.
Abstract: The paper reviews research efforts on wind power development in Hawaii in the following topics: wind characteristic studies; wind energy battery storage, the Avery variable stroke water pumper, wind energy nitrogen and phosphorous fertilizer generation. Proposed R & D projects include investigations into wind turbulence, noise, safety and aesthetics, the charging of vehicle batteries with wind energy conversion systems, and desalination by reverse osmosis and heat generation for aquaculture. (A.J.)

Title: Design of stand-alone wind energy conversion systems with energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Ashenayi, K.; Ramakumar, R.
Abstract: The paper discusses the application of the Loss of Power Supply Probability (LPSP) method to the design of stand alone wind energy conversion systems (WECS) with energy storage. The entire output of the WECS is assumed to be processed through the storage and the wind resource is modelled using a Weibull distribution. The WECS power output characteristic is approximated in terms of two straight line segments and the load is assumed to have a uniform distribution. Equations and assumptions related to the modelling and design are documented in the paper. Representative numerical results for typical wind regimes and for different combinations of system parameters are presented and discussed. (A)

Title: Direct-contact high-temperature thermal energy storage heat exchanger. Final subcontract report.
Authors with affiliations: Alario, J.; Brown, R.
Abstract: A 10-kWh scale model high temperature thermal energy storage heat exchanger thermal energy storage system was designed and fabricated. Aresearch programme was structured in three separate phases to permit: Phase I the inspection and evaluation of the origin at hardware, which suffered extensive corrosion and damage in a previous experimental programme; Phase II redesign and fabrication of a modified system; and Phase III detailed test evaluation. At the end of Phase II, the system was in a ready for test condition but the programme was terminated before the start of the Phase III test evaluation. Since testing was never implemented, this presents only the results for the design annd fabrication phase of the programme. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Tristan da Cunha - harnessing the wind resource.
Authors with affiliations: Garside, A.J.; Kyles, B.
Abstract: The development of wind power on the island of Tristan da Cunha is described. The present generating system and the Island's resources are first considered. Preliminary studies of the wind energy potential and then a detailed study over 18 months are reported. The demand for electrical power, methods of power storage, and the design of a wind powered generator system are described. The hardware selection and transportation from South Africa and its installation are discussed. Commissioning and ongoing problems and system performance are reported. (A.J.)

Title: SUMMARIES OF CANMET ENERGY RESEARCH CONTRACTS 1982-1983.
Source title: CANMET Report (Canada Centre for Mineral and Energy Technology)
Authors with affiliations: Lanzer, Tom P.(Compiler)
Abstract: This report summarizes energy related R & D contracts which were sponsored by CANMET and completed in 1982 and 1983. The summaries were prepared to assist in transferring to industry the new technology which has been created through CANMET's extensive contracting-out program. In fiscal year 1982-83, the value of energy related R & D which was contracted-out exceeded 8. 5 million, representing 23% of the CANMET Energy Technology Activity budget for the year. Energy contracts completed prior to 1982 were summarized previously in CANMET Reports 78-1, 79-26 and 82-11. Final reports for the contracts outlined in these summaries are available through the Technology Information Division, Canada Centre for Mineral and Energy Technology (CANMET), Department of Energy, Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ontario. The summaries are grouped under the following headings: Conservation, Petroleum Supply, Coal, Nuclear Energy, and Renewable Energy.
Index Keywords: COAL - Canada; Direct energy conversion; Fuels; MINERAL INDUSTRY AND RESOURCES - Canada; Nuclear energy; COAL-LIQUID MIXTURES; ENERGY CONSERVATION; HEAT STORAGE SYSTEMS; RENEWABLE ENERGY; SOLAR ENERGY; Energy resources

Authors: Jenks G.J., Masinskas J.J., Price D.A.
Title: DETONATION PARAMETERS FOR AUSTRALIAN HIGH-EXPLOSIVES COMPOSITION.
Authors with affiliations: Jenks, G.J.; Masinskas, J.J.; Price, D.A.
Abstract: The choice of explosive depends on its sensitivity during manufacture, storage and transport, its performance and, of course, its cost. Different environments (such as underwater in the warhead of a torpedo or in an air-burst artillery shell) dictate different explosive compositions.
