Systems analysts require data on explosive parameters so that weapon performance can be predicted. The explosive parameters of interest in such an analysis are detonation velocity, pressure, temperature and energy output. Theoretical estimates of detonation parameters are based on suitable high-pressure equations-of-state for the gaseous detonation products.
Index Keywords: DETONATION - Computer Aided Analysis; BECKER-KRISTIAKOWSKY-WILSON EQUATION; Explosives

Title: STEADY-STATE AND DYNAMIC EVALUATION OF THE ELECTRIC PROPULSION SYSTEM TEST BED VEHICLE ON A ROAD LOAD SIMULATOR.
Authors with affiliations: Dustin, Miles O.
Abstract: The propulsion system of the NASA Lewis Research Center's electric propulsion system test bed vehicle was tested on the road load simulator. This propulsion system, consisting of a series-wound dc motor controlled by an infinitely variable SCR chopper and an 84-v battery pack, is typical of those used in electric vehicles made in 1976. Steady-state tests were conducted over a wide range of differential output torques and vehicle speeds. Efficiencies of all of the components were determined. Effects of temperature and voltage variations on the motor and the effect of voltage changes on the controller were examined.
Index Keywords: PROPULSION - Electric Energy; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Title: NASA REDOX STORAGE SYSTEM DEVELOPMENT PROJECT CALENDAR YEAR 1982.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Development was continued for iron-chromium battery operation at 65 degree C. Membranes that were adequate at 25 degree C were shown to be unacceptable at 65 degree C with regard to selectivity. This led to the elevated-temperature, mixed-reactant mode of operation, in which each reactant solution, when discharged, contains both ferrous and chromic chlorides. This operating mode allows the use of very low-resistivity membranes, resulting in high energy efficiencies at current densities. It also allows the use of very simple techniques to correct for solvent or reactant transfer through cell membranes. Screening of candidate catalysts for the chromium electrode led to the development of a bismuth-lead candidate having several attractive characteristics.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Redox; Membranes; Electric batteries

Title: NICKEL-HYDROGEN COMPONENT DEVELOPMENT.
Authors with affiliations: Charleston, Jo Ann
Abstract: The NASA Lewis Research Center is currently involved in the research and development of light weight energy storage systems for future space missions. One of the systems now being studied is the nickel-hydrogen battery. This battery is designed to achieve longer life, improve performance, and higher energy densities for space applications. This paper discusses the recent nickel-hydrogen component development. Test data from polarization measurements of the hydrogen electrode component are presented.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries

Title: Buoyancy-induced flow studies in thermally stratified loop of a double-envelope building.
Authors with affiliations: Ghaffari, H.T.; Jones, R.F.
Abstract: A double envelope section of a building, in which thermally stratified air flow serves to hold a moderate air temperature around the building, to reduce thermal losses and air infiltration, and, potentially, to provide day time heat storage for night time use, was monitored from October 1981 to October 1982. The results were analyzed and the usefulness of the system is discussed. (N.G.G.)
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Solar energy

Title: A wind turbine mechanical heating system.
Authors with affiliations: Okutani, J.
Abstract: A wind turbine mechanical heating system is proposed as an additional application of wind energy. The system is composed of a wind turbine with constant pitch blades of 15 m in diameter, an electronic controller, a water storage and circulation system, and a heat utility system. The mechanical heating unit incorporated with the turbine is the so called eddy current brake, which enables rotor speed fine control because of its high responsibility to the variation in wind speed. The blades are made by FRP pulltrusion method. The specifications, configurations, controls, and performance are presented in some detail. According to the experiment the present system has been proved to have a potential as a new heat source. (A)

Authors: Klett D.E., Goswami D.Y., Saad M.T.
Title: Thermal performance of submerged coil heat exchangers used in solar energy storage tanks.
Authors with affiliations: Klett, D.E.; Goswami, D.Y.; Saad, M.T.
Abstract: This paper discusses thermal performance of submerged coil heat exchangers used in closed loop solar energy systems. A rig for thermal performance testing of heat exchangers is described. Thermal performance curves for single wall and double wall submerged fin tube heat exchangers in 300 l and 450 l storage tanks are presented. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Installation and operation of WTG systems in remote Arctic and sub-Arctic regions.
Authors with affiliations: Quihlan, C.M.
Abstract: The installation and operation of wind turbine generators (WTG) in Alaska is examined. The potential wind energy applications include water pumping, space heating, water heating for large outdoor storage and domestic uses and electric power. The Alaskan conditions of salt spray, high winds and below zero temperatures are considered and the problems of transportation and construction are examined. Operation and maintenance in the absence of skilled labour are discussed. (A.J.)

Title: A computer prediction of hybrid wind turbine generator and solar photovoltaic performance.
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, L.A.
Abstract: The computer simulated performance of a hybrid wind turbine generator and solar photovoltaic power system with battery storage is described and discussed. Actual site weather is a major input to the computer program. Performance is related to initial and life cycle costs. An extension of the computer prediction technique replacing the storage battery with stored hydodynamic energy is suggested. (A)

Authors: McGraw B.A., Reid R.L., Bledsoe B.L., Pierce K.L.
Title: Design, construction and testing of a solar collector/storage unit.
Authors with affiliations: McGraw, B.A.; Reid, R.L.; Bledsoe, B.L.; Pierce, K.L.
Abstract: A multi use modular dryer using solar heated air has been built at the Middle Tennessee Agricultural Experiment Station at Spring Hill, Tennessee. Its primary use is to be for rapid drying (2-3 days) of large round bales of high moisture hay. The component of the dryer facility that stores the solar heat for nighttime use is termed the collector/storage unit. The Energy, Environment, and Resources Centre was charged with the task of redesigning and optimizing the performance of the collector/storage system originally designed by Georgia Tech. The dryer facility, which has the capacity to dry 32 large round bales of hay, was utilized in late September, 1982. Initial hay moisture varied form 34% to 51%. Wet weight density of the bales varied from 215 to 250 kg/m SUP 3 for all bales. This density developed fan static pressures of 1120 Pa (4.5 in. of water). The hay was dried in 4-5 days of mostly inclement weather (only 2 fair days not consecutive out of 5). The analysis led to some operational and design changes that may reduce the drying time. (A)

Title: COMPARATIVE EVALUATION OF THE IMPACT ON UTILITIES OF BATTERY VERSUS SYNTHETIC FUEL-POWERED VEHICLES.
Source title: Research and Development Report - Canadian Electrical Association
Authors with affiliations: Masson, L.; Belanger, G.
Abstract: The increasing cost of fuel has aroused great interest in electric vehicles but, because of their limited performance, there may be an advantage in developing other methods of using electricity as the energy source, in the form of hydrogen or synthetic fuels, for example. This study identifies five typical scenarios which could possibly replace gasoline fueled vehicles and compares the impact of these scenarios on a utility from the point of view of energy and power demand. It concludes that although battery-powered vehicles have the least impact, hydrogen-propelled vehicles also have a relatively low impact. Finally a number of subjects requiring further investigation are identified.
Index Keywords: AUTOMOBILES - Electric; Gasoline; Hydrogen fuels; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; Synthetic fuels; Propulsion

Title: Wind effect on the growth of the upper convective zone of the solar pond.
Authors with affiliations: Onwubiko, C.; Forbes, R.
Abstract: An experimental study was conducted on the effect of wind on the growth of the upper convective zone. A solar pond installed with vertical wave barriers was modelled in the laboratory. Due to the complexity of modelling atmospheric flows, the shear stress induced by wind was modelled. The growths of the upper convective zone with various wind speeds were recorded. The effect on the function of a solar pond as an energy collector and store is discussed. (from authors' abstract)
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Solar energy; wind tunnel

Title: Wind turbine air compressor systems for energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Eggleston, D.M.; McAllister, D.
Abstract: Several preliminary wind turbine compressed air energy storage WTCAES, layouts using existing compressors are investigated. It is shown that with the addition of a clearance control system it is possible, using a commercially available reciprocating compressor, to very nearly match power absorbed to that of a wind turbine rotor. This variable speed operation can result in up to 40% greater capacity factor for energy capture relative to a constant RPM induction generator WECS. The economics of these systems is compared using as a basis the NASA Mod-X design in a standard format developed by SERI. THe thermodynamics of WTCAES is reviewed and expressions are derived for the overall efficiencies and charging times for various sized reservoirs. It is shown that concentrating solar collectors could substantially improve the performance and economic viability of the complete system. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Transition from fossil fuels to alternative sources - the role of a large electrical utility.
Authors with affiliations: Wright, J.K.
Abstract: Describes how the CEGB is facing up to the challenge of diminishing fossil fuel reserves. Sections cover thermal reactors, fast reactors, renewable energy sources, energy storage, fluidised bed combustion, coal gasification and combined heat and power. - from CEGB Digest

Title: Hydroelectricity.
Authors with affiliations: Pryde, P.R.
Abstract: Outlines advantages of hydroelectric power as a source of electrical energy. Studies present and future use worldwide of hydroelectric power, quoting some statistics on installed capacity. Pumped storage plants are increasingly popular in the U.S.A., and present plants and some sites under consideration are noted. Describes some characteristics of small scale hydroelectric power stations, and mentions some investigative studies in the U.S.A. Construction of dams and reservoirs for hydroelectric schemes incurs a variety of environmental problems, including possible damage to the ecology, sedimentation problems, potential dam failure, and possibility of induced earthquakes. Examines, region by region, remaining hydroelectric potential in the U.S.A. (C.J.U.)

Title: Nonconventional energy resources.
Authors with affiliations: Pryde, P.R.
Abstract: Studies nonconventional energy resources, in particular, the renewable energy resources. Discusses the limits of fossil fuel resources, and prospects for nuclear power; with consideration of environmental and safety factors. The chapter on hydroelectricity examines present prospects, pumped storage plants, small scale power schemes and environmental considerations with dams and reservoirs. Various aspects of ocean energy resources are studied, including tidal power, wave power, and ocean thermal energy conversion. Discusses types of systems, prospects, environmental/economic considerations for geothermal energy, solar energy and wind energy. Remaining chapters study biofuels (gasohol, biomass), electrochemical power (fuel cells, batteries) and the last chapter discusses potential for such nonconventional energy resources. (C.J.U.)
Index Keywords: book

Title: Pumped-storage on offer.
Authors with affiliations: Acker, F.
Abstract: The author believes that there is an increasing need for pumped storage schemes, and that the tendency will be for high head machines to be developed, with the 1000 m head not too far away. (E.B.D.)
Index Keywords: energy

Title: Papers presented at the 2nd BHRA Fluid Engineering International Conference on Energy Storage: Energy Storage for Energy Management, held in Stratford-upon-Avon, U.K. on May 24-26, 1983.
Abstract: The 2nd BHRA Fluid Engineering International Conference on Energy Storage provided surveys of EEC research, general industrial potential, and assessment of particular industries. Design of domestic, commercial and institutional energy storage systems in space heating was discussed, and topics included use of encapsulated phase change materials, water, electric storage boilers and low temperature systems. Heat pumps and heat pipes were discussed. Three paper discussed performance analysis or economic analysis of systems, and another three studied the application of energy storage to utility operations e.g. combined heat and power stations. Advances in solar energy storage were described. (C.J.U.)
Index Keywords: conference proceedings

Authors: Smith H.O., Hibberd H.J., Warnock J.G.
Title: Large capacity energy storage in excavated caverns - use of the subsurface for energy management.
Authors with affiliations: Smith, H.O.; Hibberd, H.J.; Warnock, J.G.
Abstract: Large capacity caverns excavated in underground natural rock can be used as storage facilities for energy in the form of either thermal potential energy (fossil fuel or hot water) or the potential energy of pressure (compressed air or water at high head). The energy per unit volume of these types is compared. The use of storage for the management of energy between the points of supply and demand is discussed. Ccnstruction of large scale caverns is shown to be a marriage between engineering and mining methods. The authors' studies in underground pumped hydroelectric power, compressed air and oil storage are reviewed, and reference is made to the development of technical concepts for high head underground pumped hydro (UPH). The use of modern mining methods to facilitate underground excavation in order to give low unit costs of construction is discussed. (A)
Index Keywords: aquifer; Heat storage

Authors: Vasconcelos J.J., Ainsworth S.C., Naecker P.A., Willers F.J.
Title: Las Vegas' water system computer model.
Authors with affiliations: Vasconcelos, J.J.; Ainsworth, S.C.; Naecker, P.A.; Willers, F.J.
Abstract: The Las Vegas Valley Water District's computer based supervisory control system for monitoring and control of the District's Water production, storage, and distribution facilities is described. The present water system facilities are explained and the development of a water system network model are summarized. The three objectives of the model are development and testing of algorithms; development and testing of energy, management strategies; and use in planning and preliminary design of future system additions. The development of an algorithm for minimizing energy costs is discussed. (A.J.)

Title: POSTWELD HEAT TREATMENT OF HUGE CAUSTIC STORAGE TANKS TO PREVENT STRESS CORROSION CRACKING.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Three of the world's largest thin wall caustic storage tanks have been successfully heat treated 'on-the-spot' with fabrication by welding taking place at two sites in Western Australia. They comprised two tanks 42m dia. x 18. 8m high and one 47m dia. x 12. 6m high, each weighing in excess of 600 tons. Postweld heat treatment was required to avoid stress corrosion cracking at the welds during service of the tanks. To successfully heat treat each tank a total of ten Cooperheat compact burner trains were used, each comprising a high velocity 8 million Btu burner, motorized fan blower and semi-automatic control station with automatic gas shut-off feature. The heating cycle over 50 hours was controlled to 600 degree C maximum and used only 30 tons of propane gas for each tank firing. The complete process was program-controlled using microprocessor. An important feature of the treatment is the maintenance of a constant positive pressure within the thin-wall tank to prevent distortion. Monitoring by magnahelic gauges positioned at the top and bottom of the tank with adjustment of damper at the exhaust flues, provided the correct positive pressure. To provide temperature measurement and control, a total of 326 type 'K' nickel-chromium/nickel-alumel thermocouples were affixed to the tank by the capacitance discharge method. For quality assurance, one-third were connected to multipoint temperature recorders and two-thirds to a data log printer. Additionally, the contract included the postweld heat treatment of three smaller caustic storage tanks of 35 m x 12 m, 9 m x 9 m and 8 m x 5 m.
Index Keywords: CAUSTIC SODA - Storage; Gas burners; INDUSTRIAL HEATING - Energy Conservation; CAUSTIC STORAGE TANKS; ON-THE-SPOT HEAT TREATMENT; POSTWELD HEAT TREATMENT; TANKS

Authors: Weston Kenneth C., Moran Timothy R.
Title: ENERGY RECOVERY FROM NATURAL GAS STORAGE CAVERNS.
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers of AIME, (Paper) SPE
Authors with affiliations: Weston, Kenneth C.; Moran, Timothy R.
Abstract: Underground storage of natural gas has been employed for years by industry to compensate for variations in gas supply and demand. A relatively new method of underground storage makes use of solution-mined salt caverns rather than natural reservoirs. This paper analyzes the cavern expansion process and evaluates an energy-conserving technique for gas withdrawal.
Index Keywords: GAS STORAGE - Energy Utilization; UNDERGROUND STORAGE; Natural gas

Title: Liquefied energy gas storage tanks - construction considerations.
Authors with affiliations: Steimer, J.G.
Abstract: The construction of LNG and LPG storage tanks using free-standing metallic liquid containers is described. One particular example is that of a double wall metal tank, since the construction of single wall tanks is similar, but most areas of concern are covered by the double wall example. Special problems related to the double containment concept are discussed. (P.J.B.)
Index Keywords: LNG; LPG; storage vessels

Title: DYNAMIC MECHANICAL PROPERTIES OF N-PHENYLNADIMIDE MODIFIED PMR POLYIMIDE COMPOSITES.
Authors with affiliations: Pater, Ruth H.
Abstract: The rheological behavior of newly developed Celion 6000/n-phenyladimide modified PMR polyimide and PMR-15 composites was investigated. The objective was to correlate the dynamic mechanical properies with the structure of N-phenyllnadimide-modified PMR polyimides. The storage modulus (G prime ), loss modulus (G double prime ), and loss tangent (tan delta ) of four composite systems were measured over a temperature range from minus 150 to 400 degree C. Three well-defined peaks were seen in the regions of 360, 100, and minus 120 degree C, corresponding to the alpha , beta , and gamma relaxations, respectively, of the matrix resins. The activation energies of the alpha , beta , and gamma relaxations were estimated to be 232, 60. and 14 kcal/mole, respectively, for PMR-15.
Index Keywords: PLASTICS, REINFORCED - Mechanical Properties; POLYIMIDES - Mechanical Properties; Composite materials

Title: ASSESSMENT OF EUROPEAN DISTRICT HEATING TECHNOLOGY.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Oliker, I.
Abstract: The report assesses European district heating turbine, piping, consumer connection, and thermal energy storage technology from the viewpoint of its application to prospective implementation of district heating systems by electric utility companies in the United States. Since hot water is generally used as the heat transport medium in Europe, it is the basis for the study. Major emphasis is placed on European turbines with condensing tails, prefabricated insulated conduit, consumer connections, using three-stage heat exchange, and thermal energy storage.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Space Heating; Heating

Authors: Lee S.T., Albert R.S., Imamura D.T.
Title: EVALUATION OF SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Lee, S.T.; Albert, R.S.; Imamura, D.T.
Abstract: The objective was to estimate the breakeven capital cost of Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) and its highest possible value. The results are compared by EPRI to the capital cost of SMES being estimated by Bechtel in a related study. The most resonable estimate of the SMES breakeven capital cost is 1080 /kw in 1981 dollars. The highest possible value for an ideal SMES with perfect availability, zero refrigeration load and 100% incremental cycle efficiency is 1570 /kw when installed in a utility approximately one-third of the U. S. in size. Two methods of analysis are used. A single-year analysis that assigns an energy credit and a capacity credit to SMES provides the method for parametric and sensitivity analyses. A thirty-year life cycle analysis comparing SMES to a coal-fired generation alternative recognizes fuel cost escalation effects. The value of SMES to each of the six EPRI Regional Systems is computed.
Index Keywords: Superconducting magnets

Title: ROUGHNESS EVOLUTION AND DENDRITIC GROWTH IN ZINC ELECTRODEPOSITION FROM HALIDE ELECTROLYTES.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Landau, U.; Shyu, J.H.
Abstract: Evolution of rough or dendritic surface texture during electrodeposition often restricts the capacity of rechargeable batteries by limiting the thickness of the plated layer, thereby imposing economic and operation limitations on high energy storage systems such as the zinc-halogen batteries. This phenomenon has so far been treated mostly empirically. A comprehensive model for roughness evolution in electrodeposition, taking into account the combined effects of transport by diffusion and convection, reaction kinetics and the surface energy, is reported. Critical over potentials and induction times for roughness initiation and propagation of roughness elements are determined. Morphological stability analysis explains why certain electrodes remain smooth whereas others evolve dendrites, and defines conditions for smooth deposition. Once roughness evolution is indicated, the complete growth history of the nodules is proved in terms of the current density and the applied potential, the convective flow, chemical composition and the macroscopic and microscopic geometry. The density and distribution of roughness elements evolving over extended electrodes subject to non-uniform flow and potential fields are modelled. Severe localized dendritic growth is indicated, well below the limiting current, under certain conditions.
Index Keywords: Electrolytes; ZINC COMPOUNDS - Electric Properties; ZINC DENDRITES; ZINC HALIDES; Electric batteries, Secondary

Authors: Balzan H.L, Birk J.R., Fiss E.C., Johnson A., Michel G., Shafer W.
Title: UTILITY BATTERY OPERATIONS AND APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Balzan, H.L; Birk, J.R.; Fiss, E.C.; Johnson, A.; Michel, G.; Shafer, W.
Abstract: This report was compiled for use by utility personnel and battery developers to provide a common basis for battery design approaches and operational opportunities. The report considers three aspects: operational requirements - the desired approaches to operating batteries in a utility system are described and the impact of these approaches on battery requirements is reviewed; value and design considerations - the value of battery systems is estimated and approaches are recommended to determine trade-offs among capital cost, design, availability, performance, and maintenance to achieve a cost-optimized system; siting considerations - economics, benefits, requirements, and safety guidelines are proposed for siting batteries in utility systems and in utility-customer locations. The design and operating approaches are based upon common practices of the utility industry. In several cases, extrapolations of industry practice are presented to account for gaps in knowledge that exist because batteries are not used for bulk energy storage.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC UTILITIES - Energy Storage; Electric batteries, Secondary

Title: ANALYSIS OF THE ECONOMICS OF PHOTOVOLTAIC-DIESEL-BATTERY ENERGY SYSTEMS FOR REMOTE APPLICATIONS.
Authors with affiliations: Brainard, William A.
Abstract: Computer simulations were conducted to analyze the performance and operating cost of a photovoltaic energy source combined with a diesel generator system and battery storage. The simulations were based on the load demand profiles used for the design of an all-photovoltaic energy system. Total energy produced, energy consumed, operation and maintenance costs were calculated. The life cycle and levelized energy costs were determined for a variety of system configurations. The system configuration producing the minimum levelized energy cost was determined. Results are represented for three sets of economic assumptions and for two different photovoltaic module efficiencies representative of standard and high density.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Photovoltaic cells

Title: A new concept in subsea storage.
Abstract: The costs associated with constructing subsea pipelines for transporting oil from offshore fields are often prohibitive and, consequently, on many offshore fields oil is stored on site and then transported to shore by tanker. A new oil storage and loading system has been developed which can be installed in water depths between 120 m and 220 m and can safely store from 400,000 barrels to 750,000 barrels of oil even in harsh environments such as the North Sea. The system, known as SISSAC (self installed subsea storage system and articulated column), was designed and tested by Halcrow-Ewbank with support from the Deparment of Energy and in association with EMH. (A)
Index Keywords: storage vessels

Title: OPPORTUNITIES IN THERMAL STORAGE R&D.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Hausz, W.; Berkowitz, B.J.
Abstract: On January 17-18, 1983 a Heat Storage Workshop was sponsored by EPRI in Palo Alto; on January 19-20, 1983 a Cool Storage Workshop followed. Possible technical and economic improvements were discussed for the application of such thermal energy storage for electric load management on the residential and commercial user's premises. Systems discussed included heat storage and ceramic bricks, in pebble or rock beds, in tanks of water, and in containers of phase-change materials (PCMs). For cool storage, systems discussed included icemaking; use of other PCMs such as clathrates, conjugate binary liquids and salt hydrates; and use of desiccants to dehumidify. Related technologies were discussed that have an important effect on system cost, thermal efficiency, safety and reliability. These included insulation, heat exchangers, and sensors of performance. Recommendations in each of these categories were made.
Index Keywords: Heating; THERMAL STORAGE; Energy storage

Title: NASA REDOX STORAGE SYSTEM DEVELOPMENT PROJECT.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The most significant development in the NASA Redox Storage System Development project during calendar year 1981 was the demonstration that raising the operating temperature from 25 degree C greatly enhances the kinetics of the chromium electrode charging reactions. The design of the auxiliary electrochemical cell, which is used to keep both reactants at the same state of charge, was modified, leading to better and more stable performance. Preliminary testing has shown that the four-tank mode of operation improves energy efficiency as much as 5 percentage points over the conventional two-tank mode. Another variation in operating mode, the use of mixed reactants, potentially offers several very attractive advantages. Preliminary reactants cost studies lend further weight to the feasibility of the mixed-reactant concept. Electrode studies have shown that reproducibility of the mixed- performance is very dependent on the pyrolysis temperature at which the carbon/graphite felt substrate is formed. Membrane temperature at which the carbon development work continued to concentrate on cost reduction and the enhancement of resisitivity and selectivity.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Redox; Electric batteries; Electrochemistry

Authors: Gahn Randall F., Hagedorn Norman H., Ling Jerri S.
Title: SINGLE CELL PERFORMANCE STUDIES ON THE Fe/Cr REDOX ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEM USING MIXED REACTANT SOLUTIONS AT ELEVATED TEMPERATURE.
Authors with affiliations: Gahn, Randall F.; Hagedorn, Norman H.; Ling, Jerri S.
Abstract: Experimental studies in a 14. 5 cm**2 single cell system using mixed reactant solutions at 65 degree C are described. Systems were tested under isothermal conditions, i. e. , reactants and the cell were at the same temperature. Charging and discharging performance were evaluated by measuring watt-hour and coulombic efficiencies, voltage-current relationships, hydrogen evolution, and membrane resistivity. Watt-hour efficiencies ranged from 85% at 43 ma/cm**2 to 75% at 129 ma/cm**2 with corresponding coulombic efficiencies of 92% and 97%, respectively. Hydrogen evolution was less than 1% of the charge coulombic capacity during charge-discharge cycling. Bismuth and bismuth-lead catalyzed chromium electrodes maintained reversible performance and low hydrogen evolution under normal and adverse cycling conditions. Reblending of the anode and cathode solutions was successfully demonstrated to compensate for osmotic volume changes. Improved performance was obtained with mixed reactant systems in comparison to the unmixed reactant systems.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Redox; Electrochemistry; Electric batteries

Title: ELECTROCHEMICAL REBALANCE CELL FOR REDOX SYSTEMS.
Authors with affiliations: Stalnaker, Dale K.
Abstract: An electrochemical rebalance cell for maintaining electrochemical balance, at the system level, of the acidified aqueous iron chloride and chromium chloride reactant solutions in the NASA Redox Energy storage system was constructed and evaluated. The electrochemical reaction for the cathode is Fe** plus **3 plus e** minus yields Fe** plus **2, and that for the anode is 1/2H//2 yields H** plus e** minus . The iron (carbon felt) electrode and the hydrogen (plantinized carbon) electrode are separated by an anion exchange membrane. The performance of the rebalance cell is discussed as well as the assembly of a single rebalance cell and multicell stacks. Various cell configurations were tested and the results are presented and discussed.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Redox; Electrochemistry; Electric batteries

Title: ADVANTAGE OF RESONANT POWER CONVERSION IN AEROSPACE APPLICATIONS.
Authors with affiliations: Hansen, Irving G.
Abstract: An ultrasonic, sinusoidal aerospace power distribution system is shown to have many advantages over other candidate power systems. These advantages include light weight, ease of fault clearing, versatility in handling many loads including motors, and the capability of production within the limits of present technology.
Index Keywords: ENERGY MANAGEMENT - Ultrasonic Devices; POWER GENERATION - Energy Storage; Spacecraft

Title: Heat transfer in energy problems.
Authors with affiliations: Mizushina, T.; Yang, W.J.
Abstract: With limited supplies and soaring prices, energy has become a matter of worldwide concern. An urgent need for both the conservation of energy and the development of new energy resources is well recognized today. Heat transfer plays an important role in fulfilling the need, as it is directly involved in the processes of energy conversion, transfer, disposal, and storage. Both the United States and Japan represent high energy consuming countries and are technically advanced in heat transfer research. Therefore, it is very timely for Japanese and U.S. scientists in heat transfer engineering to meet to exchange first hand information, to identify key problems, to discuss research strategies, and to promote areas of future cooperative heat transfer research. For this purpose a joint seminar was held September 29- September 29-October 2, 1980, in Tokyo, under the financial support of the U.S.-Japan Cooperative Science Program. This programme is jointly administered by the U.S. Division of International Programs (INT)/National Science Foundation and the Japan Society for the Promotion for Science (JSPS). This volume, the edited version of the proceedings, begins with an introduction to current Japanese heat transfer research in energy problems, including basic research, the Sun-shine project, the Moon-light project, and the Green project, and to the new research endeavours in the United States. (from preface)
Index Keywords: Heat exchangers

Title: The thermal behavior of oscillating squeeze films
Affiliations: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY, 12181, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tichy, J.A., Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY, 12181, United States; Smith, R.N., Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY, 12181, United States
Abstract: An analytical solution to the energy equation is provided for oscillating squeeze film flow, such as that which occurs in squeeze film damper bearings. Assumptions are: (a) the usual lubrication conditions for two-dimensional flow, (b) small oscillations, and (c) constant viscosity. Specific conditions are established for the latter assumption, which may be in force for stably operated squeeze film bearings. Relatively simple expressions are presented for the thermal performance variables (temperature field, average temperature, Nusselt number) for a variety of cases. The results are interesting from a heat transfer point of view in that the proper energy balance consists of dissipation, conduction, and storage terms, rather than convection terms as is usual in lubrication studies. Thus inferences drawn from other thermal analyses may be in error. Both average cross-film temperature rise and heat transfers are seen to increase from zero Pe'clet number and asympotically approach constant values. Due to the negligible convection conditions, the conventional definitions of bulk temperature, Nusselt number, and Pe'clet number are not appropriate. As a result of the thermal storage effect, interesting temporal phase-shift and temperature swing effects are exhibited. © 1983 by ASME.

Title: A Study on Photoreducible Agents for the Photoactivation Type Physical Development
Affiliations: Imaging Science and Engineering Laboratory, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama-shi 227, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tanaka, K., Imaging Science and Engineering Laboratory, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama-shi 227, Japan; Kokado, H., Imaging Science and Engineering Laboratory, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Nagatsuta, Midori-ku, Yokohama-shi 227, Japan
Abstract: The photoactivation type physical developer, previously proposed, could stand for a long-term storage. For example, a developer consisting of a methanol-water solution of silver salt (0.5mol/l) and p-benzoquinone (0. 47mol/l)2)3) showed little or no deterioration after storage for two days in the dark. The resolution of developed image depended on the anion species in the solution and also on the species of the nucleus metal. The typical value of the resolution was 200 line pairs/mm. Though the developing time as short as 4~5 minutes could yield an image of transmission density 3, the developing rate had to be improved further for meeting practical requirements. In this paper, an investigation was made to find out better precursors for the developing agent (reductant). Precursors were chosen from families of quinones and diazonium salts. Among many compounds, p-diethylaminobenzenediazonium tetrafluoroborate was found to give the best result. When this compound was chosen as the precursor and dissolved into a methanol-water solution (0.13mol/l) together with a silver salt (0. 5mol/l), the developing rate was 3 times higher than that of the former p-benzoquinone type developer. This rate is satisfactorily rapid for practical use. The stability during the storage in the dark and resolution were not lost by the replacement of p-benzoquinone with the diazonium salt. For the palladium nucleus, the exposure energy required for getting the transmission density of unity was 0.8 mJ/cm2, which was lower by factor of 4 than that for silver nucleus. © 1983, The Chemical Society of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Saito A., Utaka Y., Nagakubo S.-I., Katayama K.
Title: A Study on the Heat Transfer of Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage : 2nd Report, Discussions of the Inner Structure to Improve the Heat Removal Performance
Source title: Nihon Kikai Gakkai Ronbunshu, B Hen/Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers, Part B
Authors with affiliations: Saito, A.; Utaka, Y.; Nagakubo, S.-I.; Katayama, K.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Author Keywords: Heat Removal Characteristics; Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage; Numerical Analysis; Phase Change; Thermal Conduction

Authors: Ogawa H., Araki S., Oohusa T., Kayama M.
Title: The Relation between Water and Ascorbic Acid in a Dried Laver “Nori” during the Storage
Affiliations: Yamamoto Nori Research Laboratory, 5-2-12 Oomori-Higashi, Oota, Tokyo 143, Japan; Laboratory of Marine Biochemistry, Faculty of Applied Biological Science, Hiroshima University, Midori, Fukuyama, Hiroshima 720, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ogawa, H., Yamamoto Nori Research Laboratory, 5-2-12 Oomori-Higashi, Oota, Tokyo 143, Japan; Araki, S., Yamamoto Nori Research Laboratory, 5-2-12 Oomori-Higashi, Oota, Tokyo 143, Japan; Oohusa, T., Yamamoto Nori Research Laboratory, 5-2-12 Oomori-Higashi, Oota, Tokyo 143, Japan; Kayama, M., Laboratory of Marine Biochemistry, Faculty of Applied Biological Science, Hiroshima University, Midori, Fukuyama, Hiroshima 720, Japan
Abstract: The influence of water activity (aw) on the destruction of reduced and oxidized ascorbic acids (AH2, DH respectively) in a dried laver “Nori”, Porphyra yezoensis, was examined in aw (0-0.8) during storage for 10 weeks at 13–15°C in both air and an oxygen-free atmosphere. Although BET's monolayer moisture value (ML) of Nori was corresponding to aw 0.11, the most suitable condition to keep AH2 was in aw 0.05 system. According to our estimation method, an optimum water content was at aw 0.02, which was also below BET's ML. This could be due to the difference of adsorption ability of a hydrophilic surface from that of a hydrophobic one. Both the surfaces could not be covered with the monolayer of water molecules at the same time because of the differences of surface-energy. This suggests that BET's ML is an apparent value which exceeds as a ML of the hydrophilic surface. DH increased at lower aw below 0.3 and decreased at higher aw. The ratio of DH to AH2 increased with the increase in aw and storage time. DH is considered to be stabler than AH2 with regard to the influence of water. When oxygen was removed from the preservation systems, mol fraction <0.001, the destruction of AH2 and DH was reduced significantly but incompletely. © 1983, The Japanese Society of Fisheries Science. All rights reserved.

Title: Criticality Safety Analysis of Plutonium Solution and Oxide Powder Handling Facility
Source title: Journal of the Atomic Energy Society of Japan / Atomic Energy Society of Japan
Affiliations: Power Reactor and Nucl., Fuel Development Corp., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Oshima, H., Power Reactor and Nucl., Fuel Development Corp., Japan; Matsumoto, T., Power Reactor and Nucl., Fuel Development Corp., Japan
Abstract: Criticality safety analysis is one of the most important factors upon designing facilities in which a great deal of Pu solution and oxide powder are treated. The results of the criticality analysis for a Pu conversion facility adopting the oxalate precipitation method is reported for an example in this report. At first, it was verified that the accuracy of criticality analysis, using the computer code ANISN or KENO with the Hansen-Roach 16 group cross sections, lay within ±3% on the basis of the criticality experiments achieved at CEA and PNL. After describing basic analysis condition and a criticality flow sheet as the means of criticality safety design, the annular vessel for Pu solution and powder storage were analyzed from the view point of criticality, resulting in the maximum keff of 0.902 for the former and 0.755 for the later, both of which were ensured sufficiently subcritical. © 1983, Atomic Energy Society of Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: accuracy; computer codes; criticality; fuel cycle facilities; nuclear safety; Plutonium conversion; Plutonium nitrate; Plutonium oxide; safety analysis

Title: Quality of Carrots Dehydrated by Three Home Methods
Affiliations: Missouri Cooperative Extension Service, University of Missouri-Columbia, Columbia, Missouri, 65211, United States; Department of Food Science and Nutrition, University of Missouri-Columbia, Columbia, Missouri, 65211, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nichols, V.M., Missouri Cooperative Extension Service, University of Missouri-Columbia, Columbia, Missouri, 65211, United States; Baldwin, R.E., Department of Food Science and Nutrition, University of Missouri-Columbia, Columbia, Missouri, 65211, United States
Abstract: Sensory attributes, moisture and carotene contents, and energy requirements were assessed for carrots treated by home dehydration and storage practices. Flavor was less intense in carrots dehydrated in a convection oven, microwave oven, or a food dehydrator than in the freshly cooked control sample, but sweetness and texture did not differ. The convection oven consumed the least, and the food dehydrator the most, energy for the dehydration process. The microwave oven was the least convenient of the three methods because it required transferring the partially dehydrated product to a conventional oven to finish drying. Re tention of carotene in dehydrated carrots during subsequent storage (10 weeks) was favored by refrigerator rather than room temperature. 1983 American Association of Family and Consumer Sciences

Title: Ab initio MO Calculations of benzene + TCNE and naphthalene + TCNE complexes with STO‐3G π‐split basis set
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Osaka City University, Sumiyoshi-ku, Osaka, 558, Japan; Institute for Molecular Science, Myodaiji, Okazaki, 444, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Watanabe, Y., Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Osaka City University, Sumiyoshi-ku, Osaka, 558, Japan; Kashiwagi, H., Institute for Molecular Science, Myodaiji, Okazaki, 444, Japan
Abstract: Ab initio SCF MO calculations have been carried out on benzene + TCNE (tetracyanoethylene) and naphthalene + TCNE complexes with the STO‐3G, STO‐3G π‐split (STO‐3G for π orbitals and a split basis for π orbitals), and 4–31G basis sets. The interaction energy, gross charges, dipole moment, and the electron density in the middle plane of the complexes have also been evaluated. The STO‐3G π‐split basis set is appropriate for the calculation of large π–π stacking complexes from two points of view, production of reliable results and ease of computations. The approximation scheme based on the semiorthogonalized orgitals is revealed to be very efficient to save CPU time and storage in such calculations. The stable conformation and the charge‐transfer interaction of the two complexes are discussed on the basis of the calculated quantities. Copyright © 1983 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

Title: Contraction of gaussian basis sets and the total energy of fcc copper
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Astronomy, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, Louisiana, 70803, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bagayoko, D., Department of Physics and Astronomy, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, Louisiana, 70803, United States
Abstract: A brief survey of contraction schemes for atomic, molecular, and solid‐state calculations is presented. General guidelines for a simple application of the LCAO contraction procedure to solids are described with emphasis on subtle differences with the cases of atoms and molecules. By means of Wang and Callaway's program package, test computations are performed on fcc copper to produce non‐self‐consistent and self‐consistent results. The electronic energies, densities of states, and x‐ray scattering form factors compare satisfactorily with experimental results as well as with data obtained by Bagayoko et al. using a basis of 75 functions. The advantages of the contraction procedure include a factor of 6.8 savings in CPU time and a significant reduction in storage requirements. An extended version of the program package is used to compute the total energy of fcc copper for various lattice constants by a method recently introduced by Callaway and co‐workers. Copyright © 1983 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

Title: ARTIFICIAL PHOTOSYNTHESIS: QUANTUM CAPTURE and ENERGY STORAGE
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, California, 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Calvin, M., Department of Chemistry, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, University of California, Berkeley, California, 94720, United States
Abstract: Organized systems are described to achieve separation of the charges produced by quantum absorption in a sensitizer, and their stabilization in separated chemical form. These systems involve phase boundary charge separation by both membranes and charged particles, in both cases simulating the natural system. Copyright © 1983, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: Morozumi S., Nishiya K., Hasegawa J., Fujiwara H.
Title: Optimal Operation of Dispersed Energy Storage Units in Electric Power Systems
Source title: IEEJ Transactions on Power and Energy
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Morozumi, S., Faculty of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan; Nishiya, K., Faculty of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan; Hasegawa, J., Faculty of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan; Fujiwara, H., Faculty of Engineering, Hokkaido University, Japan
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: M. H.R.S., MANNHEIM C.H., PASSY N.
Title: SULPHUR DIOXIDE AND CARBON MONOXIDE GAS TREATMENT OF APPLES FOR ENZYME INHIBITION PRIOR TO FREEZING
Source title: Journal of Food Processing and Preservation
Affiliations: Department of Food Engineering and Biotechnology Technion, Israel Institute of Technology Haifa, 32000, Israel
Authors with affiliations: M., H.R.S., Department of Food Engineering and Biotechnology Technion, Israel Institute of Technology Haifa, 32000, Israel; MANNHEIM, C.H., Department of Food Engineering and Biotechnology Technion, Israel Institute of Technology Haifa, 32000, Israel; PASSY, N., Department of Food Engineering and Biotechnology Technion, Israel Institute of Technology Haifa, 32000, Israel
Abstract: The present most common method for inactivating enzymes prior to freezing is thermal blanching which is energy intensive, involves losses of nutrients and soluble solids and causes waste disposal problems. The feasibility of applying sulphur dioxide and carbon monoxide gases, as enzyme inhibitors, to apples prior to freezing was evaluated. Using catalase and polyphenoloxidase, CO gas was found to be inffective as an enzyme inhibitor. Treatment of apples with SO2 was found to inhibit enzyme activity as effectively as thermal blanching. This inhibition was maintained during 195 days storage at —8 and –18°C. Losses in soluble solids were considerably lower than in blanched samples. Hunter color “b” values were different indicating that the SO2 treated apples were yellower and the blanched ones greener. No signifiant sensoric preference was found for either sample after baking despite the obvious difference in soluble solids content and color. Residual SO2 in apples could be reduced to below 50 ppm. Copyright © 1983, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Mechanics of fluids in porous media
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, 32000, Israel; Department of Civil Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, Delaware, 19711, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bear, J., Department of Civil Engineering, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, 32000, Israel; Corapcioglu, M.Y., Department of Civil Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, Delaware, 19711, United States
Abstract: Transport of quantities such as mass component of a phase and/or heat occurs in fields as diversified as petroleum reservoir engineering, groundwater hydraulics, soil mechanics, industrial filtration, water purification, wastewater treatment, soil drainage and irrigation, and geothermal energy production. In all these areas, scientists, engineers, and planners make use of mathematical models; these models describe the relevant transport processes that occur within controlled porous medium domains and enable forecasting of the future behavior of these domains in response to planned activities. The mathematical models, in turn, are based on the understanding of phenomena, often within the void space, and on theories that relate these phenomena to measurable quantities. Because of the pressing needs in areas of practical interest such as the development of groundwater energy storage and geothermal energy production, a vast amount of research in all these fields has contributed, especially in the last two decades, to our understanding and ability to describe transport phenomena in porous media. In recent years these research efforts have been significantly accelerated, attracting scientists from many disciplines. The practical needs of solving boundary value problems in heterogeneous domains, irregular boundaries, coupled phenomena and multiple dependent variables led to the development of a variety of powerful numerical techniques. The realization that fields are highly heterogeneous and that the degree of heterogeneity depends on the scale of the problem led to the introduction of stochastic concepts as an additional tool for the description of phenomena. ©1983. American Geophysical Union. All Rights Reserved.

Title: Utilization of Subsurface Space in Developing Countries
Affiliations: Water Resources Branch NRED/TCD, United Nations, UN Plaza, New York, New York, 10017, United States
Authors with affiliations: HASHMI, T.H., Water Resources Branch NRED/TCD, United Nations, UN Plaza, New York, New York, 10017, United States
Abstract: This paper summarizes the subject matter covered at the United Nations Interregional Workshop on the Utilization of Subsurface Space convened in Stockholm, Sweden, 24–29 October 1982. The utilization of subsurface space has largely been confined to developed countries so far, and the purpose of the meeting was to focus attention upon its potential use in developing countries. Participants at the Workshop discussed the utilization of subsurface space in relation to the underground storage of food and commodities, water, petroleum and gas, and also energy production and utilization. Additional topics included transportation systems and public utilities. The implementation of such projects is discussed with respect to technology and technology transfer and to the economics of subsurface development. As capital, in particular, is a limited resource in developing countries, attention was devoted to the financing of such undertakings. The paper concludes with a brief discussion of the conclusions reached with specific attention to the possible role of United Nations organizations in this increasingly important area. Cet article résume le sujet traité par le Groupe de travail interrégional des Nations Unies sur l'utilisation de l'espace souterrain qui s'est tenu à Stockholm, en Suède, du 24 au 29 octobre 1982. Ce n'est que dans les pays industriels qu'on a jusqu'à présent largement utilisé l'espace souterrain et le but de ce Groupe de travail a été d'attirer l'attention sur le potentiel qu'il représente dans les pays en développement. Les participants ont discuté de l'utilisation de l'espace souterrain dans le cadre du stockage d'aliments et de biens de consommation, de l'eau, du petrole et du gaz, et aussi de la production et l'utilisation de l'énergie. Ils ont également discuté d'autres sujets, tels que les transports souterrains et l'enfouissement des structures industrielles. De plus, l'article traite de la mise en oeuvre de ces projets en ce qui concerne leur technologie et les transferts de technologie ainsi que des aspects économiques de la mise en valeur de l'espace souterrain. Les ressources financières étant, en particulier, limitées dans les pays en développement, le Groupe de travail s'est attaché au mode de financement de telles entreprises. L'article se termine par une brève discussion des conclusions auxquelles sont parvenus les participants en étudiant le rôle possible des organismes des Nations Unies dans ce domaine dont l'importance s'accroît. Este articulo resume el tema tratado en el Seminario Interregional de las Naciones Unidas sobre la utilización del Espacio en Subsuelo que tuvo lugar en Estocolmo, Suecia, del 24 al 29 de octubre de 1982. El espacio en subsuelo ha sido mayormente utilizado sólo por los países en desarrollo por lo cual el propósito de la reunión fue enfocado al caso de los países en desarrollo. Los participantes en la reunión discutieron la utilización del espacio en subsuelo con relación al almacenamiento de alimentos y otros bienes, agua, petróleo y gas y tambien en relación con la producción y utilización de energía. Tópicos adicionales incluyeron los sistemas de transporte y servicio público. La ejécución de tales proyectos se discuten con respecto a la tecnología del desarrollo del subsuelo. Debido a que el capital es la particular en recurso limitado en los países en desarrollo, se dió atención al financiamiento de tales proyectos. El artículo termina con una discusión breve de las conclusiones de la reunión, en especial, aquellos que se refieron al posible rol de las organizaciones de las Naciones Unidas en este área de importancia creciente. 1983 United Nations

Title: The ergonomics of electric storage heater controls
Affiliations: Ergonomics Research Group, University of Hull, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dale, H.C.A., Ergonomics Research Group, University of Hull, United Kingdom; Crawshaw, C.M., Ergonomics Research Group, University of Hull, United Kingdom
Abstract: Although storage heaters are simple from the engineering point of view, they present problems to untutored operators. Two things have to be controlled: the amount of energy stored, and its subsequent emission. The first depends upon future energy requirements which are difficult to predict. Since no units available on the market display the state of the store the operator also finds it difficult to control emission sensibly. Designers' attempts to simplify tend to confuse. © 1983, SAGE Publications. All rights reserved.

Authors: Silfvast W.T., Macklin J.J., Wood O.R., II
Title: High-gain inner-shell photoionization laser in Cd vapor pumped by soft-x-ray radiation from a laser-produced plasma source
Affiliations: Edward L. Ginzton Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, 94305, United States; Bell Laboratories, Holmdel, NJ, 07733, United States
Authors with affiliations: Silfvast, W.T., Edward L. Ginzton Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA, 94305, United States; Macklin, J.J., Bell Laboratories, Holmdel, NJ, 07733, United States; Wood, O.R., II, Bell Laboratories, Holmdel, NJ, 07733, United States
Abstract: A soft-x-ray-pumped inner-shell photoionization laser has been produced in Cd vapor at 4416 and 3250 Å. A gain of 5.6 cm-1 has been measured at 4416 Å, and a reasonably high-energy storage of 0.2 mJ/cm3 in the upper laser states has been obtained. © 1983 Optical Society of America.

Authors: Frey R., De Martino A., Pradère F.
Title: High-efficiency pulse compression with intracavity Raman oscillators
Affiliations: Laboratoire d’Optique Quantique du Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau Cédex, 91128, France
Authors with affiliations: Frey, R., Laboratoire d’Optique Quantique du Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau Cédex, 91128, France; De Martino, A., Laboratoire d’Optique Quantique du Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau Cédex, 91128, France; Pradère, F., Laboratoire d’Optique Quantique du Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau Cédex, 91128, France
Abstract: High-efficiency pulse compression has been obtained by using an intracavity Raman oscillator. The energy of a primary laser stored in its high-Q cavity is extracted at the Stokes frequency by means of a Stokes laser having a high Raman gain and a low-Q cavity. This technique, using hydrogen gas as the Raman medium, permits shortening of the pulse duration of a ruby laser by a factor of 6.7 with 87% effective quantum efficiency. It would be especially useful with low-gain (alexandrite) and with short-storage-lifetime lasers. © 1983 Optical Society of America.

Authors: Tanemoto K., Katagiri A., Mamantov G.
Title: In Situ Raman Spectroscopic Studies of the Rechargeable Low Temperature Molten Salt Cell: Na/Beta”-Alumina/S(IV) in AlCl3-NaCl
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Tennessee 37996, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tanemoto, K., Department of Chemistry, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Tennessee 37996, United States; Katagiri, A., Department of Chemistry, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Tennessee 37996, United States; Mamantov, G., Department of Chemistry, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Tennessee 37996, United States
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Author Keywords: battery; energy storage; fused salts; spectra

Title: Electrochemical Utilization of Metal Hydrides
Affiliations: The Aerospace Corporation, Chemistry and Physics Laboratory, Los Angeles, California 90009, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bittner, H.F., The Aerospace Corporation, Chemistry and Physics Laboratory, Los Angeles, California 90009, United States; Badcock, C.C., The Aerospace Corporation, Chemistry and Physics Laboratory, Los Angeles, California 90009, United States
Abstract: Fundamental and applied works involving the electrochemical utilization of metal hydrides are reviewed. In the first part of the paper, studies that investigated metal hydrides for hydrogen storage in nickel hydrogen batteries are reviewed. These studies showed that use of hydrides lowered the operating pressures in nickel hydrogen cells, which could lead to improved energy density. However, results regarding degradation of the hydriding material in an aqueous medium were conflicting. In the second part of the paper, the use of metal hydrides as reversible hydrogen electrodes is discussed. Studies reviewed included thermodynamic and kinetic investigations of a variety of hydriding materials. Conflicting results among studies are reconciled where possible, and conclusions are drawn regarding the feasibility of electrochemical utilization of metal hydrides, with suggestions for further work. © 1983, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: electrode; interfaces; oxidation; thermodynamics

Title: The consulting environmental biologist
Affiliations: Regional Operations for Ecological Analysts Inc, Sparks, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bogardus, R.B., Regional Operations for Ecological Analysts Inc, Sparks, MD, United States
Abstract: Only about 2,000 biologists are currently employed as environmental consultants, down from a 1978-79 peak of about 5,000. The prospects should improve over the next couple of years with stabilization estimated at 3,000. We got into this predicament by doing a good job of determining the effects of electric utility generating stations on the inhabitants of the water bodies upon which they are sited. The trend toward energy conservation and the recent prolonged and deep recession have aggravated the employment picture. New areas of environmental concern are developing, offering new employment opportunities. These include studies associated with toxic substances, leachates from manufacturing and storage facilities, and biological aspects of issues dominated by social, hydrological or engineering concerns. The consulting biologist of the 1980s will require skills in these areas at least sufficient for multidisciplinary communication, an understanding of fundamental business concerns such as meeting deadlines and living with budgets, and a proficiency in language and communication skills. Universities must provide opportunities and guidance in developing these new skills and supplement the classical training in taxonomy and fishery management. Jobs will exist for the best trained people. © 1983 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Schuessler H.A., Chun-Sing O., Lakkaraju H.S.
Title: Injection and Storage of Singly Charged Ions and Extension of the Principles of Ion Storage to Highly Charged Low Energy Recoil Ions
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, 77843, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schuessler, H.A., Department of Physics, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, 77843, United States; Chun-Sing, O., Department of Physics, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, 77843, United States; Lakkaraju, H.S., Department of Physics, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX, 77843, United States
Abstract: On-line experiments on low energy multiply charged ions can be performed with high sensitivity and resolution if the ions of interest are caught in flight and are subsequently accumulated in a finite observation volume. The various aspects of injecting singly and multiply charged ions into harmonic and nonharmonic ion trap devices are discussed. Injection of a continuous ion beam into an active trap was evaluated by numerical integration of the Mathieu equations to determine the finite confinement time of the injected ions. Three different modes of operation of the ion trap, namely, the radio-frequency (RF), the Penning, and the combined RF and Penning modes were considered. On the other hand the phase space method was used for a pulsed ion beam injected into the RF quadrupole ion trap for which the RF quadrupole field was switched on after the ion injection. In this way, a high trapping efficiency is reached for a suitable combination of the chosen initial RF voltage phase angle and the delay time after the ion injection. In addition, the trapped ions are confined indefinitely and energy- and mass-selective storage of the injected ions are also possible. The occurrence of ion motion induced side bands in the spectrum of stored ions and their importance for determining the ion temperature are discussed. Scaling relations are given which relate the results obtained for singly charged ions to the storage properties as they pertain to highly charged ions. Use is made of the unique environment of ion traps to speculate about novel collision and high resolution spectroscopy experiments on highly charged ions. © 1983 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Title: Silicate materials for storage of hydrogen
Source title: Transactions of the Indian Ceramic Society
Affiliations: Université de Pierre et Marie Curie, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Patel, M., Université de Pierre et Marie Curie, Paris, France
Abstract: Advantages of using hydrogen as a source of energy and silicate materials for its storage, in place of metal hydrides, have been explained. The silicates studied are vermiculites (from France, Spain and artificially prepared), montmorillonite, chlorite (USA) and zeolites (artificially prepared). It has been shown that finely divided metal particles (15-100 Å) can be formed in the interlayer space of clay minerals or in the structural voids of zeolite under suitable conditions and these can serve for storing hydrogen. © 1983 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Thermochemical Data for Gaseous Monoxides
Source title: Journal of Physical and Chemical Reference Data
Affiliations: School of Chemistry and Molecular Sciences, University of Sussex, Falmer, Brighton BN19QJ, U.K., United Kingdom

Abstract: Values for standard enthalpies of formation and dissociation energies for gaseous diatomic monoxides have been selected by critical assessment of experimental data from the literature. Gibbs energy functions, (âˆ’(Gâ—‹T âˆ’Hâ—‹298)/T), and enthalpy functions, (Hâ—‹T âˆ’Hâ—‹298), have been calculated from literature values for molecular parameters. Computer methods of storage, processing and retrieval are described and the resulting data are given in tables 4 to 11. © 1983, American Institute of Physics for the National Institute of Standards and Technology. All rights reserved.
