Title: PASSIVE SOLAR FLOORS.
Authors with affiliations: Hager Jr., N.E.
Abstract: To the extent that passive use of solar energy becomes important, storage of surplus energy during sunlit hours must also become important. Currently, the concrete slab floor is one of the most effective and practical means for achieving such storage. Whatever uncertainty remains about the relative suitability of various floor coverings, it largely stems from the mathematical complexity of the transient heat flow occurring when sunlight falls on a covered floor slab. The purpose here is to show that, under the special circumstances of sunlight falling on a relatively thin floor covering attached to a massive slab, the net heat flow into the floor system can be closely approximated with simple steady-state equations. A further purpose is to show how the resultant simplification provides a systematic engineering basis for estimating the solar-storage performance of commercially available floor coverings.
Index Keywords: HEAT SINKS - Energy Storage; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; CONCRETE SLAB FLOORS; Floors

Authors: Wheaton F.W., Lawson T.B., Brinsfield R.B., Yaramanoglu M.
Title: Aquacultural ponds as energy storage and waste recycling systems
Affiliations: Agricultural Engineering Department, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Agricultural Engineering Department, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Agricultural Engineering Department, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wheaton, F.W., Agricultural Engineering Department, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Lawson, T.B., Agricultural Engineering Department, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA 70803, United States; Brinsfield, R.B., Agricultural Engineering Department, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Yaramanoglu, M., Agricultural Engineering Department, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Abstract: Considerable research has been done in an attempt to utilize solar energy to improve the productivity of aquatic culture systems. At the same time solar energy research has identified energy storage as a problem in commercializing the use of solar energy for heating and other purposes. Thus, a system is proposed to combine aquacultural production facilities and solar energy storage with the possibility of later combining recycling of agricultural wastes into the combined system. System feasibility is being explored by use of mathematical simulation models. Six model components on interacting models are briefly outlined and progress on detailed model development is described. A model capable of predicting the hourly solar energy available at any point on the earth's surface for which cloud cover, clearness number and latitude are known, is described. Example model output is presented and compared to measured data. © 1983.
Index Keywords: AGRICULTURAL WASTES - Recycling; SOLAR ENERGY - Mathematical Models; SOLAR RADIATION - Energy Storage; AQUACULTURE; FISH-FARM PONDS; INSOLATION; FISHERIES

Title: Battery storage in residential applications of energy from photovoltaic sources
Affiliations: US Department of Energy, Washington, DC 20585, United States; The Aerospace Corporation, Washington, DC 20024, United States
Authors with affiliations: Landgrebe, A.R., US Department of Energy, Washington, DC 20585, United States; Donley, S.W., The Aerospace Corporation, Washington, DC 20024, United States
Abstract: Electric energy storage in batteries is discussed for future applications in homeowner-controlled grid-tied photovoltaic power generation systems for residences. Energy storage would enable more effective matching of the intermittent solar-generated energy to high-use periods, as well as storage of energy for sale to the utilities, taking advantage of future variable (time-of-day) utility rate and buy-back structures. State-of-the-art lead-acid batteries are economically viable for utility rate scenarios that are expected to be in effect in many areas of the United States in the mid-1980s.1 'Advanced batteries' (e.g. sodium-sulfur, zinc-bromine, lithium-metal sulfide) with decreased capital investment costs, minimal maintenance and improved performance characteristics could have enhanced consumer acceptance in the late 1980s. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC ENERGY STORAGE; PHOTOVOLTAIC CELLS; ELECTRIC BATTERIES

Title: Accelerated Testing of Additives in Zinc Plates of Nickel Zinc Cells
Affiliations: CSIRO, Institute of Energy and Earth Resources, Division of Mineral Chemistry, Port Melbourne, Victoria 3207, Australia; Department of Chemistry, Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong, China

Abstract: An accelerated test for zinc plates in nickel/zinc cells has been developed. Using the test, a large number of additives have been screened to see if they improve zinc utilization over 100 deep discharge cycles of the zinc plate. Three additives have yielded statistically significant results. These are Bi2O3, CdO, and acetylene black. The mechanism of capacity loss of zinc plates was investigated by scanning electron microscopy. It was found that the major mechanism of capacity loss was a decrease in the porosity of active material. © 1983, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Use of energy storage in industry- potential in Sweden
Affiliations: Linkoping Institute of Technology, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Division of Energy Systems, S-581 83 Linkoping, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Soderstrom, M.F., Linkoping Institute of Technology, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Division of Energy Systems, S-581 83 Linkoping, Sweden; Johansson, T.R., Linkoping Institute of Technology, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Division of Energy Systems, S-581 83 Linkoping, Sweden
Abstract: The industrial energy use is characterized by fluctuating power demand. Mainly the variation is built up by three components: • seasonal variations due to the climate; • power demand variations caused by the fluctuating production rates; • variations due to the choice of equipment and processes. To make the best use of an energy storage it should be charged and discharged. Thus energy storages would play an important role in levelling power demand variations having short periods, e.g. differences between production and non-production hours. The transfer of energy between seasons is more advantageously solved by other means. The needs and possibilities for the use of energy storage depend upon the following factors: • mismatch between energy source and sink; • existence of surplus energy; • sufficient potential levels. Energy use patterns vary according to branch due to the choice of processes. Thus the potential for short time energy storage has been investigated branch by branch. Energy storage possibilities are of different kinds in different branches of industry. Heating of buildings and tapwater as well as the use of process surplus heat for other production processes are considered. Case studies from four of the investigated branches (plastics, heat treatment, brick works and foundries) are presented including potential solutions to the storage applications. Swedish industrial energy use amounts to 417 PJ annually, corresponding to one third of the country's energy use. This study comprehends industrial branches outside the process industries (by process industries we mean the paper and pulp, chemical and iron and steel industries). Energy use within the studied branches is 135 PJ and the potential for short time energy storage is approximately 18 PJ. © 1983.
Index Keywords: HEATING

Authors: Ostmeyer Jeffrey G., Cutter Bruce E., McGinnes Jr. E.Allen
Title: ABANDONED SAWMILLS: POTENTIAL ENERGY SOURCES?
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Sch of, Forestry, Fisheries & Wildlife,, Columbia, MO, USA, Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Sch of Forestry, Fisheries & Wildlife, Columbia, MO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ostmeyer, Jeffrey G., Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Sch of, Forestry, Fisheries & Wildlife,, Columbia, MO, USA, Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Sch of Forestry, Fisheries & Wildlife, Columbia, MO, USA; Cutter, Bruce E., Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Sch of, Forestry, Fisheries & Wildlife,, Columbia, MO, USA, Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Sch of Forestry, Fisheries & Wildlife, Columbia, MO, USA; McGinnes Jr., E.Allen, Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Sch of, Forestry, Fisheries & Wildlife,, Columbia, MO, USA, Univ of Missouri-Columbia, Sch of Forestry, Fisheries & Wildlife, Columbia, MO, USA
Abstract: This study evaluated: 1) the fuel potential of five-year-old oak sawdust using bomb calorimetry, 2) the effect of storage on sawdust fuel values, and 3) the comparison of the energy potential of old white oak sawdust to fresh white oak sawdust. Long-term storage decreases the suitability of sawdust for use as a fuel by increasing moisture content and decreasing fuel value. However, drying of the piled residues prior to utilization as a fuel can substantially increase the usable heat available. The source of heating within piled residues appears to be a result of several procedures. These different processes appear to be responsible for the variations in heating values of piled wood residues.
Index Keywords: Wood waste; BOMB CALORIMETRY; FIVE-YEAR-OLD OAK SAWDUST; FRESH WHITE OAK SAWDUST; FUEL POTENTIAL; LONG-TIME STORAGE EFFECTS; USABLE HEAT AVAILABILITY; Energy resources

Title: SOLAR DECISION MAKING FOR THE TROPICS.
Affiliations: Arizona State Univ, Dep of Planning,, Tempe, AZ, USA, Arizona State Univ, Dep of Planning, Tempe, AZ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Cook, Jeffrey, Arizona State Univ, Dep of Planning,, Tempe, AZ, USA, Arizona State Univ, Dep of Planning, Tempe, AZ, USA
Abstract: Solar applications are viewed as being a particularly efficient and effective energy source for urban tropical locations. The goal of encouraging the inevitable transition to the permanency of solar energy will require many human commitments. Capital formation requires education, hardware and software investments in addition to a business atmosphere that encourages innovation and entrepreneurship. Commercialization requires initial experimental and demonstration stages. Solar decision incentives and patterns of early solar adoption in the United States are characterized. In conclusion, the rate of popularization appears to be the key to measuring solar commercialization and early small scale solar applications appear to precede larger urban and industrial solar installations. Refs.
Index Keywords: Economics; Energy storage; Environmental impact; METEOROLOGY - Climatology; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; HARDWARE; INVESTMENT SOURCES; SOLAR APPLICATIONS; TROPICAL LOCATIONS; URBAN TROPICAL LOCATIONS; Solar energy

Authors: Infield D.G., Slack G.W., Lipman N.H., Musgrove P.J.
Title: REVIEW OF WIND/DIESEL STRATEGIES.
Source title: IEE Proceedings A: Physical Science. Measurement and Instrumentation. Management and Education. Reviews
Authors with affiliations: Infield, D.G.; Slack, G.W.; Lipman, N.H.; Musgrove, P.J.
Abstract: A large potential demand exists for electricity in areas isolated from grid supply. Diesel generation in these usually remote areas is expensive and wind/diesel systems, with the wind turbine viewed primarily as a fuel saver, can be seen as attractive. Integration of wind energy is not straightforward, and in particular can cause operational problems for the diesel generator set. These difficulties are discussed and various approaches, including a twin diesel system, are presented. The role of energy storage is examined, both to deal with operational problems and to improve wind-energy utilization. An example of battery storage is developed in some detail. A summary and actual installations and their performance is included to highlight some of the problems, and indicate the approaches being taken to deal with them.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATIONS - Equipment; WIND/DIESEL SYSTEMS; Wind turbines

Authors: Arnould M., Deveughele M., Efforsat J.
Title: Using old underground quarries in paris area for interseasonal storage of solar energy, for housing [Utilisation de carrieres souterraines de la region parisienne pour stockage intersaisonnier d'energie solaire pour l'habitat]
Source title: Bulletin of the International Association of Engineering Geology - Bulletin de l'Association Internationale de Géologie de l'Ingénieur
Affiliations: Centre de Géologie de l'Ingénieur commun à l'Ecole Nationale des Ponts et Chaussées et à l'Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines de Paris, Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines de Paris, 60 Boulevard Saint Michel, Paris cedex, 75272, France
Authors with affiliations: Arnould, M., Centre de Géologie de l'Ingénieur commun à l'Ecole Nationale des Ponts et Chaussées et à l'Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines de Paris, Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines de Paris, 60 Boulevard Saint Michel, Paris cedex, 75272, France; Deveughele, M., Centre de Géologie de l'Ingénieur commun à l'Ecole Nationale des Ponts et Chaussées et à l'Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines de Paris, Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines de Paris, 60 Boulevard Saint Michel, Paris cedex, 75272, France; Efforsat, J., Centre de Géologie de l'Ingénieur commun à l'Ecole Nationale des Ponts et Chaussées et à l'Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines de Paris, Ecole Nationale Supérieure des Mines de Paris, 60 Boulevard Saint Michel, Paris cedex, 75272, France
Abstract: La ville de Paris et sa banlieue comportent de nombreuses anciennes carrières souterraines. Elles posent des problèmes de stabilité du sol et provoquent même des effondrements. On a cherché à les consolider tout en les utilisant pour stocker de l'eau chauffée par des capteurs solaires en vue du chauffage de bâtiments. Une étude fine, à l'aide d'un modèle par différences finies, des transferts thermiques dans le stock d'eau non isolé met en évidence la participation du massif rocheux encaissant à la fonction de stockage. Un tel projet semble faisable à condition d'exploiter le stock à un niveau thermique bas (environ 30°C) avec l'aide d'une pompe à chaleur. © 1983, International Association of Engineering Geology. All rights reserved.

Title: Optimum mass flow rate of water in a flat plate solar collector coupled with a storage tank and an organic Rankine cycle power loop
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, King Abdulaziz University, P.O. Box # 9027, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Eldighidy, S.M., Mechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, King Abdulaziz University, P.O. Box # 9027, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia; Taha, I.S., Mechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, King Abdulaziz University, P.O. Box # 9027, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: The optimum flat plate solar collector operation for maximizing solar organic Rankine cycle work output is investigated. A mathematical model for the flat plate solar collector water system integrated with a solar storage tank and an organic Rankine cycle loop is developed. The mass flow rate of water is searched for to obtain the maximum net work output from the integrated system during 1 yr of operation. Curve fittings of thermodynamic properties of some chosen organic fluids (R-11, R-21 and R-113) are derived for computer use. The Hooke and Jeeves optimization technique is used to determine the optimum mass flow rate of water in the collector for different values of collector inner tube diameters and boiler heat transfer coefficient-area product. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE; FLOW OF WATER; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; SOLAR ENERGY; SOLAR RADIATION

Title: Proton upsets in orbit
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C., United States
Authors with affiliations: Bendel, W.L., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C., United States; Petersen, E.L., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C., United States
Abstract: This paper presents a method of predicting proton-induced single event upset rates in spacecraft RAMs. The approach uses a sensitivity parameter A, determined from one or more experimental measurements of upset cross sections made at any proton energy above threshold. Parameter A uniquely determines a curve for the energy dependence of the upset cross section. This curve can be combined with the proton spectrum at the RAM to predict its upset rate. Predicted upset rates for 600 circular orbits are presented. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: RADIATION EFFECTS; SPACECRAFT; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL

Authors: Wood R.J., Baldwin D.T., O'Callaghan P.W., Probert S.D.
Title: A survey of the industrial potential for thermal energy storage systems
Affiliations: Applied Energy Group, School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Cranfield, Bedford, MK43 0AL England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wood, R.J., Applied Energy Group, School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Cranfield, Bedford, MK43 0AL England, United Kingdom; Baldwin, D.T., Applied Energy Group, School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Cranfield, Bedford, MK43 0AL England, United Kingdom; O'Callaghan, P.W., Applied Energy Group, School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Cranfield, Bedford, MK43 0AL England, United Kingdom; Probert, S.D., Applied Energy Group, School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield Institute of Technology, Cranfield, Bedford, MK43 0AL England, United Kingdom
Abstract: The opportunities for energy conservation through the application of storage cascades has not previously been examined in sufficient detail to enable the overall technical and economic potential to be estimated. The objective of the research reported here, is the evaluation of this potential for U.K. industry. A detailed survey of a representative sample frame of U.K. industry has shown that the technical and economic potential represents about 1% of the total energy use in the manufacturing sector of the U.K. economy. Using technical constraints based on achievable power densities for a variety of storage technologies and economic constraints based on annual charge cycle frequencies, the feasible percentage of processes has been established for a variety of storage technologies. These results have been scaled using the 1980 reference energy use as a function of process operating temperature. Final scaling of the results to determine the U.K. industrial potential for storage cascades was obtained by evaluating the probability of two or more 'on-site' process cascade matches. The highest probability of a satisfactory cascade match occurs in the temperature range 100°C < T < 250°C. Steam accumulators appear to be able to contribute most to industrial energy conservation in intermittent processes. New generations of storage technology are far less significant. © 1983.
Index Keywords: TURBOMACHINERY - Cascades; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Israel's Dead Sea project ( HEP generation).

Abstract: The background to this feasibility study is that energy supply is precarious, with almost total dependence on oil imports, no coal resources, difficulties with nuclear power, and struggles to regain leadership in solar energy R & D. The 400 m fall from the Mediterranean to the Dead Sea, first noted for potential HEP generation in 1896, is currently being evaluated. Raises important environmental issues in the selection of a route for the conduit. Details three estimates of economic feasibility. Additional applications exist along at least one route, the recommended Qatif - Massada alignment. These include storage of solar energy, the cooling of inland power stations, artificial lakes, and desalination. -A.F.Pitty

Title: EFFECTS OF RADIATIVE DIFFUSION ON THE SPIN-FLIP IN ELECTRON STORAGE RINGS.
Authors with affiliations: Yokoya, Kaoru
Abstract: A radiative polarization process in storage rings polarizes electrons in a definite direction determined by the location of the particles in the ring and by the structure of the ring. From the experimental point of view, it is desired to change the direction of the electron spins as easily as possible. It is known that in a ring with low beam energy the spin can be flipped by imposing a perturbation resonating with the spin motion. In high-energy rings, however, the effect of the synchrotron radiation becomes important in the above spin-flip process. This effect is quantitatively estimated in the present paper, together with the effect of synchrotron oscillations which exists in proton rings as well. The results are summarized in a few formulae suitable for designing the spin-flipping devices.
Index Keywords: RADIATIVE DIFFUSION; SPIN FLIP; SYNCHROTRON RADIATION; Accelerators, Electron ring

Title: Scaling of gamma dose rate upset threshold in high density memories
Affiliations: Rome Air Development Center, Solid State Sciences Division, Hanscom AFB, MA, 01731, United States; Mission Research Corporation, 5434 Ruffin Road, San Diego, CA, 92123, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vail, P.J., Rome Air Development Center, Solid State Sciences Division, Hanscom AFB, MA, 01731, United States, Mission Research Corporation, 5434 Ruffin Road, San Diego, CA, 92123, United States; Burke, E.A., Rome Air Development Center, Solid State Sciences Division, Hanscom AFB, MA, 01731, United States
Abstract: Pulsed gamma upset threshold for high density RAMs is explored using constant field scaling rules. The analysis indicates that the upset threshold for DRAMs will not decrease with increased levels of integration and may improve relative to present technology. Potential improvement may be limited by statistical effects in gamma energy deposition. It is shown that statistical effects are magnified both by the increasing number of memory cells on a chip and by their extremely small feature size. Extreme value statistical techniques are used to determine worst-case cell memory loss. The paper also presents parallels of pulsed gamma and single event upset (SEU) effects that may be useful in SEU hardness assurance for VLSI memories. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: GAMMA RAYS; RADIATION EFFECTS; DATA STORAGE, DIGITAL

Authors: Wood R.J., Baldwin D.T., O'Callaghan P.W., Probert S.D.
Title: ENERGY CASCADING COMBINED WITH THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE IN INDUSTRY.
Source title: Commission of the European Communities, (Report) EUR
Affiliations: Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl, Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Wood, R.J., Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl, Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl; Baldwin, D.T., Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl, Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl; O'Callaghan, P.W., Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl, Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl; Probert, S.D., Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl, Cranfield Inst of Technology, Cranfield, Engl
Abstract: The opportunities for energy conservation through the application of storage cascades has not previously been examined in sufficient detail to enable the overall technical and economic potential to be estimated. The objective of the research reported here, is the evaluation of this potential for UK industry. Using technical constraints based on achievable power densities for a variety of storage technologies and economic constraints based on annual charge cycle frequencies, the feasible percentage of processes has been established for each storage technology. Steam accumulators appear to be able to contribute most to industrial energy conservation in intermittent processes.
Index Keywords: HEAT EXCHANGERS - Regenerators; STEAM ACCUMULATORS - Design; HOT WATER STORAGE; POWER DENSITY; STEAM STORAGE; STORAGE CASCADES; Industrial plants

Title: The structure of guppy life histories: the tradeoff between growth and reproduction.
Affiliations: Dept. of Biol., Univ. of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19104, USA., United States
Authors with affiliations: Reznick, D., Dept. of Biol., Univ. of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19104, USA., United States
Abstract: One experiment compares the growth of reproducing and nonreproducing sibling Poecilia reticulata raised on controlled levels of food availability. Nonreproducing females have significantly more energy in somatic tissues. The bulk of this energy is in fat tissues. Standard length and 'protein' do not differ significantly. The extra energy in nonreproducers is therefore devoted predominantly to energy storage, as opposed to somatic growth. Most of the energy 'saved' by not reproducing does not appear in somatic tissues. The cause of this loss is unknown. A 2nd experiment compares the somatic growth of different stocks of Trinidadian guppies which had previously been demonstrated to devote different quantities of energy to reproduction. Increases in the amount of energy devoted to reproduction were matched by decreases in the energy devoted to somatic tissues. All stocks have equal total production. These fish are therefore equally efficient in converting food into biomass but differ in how this biomass is allocated to growth and reproduction. -from Author
Index Keywords: Poecilia reticulata; reproductive effort.

Title: A first approximation of the energetics of Cape sugarbirds ( Promerops cafer) and orange-breasted sunbirds ( Nectarinia violacea).
Affiliations: Percy Fitzpatrick Inst of African Ornithology, Univ of Cape Town, Cape Town, South Africa., South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Collins, B.G., Percy Fitzpatrick Inst of African Ornithology, Univ of Cape Town, Cape Town, South Africa., South Africa
Abstract: Estimated expenditures vary througout the day, with highest rates occurring during the morning when nectar availability is greatest. Energy storage needed to satisfy overnight requirements by these nectarivores probably occurs only during the morning, with deficits being incurred at other times, although ingestion of insects may help to reduce these deficits. Male and female P. cafer are frequently territorial, showing a clear preference for foraging at partially opened inflorescences of Mimetes hirtus, Smaller male N. violacea are usually excluded from M. hirtus and obliged to forage on less rewarding Erica perspicua.-Author
Index Keywords: Erica perspicua; Mimetes hirtus; nectarivorous birds

Title: Energetics and growth patterns of three tropical bird species.
Affiliations: Dept Biology, Univ of Stirling, Stirling FK9 4 LA, UK., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bryant, D.M., Dept Biology, Univ of Stirling, Stirling FK9 4 LA, UK., United Kingdom; Hails, C.J., Dept Biology, Univ of Stirling, Stirling FK9 4 LA, UK., United Kingdom
Abstract: Energy budgets and growth data are presented for nestlings of the tropical insectivores white-bellied swiftlets Collocalia esculenta, blue-throated bee-eaters Merops viridis and Pacific swallows Hirundo tahitica. The peak energy demand in this tropical sample averaged c605 of temperate counterparts. Savings are attributed to slow growth rates, reduced thermoregulatory requirements, a low resting metabolism (in swallows only), asynchronous hatching (in bee-eaters), and low nestling activity levels. Patterns of energy storage as lipid in nestlings of the three species were similar to the pattern in temperate swallows (Hirundinidae) and swifts (Apodidae), with those species feeding at the greatest heights, and hence on the most unpredictable supplies, storing the most fat while in the nest.-from Authors
Index Keywords: Apodidae; bee eater; blue throated; Collocalia esculenta; Hirundinidae; Hirundo tahitica; Merops viridis; Pacific; swallow; swiftlet; white bellied; Apodidae; Apoidea; Aves; Collocalia esculenta; Hirundinidae; Hirundo tahitica; Merops viridis

Title: The NTS test bed for novel HVAC systems evaluation
Authors with affiliations: Edelstein, A.; Lieberman, P.
Abstract: A novel test bed has been constructed which is capable of testing heating, ventilating and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems to save peak power and/or energy. This paper describes the test bed, and also a particular HVAC system that is currently undergoing evaluation. The HVAC system includes a hydronic heat pump, pre-cool and pre-heat heat exchange coil, heat exchange coil to service a chilled water storage tank, and chilled water storage tank. The test bed includes an air flow system, water flow system, electrical power, and instrumentation that is sufficiently general to evaluate HVAC systems for energy savings when loaded by prescribed latent heat, sensitive heat and chilled air sources.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Testing; Energy conservation; HEATING - Testing; VENTILATION - Testing; Heat pump systems; air conditioning; nonhuman; prevention

Title: SOLAR-ASSISTED HEAT PUMP IN USE.
Authors with affiliations: Suter, Jean-Marc; Valenti, Pietro
Abstract: Results in service are discussed of a solar-assisted ground-coupled heat pump in a house in central Switzerland north of the Alps. The solar collectors are the unglazed, low-temperature type. The system was found to work reasonably well in the local climate, although storage losses and the parasitic electrical power of the auxiliary equipment could usefully be reduced. Measured seasonal coefficient of performance, including the power losses, worked out at 2. 4. Preliminary results from other systems are briefly mentioned for comparison, but no comparison with theory or economic analysis is made for the system. However, there are important inferences to be drawn on the climatic dependence of the configuration of such systems and on sensitive factors which must be considered at design.
Index Keywords: METEOROLOGY - Climatology; Solar energy; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; Heat pump systems

Title: CHALLENGE OF NEW TECHNOLOGY.
Authors with affiliations: Krall, H.A.
Abstract: The lecture covers forecasting and long-range planning, the development of production processes, continuous casting of cast iron, robot and sensor technology, fiber manufacture, recycling, computer aided design of gravity diecasting molds, energy storage technology, microprocessors and future prospects.
Index Keywords: Steel foundry practice; Iron foundry practice

Title: Design of Co-Conversion Facility of Pu-U Nitrate Solution to Mixed Oxide Powder using Microwave Heating Direct Denitration Method
Source title: Journal of the Atomic Energy Society of Japan / Atomic Energy Society of Japan
Affiliations: wer Reactor & Nucl., Fuel Development Corp., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Oshima, H., wer Reactor & Nucl., Fuel Development Corp., Japan; Naruki, K., wer Reactor & Nucl., Fuel Development Corp., Japan
Abstract: Power Reactor and Nuclear Fuel Development Corp. (PNC) has developed the co-conversion process of Pu-U nitrate solution to the mixed oxide powder using the microwave heating direct denitration method and has designed the co-conversion facility at Tokai Works, PNC. The capacity of this facility is 10 kg(Pu+U)/d and the facility is consisted of the following processes: Pu&U receiving, Conversion, Powder treatment, Powder storage, Waste treatment and Analytical laboratory, etc. To keep personnel exposure as low as practical, main process equipment is designed to be remotely controlled and new type of glove box with shielding materials (lead and polyethylene containing boron) is developed. And other safety consideration, e.g. criticality safety, ventilation system, safeguard for nuclear materials, are taken into account to the facility design. © 1983, Atomic Energy Society of Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: co-conversion facility; criticality; direct denitration; fuel cycle facility; glove box; microwave heating; mixed oxide powder; nuclear safety; Plutonium; plutonium conversion; remote operation; safety design; storage; uranium
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL OPERATIONS; PLUTONIUM AND ALLOYS; CO-CONVERSION PROCESS; NUCLEAR SAFETY, MIXED OXIDE POWDER; NUCLEAR FUELS

Authors: Boyd D.W., Buckley O.E., Clark Jr. C.E.
Title: ASSESSMENT OF MARKET POTENTIAL OF COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Authors with affiliations: Boyd, D.W.; Buckley, O.E.; Clark Jr., C.E.
Abstract: Extensive sensitivity analyses are conducted to determine the variables having the largest impact on the potential market for CAES. The market projections indicate that if the utility operating environment improves, there will be significant market potential for CAES systems.
Index Keywords: Compressed air

Title: SUBSURFACE GEOLOGIC CONSIDERATIONS IN SITING AN UNDERGROUND PUMPED-HYDRO PROJECT.
Authors with affiliations: Coates, M.S.
Abstract: Geologic criteria for underground pumped-hydro (UPH) facilities require massive homogeneous rock, with minimal stratigraphic or structural weakness, low permeability, superior stability, and acceptable in situ stress relationships. In northern Illinois, only Precambrian granite fulfills these qualifications. A variety of geologic and geophysical methods was utilized to identify and confirm areas of shallowest Precambrian basement, where construction difficulties in the overlying water-bearing sedimentary strata would be minimized. Three deep core holes were extensively tested. The results show that the granite meets the criteria required for siting a UPH project. Additional core research and down-hole testing were performed subsequently by the academic community.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; GEOLOGY - Subcrustal; POWER PLANTS - Site Selection; Hydroelectric power plants; pumped; storage

Title: IN SITU STRESS MEASUREMENT AND DESIGN GUIDELINES FOR COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE/UNDERGROUND PUMPED-HYDRO EXCAVATIONS.
Authors with affiliations: O'Rourke, J.E.; Smith, R.E.
Abstract: This paper focuses on past experience with conditions of in situ rock stress and their effects on underground excavations and presents relevant guidelines for the designers of underground pumped hydro or compressed air energy storage projects. An overview is given on what is known of magnitudes and directions of in situ rock stress from some worldwide field measurement data. The geological engineering experience in designing underground excavations for in situ stress conditions recommended from extensive practice in Norway is described. Field examples are taken from U. S. underground construction and mining that verify some principles found in Norwegian practice. Hydrofracturing and overcoring for in situ stress measurements are then described and costs are discussed.
Index Keywords: COMPRESSED AIR - Storage; Energy storage; Excavation; POWER PLANTS - Underground; STRESSES - Measurements; Hydroelectric power plants

Title: ANALYTICAL SIMULATION OF THE CHAMPAGNE EFFECT IN CAES POWER PLANTS.
Authors with affiliations: Giramonti, A.J.; Smith, E.B.
Abstract: The champagne effect is a two-phase flow instability that could occur in a hydraulically compensated compressed air energy storage (CAES) power plant. The governing physical mechanisms of the champagne effect have been incorporated into a computer simulation model. The model is based on a one-dimensional, drift flux representation of the two-phase flow in the water compensating shaft. The model includes a comprehensive simulation for the rate of release of air from solution during the flow transient. Preliminary results of the analysis suggest that by proper design of the system, including a U-bend and flow restriction, the champagne effect should not be a major deterrent to the commercialization of this type of CAES power plant.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; POWER PLANTS - Underground; CAES; CHAMPAGNE EFFECT; COMPRESSED AIR ENERGY STORAGE; Compressed air

Title: EFFECTS OF CYCLING AN AIR-WATER INTERFACE IN ST. PETER SANDSTONE.
Authors with affiliations: Pujol-Rius, Alberto; Pincus, Howard J.
Abstract: The properties of the rocks tested in the system were compared to the properties of uncycled control specimens. Rock properties investigated included compressive strength, Young's modulus, permeability, porosity, and fabric. No significant changes were found to be associated with air-water cycling. These laboratory results correspond to those from earlier studies on the same rock. The St. Peter Sandstone appears to be a good candidate for reservoir rock.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; CAES; Compressed air

Title: STORAGE OPTIONS FOR HARNESSING WIND ENERGY.
Authors with affiliations: Ramakumar, R.
Abstract: Barriers to large-scale use of wind energy stem from its inherent variability and the capital-intensive nature of the hardware necessary for its effective use. Although the wind resource in a region is relatively consistent on an annual basis, it is however, highly variable, site-specific, and terrain-specific. It has instantaneous, minute-by-minute, hourly, diurnal, and seasonal variations. Various energy storage and reconversion options are possible. Energy storage decouples the input and the output energy rates of an energy system. Energy can be stored in mechanical, chemical, thermal, or electrical (electro-magnetic) form. The type of end-use of the energy will determine the suitability of the different possible energy storage and reconversion options.
Index Keywords: Electric power distribution; Wind power

Authors: Panahi Z., Batty J.C., Riley J.P.
Title: Numerical simulation of the performance of a salt-gradient solar pond
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Desert Research Institute, Energy Systems Center, Boulder City, NV, 89005, United States; College of Engineering, Utah State University, Logan, UT, 84322, United States
Authors with affiliations: Panahi, Z., Desert Research Institute, Energy Systems Center, Boulder City, NV, 89005, United States; Batty, J.C., College of Engineering, Utah State University, Logan, UT, 84322, United States; Riley, J.P., College of Engineering, Utah State University, Logan, UT, 84322, United States
Abstract: A one-dimensional mathematical model which simulates the dynamic performance of stratified solar brine ponds is described. The model simulates the upper convective zone, the middle nonconvective zone, and the lower convective zone. In addition to the energy flux, the model simulates the varying brine densities as a function of temperature and salt concentration, and thus is able to examine various pond stability criteria. On the basis of model operational studies, the following results are presented: (i) a study of overall pond efficiency in terms of the upper convective layer; (ii) an optimization study of the thickness of the nonconvective zone in terms of net energy transmission to the lower convective zone; (iii) an investigation of the heat storage efficiency and of the overall pond efficiency as a function of pond loading rate for a particular depth of storage zone. © 1983 by ASME.
Index Keywords: MATHEMATICAL MODELS; WATER RESOURCES - Mathematical Models; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Penman J., Fraser J.R., Smith J.R., Grieve M.D.
Title: Complementary energy methods in the computation of electrostatic fields
Affiliations: Department of Engineering, University of Aberdeen, Marischal College, Aberdeen, AB9 1AS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Penman, J., Department of Engineering, University of Aberdeen, Marischal College, Aberdeen, AB9 1AS, United Kingdom; Fraser, J.R., Department of Engineering, University of Aberdeen, Marischal College, Aberdeen, AB9 1AS, United Kingdom; Smith, J.R., Department of Engineering, University of Aberdeen, Marischal College, Aberdeen, AB9 1AS, United Kingdom; Grieve, M.D., Department of Engineering, University of Aberdeen, Marischal College, Aberdeen, AB9 1AS, United Kingdom
Abstract: It is shown how complementary energy methods can be applied to problems involving the calculation of electrostatic fields. The results obtained using such methods provide error bounded solutions to the system energy, and may be compared with those found through application of the conventional finite element method. To illustrate the technique the classical problem of a cylindrical tank, half filled with a charged liquid, is investigated. Comparisons are made on the basis of computer C.P.U. time, and core storage requirements, for a given degree of accuracy in total system energy. The question of local error in primary field quantities is also examined. © 1983 IEEE
Index Keywords: ELECTROSTATIC FIELDS; ELECTRIC FIELDS

Title: 2 D - Computation problems in magnetic recording and printing
Affiliations: CII HONEYWELL BULL, Les Clayes sous Bois, Clayes sous Bois, France
Authors with affiliations: Tual, J.-P., CII HONEYWELL BULL, Les Clayes sous Bois, Clayes sous Bois, France
Abstract: The appearance of both new principles and new technologies in the field of magnetic recording and printing, (perpendicular recording, thin film heads and layers.) leads to more and more complex associated computing and design tools. From the magnetic point of view, anisotropic and/or hysteresis phenomena are crucial here. The numerical and physical formulation of such problems is not easy and has not been totally explored up to now. Many other numerical problems can become very critical in the complete simulation of a whole recording structure, such as a head-disc couple: fluid mechanics problems (stabilisation of the flight of the head at 0.2 m over the disc), signal theory (peakshift, diaphony …) etc. We will here limit ourselves to the magnetic aspects: as regards computation, the finite element methods coupled with the minimum energy principle are systematically used. Tools and results in computing and designing magnetic structures are presented at the end of this paper. © 1983 IEEE
Index Keywords: MAGNETIC PRINTING; MAGNETIC RECORDING; DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC

Title: COAL-FIRED CAES SYSTEM USING FLUIDIZED BED COMBUSTION.
Authors with affiliations: Moskowitz, S.; Schaeffer, R.
Abstract: Utility requirements for peaking power can be addressed with coal through the unique marriage of the compressed air energy storage and fluidized bed combustion technologies. This paper discusses the results of an evaluation of a pressurized fluidized bed combustion system at air storage pressures from 27 to 68 atm. A conceptual design of the PFBC configuration in a CAES system is presented. Major components of the system are identified as either state-of-the-art or requiring further R&D. The performance of the compressed air energy storage system with an efficiency of 83. 4% (based on coal input energy) is presented. The effects of recovery of rejected heat are discussed also.
Index Keywords: COMBUSTION - Fluidized Beds; Energy storage; Compressed air

Title: Wake force computation in time and frequency domain for cylindrically symmetric structures excited by bunches of electrons at the speed of light
Affiliations: Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron DESY, Notkestr. 85, D–2000 Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Weiland, T., Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron DESY, Notkestr. 85, D–2000 Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: In high energy electron/positron accelerators and storage rings intense bunches of charged particles pass cylindrically symmetric structures at almost the speed of light. These charges excite electromagnetic self fields having in general all six components. The induced fields produce highly nonlinear self forces in all three spatial directions which do limit the performance of most of existing and planned high energy machines. Two complementary approaches are presented for the computation of the electromagnetic fields in either time or frequency domain by means of a mesh method allowing for arbitrarily. shaped geometries. Results of these computer codes represent a key element in analysis and prediction of performance for future high energy facilities. © 1983 IEEE
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS

Title: A TRNSYS/GROCS simulation of the TECH house I ground-coupled series solar-assisted heat pump system
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department, Energy, Environment, and Resources Center, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, United States; Carolina Power and Light Co., United States; Mechanical and Industrial Engineering Dept., University of Texas, El Paso, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roeder, D.J., Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department, Energy, Environment, and Resources Center, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, United States, Carolina Power and Light Co., United States; Reid, R.L., Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department, Energy, Environment, and Resources Center, University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, United States, Mechanical and Industrial Engineering Dept., University of Texas, El Paso, United States
Abstract: The series solar-assisted heat pump heating system with ground-coupled storage in The University of Tennessee’s TECH House I in Knoxville, Tennessee, has been modeled using TRNSYS/GROCS and was compared to the experimental performance for the 1980-81 heating season. The simulation results were within 8 percent of the experimental measurements. Both simulation and experimental results showed that ground coupling of thermal storage led to the elimination of electric resistance backup heat and a large reduction in the peak heating demand of the house. Results of a parametric study showed that, in general, a ground-coupled storage tank performs better than a storage tank placed outdoors in the Knoxville area. Application of a next generation heat pump resulted in the most significant impact on the seasonal performance factor. As expected, higher performance collectors and larger collector areas led to higher system seasonal performance. An economic analysis showed that the series solar heat pump system cannot economically compete with the stand-alone heat pump system in the Knoxville area. © 1983 by ASME.
Index Keywords: COMPUTERS - Applications; METEOROLOGY; SOLAR ENERGY; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS

Authors: Lugtu R.L., Marcus J., Parker R.M., Snyder K.D., Wavrek S.J., Merrick B.W.
Title: The Ohio edison energy control center
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Power Apparatus and Systems
Affiliations: Harris Corporation, Controls Division, Melbourne, Florida, United States; Ohio Edison Company, Akron, Ohio, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lugtu, R.L., Harris Corporation, Controls Division, Melbourne, Florida, United States; Marcus, J., Harris Corporation, Controls Division, Melbourne, Florida, United States; Parker, R.M., Harris Corporation, Controls Division, Melbourne, Florida, United States; Snyder, K.D., Ohio Edison Company, Akron, Ohio, United States; Wavrek, S.J., Ohio Edison Company, Akron, Ohio, United States; Merrick, B.W., Ohio Edison Company, Akron, Ohio, United States
Abstract: The Ohio Edison Company is implementing a new Energy Control Center for its System Dispatch Office (SDO) to perform Economic Dispatch and Automatic Generation Control, Data Acquisition and Supervisory Control of its transmission system and Advanced Security Assessment. The system being implemented consists of 4 computers coupled by redundant banks of shared memory which serve as the medium for data base storage and for inter-CPU communications. The system load is shared by the various CPUs through a hierarchial, distributed processing architecture. The paper discusses the architectural highlights of the system, features of the man-machine interface and the various application functions performed as called for the SDO. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER NETWORKS - Local Networks; COMPUTERS - Data Communication Equipment; CONTROL EQUIPMENT - Computer Applications; SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS - Man Machine Systems; POWER CONTROL CENTERS; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: EXPERIMENTAL MODEL OF BUBBLE FORMATION IN CAES PLANTS.
Authors with affiliations: Vann, R.D.; Feezor, M.D.
Abstract: Very little experimental data are available on the evolution of bubbles in depressurized liquids. The object of this Note is to develop such data using an experimental model. Using this model the effects on bubble formation of saturation pressure, temperature, gas solubility, pressurization and depressurization rates, water flow rate, and other parameters will be evaluated. This Note reports on the preliminary findings of these investigations.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; LIQUIDS - Bubble Formation; CAES; Compressed air

Title: Short-Pulse Grating Formation in Photorefractive Materials
Affiliations: Hughes Research Laboratories, Malibu, CA 90265, United States
Authors with affiliations: Valley, G.C., Hughes Research Laboratories, Malibu, CA 90265, United States
Abstract: Solutions are obtained for the refractive index grating in a photorefractive material in which the writing or erasing beams are short-pulse (less than tens of nanoseconds), high-irradiance (greater than kW/cm2) lasers. The response of the photorefractive material is mod eled using the continuity equation for the charge carriers, a rate equa tion for the ions, a current equation, and Poisson's equation for the space charge field. Two cases are discussed in detail: 1) the time for re combination of carriers with ions is much less than the pulse length of the laser; and 2) the recombination, drift, and diffusion times are all much longer than the pulse length. The energy requirements for short-pulse writing and erasing are greater than or equal to those obtained for typical CW lasers in all cases investigated. Application to previous ob servations in BaTiO3, Bi12SiO20, and LiNbO3 is discussed. © 1983 IEEE
Index Keywords: BARIUM COMPOUNDS; BISMUTH COMPOUNDS; LITHIUM COMPOUNDS; PHOTOREFRACTIVE MATERIALS; DATA STORAGE, OPTICAL

Title: AC INDUCTION MOTOR DRIVE SYSTEMS FOR ELECTRIC VEHICLES.
Source title: Transactions of the Institution of Professional Engineers New Zealand, Electrical/Mechanical/Chemi
Authors with affiliations: Byers, David J.
Abstract: The development of variable speed ac induction motor drive systems for electric vehicles, carried out at the University of Canterbury, Great Britain, is outlined. Optimal current as well as voltage control strategies are discussed, both from the point of view of operating the induction motor at maximum efficiency over the entire speed and torque ranges of the motor and of reducing harmonic power losses within the motor. The need to conserve the battery's minimal store of energy is seen to be the major constraint in electric vehicle design so, for optimal vehicle performance, it is shown that vehicle power demands must be minimized and drive system efficiency contours must be carefully matched to the anticipated vehicle power demands. It is shown that the output characteristics of the rugged and reliable controlled ac induction motor drive system are eminently suitable for the role of electric vehicle drive system and this high performance system seems likely to form the basis of electric vehicle drive systems in the future.
Index Keywords: Electric motors, AC; Electric motors, Induction; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Title: EXPERIMENTAL FACILITY FOR THE INVESTIGATION OF THE TWO-DIMENSIONAL STEFAN PROBLEM.
Authors with affiliations: Schneider, G.E.; Kaptein, M.
Abstract: An experimental facility which can be used to provide detailed temperature field measurements of a phase change material experiencing two-dimensional energy transport is described. With particular attention given to the resolution of difficulties encountered in the fabrication of the facility and in the execution of the experimental program. In addition, new experimental results are given for a specific geometric configuration for the eicosane-aluminum material combination for a variety of heating rates.
Index Keywords: Heat transfer; Energy storage

Title: Natural convection with coupled mass transfer in porous media
Source title: International Communications in Heat and Mass Transfer
Affiliations: Division of Energy Technology Commonwealth Scientific Industrial, Research Organization Highett, Vic. 3190, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Close, D.J., Division of Energy Technology Commonwealth Scientific Industrial, Research Organization Highett, Vic. 3190, Australia
Abstract: For certain types of packed beds used for thermal energy storage, high discharge rates can be achieved if the effective conductance is increased over that achievable with stagnant gases and liquids. A packed bed containing a fluid mixture with one condensing component and with the fluid mixture simultaneously convecting may achieve the required high conductances. An analogy has been developed with a similar system with no coupled mass transfer. It provides some useful insights into the role of gas/vapour mixture properties on the effective conductivity of such systems, and suggests that very large increases in effective conductivity are achievable. © 1983.
Index Keywords: FLOW OF FLUIDS - Packed Beds; HEATING - Heat Storage; MASS TRANSFER - Efficiency; THERMAL STORAGE; HEAT TRANSFER

Authors: Blum S.E., Brown K.H., Srinivasan R., von Gutfeld R.J.
Title: ARCHIVAL STORAGE WITH UV LASERS.
Authors with affiliations: Blum, S.E.; Brown, K.H.; Srinivasan, R.; von Gutfeld, R.J.
Abstract: This article describes the use of UV light with a laser for the purpose of ablating polymers either self-supporting or deposited on substrates to form a read-only memory with the patterns created in the polymers. The short wavelength permits a smaller spot to be formed, so a larger bit density can be achieved. A lower energy density is required to write data because bond-breaking (which is the mechanism of ablation used) requires less energy than the usual writing process.
Index Keywords: LASER BEAMS - Applications; UV LASERS; Data storage, Digital

Title: NUMERICAL STUDY OF PHASE CHANGE ENERGY TRANSPORT IN TWO-DIMENSIONAL RECTANGULAR ENCLOSURES.
Authors with affiliations: Schneider, G.E.
Abstract: A computational model is presented for diffusion dominated, solid/liquid phase change energy storage within cells of rectangular cross section. A modified enthalpy model is employed, with flags used to identify the state of individual discrete control volumes. A novel computational procedure is used, and costs an order of magnitude lower than that required by conventional codes are the result.
Index Keywords: Energy storage

Title: DESIGN OF A REGENERATIVE HYDROSTATIC TRANSMISSION.
Authors with affiliations: Eleftherakis, J.G.; Maguire III, C.F.
Abstract: The authors studied the feasibility of propelling a car with a hydrostatic transmission and used mathematical models to establish parameters for vehicle requirements and transmission characteristics. The theoretical models also included an accumulator for energy recovery and storage as well as hydrodynamic braking and a preliminary control system.
Index Keywords: HYDRAULIC MACHINERY - Mathematical Models; Automobile transmissions

Authors: White M.S., Curtis M.L., Sarles R.L., Green D.W.
Title: EFFECTS OF OUTSIDE STORAGE ON THE ENERGY POTENTIAL OF HARDWOOD PARTICULATE FUELS: PART II. HIGHER AND NET HEATING VALUES.
Authors with affiliations: White, M.S.; Curtis, M.L.; Sarles, R.L.; Green, D.W.
Abstract: Higher heating values of the three fuels studied - hardwood whole-tree chips, bark, and sawdust - were relatively constant during the first 4 months of storage. By the end of the year, however, they declined by 9, 7, and 3 percent, respectively. These decreases coupled with increases in fuel MC resulted in significant declines in average net heating values. After 1 year of storage in 15-foot piles, average net heating values of whole-tree chips, sawdust, and bark declined by 24, 40, and 50 percent, respectively. Losses can be reduced by storing larger sized particles, increasing pile heights, and shortening storage cycles to 60 days or less.
Index Keywords: FUELS - Calorific Value; WOOD PRODUCTS - Storage; Wood

Title: A practical approach to the disposal of highly toxic and long-lived spent nuclear fuel waste between Venus and Earth
Affiliations: Space Global Co., 845 Lamplight Drive, La Jolla, CA 92037, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ehricke, K.A., Space Global Co., 845 Lamplight Drive, La Jolla, CA 92037, United States
Abstract: Extraterrestrial disposal, while not the only alternative (there is at least one very safe terrestrial method), nevertheless assures definite and irreversible removal of the most toxic and long-lived waste from the biosphere. In the foreseeable future, there is far less need to retrieve nuclear waste for later use then to dispose of it in a publicly acceptable manner, beginning in the near future (middle 1980s). It is, therefore, more important to assure safety in the weakest link of this disposal process-transportation into near-Earth orbit-than to engage in a retrievable disposal beyond Earth. The disposal "site" should lie at minimum safe transfer energy level. Primary candidate is the space between Venus and Earth. The number of propulsion phases should be a minimum, preferably only one (out of near-Earth orbit). Lunar gravity assist can be helpful to achieve higher inclination of the heliocentric orbit relative to the ecliptic. Solidified spent fuel isotopes and actinides, sufficient to reduce the residual terrestrial waste to the radiation level of natural uranium deposits after 30-40 yr instead of 1000-1500 yr, is deposited into heliocentric orbits. Transportation systems, requirements, costs and the associated socio-economic benefit potentials of an environmentally more benign and a more vigorous nuclear power generation program are presented. Prior to solidification, an interim storage of 10 yr, following removal from the reactor, may be required. The Shuttle, with one Orbiter modified as Nuclear Waste Carrying Orbiter (NWCO) and an out of near-Earth orbit booster, provides a safe and economic transportation system at (1979$) disposal mission costs from surface to disposal orbit of less than 0.5¢/kWhe or ≤ 0.1¢/kWhe (some 70% of overall exo-disposal cost), depending on level of orbital operations (this at basic Shuttle flight cost of $30M). The orbital operations mode can be selected according to lead time and costs, and can be advanced sequentially, lowering disposal costs while at the same time financing the development of orbital operations techniques needed also for other and larger-scale exo-industrial activities. An average of 10-15 disposal missions of the NWCO is required annually, at the given conditions, to service the spent fuel of 173 reactors 1978 in operation in W. Europe, Japan and North America. © 1983.
Index Keywords: EXTRATERRESTRIAL ATMOSPHERES - Waste Disposal; SPACE FLIGHT - Interplanetary Flight; NUCLEAR FUELS

Authors: Tuscher E., Weinzierl P., Eder O.J.
Title: Dynamic characteristics of single- and dual-hydride bed devices
Affiliations: Institut für Experimentalphysik der Universität Wien, Strudlhofgasse 4, A-1090 ViennaAustria; Physikinstitut Österreichisches Forschungszentrum, Seibersdorf, Lenaugasse 10, A-1080 ViennaAustria
Authors with affiliations: Tuscher, E., Institut für Experimentalphysik der Universität Wien, Strudlhofgasse 4, A-1090 ViennaAustria; Weinzierl, P., Institut für Experimentalphysik der Universität Wien, Strudlhofgasse 4, A-1090 ViennaAustria; Eder, O.J., Physikinstitut Österreichisches Forschungszentrum, Seibersdorf, Lenaugasse 10, A-1080 ViennaAustria
Abstract: Storage units containing LaNi4.6Al0.4 as hydrogen storage material were tested with regard to their dynamic behaviour in energy conversion systems. For hydrogen absorption of a single storage unit at 286 K, a half-reaction time of 90 s was found at a constant hydrogen pressure of 5.0 bar. The dynamic "quasi-isotherms" showed an increasing hysteresis with increasing hydrogen sorption rates. In a dual-hydride bed assembly (chemical compressor) the hydrogen flow, the total hydrogen flow and the hydrogen pressure were measured at various half-cycle times with water at 286 and 353 K. The calculation of the operating characteristics of such a system based on the experimental data shows that the efficiency of energy conversion decreases with increasing hydrogen flow. © 1983.
Index Keywords: HYDROGEN - Storage; INTERMETALLICS; HYDROGEN INORGANIC COMPOUNDS

Title: SYNTHESIS OF AN ACTIVE FLUTTER SUPPRESSION LAW BASED ON AN ENERGY CRITERION.
Authors with affiliations: Klein, A.F.
Abstract: Theory and results are presented which show that it is questionable to base a flutter suppression law, synthesized in terms of an energy dissipation criterion, entirely on aerodynamic data. It is shown that aileron mass balance and aileron/JACK impedance can adversely affect regions of stability which have been predicted using aerodynamic terms alone. Comments are also made which attempt to unify various cost functions which are used when either an energy dissipation or an energy dissipation and storage criterion is used in the formulation of flutter suppression laws.
Index Keywords: FLUID DYNAMICS - Theory; Aerodynamics

Authors: Kaushika N.D., Banerjee M.B., Katti Y.
Title: Honeycomb solar pond collector and storage system
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, ND-, 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Kaushika, N.D., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, ND-, 110016, India; Banerjee, M.B., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, ND-, 110016, India; Katti, Y., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, ND-, 110016, India
Abstract: An analysis of a honeycomb-stabilized, saltless solar pond as a solar energy collector and long term (spanning seasons) storage system is presented. The solar pond is considered with a nonconvective zone made up of an oil layer and air honeycomb configuration. A heat flow model is developed using the two loss mechanisms (conduction and radiation). The efficiency of heat collection and the storage characteristics of the system are excellent for hot water production and process heat applications. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Applications; HEAT TRANSFER - Mathematical Models; WATER HEATERS - Solar; SENSIBLE HEAT STORAGE; SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR RADIATION

Authors: Mitaru B.N., Reichert R.D., Blair R.
Title: Improvement of the nutritive value of high tannin sorghums for broiler chickens by high moisture storage (reconstitution).
Authors with affiliations: Mitaru, B.N.; Reichert, R.D.; Blair, R.
Abstract: Grains from three high and one low tannin sorghum cultivars were treated as follows: 1) untreated, no water was added, the dry grain had an average moisture content of 8% and 2) the moisture content of the grain was raised by adding 25% (w/w) distilled water to the grain. The treated grain was then stored for 10 or 20 days with a 2% level of acetic-propionic acid mixture (60/40, v/v) added to deter fungal growth. This treated grain was used in diets during a 3-week feeding trial with broiler chickens. High moisture storage (reconstitution) of high tannin sorghums decreased their extractable tannin content. Chickens fed diets containing these treated sorghums had improved weight grains (23 to 83 g) and feed efficiencies compared to birds fed diets containing the untreated grain. Treatment of low tannin sorghum did not improve weight gains. Reconstitution of high but not low tannin sorghums improved protein digestibility (6 to 16%) and dietary metabolizable energy (.1 to .3 kcal/g) for broiler chickens. There was a highly significant cultivar effect on leg scores, but the correlation between dietary tannin content and leg scores was low (r = .10), suggesting that tannin content was not a major factor in leg abnormality incidences shown. The improvement in weight grains, feed efficiencies, and protein digestibilities at 10 and 20 days storage periods was not different (P greater than .05), indicating that the benefits of high moisture storage were already obtained by 10 days.
Index Keywords: tannin derivative; water; animal; animal disease; article; bird disease; body weight; bone disease; cereal; chicken; energy metabolism; food handling; leg; metabolism; millet; nutritional value; protein intake; Animals; Body Weight; Bone Diseases; Cereals; Chickens; Dietary Proteins; Energy Metabolism; Food Handling; Leg; Nutritive Value; Panicum; Poultry Diseases; Tannins; Water; MLCS; MLOWN

Title: Database methods in power system control centres
Source title: International Journal of Electrical Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: Macro Corporation, 1260 Virginia Drive, Fort Washington, PA 19034, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lehman, R., Macro Corporation, 1260 Virginia Drive, Fort Washington, PA 19034, United States; Mattioni, J., Macro Corporation, 1260 Virginia Drive, Fort Washington, PA 19034, United States
Abstract: Historically, the electric power industry has used computer systems in energy control centres to monitor and control power system devices. Little heed was paid to the efficient management of the databases for evolving applications such as system security studies, extensive data storage and retrieval, and reporting functions. As these applications have grown in importance, however, vendors have developed and supplied ad hoc software for managing the databases, thereby increasing their practical usefulness. Current practices in database management are summarized and proposed approaches now in their early development stages are considered. © 1983.
Author Keywords: computer software; database management systems; electric power systems + control systems; energy control centres
Index Keywords: COMPUTER SOFTWARE; DATABASE SYSTEMS; ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: Exergy analysis of the influence of primary energy sources scenario on design and management of pumped-storage powerplants
Affiliations: Istituto di Fisica Tecnica, Facoltà di Ingegneria, Università di Roma, Via Eudossiana 18, 00184 Roma, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Spena, A., Istituto di Fisica Tecnica, Facoltà di Ingegneria, Università di Roma, Via Eudossiana 18, 00184 Roma, Italy
Abstract: A long-term comparison between ternary and binary units in pumped-storage powerplants is presented. We concentrate on technical and economic aspects relating to the efficiency of the storing cycle and the life expenditure of the machinery. Several scenarios of primary energy sources used in base-load electrical power generation are considered, and the corresponding marginal costs of the energy to be stored are taken into account. Our results agree with present industrial trends and also show that, in the future, wider use of nuclear power might reverse these trends. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ENERGY UTILIZATION - Analysis; PUMPED-STORAGE BINARY UNITS; PUMPED-STORAGE TERNARY UNITS; HYDROELECTRIC POWER PLANTS

Title: Net energy analysis of district solar heating with seasonal heat storage
Affiliations: Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, SF-02150 Espoo 15, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Lund, P.D., Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, SF-02150 Espoo 15, Finland; Kangas, M.T., Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, SF-02150 Espoo 15, Finland
Abstract: A net energy analysis of district solar heating using seasonal heat storage has been performed. The use of seasonal heat storage is of great importance in northern latitudes when the solar contribution is to be increased. Different system alternatives were considered. Net energy ratios for the most favourable options were found to be between 3 and 5. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Applications; ENERGY UTILIZATION - Analysis; HEAT PUMP SYSTEMS - Applications; SOLAR RADIATION - Collectors; NET ENERGY ANALYSIS; SOLAR DISTRICT HEATING; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; HEATING

Authors: Vogel Gregory A., Martin Edward J.
Title: ESTIMATING COSTS OF EQUIPMENT AND ACCESSORIES.
Authors with affiliations: Vogel, Gregory A.; Martin, Edward J.
Abstract: Because of the large variety of incinerators available for hazardous-waste destruction, the method of cost estimation that is presented has been formulated to cover many designs. Versatility is attained by providing estimates of the costs of facility components, including: waste-storage tanks, waste-loading system, incineration combustion chambers, energy recovery equipment, air-pollution-control system, and fluegas-handling unit. This paper shows how capital costs of waste-storage and waste-loading systems and combustion chambers in integrated facilities can be estimated from graphs relating costs to equipment size.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL PLANTS - Equipment; INDUSTRIAL WASTES - Storage; Nomograms; REFUSE DISPOSAL - Combustion; Refuse incinerators; Chemical equipment

Title: A Programmable Microcomputer-Based Sonar Echo Processor for Real-Time Processing
Affiliations: Geophysical and Polar Research Center, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Marine Studies Center, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Powell, L.A., Geophysical and Polar Research Center, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States; Stanton, T.K., Marine Studies Center, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: A programmable microcomputer-based sonar echo processor has been developed and field tested to process echo data in real time. The device was designed for use in fisheries acoustics and to analyze echoes from the sea floor. The instrument simultaneously performs the functions “echo integration” and “echo peak detection” on the sonar signal. The “echo integration” circuitry measures the relative acoustic energy of the echo while the “echo peak detection” electronics measure the probability density function (PDF) of the peak of the echo envelope. Each process is gated so the echoes may be processed in many short time intervals. In fisheries applications, estimates can be made of fish density (fish per unit volume), average backscattering cross section, and a combination of fish size and behavior. When using the device to analyze bottom echoes, it is possible to measure both the returned energy from the bottom sediment interfaces and the microrelief characteristics. The durability, flexibility, computer link, and floppy-disk data-storage features of the system are discussed. Data are presented of the processed echoes from biological organisms and the ocean bottom from a recent research cruise on the Atlantic Ocean near Cape Hatteras, NC. The biological results illustrated the organisms to be clearly divided into two separate spatial distributions-an observation not obvious from a standard echogram which was simultaneously used. The results from the bottom showed both 1) the difference In sub-bottom structure between two locations and 2) changes in microrelief of the water-bottom interface between another pair of locations. © 1983 SDAIEEE
Index Keywords: FISHERIES; OCEANOGRAPHY; SONAR

Title: PUMPED-STORAGE ON OFFER.
Authors with affiliations: Acker, Fabian
Abstract: More than 60 countries now use pumped-storage plants as a matter of course to operate their electrical systems more efficiently or more economically or more reliably than would otherwise be the case. The trend is clearly well established and it is useful to consider the arguments for adding pumped-storage to an electrical system (or increasing the exisiting capacity) and see what advances have been made in various plants around the world. Many elements of energy generation are leading to an increasing need to develop pumped-storage.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Costs; ENERGY STORAGE - Design; Pumping plants

Authors: Yonezawa Yoshiro, Okai Makoto, Ishino Masato, Hada Hiroshi
Title: PHOTOCHEMICAL STORAGE BATTERY WITH AN n-GaP PHOTOELECTRODE.
Source title: Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yonezawa, Yoshiro; Okai, Makoto; Ishino, Masato; Hada, Hiroshi
Abstract: The authors have constructed a photochemical storage battery with an n-GaP Photoelectrode. A two-compartment cell, n-GaP/aqueous K//3 left bracket Fe(CN//6 right bracket -K//4 left bracket Fe(CN)//6 vertical aqueous NiSO//4/Pt, is capable of being charged by the irradiation of the photoelectrode. The current efficiency of nickel deposition on the storage electrode was 80%. When the electrical energy was withdrawn from the battery the deposited nickel could act as Ni electrode in the Ni**2** plus solution. The power efficiency of storage battery amounted to about 2%. It was possible to recharge the battery more than five times after discharge.
Index Keywords: Electrodes; PHOTOCHEMICAL STORAGE BATTERY; PHOTOELECTRODE; Electric batteries

Authors: Enriquez-Granados M., Valentin G., Storck A.
Title: Electrochemical removal of silver using a three-dimensional electrode
Affiliations: Laboratoire des Sciences du Génie Chimique, CNRS-ENSIC, 1, rue Grandville, 54042 Nancy Cédex, France
Authors with affiliations: Enriquez-Granados, M., Laboratoire des Sciences du Génie Chimique, CNRS-ENSIC, 1, rue Grandville, 54042 Nancy Cédex, France; Valentin, G., Laboratoire des Sciences du Génie Chimique, CNRS-ENSIC, 1, rue Grandville, 54042 Nancy Cédex, France; Storck, A., Laboratoire des Sciences du Génie Chimique, CNRS-ENSIC, 1, rue Grandville, 54042 Nancy Cédex, France
Abstract: An electrolytic silver recovery cell using three-dimensional electrodes and operated under galvanostatic and potentiostatic conditions is described. The influence of most important hydrodynamic (electrolyte flow rate and residence time) and electrochemical (current intensity and electrode potential) parameters on the concentration-time relationship and current efficiency is presented. A theoretical model assuming a batch recirculation system allows determination of the current efficiency as a function of the silver concentration inside the fixing bath's storage tank and is found to be in excellent agreement with experimental results. Concentrations of about 1 p.p.m can be obtained with satisfactory current yield and energy consumption. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ELECTROCHEMISTRY; SILVER AND ALLOYS; ELECTRODES

Title: Advanced Research in Solar Energy Storage†
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Institute, 1617 Cole Boulevard, Golden, Colorado 80401, United States
Authors with affiliations: Luft, W., Solar Energy Research Institute, 1617 Cole Boulevard, Golden, Colorado 80401, United States
Abstract: This paper gives an overview of the Solar Energy Storage Program at the Solar Energy Research Institute. The program provides research, systems analyses, and economic assess- ments of thermal and thermochemical energy storage and transport. Current activities include experimental research into very high temperature (above 800°C) thermal energy storage and assessment of novel thermochemical energy storage and transport systems. The applications for such high-temperature storage are thermochemical processes, solar thermal-electric power generation, cogeneration of heat and electricity, industrial process heat, and thermally regenerative electrochemical systems. The research results for five high-temperature thermal energy storage technologies and two thermochemical systems are described. © 1983, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY

Title: RATIONALIZATION OF CEMENT DISTRIBUTION IN SWEDEN.
Authors with affiliations: Naredi, R.
Abstract: To ensure cement is competitive with other building materials, the cost of distribution as well as production is, nowadays, increasingly important. The latter is made up of unavoidable and initially heavy capital costs together with the major day to day expenses of fuel, electricity, labor and maintenance repairs. These developments have been very significant in Sweden - a sparsely populated country of comparatively large area - and clearly illustrate the importance of rational cement distribution, the costs of which are, approximately, an additional 25% in relation to production. Transportation, storage and handling are the major areas for examination in this respect.
Index Keywords: COST ACCOUNTING - Optimization; PRODUCTION ENGINEERING - Energy Management; CEMENT HANDLING

Authors: Yayama Hideki, Ichinomiya Osamu, Hirakawa Kazuyoshi
Title: ELECTROCHEMICAL HYDROGEN-STORAGE IN Ti-Mn ALLOY ELECTRODES.
Source title: Japanese Journal of Applied Physics, Part 2: Letters
Authors with affiliations: Yayama, Hideki; Ichinomiya, Osamu; Hirakawa, Kazuyoshi
Abstract: The structure of new hydrogen storage electrodes, consisting of TiMn//x (x equals 0. 5 to about 1. 75) and a binder, and their electrochemical properties are described. Powdered Ti-Mn alloys were sintered with Ni powder used as a binder. When the electrode potential is higher than minus 1. 075 V vs. Ag/AgCl, Ni is inactive and does not take part in the electrode reaction. The electrodes can be activated by repeating about 10 cycles of cathodic and anodic electrolysis. The amount of absorbed hydrogen increases with decrease of Mn content. Because of the large current capacity, Ti-Mn promises to be an excellent electrode for a battery with high energy density.
Index Keywords: Electrochemistry; HYDROGEN - Storage; Electrodes

Title: DESIGN PARAMETERS FOR A SMALL STORAGE RING OPTIMIZED AS AN X-RAY LITHOGRAPHY SOURCE.
Source title: Journal of Vacuum Science and Technology B: Microelectronics and Nanometer Structures
Authors with affiliations: Grobman, Warren D.
Abstract: The design parameters for a 'compact storage ring' which is matched well to x-ray lithographic requirements, but is as small as possible, are examined. This calculation uses a model of a lithographic system which obtains its input parameters from a technology of mask, resist, and beam line based on the IBM program at the Brookhaven National Laboratory vacuum ultraviolet electron storage ring. Exposure throughput is modeled as a function of storage ring parameters to understand which storage ring designs provide adequate but not excessive soft x-ray flux in the lithographically important region. The scan of storage ring sources covers a wide range of energies and magnetic fields, to permit consideration of superconducting as well as more standard strong- or weak-focusing designs. Furthermore, it is shown that the results of the calculations presented here can be scaled in a simple way to cover a wide range of x-ray lithography system assumptions.
Index Keywords: Lithography; X-RAYS - Applications; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Title: ESTABLISHING OIL RECOVERY AND RECLAMATION PROGRAMS.
Authors with affiliations: Webb, Henry R.
Abstract: This paper explores the recovery and reclamation of maintenance fluids and oils consumed in a fully integrated steel mill. Oil skimming equipment that removes oil from circulating water systems, reservoirs, and drainage ditches is discussed. In-plant reclamation systems comprising circulating pumps, filtration devices, dewatering units, and holding tanks for storage and segregating oils are mentioned. Reclaimed lubricants can be reused in original applications or can be rerouted for 'less critical applications' where new oil would normally be used.
Index Keywords: Energy conservation; Lubricating oils
