Affiliations: Mechanical Research Department, Ontario Hydro, Toronto, ON, M8Z 5S4, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Chan, A.M.C., Mechanical Research Department, Ontario Hydro, Toronto, ON, M8Z 5S4, Canada; Smereka, P.S., Mechanical Research Department, Ontario Hydro, Toronto, ON, M8Z 5S4, Canada; Giusti, D., Mechanical Research Department, Ontario Hydro, Toronto, ON, M8Z 5S4, Canada
Abstract: Transient, two-dimensional, mixed convection flows in a thermal storage tank have been studied using a previously developed numerical technique based on the marker and cell method. The governing equations are the conservation equations for laminar, natural convection flow based on the Boussinesq approximation. Forced convection flow is superimposed through the use of appropriate boundary conditions (inflow and outflow conditions). The transient heat transfer and fluid flow characteristics are examined for different boundary conditions. Typical transient temperature and velocity distributions are presented. The effect of inflow and outflow configurations on the storage tank thermal performance is also investigated. It is found that the device can store energy at a faster rate when hot water is discharged into the tank from the top and colder water is extracted from the bottom. However, the discharge direction into and from the tank, which can be either vertical or horizontal, is found to have negligible effect on the thermal storage efficiency. © 1983 by ASME.

Abstract: The thermal performance of six solar domestic hot water systems and a conventional hot water system have been carefully monitored by the National Bureau of Standards in Gaithersburg, Maryland. The system configurations include an evacuated-tube air system with a crossflow heat exchanger and two storage tanks, a single-tank direct system, a double-tank direct system, a single-tank indirect system with a wrap-around heat exchanger, a double-tank indirect system with a coil-intank heat exchanger, and a thermosyphon system. Results are presented for a oneyear time interval commencing January 1980. Abstract: Collisions of light photons with relativistic electrons have previously been used to produce polarized y-ray beams with modest (~10%) resolution but relatively low intensity. In contrast, the LEGS project (Laser+Electron Gamma Source) at Brookhaven will produce a very high flux (>2x107 s-1) of background-free polarized y rays whose energy will be determined to a high accuracy (AE =2.3 MeV). Initially, 300(420) MeV y rays will be produced by backscattering UV light from the new 2.5(3.0) GeV X-ray storage ring of the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS). The LEGS facility will operate as one of many passive users of the NSLS. In a later stage of the project, a Free Electron Laser is expected to extend the y-ray energy up to 700 MeV. Title: Operational characterization of the solar-thermal power system near Willard, New Mexico
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Pacific Gas and Electric Co., Fresno, CA, United States; Department of Mechanical Engineering, United States; Department of Agricultural Engineering, New Mexico State University, LasCruces, NM, 88003, United States; Sandia Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States
Authors with affiliations: Krivokapichi, G.A., Pacific Gas and Electric Co., Fresno, CA, United States; Fenton, D.L., Department of Mechanical Engineering, United States; Abernathy, G.H., Department of Agricultural Engineering, New Mexico State University, LasCruces, NM, 88003, United States; Otts, J.V., Sandia Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, 87185, United States
Abstract: The output capacity of the solar-thermal power system located near Willard, New Mexico was 19 kw (25 hp), with a primary application for irrigation pumping. Solar radiation was collected with north-south axis, east-west tracking, parabolic trough collectors having a total aperture area of 1275 m2 (13,720 ft2). Thermal storage was adequate for 20 hr. of power system operation utilizing a reaction-type turbine in conjunction with an organic Rankine-cycle heat engine. Operating efficiencies for the turbine component, heat engine, and the complete power system were 65-80percent, 10-16percent, and 1-3 percent, respectively. With the Willard system fully operational and near-term hardware improvement, an annual performance of 22 kw hr/m2 of collector aperature area could be expected. Examples of component operation under variable environmental conditions are presented for the winter and summer seasons. Maintenance experience with the Willard system is also given. © 1983 by ASME.

Authors: Katayama T., Chida K., Hattori T., Kadota S., Mizobuchi A., Murakami T., Nakanishi T., Noda A., Takanaka M., Tokuda N., Yamada S., Yonehara H., Yoshizawa M., Watanabe S., Hirao Y.

Abstract: TARN is a low energy, around ten MeV/nucleon, ion storage ring aimed at the beam accumulation both in the longitudinal and transverse phase spaces from the injector cyclotron Up to now, proton, H2+, a and 3He+ beams have been stored and the close agreements are shown between tne theoretical and experimental results on the beam dynamics. Twenty turn beam are injected in the betatron phase space area of 87 πmm mradby the multiturn injection method and 15 pulses are RF stacked in the momentum space Δp/p of 2.2%. Overall stacking number is then attained at around 300 turns. RF stacking is performed with the repetition rate of 30 Hz and it requires ~0.5 second to fillthe whole phase spaces with beam. The e-folding life time of 7 MeV proton is 400 s at the vacuum pressure of 1 xl0-10 Torr, whereas that of 3He+ is 60 ms at 1×10-8 Torr of 4He gas target. Collision strengths of charge exchange atomic reaction have been measured. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Title: On stochastic cooling of bunches in the colliding beam mode in high energy p-p storage rings
Affiliations: SPS Division, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Chattopadhyay, S., SPS Division, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: Possible cooling rates for stochastic cooling of intense bunches of protons and antiprotons in the colliding beam mode in the Fermilab Tevatron and the CERN SPS pp colliders are estimated, based solely on the bandwidth of the cooling system and the phase-space structure of the bunches and found to be a few tens of hours for high frequency large bandwidth feedback systems typically in the 8–16 GHz range and higher. The feasibility of even such slow cooling schemes, will depend on successful design of pick-ups, kickers and novel signal processing schemes in this high frequency regime, all of which demand detailed study. Title: Superconducting combined function magnets
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hahn, H., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York 11973, United States; Fernow, R.C., Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, New York 11973, United States
Abstract: Superconducting accelerators and storage rings, presently under construction or in the design phase, are based on separate dipole and quadrupole magnets. It is here suggested that a hybrid lattice configuration consisting of dipoles and combined function gradient magnets would (1) reduce the number of magnet units and their total cost and (2) increase the filling factor and thus the energy at a given field. Coil cross sections are presented for the example of the Brookhaven Colliding Beam Accelerator. An asymmetric two-layer cable gradient magnet would have transfer functions of 10.42 G/A and 0.628 G cm-1/A versus 15.77 G/A and 2.03 G cm-1/A of the present separate dipoles and quadrupoles. Title: Time-jitter reduction on the RF buncher signal for the los alamos proton storage ring (PSR)
Affiliations: Los Alamos National Laboratory, AT-3, MS H808, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Higgins, E., Los Alamos National Laboratory, AT-3, MS H808, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States; Paffenroth, G., Los Alamos National Laboratory, AT-3, MS H808, Los Alamos, NM 87545, United States
Abstract: The PSR at LAMPF will accumulate protons from the linear accelerator in both long- and short-bunch operational modes. Beam accumulation takes place for hundreds or thousands of turns. Ring buncher frequencies for these modes are 2.795 and 503.125 MHz, respectively. The bunching waveforms must be accurately correlated with the linac frequency standard so that the injected bunches fall into the ring rf buckets at precisely zero phase angle during accumulation. The PSR's rf wave also must have excellent phase stability. Long-term stability is assured by locking the PSR frequency reference to the linac's low-noise, temperature-stabilized crystal standard and by using delay-correction circuits in the transmission-line paths. However, the short-term stability of the rf reference signal is not as easily controlled because additive spurious signals can enter the long rf-signal transmission path (1-km linac-to-PSR), causing sideband energy increases very close to the carrier frequency. This increases time jitter. Also, some phase noise is spuriously developed by the signal-processing circuits providing frequency multiplication and division, the required processes for generating the necessary harmonic and subharmonic bunching frequencies at 503.125 and 2.795 MHz, respectively. The measure of control pursued by the described circuit design will provide rf references with timing uncertainty much less than the expected uncertainty in the micropulse time of arrival at the ring, ΔT ≈ ±80 ps. For the short-bunch PSR mode where timing is much more critical than for the long-bunch mode, and where the bunching wave has a ≈2-ns period, a maximum uncertainty of ±10 ps was chosen as the error budget for the low-level rf system. This paper discusses the steps taken to develop the low-level rf reference signal with some measure of margin relative to this ±10-ps budget. Phase-locked loop stabilizers, narrow-band high rejection-rate filters, and low-noise multipliers/dividers provided the means to achieve the goal. The multiplier described in this paper is part of a considerably larger system whose function is to generate several synchronizing signals for the PSR. Without examining the details, the larger sync system must, from a basic 201.25-MHz clock rate, generate phase-coherent, low-noise cw signals of 2.795 MHz for the LF buncher, 100.625 MHz for low-precision timing, and 16.77 MHz for the prebuncher in addition to the 503.125-MHz HF buncher described above. In very general terms, implementing these requirements involved dividing the 201.25-MHz clock rate by 72 to obtain 2.795 MHz and multiplying this rate by 6 to obtain 16.77 MHz using techniques very similar to those described in this paper. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: PROTONS; BEAM BUNCHERS; RF SYSTEMS; ACCELERATORS

Title: Experience with the cern pp- complex
Affiliations: European Organization for Nuclear Research – CERN, CH-1211, Genève 23, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Brianti, G., European Organization for Nuclear Research – CERN, CH-1211, Genève 23, Switzerland
Abstract: In the CERN pp- complex, antiprotons for collisions with protons or for direct use in experimental targets are provided over a very wide energy range, namely : pp- collisions at √S = 540 GeV in the SPS, pp- collisions at √S = 52 GeV in the ISR, p-‘s down to a kinetic energy of 5 MeV from LEAR. This report gives an account of the experience gained so far, mainly in 1982, in actual physics runs in SPS and ISR, and during the commissioning of LEAR. The main novelty concerns an extended physics run of two months in the SPS, where a peak luminosity of 5.3x1028 cm-2 s-1 was reached and an integrated luminosity of 28 nb-1 (or 2.80×1034 cm-2) was supplied to the two main experiments UA1 and UA2. Another very encouraging result was obtained in LEAR where p- beams, extracted from the Antiproton Accumulator at 3.5 GeV/c and decelerated in the PS to 0.6 GeV/c, were successfully injected and captured in LEAR, decelerated to 50 MeV kinetic energy and stochastically cooled. The first physics run will take place this summer. The ISR have exploited their excellent vacuum and reliability by storing antiprotons for physics runs of up to two weeks. There have been 10 physics runs to date and the peak luminosity achieved was 2.5×1028 cm-2 s-1. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Abstract: A beam position monitoring system has been constructed for the 2.5 GeV electron storage ring in the Photon Factory. Title: Laser photoionization of Ho beams for charge-changing injection
Affiliations: Los Alamos National Laboratory, AT-3, MS H808, Los Almos, NM 87545, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blind, B., Los Alamos National Laboratory, AT-3, MS H808, Los Almos, NM 87545, United States; Jason, A.J., Los Alamos National Laboratory, AT-3, MS H808, Los Almos, NM 87545, United States
Abstract: The two-step charge-changing injection used in the Los Alamos Proton Storage Ring (PSR) requires stripping of H- to Ho by high magnetic fields and subsequent stripping of Ho to H+ by a carbon foil.1 We consider single- and multiphoton laser ionization as alternatives to using a fragile foil. The multiphoton case is of possible interest for selection of practical lasers, which tend to have increased power output at higher wavelengths. The formulas derived express the necessary laser powers for ionization of monoenergetic Ho beams; they also hold for beams of particles other than atomic hydrogen. The numerical examples given are for the 800-MeV PSR beam with momentum spread taken into account. Additionally, we discuss selective stripping as an implication of the inherent energy selectivity of the photoionization process. Title: Electron Cooling and Accumulation of 200-MeV Protons at Fermilab

Abstract: Experimental measurements have been made of the cooling of 200-MeV protons by an electron beam of 1 to 3 A and an energy of 110 keV. These experiments are an extention of earlier measurements on the cooling of 115-MeV protons and were performed in the Fermilab experimental proton storage ring. At 200 MeV the proton beam lifetime in the storage ring is extended from 10 to 4000 sec with electron cooling. The cooling times with an electron beam current of 1 A were approximately 2 sec for momentum and 5 to 10 sec for transverse cooling of the proton beam. For proton intensities of approximately 2 x 106 particles, the six-dimensional phase-space density Qf the proton beam was increased by a factor of 2 x 105. These results and data on equilibrium proton distributions and frictional forces are in reasonable agreement with the theoretical predictions. In addition, the accumulation of successive “hot” batches of protons into a cold core, i.e. stacking, has been demonstrated. Title: Proposal for an extra RF system dedicated to bunch length control and synchrotron movement stabilization
Affiliations: Laboratoire pour l'Utilisation du Rayonnement Electromagnetique, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Bergher, M., Laboratoire pour l'Utilisation du Rayonnement Electromagnetique, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Abstract: A gain limitation for the F.E.L. installed in ACO appears as the charge density decreases in connection with the “anomalous lengthening” and the synchrotron movement instabilities which are affecting high current operation of the storage ring. An extra RF system is designed to cure both these effects. The basic component of the system is an extra cavity driven through a power RF amplifier by a signal whose spectrum is composed by the even harmonics of the revolution frequency and the nfo -fs side bands. The proper input is achieved from the signal induced by the beam on a radial pick-up electrode by means of a pulsed window amplifier. The amplifier equalizes the two components of the picked-up signal, one due to energy oscillation and the other to phase oscillation and thus realizes the suitable spectrum for the input. A feedback loop ensures the normalization of that signal. Synchrotron movement stabilization and bunch length control are expected to work for stored currents up to 100 mA. Title: A 600-MeV ETL electron storage ring
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura, Niihari, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tomimasu, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura, Niihari, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Noguchi, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura, Niihari, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Sugiyama, S., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura, Niihari, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Yamazaki, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura, Niihari, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Mikado, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura, Niihari, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Chiwaki, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Sakura, Niihari, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: A 600-MeV electron storage ring has been constructed in only ten months at a cost of 200 million yen at the Electrotechnical Laboratory (ETL) in Tsukuba. The ring consists of eight bending magnets (r = 2m) and four triplets of quadrupole magnet. The circumference is 31.45 m and λp is 22 Å. The lattice order is 0/2 BdQfQdQfBd 0/2. The harmonic number is 17. The maximum stored current is 160 mA and 1/e lifetime is 1.5 hours at present. The radiation is used for calibrating photometry and soft X-ray standards, photoelectric analysis of electronic materials, and LSI lithography. Title: Surf-II upgrade features magnet and RF system enhancements
Affiliations: National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rakowsky, G., National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC 20234, United States
Abstract: The NBS electron storage ring, SURF-II, has been upgraded with a number of major enhancements. The magnet system capability has been increased from 240 to 300 MeV, although actual operation is presently RF limited to 280 MeV. The storage ring magnet has been carefully mapped, resulting in more precise determination of beam energy and better radiometric data. The RF system has been augmented by an auxiliary second harmonic system, terminating in a novel, dual purpose cavity. This structure performs the function of the bump coil during injection, while during acceleration and stored beam operation it functions as a second harmonic cavity. In the latter mode it can either be tuned passively to suppress longitudinal bunch oscillations, or it can be driven actively to modify the longitudinal bunch shape. With proper amplitude and phasing relative to the main RF cavity, bunch lengthening can be achieved, resulting in improved beam lifetime without an increase in vertical size. Index Keywords: AMPLIFIERS, RADIO FREQUENCY; RF CAVITIES; ACCELERATORS, ELECTRON RING

Title: BEHAVIOUR IN AIR AT 175-250 degree C OF UO2 FUEL FRAGMENTS EXTRACTED FROM IRRADIATED ELEMENTS.
Source title: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited, AECL (Report)
Authors with affiliations: Hastings, I.J.; Novak, J.
Abstract: The authors have heated in air UO//2 fuel fragments extracted from intact and defected irradiated CANDU fuel elements. The temperature range was 175-250 degree C for times in excess of 1200 h. Maximum pre-test burnups and linear powers were 190 MW. h/kg U (8000 MW. d/TeU) and 45 kW/m, respectively. Rates of weight gain varied from about 10** minus **4 wt%/h to 2 multiplied by 10** minus **2 wt%/h at 175 and 250 degree C respectively. All data are described by a process with an activation energy of about 130 kJ/mol. Irradiation and fragment size had significant effects on the rate of weight increase. The results have application to the station handling, transport and dry storage of irradiated nuclear fuel in the temperature range to 250 degree C.
Index Keywords: NUCLEAR FUELS - Oxidation; Nuclear reactors, Heavy water

Title: PLUTON EXCAVATED FOR UNDERGROUND RESEARCH INTO NUCLEAR FUEL WASTE MANAGEMENT.
Authors with affiliations: Pronger, Doug
Abstract: Construction has started at the site of the Underground Research laboratory (URL), a research facility in Canada's Nuclear Fuel Waste Management Program. The project is located near Atomic Energy of Canada Limited's Whiteshell Nuclear Research Establishment in Manitoba. The URL is being built in the Lac du Bonnet batholith, a plutonic rock formation that is a common feature of the Canadian Shield. The various segments of the experimental program are directed toward evaluation of plutonic bodies, defining the undisturbed hydrogeology and rock-mass parameters and predicting long-term changes in these characteristics due to construction, loading and closure of an underground vault.
Index Keywords: RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS - Storage; Nuclear fuels

Authors with affiliations: Garrett, Ken
Abstract: Commercial vehicles equipped with a new constantly variable transmission (CVT) by Leyland will be in the hands of operators for user trials by the end of 1984 and production is planned to begin in 1986. The same CVT, together with a flywheel energy storage system for regenerative braking, will be in a Leyland National bus by the end of 1984, and this is expected to be on user trials by 1986. The concept shows prospects for improving fuel economy by about 22 per cent, while the addition of flywheel regenerative braking should bring this figure up to 30 or 40 per cent.

Authors: Hasegawa Fusao, Yoshino Hiroshi, Kimura Ken-ichi, Ishikawa Yoshimi, Matsumoto Hiroshi
Title: PERFORMANCE EVALUATION OF PASSIVE SOLAR SYSTEMS USING A TANDEM-TYPE TEST HOUSE.
Authors with affiliations: Hasegawa, Fusao; Yoshino, Hiroshi; Kimura, Ken-ichi; Ishikawa, Yoshimi; Matsumoto, Hiroshi
Abstract: A tandem-type test house is used for the performance evaluation of passive solar systems. It is first confirmed that the two test rooms have the same air-tightness and the same daily air temperature profile. For one part of the investigation, one test room is equipped with a passive system and the other one is not so equipped. For another part of the investigation, each room is equipped with a different type of passive system. After measuring the room temperature, the solar radiation, etc. , over a period of two or three weeks, the performance of the passive system is evaluated by comparing the indoor temperature profile of the two rooms. Passive systems examined in this paper are as follows: A large window facing south, an insulating weather shutter, a clerestory for taking solar radiation into the northern portion of the room, a heat storage floor as a direct gain system, and an underground cooling tube for ventilation in the summer.
Index Keywords: HOUSES - Space Heating; Solar energy; Heating

Title: Monensin effects on digestibility, methanogenesis and heat increment of a cracked corn-silage diet fed to steers.
Authors with affiliations: Wedegaertner, T.C.; Johnson, D.E.
Abstract: Six 300-kg steers were each fed a 70% cracked corn plus corn silage diet at two levels of intake above maintenance with and without 3 mg monensin/kg.75 body weight (W.75). A changeover design was used. Dietary energy and nitrogen were partitioned by duplicate, 22-h indirect respiration calorimetry measurements of heat and methane production on each animal concurrent with 7-d total feces and urine collection trials. Feed and feces were analyzed for energy, N, starch and neutral detergent fiber (NDF). The partial efficiency and(or) heat increment of metabolizable energy (ME) used for gain and maintenance was partitioned by regression of energy storage vs intake. At equalized gross energy intakes (adjustments made by covariance), monensin improved (P less than .01) the apparent digestibilities of energy, from 71.8 to 74.8%; NDF, from 50.5 to 57.5%, and crude protein, from 61.6 to 65.8%. Methane production averaged 5.7% of the control gross energy (GE), but was reduced by 26% (P less than .01) by monensin additions. Metabolizable energy was increased (P less than .01) from 63.3 to 66.8% of gross energy intake by monensin, resulting in an increase (P less than .01) in retained energy (64.7 to 72.3 kcal/W.75). Heat production was increased (P less than .05) by monensin, but only in proportion to the increased ME. Daily energy retentions adjusted to equal ME intake were similar with or without monensin (69.9 vs 67.1 kcal/W.75). No significant effects of monensin on the heat increment of ME use for maintenance or gain were observed. Both NEm and NEg were improved by approximately 7% by monensin; however, the relative effect on NEm vs NEg depends on method of calculation. At equalized GE intakes, approximately one-third of the improved energy utilization was explained by the reduced methanogenesis caused by monensin and two-thirds by reduced fecal losses.
Index Keywords: food additive; furan derivative; methane; monensin; animal; article; biosynthesis; body weight; cattle; diet; digestion; drug effect; energy metabolism; maize; male; physiology; silage; Animals; Body Weight; Cattle; Diet; Digestion; Energy Metabolism; Food Additives; Furans; Male; Methane; Monensin; Silage; Zea mays

Title: A numerical study of mixed convection flow in enclosures
Affiliations: Rutgers University, New Brunswick, New Jersey, 08903, United States; Mechanical Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, India
Authors with affiliations: Jaluria, Y., Rutgers University, New Brunswick, New Jersey, 08903, United States; Gupta, S.K., Mechanical Engineering Department, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, India
Abstract: A numerical study of the velocity and temperature distributions that arise in a water body due to a thermal discharge such as that in a heat rejection or a sensible energy storage system, has been carried out. The time‐dependent distributions, as well as the steady‐state solutions, have been obtained by the use of the alternating direction implicit method for the coupled vorticity transport and energy equations. The numerical procedure employed is outlined, indicating some of the salient features and problems that arise. The numerical scheme is employed for the study of various flow configurations and the dependence of the flow on the governing parameters, particularly on the mixed convection parameter, is determined. The results obtained are discussed in terms of the physical mechanisms involved. The uncoupled problem, for an unheated discharge, is also considered and the coupled nature of the equations is evident in the results obtained for heated discharges. The relevance of the results obtained to the recirculating flow of interest in heat rejection and energy storage is discussed. Copyright © 1983 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Enclosures; Mixed convection; Numerical study; Thermal discharge in water bodies

Title: CONTINUOUS PREPARATION OF PVC DRY BLENDS ON THE EXTRUDER.
Authors with affiliations: Weber, M.
Abstract: PVC compounds are still predominantly prepared in hot-cold mixer combinations. The many different intermediate compound storage and transporting operations which are undertaken require that the compound mix is cooled down. In the extruder the compound is once more reheated to a temperature which it previously had attained. A continuous compound preparation carried out on the extruder can therefore prove to be more economical. As well as the lower energy requirements, cost reductions can be made by savings in formulation ingredients, higher extruder throughput and lower investment costs. These are demonstrated using the example of pipe production.
Index Keywords: CONTAINERS - Plastics; Economics; EXTRUDERS - Applications; Mixing; PIPE, PLASTIC - Manufacture; CONTINUOUS BLENDING; PVC DRY BLENDS; Polyvinyl chloride

Authors: Yokoyama Takao, Uemiya Hiromichi, Katayama Kozo, Katsuragi Kohei
Title: REALIZATION OF RECOVERABLE ZONE FROM THE STAND POINT OF FLOW LINES.
Authors with affiliations: Yokoyama, Takao; Uemiya, Hiromichi; Katayama, Kozo; Katsuragi, Kohei
Abstract: Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage(ATES) is very promising in such districts where seasonal variance in climate is significant and aquifer exists abundantly, for example in Japan. Regional flow, however, is feared to disturb the favorable recovery. Influences of regional flow on ATES are investigated analytically. Method for selection of appropriate location of wells under the existence of uniform regional flow and its application to practical ATES are discussed. It is concluded that mean recovery temperature of 50% is obtainable.

Source title: Transactions of Indian Society of Desert Technology and University Centre of Desert Studies

Abstract: The desert areas of Kutch, Rajasthan, etc. , in India can most profitably use these sources to solve their problem of energy shortage. This paper describes the present state of the art of various renewable energy sources, their potentials and applications as related to desert areas. Subjects covered include wind energy conversion systems, solar desalination systems, solar powered cold storages, and solar driers.

Source title: Transactions of Indian Society of Desert Technology and University Centre of Desert Studies
Authors with affiliations: Vyas, S.K.; Rani, Veena; Kaur, Manjit
Abstract: Massive adoption of the latest agricultural technology in farming in India has resulted in manifold rise in potato production. This has created an increasing demand for cold storage. Since the cold storage technique is energy intensive and costly, some sort of middle level storage technology is needed. An effort to find out a middle level technology for storage, involving suitable growth regulators to be sprayed at appropriate time in the preharvesting period and building technology incorporating inexpensive insulating building material, has been made in this paper.

Title: POSSIBLE METHOD TO REDUCE SPIN-TUNE SPREAD.
Authors with affiliations: Yokoya, Kaoru
Abstract: In high-energy electron storage rings with beam energy above a few tens of GeV, a large depolarization occurs in the radiative polarization process because of the large spin-tune spread due to the beam energy spread. A new method is proposed which reduces the spin-tune spread and is expected to provide a high degree of radiative polarization.

Title: Energy storage capacity of reversible liquid‐phase Diels Alder reaction between maleic anhydride and 2‐methyl furan
Affiliations: Chemical Engineering Department, University of Missouri-Rolla, Rolla, Missouri, 65401, United States; CONOCO, Ponca City, Oklahoma, 74601, United States

Abstract: Calorimetry was used to determine the heat of reaction and equilibrium constant at 318 K for the reaction between maleic anhydride (A) and 2‐methyl furan (B). The values were −60 kJ/gmol and 614 cm3/gmol, respectively. The motivation for this work was to find a single phase‐reacting system that could be used to store solar energy. Thus, the energy storage capacity was calculated for a mixture of A and B, both initially at 7 kmol/m3, in dioxane. The maximum apparent heat capacity of 7.37 J/cm3·K occurred at 334 K. This maximum value is 76% higher than the heat capacity of pure water. Copyright © 1983 American Institute of Chemical Engineers

Title: DESIGN AND TESTING OF LENSES FOR OPTICAL DISK TECHNOLOGY.
Authors with affiliations: Kuttner, P.
Abstract: Optical disk technology finds application in laser vision, compact disk, and data storage equipment. The required specifications of lenses which meet these requirements are discussed. Their image quality is given by rms of wave aberration, by point spread function, by encircled energy, or by modulation transfer function (MTF). Due to the automatic servo focusing technique, a certain amount of field curvature can be tolerated. Measured results of image quality are compared with theoretical values.

Authors with affiliations: Nakatani, Y., Discrete Semiconductor Eng. Dept, Fujitsu Limited, Kawasaki, 211, Japan; Kuryu, I., Discrete Semiconductor Eng. Dept, Fujitsu Limited, Kawasaki, 211, Japan
Abstract: Along with the trend toward smaller size and lower energy consumption in electronic equipment, the dc stabilized power supply has been changed from the series dropping to the switching version, which tan he made more compact and light with high efficiency. the switching frequency in these efforts has increased with each year. Component parts are required for performance in higher frequency regions and it is also hoped that switching transistors will be improved in terms of high speed and large safe operating area. High‐speed switching and large safe operating area have hitherto progressed in a trade‐off relation. This was overcome by decreasing the base resistance via S‐parameter analysis. A newly developed fine emitter structure and oxide planar structure have led to creation of an excellent switching power transistor possessing ultra‐high voltage (1200 V), high‐speed switching characteristics (rise time tr = 200 ns, storage time tstg 2500 nsec, fall time tf = 70 nsec), and large safe operating area (secondary breakdown onset current Isb = 8 A, collector * emitter clamp voltage VCEX(clamp) = 90 V). Source title: Transactions of the SAEST (Society for Advancement of Electrochemical Science and Technology)
Authors with affiliations: Mittal, S.K.
Abstract: The latest developments in lead acid battery technology are reviewed. The areas where greater developmental inputs are needed, are highlighted. Importance of low capacity sealed lead acid battery in several appliances is described. Development of lead-calcium and other special alloys for grids is the first major breakthrough in sealed cell technology. The second major breakthrough is the recombination technology. Using this concept, it is theoretically possible to seal any kind of lead-acid cell regardless of its service life. A major research program is needed in the areas of grid alloys, separator developments, plate processing and also the design parameters. Substantial technological input is needed for the development of high energy density batteries for electric vehicles.

Abstract: The addition of different acetate salts and acetamide lowers the melting point of sodium acetate trihydrate. Authors: Keirsey James L., Cusick Richard T.
Title: AUTOMATED AIRBREATHING PROPULSION TEST FACILITIES.
Source title: Johns Hopkins APL Technical Digest (Applied Physics Laboratory)
Authors with affiliations: Keirsey, James L.; Cusick, Richard T.
Abstract: The development of airbreathing propulsion systems requires ground test facilities that provide true simulation of flight Mach number, altitude, and angle of attack for testing full-scale engines and components. These facilities must therefore have large systems for the storage and supply of air to the test article, and the air heaters and exhaust systems are powered by the discharge of large heat-energy sources during brief test runs. APL's Propulsion Research Laboratory and other such facilities require automated systems for accurate control and repeatibility of test conditions, and high-speed data acquisition systems.
Index Keywords: Computers; Control systems; AIRCRAFT ENGINES, JET AND TURBINE

Title: Managing commercial high-level radioactive waste
Source title: Radioactive Waste Management and the Nuclear Fuel Cycle
Abstract: High-level radioactive waste is defined and major findings on waste disposal, reprocessing, storage transportation and integrated waste management system are recapitulated. The impact of the latter on health, socioeconomic relations, costs system logistics and backlogs of spent fuel is examined. Problems of waste management policy, such as the key issues of final isolation and interim storage, and the factors complicating its development and implementation are discussed. A comprehensive waste management policy is outlined in detail.

Title: ELECTRIC VEHICLE DESIGN FACTORS.
Source title: Journal of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Gascoigne, A.E.
Abstract: Electric vehicles of both fixed-wire and battery-powered types have an important role to play in urban transportation. An energy-conscious approach to new vehicle design is necessary to ensure satisfactory operating economics of the former, and optimum range and performance of the latter. A number of simple expressions are derived which relate motive energy requirements, range and operating costs to basic design choices. Formulae for estimating 'energy efficiency' under both motoring and regenerative-braking conditions are developed.

Abstract: A nonvolatile random access memory (RAM) is introduced where two button-sized lithium battery cells fit snugly into the top of the package of a 16-K complementary-MOS static RAM, giving a 10-year backup supply. Unlike other battery-backup schemes, this nonvolatile RAM needs no external components.

Authors: Traça de Almeida A., Martins A., Jesus H., Climaco J.
Title: Source reliability in a combined wind-solar-hydro system
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Power Apparatus and Systems
Affiliations: Universidade de Coimbra, FCTUC, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Traça de Almeida, A., Universidade de Coimbra, FCTUC, Portugal; Martins, A., Universidade de Coimbra, FCTUC, Portugal; Jesus, H., Universidade de Coimbra, FCTUC, Portugal; Climaco, J., Universidade de Coimbra, FCTUC, Portugal
Abstract: This paper describes the simulation of a combined wind-solar-hydro system for electric power generation, with energy storage facilities. A simple multivariable weather model, including the wind speed, the solar radiation and the rainfall, was developed. This model is used with the Monte Carlo simulation method to evaluate the reliability of the mixed generating system. Different percentages of wind and solar generation capacities were tried as well as the tilt of the solar arrays. On the basis of the simulation performed, the optimum share of wind power in the system is discussed looking at the corresponding probability of loss of load. In an existing generating system with a strong penetration of hydro power providing a significative storage capacity, like the Portuguese system, the introduction of wind and solar power appears attractive from the reliability point of view. The small reserve margins required also decrease the high investment associated with the conversion of these two sources of energy. Title: Bedrock fracture parameters from the interpretation of well tides ( Chalk River, Canada).
Affiliations: Dept of Energy, Mines & Resources, Earth Phys Branch, Gravity, Geothermics & Geodynamics Div, Ottawa, Ontario, K1A 0Y3, Canada.
Authors with affiliations: Bower, D.R., Dept of Energy, Mines & Resources, Earth Phys Branch, Gravity, Geothermics & Geodynamics Div, Ottawa, Ontario, K1A 0Y3, Canada.
Abstract: This paper presents a theory to account for the main features of the tidal response of an isolated plane fracture as revealed by the water level in an intersecting open borehole. According to the theory the diurnal and semidiurnal tidal constituents (both amplitude and phase) of water level variations depend on the fracture aperture, the orientation (dip and strike) and the radial extent of the fracture, and the compressibility of the asperites. The theory is applied to water level observations made in six open boreholes located in crystalline rock at a test site at the Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories, Atomic Energy of Canada Limited, in Chalk River, Ontario, Canada. The boreholes were uncased and intersected many open fractures so that a definitive test of the theory could not be made. However, in four cases a fracture model could be found which fitted the observations within the experimental error.-Author

Title: COUPLING METHODS AND THE STORAGE EQUATION.

Abstract: Coupling methods are applied to the study of the storage equation with stationary input. Results on the existence of statistical equilibria are obtained. Means of obtaining rate-of-convergence estimates are indicated.

Authors: White M.S., Curtis M.L., Sarles R.L., Green D.W.
Title: EFFECTS OF OUTSIDE STORAGE ON THE ENERGY POTENTIAL OF HARDWOOD PARTICULATE FUELS: PART I. MOISTURE CONTENT AND TEMPERATURE.
Authors with affiliations: White, M.S.; Curtis, M.L.; Sarles, R.L.; Green, D.W.
Abstract: Widespread use of woody materials for industrial fuels has generated interest and concern about the energy value of fuels stored outdoors. Three fuels - hardwood whole-tree chips, bark, and sawdust - were stored in piles 10, 15, and 20 feet high. Internal pile temperatures rose rapidly during the first weeks to highs of 45 degree C for whole-tree chips and 73 degree C for bark and sawdust. In the bark and chip piles these temperatures fluctuated seasonally. The interior temperature of the sawdust pile was insensitive to ambient temperature changes and declined slowly throughout the remainder of the study. Within the first 60 to 120 days of storage, the surfaces of all piles became saturated with moisture.
Index Keywords: FUELS - Storage; Wood

Title: COMPRESSED-AIR ENERGY STORAGE (CAES) UNIT IN THE U. S.
Source title: Energy Engineering: Journal of the Association of Energy Engineering
Authors with affiliations: Lihach, Nadine
Abstract: Soyland Power Cooperative, Inc. , of Illinois, plans to employ, during off-peak periods, inexpensive baseload electricity from coal-fired or nuclear power plants to compress and pump air into an underground storage reservoir about two thousand feet below the surface. Then, the air is released into a combustor, heated by oil or gas, and expanded through a turbine to generate peaking or intermediate power for the grid. Such a plant can save about two-thirds of the oil or gas that a conventional system uses.
Index Keywords: COMPRESSED AIR - Storage; Gas turbine power plants; COMPRESSED-AIR ENERGY STORAGE (CAES); Energy storage

Title: LEYLAND CONSTANTLY VARIABLE TRANSMISSION.
Authors with affiliations: Garrett, Ken
Abstract: Commercial vehicles equipped with a new constantly variable transmission (CVT) by Leyland will be in the hands of operators, for user trials, by the end of 1984, and production is planned to begin in 1986. Moreover, the same CVT, together with a flywheel energy storage system for regenerative braking, will be in a Leyland National bus by the end of 1984, and this is expected to be on user trials by 1986. With this CVT, it will be possible to design the engine specifically for maximum efficiency and to match the transmission to it for obtaining the required performance and driveability characteristics. Such a concept shows prospects for improving fuel economy by about 22 per cent, while the addition of flywheel regenerative braking should bring this figure up to 30 or perhaps even 40 per cent. This transmission comprises a mechanism called the variator and a planetary gear set. Control is exercised by a microprocessor. The variator input assembly comprises a pair of discs on a common shaft, and the output is a third disc interposed coaxially between them but rotating in the opposite direction on a roller bearing between it and the shaft. Three small discs, or rollers, transmit the drive from each input disc to the central output disc, so there are six of these rollers in all. Tilting them varies the ratio of the drive: when the contact between the rollers and the input disc is at a small radius and that between them and the output disc at a larger radius, the output ratio is a reduction, and vice versa.
Index Keywords: COMPUTERS, MICROPROCESSOR - Applications; DISKS - Rotating; FLYWHEELS - Energy Storage; GEARS - Epicyclic; MOTOR BUSES - Fuel Economy; CONSTANTLY VARIABLE TRANSMISSIONS; REGENERATIVE BRAKING; VARIATORS; Automobile transmissions

Title: WORLD'S FIRST ENERGY SAVING VEHICLE FLEETS TO BE CONSTRUCTED IN THE UNITED KINGDOM.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: A program undertaken by Hybrid Vehicles Ltd is reported to design a hybrid electric system for urban transportation vehicles to save fuel and reduce transport operation costs. The building of 10 medium size buses and 10 light vans is proposed. The vehicles will combine the benefits of electric vehicles with the performance and flexibility of their internal combustion engine (ICE) counterparts. The system's advantages, consisting of braking energy recovery, reduced emissions, possible installation of fuel cells, exclusive battery use in environmentally sensitive areas, minimal alteration to existing manufacturing plants and others are considered, and the cost estimated.
