Affiliations: University of Sussex, United Kingdom; University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, 53706, United States; University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Beachley, N.H., University of Sussex, United Kingdom, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, 53706, United States; Anscomb, C., University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom; Burrows, C.R., University of Strathclyde, United Kingdom
Abstract: The use of energy storage in an automobile provides two important fuel-saving advantages: first the engine can be run at or close to its condition of maximum efficiency, and secondly the energy of braking can be recovered regeneratively. This paper examines how these factors are linked to the size of the energy storage unit and describes a control policy which has the purpose of minimizing the capacity whilst retaining the fuel-saving benefits. Both flywheel and accumulator storage units are considered; results are obtained for three standard test cycles. Some preliminary attempts are made to assess the effect of road gradient. It is concluded that a capacity of the order of 0.15 to 0.20 MJ for a 1360 kg automobile would provide most of the fuel-saving benefits for typical driving patterns where grade is not an important consideration. © 1983 ASME.
Index Keywords: HYBRID ENGINE; AUTOMOBILE ENGINES

Authors: Wada Takahiro, Kimura Fumiko, Yamamoto Ryoichi
Title: STUDIES ON SALT HYDRATE FOR LATENT HEAT STORAGE: II. PSEUDO-BINARY SYSTEM, CH3CO2Na`3H2O-HCONH2.
Source title: Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan
Authors with affiliations: Wada, Takahiro; Kimura, Fumiko; Yamamoto, Ryoichi
Abstract: A pseudo-binary system CH//3CO//2Na multiplied by (times) 3H//2O-HCONH//2 has been studied by differential scanning calorimetry. In this system, a one-to-one addition compound CH//3CO//2Na multiplied by (times) HCONH//2 multiplied by (times) 3H//2O is formed. This addition compound melts congruently at 40. 5 degree C and its heat of fusion is 255 J/g. So, it is hopeful suitable for solar energy storage.
Index Keywords: Calorimetry; Organic compounds; Solar energy; Energy storage

Authors: Cuomo J.J., DiStefano T.H., Guarnieri C.R., Leary P.A., Yee D.S.
Title: OPTICAL RECORDING DISC SYSTEM AND MEMORY MEDIUM.
Authors with affiliations: Cuomo, J.J.; DiStefano, T.H.; Guarnieri, C.R.; Leary, P.A.; Yee, D.S.
Abstract: The article describes 3 methods of forming an optical storage medium. The medium comprises a substrate coated with a textured surface in the form of dendrites, cones, pyramids, pinnacles, projections, etc. which are in turn coated thinly with an energy-absorbing material selected from the elements in the Group VII, IB portion of the periodic chart, or elements selected from Al, C, Te, a seimiconductor (Si, Ge) or a dye.
Index Keywords: Data storage, Optical

Title: The Bloch Lines Dynamics in Permalloy Films
Affiliations: State University of the Mordov Assr, Saransk
Authors with affiliations: Alekhin, A.A., State University of the Mordov Assr, Saransk
Abstract: A theoretical calculation of the overall structure of the cross‐tie wall is made. The wall static and dynamic parameters (including the cross and circle Bloch lines radii) are found making use of the energy minimization of the wall unit cell. The velocity of the circle Bloch line motion and the annihilation field are calculated. The results of calculation are compared with experimental data. Copyright © 1983 WILEY‐VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA
Index Keywords: DATA STORAGE, MAGNETIC - Film; BLOCH WALLS; CROSS-TIE MEMORIES; PERMALLOY; FERROMAGNETIC METALS

Authors: Troughton Gary E., Casilla Romulo C.
Title: EDGE-GLUING UNSEASONED SPRUCE-PINE-FIR LUMBER USING A PREHEATING METHOD.
Authors with affiliations: Troughton, Gary E.; Casilla, Romulo C.
Abstract: Temperature profile curves were measured for both dry and unseasoned western spruce heated in an oven at temperatures of 100 degree , 125 degree , 150 degree , and 175 degree C. The temperature curves showed the heat stored in the wood flowed slowly to the surface and therefore could provide sustained heat energy for the curing reactions of the adhesive. Using a preheating technique, edge-joints were made from unseasoned spruce-pine-fir lumber under a variety of bonding conditions. Phenol-resorcinol formaldehyde glue was used as the binder in these experiments. Factors examined were wood storage conditions, glue spread, open assembly time, pressing time at 50 psi, and heating time at 150 degree C. Block shear and delamination samples were cut from the edge-joints to evaluate bond quality and durability properties, respectively.
Index Keywords: ADHESIVES - Curing; HEAT TRANSFER - Analysis; Wood products

Title: The loss of power supply probability as a technique for designing stand-alone solar electrical (photovoltaic) systems
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Power Apparatus and Systems
Affiliations: School of Engineering, Tel-Aviv University, Tel-Aviv, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Ofry, E., School of Engineering, Tel-Aviv University, Tel-Aviv, Israel; Braunstein, A., School of Engineering, Tel-Aviv University, Tel-Aviv, Israel
Abstract: Many solar electrical (photovoltaic) systems (SES) are designed and are in operation in many countries. Most of the analysis and design methods are based on the concept of power supply during a number of autonomous days (NAD). This NAD value refers to the number of consecutive days in which no power is supplied to the system from the solar cell array(SCA). The storage system capacity is thus based on the required energy during NAD. Though the NAD method is simple and in many cases will assure reliable power supply, it is uneconomical. With the relative high costs of solar cells and storage batteries, this means a system that may not operate at its optimum. A new method for analysis and design of SESs is presented in this paper, which enables to determine the minimum (and thus the economical) sizes of the SCA and storage system capacity. The reliability of the system is studied by the newly introduced “loss of power supply” (LOPS) probability concept. Some systems have been designed using the new method and compared to other design methods. One of the SESs has been in operation for over two years. The measured results verify the usefulness of the new method. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES, SECONDARY - Applications; ENERGY STORAGE - Optimization; RELIABILITY - Analysis; SOLAR CELLS - Arrays; LOSS OF POWER SUPPLY PROBABILITY; SOLAR POWER PLANTS

Authors: Wilson T.G., Jr., Whelan E.W., Jr., Rodriguez R., Dishman J.M.
Title: DC-to-DC Converter Power Train Optimization for Maximum Efficiency
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
Affiliations: Bell Laboratories, Whippany, NJ 07981, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, T.G., Jr., Bell Laboratories, Whippany, NJ 07981, United States; Whelan, E.W., Jr., Bell Laboratories, Whippany, NJ 07981, United States; Rodriguez, R., Bell Laboratories, Whippany, NJ 07981, United States; Dishman, J.M., Bell Laboratories, Whippany, NJ 07981, United States
Abstract: A new way is given to describe the independent and dependent design variables of the power train of a dc-to-dc converter in terms of a multidimensional design-parameter space. These concepts provide a framework for examining the problem of design optimization of the power train, with particular emphasis on the maximization of converter efficiency. Numerous examples of important parameterspace surfaces illustrate some of the major relationships between core volume, switching frequency, and output power and between efficiency, ripple, and temperature rise of the energy-storage reactor. Also, the difference in performance between the continuous and discontinuous magnetomotive (MMF) force modes of operation is explored. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: DC-DC CONVERTER; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, POWER TYPE

Title: Thermal energy storage development for solar electrical power and process heat applications1
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Livermore, CA, 94550, United States; Solar Energy Research Institute, Golden, CO, 80401, United States; Badger Company Inc., East Weymouth, MA, 02189, United States
Authors with affiliations: Radosevich, L.G., Sandia National Laboratories, Livermore, CA, 94550, United States; Wyman, C.E., Solar Energy Research Institute, Golden, CO, 80401, United States, Badger Company Inc., East Weymouth, MA, 02189, United States
Abstract: Development of thermal energy storage technologies for solar thermal systems has been conducted since the mid-1970s. This paper presents an overview of past and present experimental activities for electrical power and process heat applications both within and outside the United States. The factors affecting the selection of a storage technology for these applications, as well as the nature of those applications, are discussed. Future research needs are also described. © 1983 by ASME.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: REGIONAL HEAT GRIDS AND HEAT STORAGE SYSTEMS.
Authors with affiliations: Scholz, Franz
Abstract: Problems involved in regional district heat supply are discussed on the basis of examples from the Federal Republic of Germany. In large continuous heat grids - for example Hamburg - the consumers are directly connected to the grid. The flow temperature is operated flexibly depending on the external temperature and even on the coldest day can be limited to about 135 degree C. This is a good energetic basis for combined heat and power generation with steam turbines. On the other hand, regional ″district heat rails″ connect individual, mostly smaller local district heat grids with one another. They are designed for different flow temperatures and due to the high operating pressure of the rail they have to be supplied from the rail via heat exchangers. This fact, plus the large transportation distances in the rails (up to approx. 20 km on the Lower Rhine), leads to flow temperatures of max. 180 degree C. The Lower Rhine district heat rail is discussed in detail. The contribution of heat reservoirs to energy and oil conservation is emphasized.
Index Keywords: Energy conservation; Energy storage; Hot water supply systems; STEAM POWER PLANTS - Waste Heat Utilization; DISTRICT HEAT GRIDS; HEAT STORAGE SYSTEMS; Heating

Title: Buffer thermal energy storage for a solar brayton engine
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: AiResearch Manufacturing Company, A Division of The Garrett Corporation, Torrance, CA, 90509, United States
Authors with affiliations: Strumpf, H.J., AiResearch Manufacturing Company, A Division of The Garrett Corporation, Torrance, CA, 90509, United States; Barr, K.P., AiResearch Manufacturing Company, A Division of The Garrett Corporation, Torrance, CA, 90509, United States
Abstract: A study has been completed on the application of latent-heat buffer thermal energy storage to a point-focusing solar receiver equipped with an air Brayton engine. To aid in the study, a computer program was written for complete transient/steadystate Brayton cycle performance. The results indicated that thermal storage can afford a significant decrease in the number of engine shutdowns as compared to operating without thermal storage. However, the number of shutdowns does not continuously decrease as the storage material weight increases. In fact, there appears to be an optimum weight for minimizing the number of shutdowns. © 1983 by ASME.
Index Keywords: AIR ENGINES; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Bhardwaj R.P., Quamara J.K., Nagpaul K.K., Sharma B.L.
Title: Non‐Isothermal Depolarization Current Studies in Kapton‐H Thermoelectrets
Affiliations: Department of Applied Physics, Regional Engineering College, Kurukshetra, India; Department of Physics, Kurukshetra University, Kurukshetra, 132119, India
Authors with affiliations: Bhardwaj, R.P., Department of Applied Physics, Regional Engineering College, Kurukshetra, India, Department of Physics, Kurukshetra University, Kurukshetra, 132119, India; Quamara, J.K., Department of Applied Physics, Regional Engineering College, Kurukshetra, India; Nagpaul, K.K., Department of Applied Physics, Regional Engineering College, Kurukshetra, India, Department of Physics, Kurukshetra University, Kurukshetra, 132119, India; Sharma, B.L., Department of Applied Physics, Regional Engineering College, Kurukshetra, India
Abstract: Thermally stimulated depolarization current characteristics of Kapton‐H electrets are studied in the temperature range 303 to 573 K as functions of the polarizing field (133.3 to 500.0 kV cm−1), polarizing temperature (333 to 453 K), polarizing time (2.7 × 103 to 16.2 × 103 s), specimen thickness (2.5 × 106 to 12.5 × 106 nm), heating rate (0.017 to 0.10 K s−1), and storage time (0 to 720 h). The TSDC spectra comprise three maxima in all, namely, β, α, and ρ with their respective locations around 373, 453, and 553 K. These are attributed to dipole‐orientation, motion of space charges, and surface charge injection, respectively. A shoulder (β′) emerging around 343 K is suggested to be akin to the main β‐peak. The space‐charge peak is found to be more sensitive to the forming and storage parameters than to that involving dipoles. The observed dependence of the peak temperature as well as the activation energy for various peaks on polarizing temperature and time is indicative of a continuous distribution of relaxations. Copyright © 1983 WILEY‐VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA
Index Keywords: FILMS - Dielectric; PLASTICS FILMS; POLYIMIDES - Thin Films; KAPTON-H POLYIMIDES; THERMOELECTRETS; ELECTRETS

Title: Performance of a cylindrical phase-change thermal energy storage unit
Affiliations: Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ, United States; Arizona State University, Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department, Tempe, AZ, United States; Universal Energy Systems Inc., Dayton, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ponnappan, R., Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ, United States, Universal Energy Systems Inc., Dayton, OH, United States; Jacobson, D.L., Arizona State University, Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department, Tempe, AZ, United States
Abstract: An experimental apparatus with a water-circulated calorimeter was designed and constructed to evaluate the high-temperature performance of a phase-change material (PCM) in a cylindrical thermal-energy-storage container (TESC) sample. A 12 in. long, 1 in. diam Inconel 617 container filled with a eutectic PCM of 64 LiF- 30MgF2-6KF salt was tested. The phase-change characteristics of the salt during melting and solidification were observed by monitoring the external axial temperature profile of the container. Energy was supplied to the sample by radiation from a resistance heater and energy was rejected to the calorimeter by radiation. The sample container was mounted in an ion-pumped vacuum chamber. Analysis of phase-change heat transfer in cylindrical geometry was based on the modified heat balance integral method of Tien which provided the solidification rate and time. The thermal diffusivity of the salt at its fusion temperature was then calculated. The experimental results obtained for the eutectic salt melting point (710°C), freezing point (671°C), latent heat of fusion (782 J/g), and thermal diffusivity (0.00799 cm2) were in good agreement with those found in the literature. The experimental and analytical results of the nondimensionalized heat-transfer resistance as a function of the solidified or melted weight fraction were compared. © 1983 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: HEAT TRANSFER - Cylinders; THERMAL INSULATION; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Authors: Prakash J., Garg H.P., Datta G.
Title: Effect of baffle plate on the performance of built-in storage type solar water heater
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Ramjas College, University of Delhi, Delhi, 110 007, India; Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Prakash, J., Department of Physics, Ramjas College, University of Delhi, Delhi, 110 007, India; Garg, H.P., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India; Datta, G., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Abstract: The performance of a built-in storage water heater can be improved by using a baffle plate in the absorber tank. We have studied the following different design conditions: 1. (i) a water heater with baffle plate and with night insulation cover, 2. (ii) with baffle plate and without night insulation cover, 3. (iii) without baffle plate and with night insulation cover. We find that the best results are obtained with a baffle plate and an insulation cover at night. The performance of the system without the cover but with the baffle plate is almost as good as that with cover and without the baffle plate. We have also studied the design 1. (i) when water is withdrawn from the system at various constant flow rates. © 1983.
Index Keywords: ENERGY STORAGE - Evaluation; BAFFLE PLATES; WATER HEATERS

Title: WIND ENERGY: SOME NOTES ON ITS COLLECTION, STORAGE AND APPLICATION.
Authors with affiliations: Stobart, A.F.
Abstract: An overview is presented of the current utilization methods of wind for generation of electrical power. It was pointed out that a wind energy collector of 6 meters in diameter gave similar results with a larger one (10 meters). So a wind energy collector is not, in principle, a good source of 'shaft horsepower' for driving conventional electricity generators, or other similar devices. Batteries are only an economic storage system for very small wind energy systems. A more futuristic approach is the generation of hydrogen, using wind power to electrolyse water.
Index Keywords: WIND TURBINES - Efficiency; AEROGENERATOR; Wind power

Title: GLASS FIBRE REINFORCED EPOXY LEAF SPRING DESIGN.
Authors with affiliations: Gottenberg, W.G.; Lo, K.H.
Abstract: Composite leaf springs constructed of unidirectional glass fibers in an epoxy resin matrix are being recognized as a viable replacement for steel springs in truck and automotive suspension applications. This paper reviews the function of a spring as an energy storage device. It examines in detail the influence on that function of the material of construction (unidirectional glass fibers in epoxy versus steel) and of spring geometry. The design latitudes afforded by the variable thickness/width options are illustrated. The significance of shear stress components in planes containing the fibers is examined, particularly in its relation to the selection of the thermoset resin matrix.
Index Keywords: EPOXY RESINS - Applications; GLASS FIBER - Applications; STRESSES - Shear; Springs

Title: CALCULATION OF THE CHARACTERISTIC CURVES FOR OPTICAL DATA WRITTING IN A HETEROGENEOUS MEDIUM.
Authors with affiliations: Kabychenkov, A.F.
Abstract: A heterogeneous medium (HM) for writing optical data is addressed. The HM consists of a binder, which is a transparent material which can make an aggregative solid-liquid transition, and a filler of magnetic particles, which can absorb the writing radiation. The particles in the binder are randomly oriented and the HM film is practically nontransparent. Writing occurs as a result of the smoothing out of the binder under the action of radiation and the pulling of the particles into threads parallel to an external magnetic field applied perpendicular to the HM film. The paper presents a phenomenological theory of characteristic curve (CC) for HM, which expresses the relation between the optical density D and the energy of the writing radiation H.
Index Keywords: HETEROGENEOUS MEDIUM; Data storage, Optical

Authors: Beloshitskii P.F., Perel'shtein E.A., Shchinov B.G.
Title: SIMULATION OF RADIATION INSTABILITY IN RELATIVISTIC ELECTRON STORAGE RINGS.
Authors with affiliations: Beloshitskii, P.F.; Perel'shtein, E.A.; Shchinov, B.G.
Abstract: The growth of radiation instability in a relativistic electron storage ring is studied by numerical simulation. It is shown that during the nonlinear stage, the rate of increase in the energy spread drops as particles escape from the ring. The asymptotic behavior of the distribution of the field energy over the different harmonics is ascertained. It is found that instability is excited when the initial energy spread in the ring is substantially greater than the threshold values in the linear theory.
Index Keywords: Electrons; Accelerators

Title: Acetate-glucose relationship in growing pigs.
Authors with affiliations: Imoto, S.; Namioka, S.
Abstract: Twelve crossbred barrows from four litters (average initial body weight of 21 kg) were used to examine the relationship between acetate and glucose metabolism in pigs. The treatments were the addition of acetate in the form of triacetin to the basal diet at 0, 5 and 10% of the metabolizable energy intake. In the immediate postprandial period, the administered acetate decreased the venous plasma glucose concentration linearly (P less than .05) and increased linearly the venous plasma concentrations of lactate (P less than .01) and ketone bodies (P less than .001). There was a linear increase in the glycogen content of the liver (P less than .001), heart (P less than .001) and femoral muscle (P less than .01), as the level of acetate intake was increased. In the remote postprandial period (12 h after the last meal), glucose, which was considered to have been derived from hepatic glycogen storage, became the dominant blood metabolite in place of the acetate administered with the diet. This led to the reduction in hepatic production of endogenous acetate, arterial acetate concentration and in acetate utilization in the hind limb. Hepatic urea production was also decreased. Thus, there was a reciprocal change in acetate and glucose metabolism.
Index Keywords: acetic acid; acetic acid derivative; glucose; glycogen; ketone body; lactic acid; lactic acid derivative; triacetin; animal; article; blood; body weight; diet; glucose blood level; glycogen liver level; growth, development and aging; male; metabolism; swine; Acetic Acid; Acetic Acids; Animals; Blood Glucose; Body Weight; Diet; Glucose; Glycogen; Ketone Bodies; Lactates; Lactic Acid; Liver Glycogen; Male; Swine; Triacetin

Title: Energy storage in the primary step of the photocycle of bacteriorhodopsin
Authors with affiliations: Birge, R.R.; Cooper, T.M.
Abstract: A pulsed-dye laser low temperature photocalorimeter is used to study the enthalpy differences between light-adapted bacteriorhodopsin (bR568) and its primary photoproduct (K) at 77 K. A key feature of our experimental method is the use of the laser-induced photostationary state as an internal reference. Analyses of the forward (bR leads to K), reverse (K leads to bR), and mixed (bR in equilibrium K) photoreactions were carried out to measure delta H12 = EK - EbR. All three experiments yielded identical values of delta H12 within experimental error (delta Have12 = 15.8 +/- 2.5 kcal mol-1). Accordingly, the primary event in the photocycle of light-adapted bacteriorhodopsin stores approximately 30% of the absorbed photon energy at the 568-nm absorption maximum. We observe that the quantum yields phi f1(bR leads to K) and phi r2(K leads to bR) add up to unity within experimental error: phi f1 + phi r2 = 1.02 +/- 0.19 for phi f1 in the range 0.28–0.33. A theoretical analysis of energy storage in K suggests that at least one-half of the enthalpy difference between K and bR is associated with charge separation accompanying chromophore isomerization. © 1983, The Biophysical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: bacteriorhodopsin; carotenoid; article; energy transfer; Halobacterium; light; metabolism; thermodynamics; Bacteriorhodopsins; Carotenoids; Energy Transfer; Halobacterium; Light; Thermodynamics

Authors: Jones K.W., Gordon B.M., Hanson A.L., Hastings J.B., Howells M.R., Kraner H.W., Chen J.R.
Title: APPLICATION OF SYNCHROTRON RADIATION TO ELEMENTAL ANALYSIS.
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research, Section B: Beam Interactions with Materials and Atoms
Authors with affiliations: Jones, K.W.; Gordon, B.M.; Hanson, A.L.; Hastings, J.B.; Howells, M.R.; Kraner, H.W.; Chen, J.R.
Abstract: The use of a synchrotron storage ring as a high brightness source for production of monoenergetic variable energy, and highly polarized X-ray beams promises to revolutionize the field of elemental analysis. The results of exploratory work using the Cornell synchrotron facility, CHESS, are described. Design considerations and features of the new X-ray microprobe facility now under construction at the Brookhaven National Synchrotron Light Source are presented. This facility will be used for bulk analysis and for microanalysis with an initial spatial resolution of the order of 30 mu m.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS, SYNCHROTRON - Applications; Microanalysis; Trace analysis; X-ray analysis

Authors: Sizer Ii T., Kafka J.D., Duling Iii I.N., Gabel C.W., Mourou G.A.
Title: Synchronous Amplification of Subpicosecond Pulses
Affiliations: Laboratory for Laser Energetics, Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14623, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sizer Ii, T., Laboratory for Laser Energetics, Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Kafka, J.D., Laboratory for Laser Energetics, Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Duling Iii, I.N., Laboratory for Laser Energetics, Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Gabel, C.W., Laboratory for Laser Energetics, Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Mourou, G.A., Laboratory for Laser Energetics, Institute of Optics, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14623, United States
Abstract: In high-gain dye amplifiers, the effective storage time of the gain medium is only a few hundred picoseconds. Therefore, efficient amplification of ultrashort pulses places a stringent requirement on the synchronization between the pump pulse and the pulse to be amplified. We present a technique of short pulse generation using a dye laser synchronously pumped by a frequency-doubled CW mode locked Nd:YAG laser. Pulses as short as 70 fs are produced. The short optical pulses are subsequently amplified with two different synchronous amplification schemes using 100 ps pulses to establish the gain in the dye amplifier stages. Subpicosecond pulses with energies from a few hundred nanojoules at 500 Hz to a few hundred microjoules at 7 Hz can be obtained. © 1983 IEEE
Index Keywords: LASERS, DYE; LASERS, SOLID STATE; LASER PULSES; LASER BEAMS

Authors: Ram S., Singh S., Bansal N.K.
Title: Periodic analysis of a ventilated trombe wall
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Ram, S., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India; Singh, S., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India; Bansal, N.K., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Abstract: A periodic analysis of a ventilated Trombe wall is presented. The analysis is able to take into account the storage effects and predict the daily or long term performance of the system. The thermal flux entering an air‐conditioned space (maintained at 20°C) through the wall has been evaluated. Numerical calculations have been performed corresponding to the meteorological data on 19 January 1981 at New Delhi, a typical cold winter day. Subsequent parametric studies using the simulation indicated that the critical parameters were the mass flow rate of air, depth of plane of heat retrieval and the length of the network of pipe. Copyright © 1983 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Solar energy; Trombe wall
Index Keywords: ATMOSPHERIC TEMPERATURE - New Delhi, India; FLOW OF FLUIDS - Pipes; HEAT EXCHANGERS - Tubes; HEATING - Solar; AMBIENT TEMPERATURE; PASSIVE SOLAR HEATING; TROMBE WALLS; HEAT TRANSFER

Title: Emulsification of thermal energy storage materials in an immiscible fluid
Affiliations: Solar Energy Research Institute, 1617 Cole Blvd, Golden, Colorado, 80401, United States; Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Arizona, Tuscan, Arizona, 85721, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cease, M.E., Solar Energy Research Institute, 1617 Cole Blvd, Golden, Colorado, 80401, United States; White, D.H., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Arizona, Tuscan, Arizona, 85721, United States
Abstract: The problems of thermal energy storage are of major importance in the development of intermittent energy sources and the efficient usage of conventional energy supplies. Utilization of latent heat materials for thermal energy storage has been plagued by the build‐up of solids on cooling surfaces and the resulting low heat transfer rates. A novel system has been investigated in order to alleviate these difficulties. Small droplets of latent heat material were suspended in an immiscible heat transfer fluid to form an emulsion. The generation of stable emulsions is an empirical art, for which the selection of surface‐active agents and the method of mixing play the key roles. A total of 42 latent heat storage emulsion samples were prepared using a diphenyl compound as the organic phase. Most of the samples were prepared using a high speed mixing apparatus. Several emulsified blends exhibited favourable prolonged storage and cycling behaviour. Estimates based on apparent viscosity measurements indicated that high rates of heat transfer could be obtained with this system. Assuming turbulent flow conditions and 60 per cent salt loading, a value for the mean film coefficient of heat transfer was calculated to be about 1045 J/m2 s °C. The concept offers potentially large heat exchanger cost reductions, while retaining 60 per cent of the volume savings attainable in latent heat systems. Copyright © 1983 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Emulsions; Energy storage; Heat transfer; Latent heat energy storage
Index Keywords: EMULSIONS - Energy Storage; HEAT EXCHANGERS - Costs; HEAT TRANSFER - Measurements; HYDROCARBONS - Applications; SURFACE ACTIVE AGENTS - Applications; BIPHENYLS; HEAT TRANSFER COEFFICIENT; LATENT HEAT MATERIALS; THERMAL ENERGY STORAGE; ENERGY STORAGE

Title: Energy storage in a fuel cell with bipolar membranes burning acid and hydroxide
Affiliations: Department of Physical Chemistry, University of Göteborg, S-41296 Göteborg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Emrén, A.T., Department of Physical Chemistry, University of Göteborg, S-41296 Göteborg, Sweden; Holmström, V.J.M., Department of Physical Chemistry, University of Göteborg, S-41296 Göteborg, Sweden
Abstract: A battery is described, in which bipolar membranes are used to split water into acid and hydroxide. The liquids may be stored for an indefinite time, and energy may be recovered at room temperature. It is shown that the liquids are able to store about 400 kJ/litre, which roughly corresponds to pumping water up to an altitude of 40 km. Bipolar membranes of low area resistance have been made and tested. The area resistance appears to have been 2-3 Ω cm2. A battery containing 7 unit cells has been constructed and tested. The maximum output voltage has been 1.8 V. The cost for energy storage is estimated to range from $0.1 to 2.5 per kWh depending on the mode of operation. © 1983.
Index Keywords: HYDROCHLORIC ACID - Ion Exchange; MEMBRANES - Electric Conductivity; SODIUM COMPOUNDS - Ion Exchange; WATER; BIPOLAR MEMBRANES; WATER SPLITTING; FUEL CELLS

Authors: Comtat M., Ducarroir M., Sibieude F., Crozat G., Spinner B.
Title: Theoretical and experimental aspects of a two‐step short cycle, based on ZnO and CdO intended for storage of solar energy
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Chimie-Physique Et D'electrochimie, Universite Paul-Sabatier, Toulouse, 31078, France; Laboratoire des Ultra-Refractaires C.N.R.S, B.P. n° 5, Odeillo, 66120, France; Laboratoire de Chimie Minerale Et Thermochimie, Universite de Perpignan, 66025 Perpignan Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Comtat, M., Laboratoire de Chimie-Physique Et D'electrochimie, Universite Paul-Sabatier, Toulouse, 31078, France; Ducarroir, M., Laboratoire des Ultra-Refractaires C.N.R.S, B.P. n° 5, Odeillo, 66120, France; Sibieude, F., Laboratoire des Ultra-Refractaires C.N.R.S, B.P. n° 5, Odeillo, 66120, France; Crozat, G., Laboratoire de Chimie Minerale Et Thermochimie, Universite de Perpignan, 66025 Perpignan Cedex, France; Spinner, B., Laboratoire de Chimie Minerale Et Thermochimie, Universite de Perpignan, 66025 Perpignan Cedex, France
Abstract: In the present paper, chemical and energetical considerations about hybrid thermal electrochemical cycles based on zinc and cadmium oxides are developed. Intermediate reactions have been taken into account. Numerical data obtained from decomposition experiments of the oxides in a solar furnace and from electrolysis experiments with Zn and Cd metals (or metal‐oxide mixtures) used as an anode, are discussed. The energy balance for the hydrogen production using the mentioned cycles is compared with a direct electrolytic water‐splitting process working with thermopiles or photopiles solar plants as electricity source. Copyright © 1983 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Chemical storage; Solar energy; Two‐step cycles; Zn, Cd
Index Keywords: CADMIUM COMPOUNDS - Decomposition; ELECTROLYSIS - Applications; FURNACES - Solar; HYDROGEN - Manufacture; ZINC COMPOUNDS - Decomposition; CHEMICAL SOLAR ENERGY STORAGE; HYBRID THERMAL ELECTROCHEMICAL CYCLES; SOLAR ENERGY

Title: Probabilistic production cost model for a power system with storage
Source title: International Journal of Electrical Power and Energy Systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineerign and Applied Physics, Case Institute of Technology, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nassar, M., Department of Electrical Engineerign and Applied Physics, Case Institute of Technology, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106, United States; Gruber, S., Department of Electrical Engineerign and Applied Physics, Case Institute of Technology, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106, United States
Abstract: The conventional production cost model uses the power system load for an average day with no consideration of the uncertainty that is entailed in this load. A probabilistic production cost model is presented that considers the stochastic nature of the load which is used for a power system with energy storage operating on a daily or weekly cycle. The optimum energy storage device, in the sense of minimizing the expected cost of meeting demand, is found. The model minimizes the statistical data and permits a separation of the fuel cost from it, so that a change in fuel cost would not require a great deal of recomputation. Finally, the deterministic approach using an average load is compared with the stochastic one, and it is shown that the deterministic approach leads to significant error in the optimum storage capacity. © 1983.
Author Keywords: cost modelling; electric power systems; production planning
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC POWER SYSTEMS

Title: Effect of a booster mirror on the performance of a 'built-in' storage solar water heater
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Authors with affiliations: Dhiman, N.K., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India; Tiwari, G.N., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110 016, India
Abstract: In this paper, the performance of a 'built-in' storage solar water heater-flat mirror system has been presented. Numerical calculations have been made for a typical cold day (viz. 28 Jan. 1980) at Delhi. The booster mirror causes a minimum temperature rise during the moring and a temperature difference of 7°C excess with respect to the reference panel occurred. The reflectance of the mirror is taken as 0·88. © 1983.
Index Keywords: HEATING - Solar; SOLAR ENERGY

Authors: Grigor'ev G.K., Muratikov K.L., Podlaskin B.G.
Title: PULSED SCANISTOR PHOTOELECTRIC TRANSDUCER WITH ENERGY STORAGE.
Authors with affiliations: Grigor'ev, G.K.; Muratikov, K.L.; Podlaskin, B.G.
Abstract: This paper shows that it is possible in principle to increase the sensitivity of discrete scanistors operating in the pulse mode by storing the signal energy; the speed can also be increased by using current pulses from the diodes (rather than static pulses) to form the output signal.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC NETWORKS - Equivalent Circuits; TRANSDUCERS - Energy Storage; PULSED SCANISTORS; Photoelectric cells

Authors: Oshawa Yasuharu, Miyauchi Hajime, Hayashi Muneaki, Honda Toyohiko
Title: STABILIZATION OF LONGITUDINAL POWER SYSTEM BY MEANS OF SUPERCONDUCTING MAGNETIC ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Memoirs of the Faculty of Engineering, Kyoto University
Authors with affiliations: Oshawa, Yasuharu; Miyauchi, Hajime; Hayashi, Muneaki; Honda, Toyohiko
Abstract: A power system stabilization by means of the superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) is proposed, wherein the firing angle of the SMES thyristor bridge is controlled, based on the angular velocity deviation of the generator rotor. A simple longitudinal system is taken up as a sample system, and the optimum position of the SMES is investigated from the stabilizing point of view.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Magnetic measurements; Mathematical models; Thyristors; Electric power systems

Authors: Thiebaud D., Schutz Y., Acheson K.
Title: Energy cost of glucose storage in human subjects during glucose-insulin infusions
Source title: American Journal of Physiology - Endocrinology and Metabolism
Affiliations: Div. Clin. Biochem., CHUV, 1011 Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Thiebaud, D., Div. Clin. Biochem., CHUV, 1011 Lausanne, Switzerland; Schutz, Y., Div. Clin. Biochem., CHUV, 1011 Lausanne, Switzerland; Acheson, K., Div. Clin. Biochem., CHUV, 1011 Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: The effect of graded levels of hyperinsulinemia on energy expenditure, while euglycemia was maintained by glucose infusion, was examined in 22 healthy young male volunteers by using the euglycemic insulin clamp technique in combination with indirect calorimetry. Insulin was infused at five rates to achieve steady-state hyperinsulinemic plateaus of 62 ± 4, 103 ± 5, 170 ± 10, 423 ± 16, and 1,132 ± 47 μU/ml. Total body glucose uptake during each of the five insulin clamp studies was 0.41, 0.50, 0.66, 0.74, and 0.77 g/min, respectively. Glucose storage (calculated from the difference between total body glucose uptake and minus total glucose oxidation) was 0.25, 0.29, 0.43, 0.49, and 0.52 g/min for each group, respectively, and represented over 60-70% of total glucose uptake. The net increment in energy expenditure after intravenous glucose was 0.08, 0.10, 0.14, 0.17, and 0.23 kcal/min, respectively. Throughout the physiological and supraphysiological range of insulinemia, there was a significant relationship (r = 0.95, P <0.001) between the increment in energy expenditure and glucose storage, indicating an energy cost of 0.45 kcal/g glucose stored. However, at each level of hyperinsulemia, the theoretical value for the energy cost of glucose storage (assuming that all of the glucose is stored in the form of glycogen) could account for only 45-63% of the actual increase in energy expenditure that was measured by indirect calorimetry. These results indicate that factors in addition to glucose storage as glycogen must be responsible for the increase in energy expenditure that accompanies glucose infusion.
Index Keywords: glucose; insulin; diagnostic agent; glucose; insulin; calorimetry; drug metabolism; endocrine system; energy expenditure; glucose blood level; glycogen synthesis; human; human experiment; intravenous drug administration; liver; thermogenesis; adult; article; energy metabolism; glucose blood level; infusion; kinetics; male; metabolism; Adult; Blood Glucose; Calorimetry; Energy Metabolism; Glucose; Human; Infusions, Parenteral; Insulin; Kinetics; Male; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't

Title: Correction for loss of radon-222 in water sample caused by the use of a polyethylene bottle.
Authors with affiliations: Saito, M.
Abstract: Loss of radon-222 in water sample stored in a polyethylene bottle was analyzed. The radon content was measured by a liquid scintillation spectrometer. The radon content (corrected for radioactive decay) was plotted against the storage period in the polyethylene bottle, and the decrease with the lapse of time was observed. The loss of radon was caused by adsorption on polyethylene surface. The radon content decreased according to the first order kinetics. Apparent rate constant of the adsorption was proportional to the surface area of the polyethylene and to the reciprocal of the sample water volume. The proportionality constant was obtained as a function of temperature, K = 10200 exp (-4382/T) cm X h-1. Apparent activation energy was 36 kJ X K-1 X mol-1. The result supports physical adsorption. On the basis of the result, correction for radon content of a sample water stored in a polyethylene bottle was made possible.
Index Keywords: polyethylene derivative; radon; water; adsorption; article; laboratory diagnosis; methodology; scintillation counting; time; Adsorption; Polyethylenes; Radon; Scintillation Counting; Specimen Handling; Time Factors; Water

Title: COLLECTING AND STORING SOLAR HEAT IN A WATER CISTERN SYSTEM.
Authors with affiliations: Coutts, Jack
Abstract: Since there is considerable sunshine in the summer in interior Alaska, it seemed that it might be economical to collect and store some of the solar energy in a water cistern system in the author's house near Fairbanks. A description is given of the construction, assembly and the operation of the solar panels, some of which were covered with plastic and fiberglass glazing to capture the insolation and prevent water evaporation and contamination. The method of data collection and cost estimation is outlined, and the results of an economic analysis of the solar collector system are presented.
Index Keywords: SOLAR ENERGY - Storage; WATER TANKS AND TOWERS; Heating

Title: DECENTRALIZED LOAD FREQUENCY CONTROL USING SUPERCONDUCTIVE ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Report of the College of Engineering of Hosei University
Authors with affiliations: Shirai, Goro
Abstract: This paper presents a method of designing decentralized controller using super-conductive energy storage for load frequency control of interconnected electric power systems. The proposed method is composed of hierarchical structure, a two-level control strategy. The design of the optimal feedback gains in each area can be constructed by using the state variables belonging to the corresponding decoupled area and the integral of frequency in the neighboring areas.
Index Keywords: CONTROL SYSTEMS, CASCADE - Applications; ELECTRIC POWER DISTRIBUTION - Control; LOAD DISTURBANCES; TRANSIENTS; Electric power systems

Title: BUNCHED BEAM INSTABILITY ASSOCIATED WITH CAVITY IMPEDANCE.
Source title: Japanese Journal of Applied Physics, Part 1: Regular Papers & Short Notes
Authors with affiliations: Nishimura, Hiroshi
Abstract: Investigtion is made on the longitudinal single bunch instability of the electron beam in a high energy storage ring. It is shown that the Robinson instability of a parastic mode is caused by the interaction between a higher order synchrotron oscillation and higher order resonate mode of an rf cavity. Two damping mechanisms, the Landau damping and the radiation damping, are investigated and the stability criteria are obtained.
Index Keywords: ACCELERATORS - Storage Rings; Electron beams

Title: LOOKING AT REGENERATIVE SYSTEMS.
Authors with affiliations: Miller, J.L.
Abstract: The photovoltaic solar array dominates space power system planning for the late '80s. Even so, over the next few years much must be done to reduce fabrication cost and increase the life of arrays. The leading candidate for achieving these goals is the concentrator array, in which highly reflective surfaces concentrate solar energy onto the solar cells. Two types of concentrator arrays are being considered. One is a concentrating array element having a low geometric concentration ratio, while the other employs a cassegrainian concentrator. The cassegrainian approach requires a new cell to be developed and new techniques of incorporating the cell into the system. While the predominant problem in solar arrays has been cost, the big concerns in energy storage have been mass and lifetime. Historically, energy storage has been accomplished almost entirely by secondary nickel-cadmium (NiCd) batteries, which are very heavy. An attractive lighter alternative may be the bipolar nickel-hydrogen (NiH//2) battery under study at NASA-Lewis. This hybrid fuel-cell/battery uses a hydrogen electrode similar to that of the hydrogen/oxygen fuel cell to replace the cadmium plate in the NiCd system. Another, even lighter system for energy storage is being pursued at both NASA Johnson Space Center and NASA Lewis. Unlike the hybrid NiH//2 battery, it uses two fuel-cell-related technologies. Called a regenerative fuel-cell/electrolysis (FCE) system, it offers a specific energy of 40 Wh/kg - more than twice the NiH//2 battery's specific energy.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; SOLAR CELLS - Arrays; Spacecraft

Authors: Hannervall L., Olsson C., Ristborg H.
Title: ENERGY LOGGING WITH AN ON-BOARD COMPUTER.
Authors with affiliations: Hannervall, L.; Olsson, C.; Ristborg, H.
Abstract: A primary consideration of the Swedish energy program is to reduce the very high oil dependence. It is therefore necessary to alter the pattern of energy consumption for transport where possible, and to introduce electric road vehicles for suitable applications. An important aspect in this respect is obviously the energy efficiency of various types of vehicles.
Index Keywords: STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES - Computer Applications; AUTOMATIC DATA LOGGING; ENERGY EFFICIENCY; OIL DEPENDENCE REDUCTION; Transportation

Title: ALUMINUM-AIR/OXYGEN BATTERY SYSTEM ATTRACTIVE FOR USE IN ELECTRIC VEHICLES.
Authors with affiliations: Katrynioch, D.; Ruch, J.
Abstract: The fuel cell development starting in the sixties supported new interest in metal-air cells. Several problems could be solved by application of results of materials research. Today's metal-air batteries achieve higher energy and power densities than common battery systems and are of interest for use in electric vehicles.
Index Keywords: Fuel cells; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES - Energy Conservation; AIR-OXYGEN BATTERY; METAL-AIR CELLS; Electric batteries, Secondary

Authors: Itoh Y., Morishima Y., Nazakura S.
Title: CHARGE SEPARATION IN THE LIGHT-INDUCED ELECTRON TRANSFER REACTION OF AMPHIPHILIC COPOLYMERS CONSISTING OF POLYANION AND PHENANTHRENE SEGMENTS.
Source title: Journal of polymer science. Part B, Polymer letters
Authors with affiliations: Itoh, Y.; Morishima, Y.; Nazakura, S.
Abstract: A report is given of the fact that charged segments in the amphiphilic polymers, consisting of electrolyte and hydrophobic segments as media for electron transfer in an aqueous systems forming microheterogeneous phases, can retard the back electron transfer reaction (back-reaction) of the photo-products. It is demonstrated that the electrolyte segments of amphiphilic polymers can play a role to drive the charge separation of charged products in the photoinduced electron transfer reaction. An analogous effect has often been demonstrated with surfactant micellar systems. An appropriate combination of the acceptor and amphiphilic polymers could serve as a storage system for light energy.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Copolymers

Authors: Chin S.A., Chen D.Y., Lee F.C.
Title: Optimization of the Energy Storage Inductors for DC-to-DC Converters
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, Va. 24061, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chin, S.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, Va. 24061, United States; Chen, D.Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, Va. 24061, United States; Lee, F.C., Department of Electrical Engineering, Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Blacksburg, Va. 24061, United States
Abstract: Three sets of design graphs and equations are developed to facilitate design of the Energy Storage inductors for dc-to-dc converters. Using the design graphs, a quick estimate of the inductor minimum weight, the transistor peak current, and the inductor power loss can be obtained. Tradeoff studies can be conveniently conducted using these graphs. The effects of duty cycle controllers, constant frequency and constant tON, on the optimal selection of the energystorage inductors are assessed. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC INDUCTORS; ELECTRIC CONVERTERS, STATIC

Authors: Kryszewski M., Wandelt B., Birch D.J.S., Imhof R.E., North A.M., Pethrick R.A.
Title: EFFECT OF ANNEALING ON PHOTO-ENERGY TRANSFER IN POLY(2,6-DIMETHYL-1,4-PHENYLENE OXIDE), POLYSTYRENE AND THEIR BLENDS.
Authors with affiliations: Kryszewski, M.; Wandelt, B.; Birch, D.J.S.; Imhof, R.E.; North, A.M.; Pethrick, R.A.
Abstract: Observations of fluorescence intensity and lifetime in polystyrene, poly(2,6-dimethyl-1,4-phenylene oxide) and a blend of these show that annealing and storage permit chain packing rearrangements which favor non-radiative energy conversion and transfer processes at the expense of direct chromophore emission.
Index Keywords: POLYSTYRENES - Heat Treatment; Polyphenylene oxides

Title: RENEWABLE ENERGY PROJECTS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW SOUTH WALES.
Authors with affiliations: Sergeant, G.D.
Abstract: The Energy Research, Development and Information Centre (ERDIC) at the University of New South Wales, Sydney, Australia, was established in July 1978. Included in the ERDIC is the coordination of the energy research activities on campus and the preparation of an annual report which summarizes the active projects. Solar energy research, having as its primary objective the conversion of solar energy into more useful forms of energy, particularly electricity and heat, continues to attract good levels of research funding and to produce encouraging results. Projects in passive solar architecture, photovoltaic conversion, thermal conductivity, photoelectrochemical conversion, photoconductivity polymers, solar non-tracking concentrators, solar water heaters, drying of primary produce, energy storing in greenhouses, solar electric pumping, solar beam lighting, wind and solar surveying, wind turbines and generators, and energy form biomass are briefly described.
Index Keywords: Biomass; GREENHOUSES - Energy Storage; Solar radiation; WATER HEATERS - Solar; WIND POWER - Australia; DRYING; PHOTOELECTROCHEMICAL CONVERSION; PHOTOVOLTAIC CONVERSION; Solar energy

Title: SOLAR PONDS IN AUSTRALIA.
Authors with affiliations: Charters, W.W.S.
Abstract: Solar ponds have the potential to supply agricultural or industrial process heat, at temperatures up to 80 degree C, at relatively low cost because of the use of standard civil engineering construction techniques and low-cost materials. They can also be used with devloped low temperature heat engines to provide mechanical and electrical power at remote locations, at costs competitive with standard diesel generator sets. In Australia, operational experience with reasonably sized test ponds is very limited and has in fact been accrued only over the last few years. This practical experience is useful in focusing attention on some of the important problem areas. Further research and field development is required to overcome some of the identified materials problems and to refine techniques for reducing the top heat loss from the heated pond. 6 refs.
Index Keywords: RESERVOIRS - Energy Storage; SALTS - Applications; WATER RESOURCES - Saline Water; HONEYCOMB STABILIZED PONDS; SALT GRADIENT SOLAR PONDS; SOLAR PONDS; Solar radiation

Authors: Baraev S.V., Korovin O.P., Min'kin K.G.
Title: METHOD FOR INCREASING THE EFFICIENCY OF ENERGY TRANSFER TO A CAVITY.
Authors with affiliations: Baraev, S.V.; Korovin, O.P.; Min'kin, K.G.
Abstract: This paper considers increasing the energy storage efficiency in the cavity of a pulse former by connecting an auxiliary cavity between the main (storage) cavity and the transmission lines. The efficiency will be increased if the storage cavity is 'critically' coupled at its input, the microwave generator operates continuously, and the stored energy is output at equal time intervals.
Index Keywords: ELECTRONIC CIRCUITS, PULSE SIGNAL - Coupling; Microwave generation; Pulse generators

Authors: Bangert U., Belson J., Wilson I.H.
Title: DAMAGE EFFECTS OF ION/ATOM BEAM MILLING ON MNOS (Al/Si3N4/SiO2/Si) CAPACITORS.
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research, Section B: Beam Interactions with Materials and Atoms
Authors with affiliations: Bangert, U.; Belson, J.; Wilson, I.H.
Abstract: Low energy argon ion and atom beams produced by saddle field sources have been used to study changes in CVD Si//3N//4/SiO//2/Si structures after bombardment of the bare nitride at a particle energy of 2. 9 kev. Interface state densities N//s//t and flatband voltages V//F//B were extracted from high frequency (1. 3 MHz) and quasi-static C-V curves. Bombardment was found to induce an increase in N//s//t and positive and negative charge storage associated with the nitride (or the nitride/oxide interface). The effect was more pronounced under ion bombardment. On the supposition that displacement damage is similar for ion and atom bombardments the differences in charge storage are interpreted in terms of enhanced trapping under the field associated with ion bombardment.
Index Keywords: Ion beams; Capacitors

Title: A Summary of EHV Propulsion Technology
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Center, Mail Stop 500-214. 21000 Brookpark Rd., Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schwartz, H.J., NASA Lewis Research Center, Mail Stop 500-214. 21000 Brookpark Rd., Cleveland, OH 44135, United States
Abstract: The quest for a commercially successful electric vehicle invariably centers around three major factors which influence buyer decisions: performance, range, and cost. Using today's technology, two items within an electric vehicle have the greatest influence on these factors. The battery is the primary determinant of range and to a lesser extent of performance. The design of the propulsion system sets the performance level of the vehicle and has a smaller effect on range. While the battery has the greatest impact on the life cycle cost of a vehicle, the propulsion system is a much larger contributor to the purchase price. Propulsion subsystem weight, efficiency, and cost are related to the specified combination of components used. Under the United States Department of Energy's Electric and Hybrid Vehicle Program, propulsion component and system advancements have been made which will result in weight savings of 35–50 percent, efficiency gains of 25 percentage points, and significantly lower cost when compared to the state of the art at the inception of the program. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Inc.
Index Keywords: STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES - Design; ELECTRIC AND HYBRID VEHICLE (EHV); VEHICLE PROPULSION SYSTEMS; AUTOMOBILES

Title: The Lead-Acid Battery—Demonstrating the Systems Design Approach to a Practical Electric Vehicle Power Source
Affiliations: Johnson Controls, Inc., Globe Battery Division, 5757 N. Green Bay Ave., Milwaukee, WI 53201, United States
Authors with affiliations: Andrew, M.G., Johnson Controls, Inc., Globe Battery Division, 5757 N. Green Bay Ave., Milwaukee, WI 53201, United States; Weinlein, C.E., Johnson Controls, Inc., Globe Battery Division, 5757 N. Green Bay Ave., Milwaukee, WI 53201, United States
Abstract: Resurgent interest in electric vehicles has resulted in extensive research and development programs, including government support, to develop a lead-acid battery system which can deliver acceptable range and cycle life. In the last decade, significant gains in energy density, power density, and cycle life have been made. The Improved State of the Art (ISOA) Electric Vehicle (EV) battery developed by the Globe Battery Division of Johnson Controls, Inc., utilizes the leading edge technology responsible for these improvements. The patented electrolyte circulation system is the cornerstone of this design. Emphasis was placed on a systems design approach which included priority consideration for safety and ease of maintenance. Efforts toward achieving the ambitious “Advanced Battery” goals are progressing. Rival exotic energy storage systems require considerable additional development before they might become practical alternatives. The major advantages of the lead-acid system firmly position it as the most practical energy source for electric vehicles, both now and in the near future. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Inc.
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC BATTERIES - Applications; ELECTROLYTES - Applications; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES - Equipment; LEAD-ACID BATTERIES; AUTOMOBILES

Title: Energy storage and flow control by means of a 2-port, time-variable coupling network
Source title: IEE Proceedings G: Electronics Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Tel Aviv University, Ramat Aviv, Tel Aviv, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Singer, S., Faculty of Engineering, Tel Aviv University, Ramat Aviv, Tel Aviv, Israel
Abstract: A new approach to power-flow control between a linear energy-storage device and an arbitrary load is described. Control is achieved by changing the parameters of a lossless time-variable 2-port coupling network. The load can be operated at any required (time-variable) operating point. This type oflossless energy transfer is also applicable in cases in which a charged capacitor is coupled to a noncharged capacitor; the conventional method, on the other hand, involves energy loss when two capacitors charged to different voltages are directly connected. © 1983, The Institution of Electrical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Circuit theory and design; Control systems; Networks
Index Keywords: ELECTRIC NETWORKS

Title: Dispersed storage and generation impacts on energy management systems
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Power Apparatus and Systems
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, California, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kirkham, H., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, California, United States; Klein, J., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, California, United States
Abstract: This paper examines the various technologies for small-scale generation or storage of electricity known collectively as dispersed storage and generation, DSG. DSGs are seen to be an inhomogeneous group. The impact on energy management due to the integration of DSGs into the power system is examined, with emphasis on control, monitoring and operating problems. Authors: Reed George P., Sedrick Arthur V.
Title: DAYLIGHTING PASSIVE SOLAR MANUFACTURED BUILDINGS FOR COMMERCIAL APPLICATIONS.
Source title: Lighting Design and Application: LD and A
Authors with affiliations: Reed, George P.; Sedrick, Arthur V.
Abstract: Daylighting has been integrated with passive solar energy techniques using a translucent, insulated building envelope to minimize the total annual, nonrenewable energy requirements of manufactured buildings in commercial applications. The translucent envelope building design consists of three elements: translucent envelope panels, reflective roof shutter and thermal storage. The unique features of a translucent, manufactured solar building for commercial applications are described, and their daylighting performance analyzed for Boston, Massachusetts. Total annual source energy consumption for this design is 78 percent less than the design energy budget of the U. S. Building Energy Performance Standards (BEPS). Lighting savings due to daylighting account for 61 percent of this source energy savings. Electric lighting energy is reduced by 96 percent compared to the Massachusetts Code Energy Standard design which does not use daylighting. Photographic and photometric studies demonstrate that daylighting through a translucent envelope provides a high quality of task illuminance.
Index Keywords: Solar radiation; DAYLIGHTING; MANUFACTURED BUILDINGS; Buildings

Authors: NICKEL H., SENDER F., THIERBACH R., WEICHART H.
Title: EXPLORING THE INTERIOR OF SALT DOMES FROM BOREHOLES
Affiliations: Bundesanstalt Für Geowissenschaften Und Rohstoffe, Postfach 510153, Hannover, 3000, Germany; Prakla-Seismos GmbH, Postfach 4767, Hannover, 3000, Germany; Niedersächsisches Landesamt für Bodenforschung, Postfach 510153, Hannover, 3000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: NICKEL, H., Bundesanstalt Für Geowissenschaften Und Rohstoffe, Postfach 510153, Hannover, 3000, Germany; SENDER, F., Prakla-Seismos GmbH, Postfach 4767, Hannover, 3000, Germany; THIERBACH, R., Niedersächsisches Landesamt für Bodenforschung, Postfach 510153, Hannover, 3000, Germany; WEICHART, H., Prakla-Seismos GmbH, Postfach 4767, Hannover, 3000, Germany
Abstract: Presently, salt deposits are used for storage of energy from liquid or gaseous carrier materials. Another application being considered is the storage of radioactive material. In order to avoid possible future environmental risk, extremely high security has to be guaranteed in advance for a long period. Therefore, a very precise exploration is absolutely necessary. Exploration methods already known—which are applicable during and after drilling of test holes—help in the recognition of structures in the salt only in the close vicinity of the holes. Radiowave electromagnetic methods developed for routine measurements in salt mines provide a penetration of some hundred meters. Appropriate well‐logging equipment has been designed here for measurements from surface boreholes. Discontinuities around one borehole in the salt can be detected through the electromagnetic reflection method. When measuring between two boreholes, additional reflecting zones can be detected, and attenuation of directly pathed waves can point out material with greater absorption properties between the holes. Additional attempts to use acoustic waves of nearly the same wavelength proved that it is possible to recognize the direction of signals arriving at the receiver and allow separation of P‐ and S‐waves. Instrumentation as well as recent results are reported. Copyright © 1983, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Index Keywords: BOREHOLES - Logging; GEOLOGY - Tectonics; SALT DEPOSITS

Authors: Douglas David L., Birk James R.
Title: BATTERIES FOR ENERGY STORAGE.
Authors with affiliations: Douglas, David L.; Birk, James R.
Abstract: Four large battery R&D programs are concentrated on. Two are individual electrochemical systems for electric utility energy storage: zinc-chlorine and sodium-sulfur. The third is a high-temperature battery, lithium-iron sulfide, which is expected to be applicable in electric vehicles. Finally the nearer term ev battery development programs are reviewed which include zinc-nickel oxide, iron-nickel oxide, and lead-acid batteries.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries, Secondary

Title: Radiation effects in silicate glasses pertinent to their application as a radioactive waste storage medium
Affiliations: Argonne Natl. Lab., Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Primak, W., Argonne Natl. Lab., Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Abstract: A variety of radiation effects are delineated in complex silicate glasses: formation of centers, expansion, two kinds of contraction, surface alkali activation, and enhanced leaching. The intense energy deposition in the last fraction of the ranges of the actinide recoils appears to produce other effects than those from the diffuse energy deposition associated with the light ions and with ionization. Although there are other serious gaps in our knowledge of the radiation behavior of these materials, and the data available are rather limited, the most serious deficiency for waste management is the lack of adequate temporal and thermal data.A variety of radiation effects are dilineated in complex silicate glasses:formation of centers, expansion, two kinds of contraction, surface alkali activation, and enhanced leaching. The intense energy deposition in the last fraction of the ranges of the actinide recoils appears to produce other effects than those from the diffuse energy deposition associated with the light ions and with ionization. Although there are other serious gaps in the knowledge of the radiation behavior of these materials, and the data available are rather limited, the most serious deficiency for waste management is the lack of adequate temporal and thermal data.

Title: Renewable energy sources and developing countries
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Power Apparatus and Systems
Affiliations: Professor of Electrical Engineering, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74078, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ramakumar, R., Professor of Electrical Engineering, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74078, United States
Abstract: The role of renewable energy sources in meeting the energy needs of developing countries is examined in the context of the burgeoning fuel prices and the associated geopolitical realities and economic burdens. The acute energy needs and the unavailability of commercial fuels in the rural areas offer a rewarding opportunity for the utilization of locally available renewable energy sources. Small-scale decentralized integrated system concepts for harnessing renewable energy sources are discussed. The basic economic factors involved in the introduction of renewable energy sources in the rural areas of developing countries are outlined to assist the designer in the selection of appropriate components and system concepts. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.

Title: Electric Vehicle Field Test Experience
Affiliations: Delco-Remy Division, General Motors Corporation, 2401 Columbus Ave., Anderson. IN 46018, United States; GMC Truck and Coach Division, General Motors Corporation, Plant 12, 5th Floor, 660 South Blvd., Pontiac. MI 48053, United States

Abstract: Thirty-five experimental GMC electric vans accumulated over 300 000 miles in a field test application as telephone service and repair vehicles. Information was obtained on recharging lead-acid traction batteries which led to microprocessor control of the recharge. Energy consumption, ac kilowatt hours per mile, was greatly reduced and recharge efficiency increased by accurate control of the recharge. Battery energy density (range) and wear-out remain concerns which promote the need for a new energy source for commercial electric vehicles. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Inc.

Title: Electric Vehicle Test and Evaluation Program: Site Operators' Experience
Affiliations: Transportation Consulting Division, Booz, Allen & Hamilton, Inc., Bethesda, MD, United States; General Electric Company, Crystal Gateway One, 1235 Jefferson Davis Highway, Arlington, VA 22202, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yanni, L.A., Jr., Transportation Consulting Division, Booz, Allen & Hamilton, Inc., Bethesda, MD, United States, General Electric Company, Crystal Gateway One, 1235 Jefferson Davis Highway, Arlington, VA 22202, United States; Yanni, L.A., Jr., Transportation Consulting Division, Booz, Allen & Hamilton, Inc., Bethesda, MD, United States, General Electric Company, Crystal Gateway One, 1235 Jefferson Davis Highway, Arlington, VA 22202, United States
Abstract: A total of 35 private companies and federal, state, and local agencies are currently participating in the Department of Energy's Electric Vehicle Test and Evaluation Program. These participants are operating, in aggregate, 712 electric vehicles in 22 states and the District of Columbia, and reporting monthly to the Department of Energy (DOE) on their operating and maintenance experience with the vehicles. When the program closes in 1985, an estimated 25 000 vehicle-months of data will have been collected. At this time, approximately 6000 vehicle-months of data have been collected since the program's first fully operational fleet was put into service in January 1980. The data show that battery reliability and maintenance constitute a significant problem in the vehicles now in operation. Copyright © 1983 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Inc.

Title: OPTIMAL CONTROL OF SOLAR HEATING AND OFF-PEAK ENERGY STORAGE INSTALLATIONS.
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Authors with affiliations: Winn, C.B.; Winn, R.C.
Abstract: Control strategies for solar heating systems and for off-peak heat storage systems have been developed and investigated in terms of utility cost of supply for the year 1990. This paper includes a discussion of results obtained for off-peak storage systems, solar heating systems, and combined solar and off-peak systems for the area served by Public Serivice Co. of New Mexico.

Authors: Borgarello E., Graetzel M., Kalyanasundaram K., Pelizzetti E.
Title: PHOTOCHEMICAL WATER SPLITTING.
Authors with affiliations: Borgarello, E.; Graetzel, M.; Kalyanasundaram, K.; Pelizzetti, E.
Abstract: The generation of hydrogen by visible light from cheap and readily available sources is a high-priority subject in solar energy research. In addition to water, other agents such as hydrogen sulfide have potential for playing important roles as alternative sources for hydrogen production using sunlight. Sulfides occur widely in nature and H//2S is produced in large quantities as an undesirable by-product in the coal and petroleum industries. A new catalytic system is described in which the cleavage of H//2S into hydrogen and sulfur is driven by visible light. The standard enthalpy of reactions is plus 9. 4 kcal/mol, so this process provides a method for energy conversion and storage. As catalyst, CdS particles loaded with an ultrafine deposit of RuO//2 were used.

Title: Biogas energy from animal wastes and energy crops.

Title: Heat balance of rats acclimated to diurnal 2-hour feeding
Affiliations: Department of Physiology, School of Medicine Kanazawa University, 13-1, Takaramachi, Kanazawa, 920, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sugano, Y., Department of Physiology, School of Medicine Kanazawa University, 13-1, Takaramachi, Kanazawa, 920, Japan
Abstract: Heat production (M) and heat loss (H) of ad lib fed rats and of rats fed for 2-hr daily for 2 months (2-hr fed rats) were simultaneously measured by direct and indirect calorimetry over a period of 48 hours. The ad lib fed rats showed a clear nocturnal increase in M and H, which consisted of several discrete increases associated with discrete rises in feeding activity. In each increase, however, M and H were somewhat out of phase with each other. During feeding, a positive shift of heat storage occurred, which was repaid by H being higher than M thereafter. No such increases of M and H were observed in either the fasted ad lib fed rats or the 2-hr fed rats. The 2-hr fed rats showed a very large increase in M and H following the meal, which obscured the nocturnal increase of metabolic rate. Without food, this diurnal increase was greatly reduced but not to the minimum level, and two definite peaks of M and H associated with increased food exploratory activity, one in the day and the other at night, were obtained. There was a sharp fall in RQ 1-2 hr prior to the diurnal feeding. These observations suggest that, besides diet-induced heat production, feeding can be an additional time cue for increasing energy metabolism, but a more basic biological clock mechanism synchronizing the day-night cycle drives circadian rhythms of physical activity and biochemical processes related to energy expenditure in rats. © 1983.
Author Keywords: Circadian rhythm; Diet-induced heat production; Direct and indirect calorimetry; Diurnal feeding; Heat balance

Authors: Affolter H., Peyer M., Pletscher A.
Title: Storage of biogenic amines in guinea‐pig brain synaptosomes: influence of proton gradient and membrane potential
Affiliations: Department of Research, University Clinics, Kantonsspital, Basel, 4031, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Affolter, H., Department of Research, University Clinics, Kantonsspital, Basel, 4031, Switzerland; Peyer, M., Department of Research, University Clinics, Kantonsspital, Basel, 4031, Switzerland; Pletscher, A., Department of Research, University Clinics, Kantonsspital, Basel, 4031, Switzerland
Abstract: The effects of K+, NaCN and the ionophores monensin, nonactin and carbonyl‐cyanide‐p‐trifluoro‐methoxyphenylhydrazone (FCCP) on the contents of [3H]‐5‐hydroxytryptamine ([3H]‐5‐HT), [3H]‐dopamine and [3H]‐noradrenaline ([3H]‐NA) in guinea‐pig synaptosomes preloaded with these amines were measured. In the presence of Ca2+, K+ markedly reduced the amine content of the synaptosomes, indicating an acceleration of spontaneous amine release. In the absence of Ca2+, K+ had much less effect. Monensin, nonactin and FCCP caused a release of all the three labelled amines. This release was considerably faster and more marked than that induced by K+ and showed no dependence on Ca2+. The ionophores did not release lactate‐dehydrogenase from synaptosomes. NaCN, a blocker of oxidative energy production, did not enhance the spontaneous release of [3H]‐5‐HT nor did it influence the monensin‐induced release of [3H]‐5‐HT. It is concluded that (a) the intragranular storage of 5‐HT, dopamine and NA is dependent on the maintenance of a pH‐gradient across the granular membrane as well as on the granular membrane potential; (b) the ionophores cause a non‐exocytotic release of granular amines, and (c) blood platelets are partial models for aminergic brain neurones as far as intragranular amine storage is concerned. 1983 British Pharmacological Society

Title: Estimation of Flows of Organic Matter and Nitrogen Components in Postruminal Digesta and Effects of Level of Dietary Intake and Physical Form of Protein Supplement on Such Estimates
Affiliations: National Institute for Research Dairying, Shinfield, Reading, RG2 9AT, Berkshire, United States
Authors with affiliations: McAllan, A.B., National Institute for Research Dairying, Shinfield, Reading, RG2 9AT, Berkshire, United States; Smith, R.H., National Institute for Research Dairying, Shinfield, Reading, RG2 9AT, Berkshire, United States
Abstract: 1. Steers fitted with simple rumen, abomasal and sometimes duodenal cannulas were given isonitrogenous and isoenergetic diets consisting of pellets containing equal amounts of rolled barley and chopped straw together with tapioca alone (B), or with some tapioca replaced by coarse soya-bean meal (M) or finely ground soya-bean flour (F). Diet B had an estimated rumen degradable nitrogen (RDN): metabolizable energy (me) value of approximately 0.8 g/MJ. The corresponding value for each of the supplemented diets was 1.3-1.4. Diets were given at two levels of intake designed respectively to provide ME intakes to support weight gains of 0.5 kg/d (L) and 1.0 kg/d (H). Chromic oxide and polyethylene glycol were given as indigestible markers. Values were calculated for flows (g/24 h) at the abomasum of organic matter (om), non-ammonia-n (NAN) and microbial (bacterial)-N (MN). Estimates of MN were based on RNA and a-e-diaminopimelic acid (DAP) measurements. The steers had low rumen protozoal counts throughout the whole experiment with fewer than 8000 ciliate protozoa/ml of rumen fluid. 2. Proportions of om apparently digested between the mouth and abomasum were significantly lower for H than for L intakes but showed no other significant differences. Mean estimated efficiency of microbial protein synthesis was approximately 17 g N/kg om apparently digested in the rumen for the LB diet, but was significantly greater at approximately 26 g N/kg om apparently digested for the HB diet. The protein-supplemented diets gave values of 31–32 which were significantly greater than the value for the LB but not the HB diet. 3. Amounts of feed nitrogenous constituents surviving between the mouth and the abomasum were estimated from NAN minus MN corrected for endogenous N. Values for the proportions of feed N degraded, derived from these estimates, were 0.71, 0.66, 0.72, 0.69, 0.67 and 0.70 for diets LB, HB, LM, HM, LF and HF respectively. There were no significant differences due to level of feeding, supplementary protein or the physical form of that protein. 4. Estimates of MN flows at the abomasum based on RNA determinations in fresh samples did not differ significantly from estimates based on DAP determinations. However, storage of aqueous suspensions of mixed rumen bacteria by deep-freezing or freeze-drying resulted in significant losses of RNA. No such losses were observed for abomasal digesta. This meant that if samples were stored by these means before analysis, the use of RNA as a microbial marker was vitiated. 5. In some experiments digesta samples were taken from the duodenum as well as the abomasum. Estimates of total N flows did not differ significantly between these sites. © 1983, The Nutrition Society. All rights reserved.
