Abstract: Production of proton-antiproton pairs by two-photon scattering has been observed at the electron-position storage ring PETRA. A total of eight proton-antiproton pairs have been identified using the time-of-flight technique. We have measured a total cross section of 4.5 ± 0.8 nb in the photon-photon c.m. energy range 2.0-2.6 GeV. © 1982.

Title: Water for power: some economic aspects.
Authors with affiliations: Scott, M.
Abstract: The four hydroelectric power schemes, run-of-the-river, conventional storage, pumped storage, and micro hydropower, are defined. The economics of installing hydropower versus oil/coal fired utilities are compared and wider economic considerations are discussed for foreign exchange difficulties, tandem schemes (flood control, irrigation), flooding (loss of agricultural land), fish production in new reservoirs, population relocation. Future prospects for the developing world are considered. References are made to the export of surplus electricity generated from hydropower resources, the establishment of energy intensive industries close to hydropower sites, development of microhydro projects in isolated communities. (A.J.)

Authors: Rowe D.S., McMonagle Rowe & Assocs. C.A.
Title: Analytical modeling of the champagne effect in hydraulically compensated CAES reservoirs.
Authors with affiliations: Rowe, D.S.; McMonagle Rowe & Assocs., C.A.
Abstract: An analytical model was developed and a variety of preliminary, conservatively oriented calculations were performed which indicate the champagne effect is unlikely to cause blow out for a properly designed compressed air energy system. A one dimensional analytical model is used to represent the entire system consisting of the air pipe, storage cavern, compensation pipe and surface reservoir. Thermohydraulic aspects of air, water and dissolved air are modelled using the two fluid approach. Variations in design and constitutive relationships were studied to show that reduction of dissolved air, an increase of friction and a deep compensation reservoir mitigate the champagne effect. The most conservative results are obtained when homogeneous flow and equlibrium deaeration of the water are assumed. Best estimate calculations of compressed air energy system operation could be done through a refinement of constitutive relations and validation with experimental data. (A)
Index Keywords: bubble; Gas; liquid

Authors: Giramonti A.J., Blecher W.A., Smith E.B.
Title: Simulation of the champagne effect in CAES power plants.
Authors with affiliations: Giramonti, A.J.; Blecher, W.A.; Smith, E.B.
Abstract: The governing physical mechanisms of the champagne effect were incorporated into a computer model called CHAMP. The CHAMP model is based on a one dimensional, drift flux representation of the two phase flow in the water compensating shaft. The model includes a comprehensive simulation for the rate of release of air from solution during the flow transient. Preliminary results of the analysis suggest that by proper design of the system, including a U-bend and flow restriction, the champagne effect should not a a major detergent to commercialization of this type of compressed air energy storage power plant. A preliminary design, test programme, and cost estimate for a high pressure two phase flow test facility are described. The test facility would provide data to calibrate the model and add credibility to the analysis. (from authors' abstract)
Index Keywords: gas-liquid

Authors: Casacci S., Roche N., Jarriand P.
Title: Renewable energy high head pumping plant.
Authors with affiliations: Casacci, S.; Roche, N.; Jarriand, P.
Abstract: The present report deals with pumped storage installations at very high heads. The authors review the features of very high head pumped storage plant, at present in operation or under construction and equipped with fixed vane multistage machines. After the advantages and disadvantages of this arrangement are reviewed, the new possibilities offered by adjustable multistage pump-turbines are considered. (from authors' abstract)

Authors: Slack G., Lipman N., Musgrove P.
Title: The integration of small wind turbines with diesel engines and battery storage.
Authors with affiliations: Slack, G.; Lipman, N.; Musgrove, P.
Abstract: A wind turbine with battery storage and diesel back-up may be regarded as the state of the art wind energy system for supplying electricity to small consumers remote from a grid system. Optimization of such a system may best be achieved by means of a computer simulation such as that reported here, which examines the effect of type and size of windmill and batteries and the system control logic used.

Title: Energy storage systems-worldwide
Affiliations: Lucas Chloride EV Systems Limited, Swinton, Manchester, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Edwards, B.D., Lucas Chloride EV Systems Limited, Swinton, Manchester, United Kingdom
Abstract: Battery electric vehicle demonstration programmes in USA and Europe have emphasised the need for a robust battery with an acceptable cost per cycle. In the UK in particular, urban delivery vehicles with lead acid batteries are close to commercial viability as replacements for the diesel or gasolene vehicle, Uncertanties on oil availability and price escalation are likely to further increase demand for the battery electric alternative. Advanced battery couples with higher energy densities are necessary for penetration into the high volume vehicle market. Of the many on-going battery programmes, no clear winner has yet emerged.
Index Keywords: Battery electric vehicles; Commercial vehicles; Commercial viability; Energy storage systems; High volumes; Higher energy density; Price escalation; Urban delivery; Lead acid batteries

Title: The fiat hybrid bus program
Affiliations: Centro Ricerche Fiat, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Brusaglino, G., Centro Ricerche Fiat, Italy
Abstract: FORWARD The development of a hybrid bus has been sponsored by Italian National Research Council. It started in the middle of 1976. The FIAT Research Center was Main Contractor and Leader of a team constituted by other industries and Research Institutes. Two possible solutions in terms of secondary on-board energy source, or buffer unit have been considered: a storage battery and a flywheel. Main objective of these studies was the evaluation of the potential fuel saving. Other objectives for the battery-hybrid version were the possibility of driving in pure electric mode in given areas and recharging of the batteries by external sources of electricity. This presentation will illustrate the recently completed battery-hybrid version program. The solution with flywheel is still under development.
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Flywheels; Fuel economy; Hybrid vehicles; Wheels; Energy source; External sources; Fuel savings; Main contractors; National Research Council; Research center; Research institutes; Storage battery; Secondary batteries

Title: Natural gas (methane), synthetic natural gas and liquefied petroleum gases as fuels for transportation
Affiliations: U.S. Department of Energy, Washington, DC, United States; Mueller Associates, Inc., Baltimore, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fleming, R.D., U.S. Department of Energy, Washington, DC, United States; Bechtold, R.L., Mueller Associates, Inc., Baltimore, MD, United States
Abstract: Gaseous fuels (natural gas, synthetic natural gas and LP-Gases) used in transportation vehicles are assessed. The fuels' physical properties require larger storage volumes than liquid fuels, posing unique environmental and safety problems. Gaseous fuels provide a significant portion of the U.S. energy supply but increased uses will probably increase imports; production of synthetic natural gas and the development of unconventional gas resources will not prevent imports due to increased demand. Gaseous fuels can allow increased efficiency of spark-ignition Otto Cycle internal combustion engines during warmup at the expense of reduced specific power output. Neat methanol allows increased fuel efficiency and specific power output and is easier to incorporate into a transportation vehicle. Gaseous fuels are best suited to stationary combustion systems served by pipelines. Liquid fuels are better suited to use in transportation; alternative liquid fuels should be developed with transportation use in mind. Copyright 1982 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Alternative fuels; Energy resources; Fuel storage; Gases; Ignition; Internal combustion engines; Liquefied petroleum gas; Liquid fuels; Liquids; Natural gas; Natural gas deposits; Natural gas vehicles; Petroleum deposits; Petroleum transportation; Synthetic fuels; Combustion systems; Energy supplies; Fuel efficiency; Safety problems; Storage volumes; Synthetic natural gas; Transportation vehicles; Unconventional gas; Natural gas transportation

Title: Optimal control for maximum mileage of a flywheel energy-storage vehicle
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Univ. of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, WI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jamzadeh, F.S., Dept. of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Univ. of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, WI, United States; Frank, A.A., Dept. of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Univ. of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, WI, United States
Abstract: The flywheel energy-storage unit is examined as a tool for engine load management. The control decision to store or retrieve energy is formulated and discussed. Vehicle dynamics are simulated on a digital computer in combination with dynamic programming techniques to obtain optimal operation policy. The simplified algorithm is explained, as well as the cost-function criteria and optimization constraints. The sensitivity of the optimal path and the vehicle gas-mileage improvements are elaborated. The study of losses indicates that the transmission is the largest energy sink in the power train. The result of this study provides an indication of the appropriate real-time control policy. Copyright 1982 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Computer programming; Cost functions; Digital computers; Energy storage; Flywheel propulsion; Flywheels; Passenger cars; Powertrains; Real time control; Wheels; Control decisions; Dynamic programming techniques; Flywheel energy storage; Optimal controls; Optimal operation policy; Optimal paths; Simplified algorithms; Vehicle dynamics; Dynamic programming

Title: A design for zinc-chlorine batteries
Affiliations: Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Mitra, S., Centre of Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, 110016, India
Abstract: An alternative design for a zinc-chlorine electrical energy storage system is described. It is proposed that operation under higher than normal press. © 1982.

Title: Operational and energetical effectiveness of road electric and hybrid propulsion
Affiliations: FIAT Research Canter, Strada Torino, 50, Orbassano Torino, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Brusaglino, G., FIAT Research Canter, Strada Torino, 50, Orbassano Torino, Italy
Abstract: Fiat Research Center is developing, since several years, activities on electric and hybrid apparatuses. These has been applied on vehicles manufactured either for experimental or for praticai operation purposes. The development has been performed with particular consideration to energetical effectiveness, driving response and maintenance requirements, taking into account the economical aspect. The efficiency is achieved both through the drive system concept and the energy management strategy. The drive system for present applications are based on separately excited d.c. motors fed by electronic power conditioners. The particular features of the traction motors and the controllers with the possible diversified version for various applications are discussed in the paper. In the field of future technology, the approach with permanent magnets has been considered. Results on a permanent magnet d.c. motor are presented. The system development and integration as well as the control strategy is explained with reference to the Fiat 900E/E2 and the Iveco Daily 2 electric vans, having a payload of 1/2 ton and 1 ton respectively. The energy consumption of these vehicles measured at the mains is some 160 wh/ton in ur-ban operation. The operational aspect is discussed referred to driving response and maintenance. In the field of hybrids, the propulsion apparatus and the energy control strategy is described for a hybrid electric bus, developed in a program supported by the Italian National Research Council. It consists of a diesei electric generator unit, storage batteries and a separately excited d.c. motor with electronic controller. The system optimization strategy allowed an improvement of- fuel economy in hybrid mode operation in urban area's in terms of 27% in comparison with the conventional version of the bus operating in the same conditions of payload and driving pattern. © 1982 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Automobile manufacture; Controllers; DC motors; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Energy management; Energy utilization; Fuel economy; Permanent magnets; Propulsion; Traction motors; Trucks; Electronic controllers; Electronic power conditioner; Energy management strategies; Hybrid electric bus; Maintenance requirement; National Research Council; Operational aspects; System optimizations; Electric machine control

Title: Field testing the Fluid Rod Production System
Source title: Proceedings - SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: KOBE, Inc., United States
Authors with affiliations: Peterson, D.G., KOBE, Inc., United States; Brady, J., KOBE, Inc., United States
Abstract: The Fluid Rod Production System introduces a new concept for the production of low volume wells. Utilizing production fluid or non-treated lease water as the power transfer medium, fluid power is transmitted from a skid mounted surface unit to a downhole stroker which directly actuates a standard API rod type pump. This Fluid power is cyclicly applied and relieved at the surface unit to create a pumping action downhole. The fluid utilized for power transfer is contained in a small diameter tubing string and with the exception of a small amount of slippage downhole, remains in this string thus eliminating the need for a large fluid supply or fluid storage and treating facility. Field testing now underway has demonstrated that the Fluid Rod Pump is a viable alternative for the production of low volume wells. Prototype system testing has been under way in Brea, California since October of 1981. During that time the system has been tested at various production rates up to 155 BFPD and the optimization of components has been carried out. A production version of the system has been operating in Wilmington, California since June of 1982. This installation has demonstrated the versatility of the system by operating at an average of 20 BFPD in a well deviated 19° from vertical at the seating depth. © 1982 Society of Petroleum Engineers (SPE). All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Energy transfer; Engineers; Gasoline; Pumps; Water treatment; Well testing; Fluid storages; Optimization of components; Power transfers; Production fluids; Production rates; Production system; Prototype system; Pumping action; Oil well pumps

Authors: Wilkins B.J.S., Rigby G.L., Dryden J.R.
Title: Thermal stress induced fracturing/stress-relaxation in rock adjacent to an underground storage vault
Affiliations: Atomic Energy of Canada Research Co., Pinawa, MB, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Wilkins, B.J.S., Atomic Energy of Canada Research Co., Pinawa, MB, Canada; Rigby, G.L., Atomic Energy of Canada Research Co., Pinawa, MB, Canada; Dryden, J.R., Atomic Energy of Canada Research Co., Pinawa, MB, Canada
Abstract: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited is studying the underground storage of nuclear waste in a vault in hard rock in the Canadian Shield. As part of this work, models are being developed to assess the possible rates of escape of various waste components through the rock to the biosphere. At the temperatures expected (<150°C) ln the vlclnlty of the vault, the response to stress perturbation will be creep, via macro- and microfracturnng. As rock permeability and the overall stability of the vault will be affected by the extent of fracturing, it is important to establish the possible extent and kinetics of fracture processes. This paper describes some aspects of this work. It presents a two-dimensional finite element model that relates stress relaxation to microfracturing using linear elastic fracture mechanics. The kinetics of the process are derived from slow crack extension data for a local granite. © ISRM International Symposium, IS 1982.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Fracture mechanics; Rock mechanics; Stress relaxation; Atomic energy of canada limiteds; Canadian shields; Linear elastic fracture mechanics; Overall stabilities; Rock permeability; Stress perturbations; Underground storage; Waste components; Rocks

Title: Evaluation of a conventional steam drive with ancillary materials: North Kern Front Field
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - SPE California Regional Meeting, CRM 1982
Affiliations: Chemical Oil Recovery Co., United States
Authors with affiliations: Eson, R.L., Chemical Oil Recovery Co., United States; O'Nesky, S.K., Chemical Oil Recovery Co., United States
Abstract: Steam drive projects account for over 64% of all of the United States' Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR) production, nearly 156,000 BOFD (24,000 m3/d). Even though steam drive is the most successful of all EOR processes, it is not without its problems. Gravity segregation and poor areal and vertical sweep efficiencies have limited recoveries in many heavy oil reservoirs. In many instances the injected steam prematurely breaks through into producing wells creating steam channels. If this steam channeling can be controlled to some degree and the steam is forced to contact more of the reservoir, overall recoveries can be improved. This paper documents efforts under a Department of Energy cost sharing contract to reduce steam channeling in a conventional steam drive using ancillary materials. A steam foam solution and a steam foam encapsulated in a polymer gel are being introduced in four steam injection patterns In the North Kern Front Field near Bakersfield, California. The ability of the ancillary materials to improve recovery will be determined through injection profiles, chemical tracer surveys, casing vent gas analyses, core and log data, and residual oil saturation data, as well as through temperature and production monitoring. It has been shown that in-situ steam foams can be used to alter the steam injection profiles to prevent excessive steam channeling. Results after injection of ancillary materials for approximately 18 months indicate that improvements in both the areal and vertical sweep efficiencies have been found in the four treated patterns when compared to the untreated control patterns.- Several techniques are still under evaluation to determine the exact amount of incremental oil produced. Disscussion of production response will be limited to two of the four treated patterns, Witmer B2-3 and Witmer B2-5. A comparison of these two patterns to the Witmer control pattern, Witmer A2-7, indicates approximately 52 B/D (8 mv/d) of incremental oil is being produced as a result of the weekly chemical treatments. © Copyright 1982, Society of Petroleum Engineers of AIME.
Index Keywords: Chemical analysis; Cost effectiveness; Crude oil; Digital storage; Engineers; Enhanced recovery; Gasoline; Heavy oil production; Oil field equipment; Oil well logging; Petroleum reservoir evaluation; Petroleum reservoirs; Recovery; Steam; Thermal logging; Chemical treatments; Department of Energy; Enhanced oil recovery; Heavy oil reservoirs; Production monitoring; Production response; Residual oil saturation; Steam injection profiles; Injection (oil wells)

Title: Recent developments in underground storage techniques
Affiliations: WPSystem AB, Stockholm, Sweden; Teknisk Databehandling AB, Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Calminder, A., WPSystem AB, Stockholm, Sweden; Hahn, T., Teknisk Databehandling AB, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: Changes in the energy situation, as well as safety aspects, have caused new and more stringent demands to be made for the storage of oil. It will become necessari to put an increasing share of the oil storage underground. However, conventoonal methods for storage of oil, on waterbed in unlined caverns are not sufficient for all types of products. Vertica, cylindrcal caverns can provide better storage conditioss for oil products. Simple calculatoons show that from a rock mechanicll point of view, such caverns are preferabee because the cylindrical wall and the dome or cone-shaped roof provides more favourable stress conditioss at the contour. © ISRM International Symposium, IS 1982.
Index Keywords: Rock mechanics; Cone-shaped; Cylindrical walls; Energy situation; Oil product; Oil storage; Safety aspects; Underground storage; Caves

Authors: Weishen Z., Dingxiang F., Shiwei B.
Title: Some considerations of research on stability of underground storage caverns
Affiliations: Institute of Rock and Soil Mechanics, Academaa Sinica, Wuhan, China
Authors with affiliations: Weishen, Z., Institute of Rock and Soil Mechanics, Academaa Sinica, Wuhan, China; Dingxiang, F., Institute of Rock and Soil Mechanics, Academaa Sinica, Wuhan, China; Shiwei, B., Institute of Rock and Soil Mechanics, Academaa Sinica, Wuhan, China
Abstract: This paper presents some considerations of research on the stability of underground storage caverss in rock. At the beginning the author introduces a conception of transformations and distribution of energy in rocks confining the cavern and proposes an approximate equation of conservation of energy which is a fundamental criterion to be followed for studying and controlling the stability of a cavern. Then, relatngg to a research work of a 40-meter-span cavern in China, this paper discusses some problems concerning the measuremests of earth stress in the fieldd the non-linear finite elemett analysis and finaly, the analytical method used for evaluatine the fracture zone of rock mass and so on. At the end of this paper a great deal of numerical analogic computation with finite elemett method for studyngg the stability analysis of a cavern with varioss joint systess in varioss stress field is liste. Some significant conclusions for selection the site and locatiod of a large span cavern as well as for design and constructnon of the suppott are given. © ISRM International Symposium, IS 1982.
Index Keywords: Engineering research; Numerical methods; Rock mechanics; Rocks; Site selection; Stability; Analytical method; Approximate equation; Conservation of energy; Fracture zone; Large-span cavern; Stability analysis; Underground storage; Underground storage caverns; Caves

Authors: Stephanson O., Bergman S.G.A., Åkesson B.Å., Stillborg B., Sagefors K.I.
Title: Nuclear power production in an underground chain
Affiliations: University of Luleå, Luleå, Sweden; Chalmers University of Technology, Gothenburg, Sweden; Stocksund, Sweden; Swedish Mining Research Foundation, Kiruna, Sweden; WP-System AB, Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Stephanson, O., University of Luleå, Luleå, Sweden; Bergman, S.G.A., Stocksund, Sweden; Åkesson, B.Å., Chalmers University of Technology, Gothenburg, Sweden; Stillborg, B., Swedish Mining Research Foundation, Kiruna, Sweden; Sagefors, K.I., WP-System AB, Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: Environmental disturbances and risks of surface nuclear energy production can be considerably reduced by locating all the components of the system underground. Reactors and turbines and also intermediate and final storage for spent fuel are then linked together by tunnels. Surface transports of radioactive fuel and waste are thus eliminated. Safety in handling, transportation and storage is improved. The halls for the reactors and turbines will need caverns with large spans and a rock cover of 40-70 m. Such caverns can also be built in medium-rated rock masses using the Rib-in-Roc method. The risk of polluting the surface environment with radioactivity after a core meltdown and vessel collapse can be considerably reduced by using safety tunnels filled with crushed rock. The contaminated gas can then expand into these tunnels instead of reaching the atmosphere. © ISRM International Symposium, IS 1982.
Index Keywords: Caves; Core meltdown; Fuel storage; Nuclear energy; Nuclear fuels; Radioactivity; Rock mechanics; Turbines; Crushed rock; Environmental disturbances; Large span; Nuclear power production; Rock mass; Surface environments; Surface nuclear energy; Surface transport; Rocks

Title: Experimental study of rocksalt for compressed air energy storage
Affiliations: Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thoms, R.L., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, United States; Gehle, R.M., Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, United States
Abstract: A combined laboratory and field test program was performed for long-term cyclic load effects on rock salt. Tesl conditions were selected to simulate compressed air energy storage (CAES) effects on salt surrounding pressurized caverns. Data are presented and discussed for permeability, mechanical response, and hydraulic fracturing of salt related to CAES effects. © ISRM International Symposium, IS 1982.
Index Keywords: Compressed air; Digital storage; Mechanical permeability; Pressure vessels; Rock mechanics; Software testing; Compressed air energy storages (CAES); Field test; Load effects; Rock salt; Compressed air energy storage

Title: The design and construction of the imaichi underground Power plant
Affiliations: Tokyo Electric Power Co. Inc., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Mizukoshi, T., Tokyo Electric Power Co. Inc., Japan
Abstract: The Tokyo Electric Power Co., Inc. is now in the process of excavating a large cavern-33.5 m wide, 51 m high, and 160 m long- to set a 1,050 MW pumped-storage power plant 400 m under the ground surface. The cross section of the cavern is horseshoe-shaped, the first time that such a shape has been used in Japan. It is planned to redistribute the stress resulting from excavation along the walls. To this end, the supports and lining of the walls are designed to make effective use of the resistance of the surrounding rock. The paper reports on the rock foundation tests, stability analyses using FEM, measurements Plan, and the supporting and lining work carried out for the cavern stability. © ISRM International Symposium, IS 1982.
Index Keywords: Caves; Electric energy storage; Pumped storage power plants; Rock mechanics; Cavern stabilities; Design and construction; Ground surfaces; Rock foundation; Stability analysis; Surrounding rock; Tokyo electric power; Rocks

Title: Demonstration of a wind energy conversion system in Skamania County, Washington. Final project performance report, September 30, 1980-September 30, 1982.
Abstract: In May of 1981, the Mars Landing Power Project (MLPP) erected the first modern wind turbine generator (WTG) in the Columbia River Gorge, in Skamania County, Washington. The WTG is a direct current generator with a 14 foot diameter blade, capable of a maximum output of 4 kW in a 27 mile per hour wind. Output is stored in a 350 amp/hour lead/acid battery bank and is used to supply electric power for 3 households. Good performance is reported, in spite of severe storms, ice, and freezing rain. The WTG supplied 2/3 of the power requirements for the three households it served. Public information activities are reported. Future plans include a hot water storage system for use in a greenhouse, and the design and installation of a computer based home heating and cooling maintenance system.

Title: Wind energy research for agriculture.
Authors with affiliations: Clark, R.N.
Abstract: The United States Department of Agriculture-Agricultural Research Service (USDA-ARS), in cooperation with the Department of Energy (DOE), began field experiments on wind machines in 1976. This work involved modern, high speed units that are capable of powering much of our modern stationary farm equipment and producing electricity compatible with utility power. The USDA-ARS is conducting these experiments to identify, develop and test applications of wind power in agriculture. Additional studies have been conducted on economics and load requirements for wind machines. Six field experiments were completed in 1980 with two each in Building Heating, Irrigation and Product Storage and Processing. Building Heating projects were conducted using a 15-kW cycloturbine to power a water churn to produce hot water. Both projects in Product Storage and Processing provided refrigeration with short and long term storage systems. Milk was cooled at a dairy and exhaust heat from the compressor was used to preheat the hot water. In the other project, apples were cooled and stored for six months. The apple storage system incorporated an ice bank for storage during non-wind periods. (from author's abstract)

Title: Wind energy system design for remote applications.
Issue: (ed.), Oxford, U.K., Pergamon Press Ltd., 1982, Topic B, Paper B11, p.165-170. (ISBN 0-08-027606-7)
Authors with affiliations: Watson, G.R.
Abstract: The main methods of obtaining wind data are compared and the results used to provide wind turbine performance comparisons. The effect of cut-in and furling speeds are shown with their implications on turbine design. Several systems are compared and their control and storage requirements discussed. (A)

Title: Energy storage for wind-generator application.
Authors with affiliations: Russell, F.M.
Abstract: A low-cost method was developed for storing energy and stiffening power supplied by wind generators. It involved inflatable, fabric reinforced elastic liners buried underground and containing a fluid, probably water, at an intermediate pressure. The ground would be subject to elastic deformation and the method could be applicable to unstable ground such as deep sand, heterogeneous sedimentary or other unconsolidated deposits in remote locations or hostile environments. While the density of energy storage was considered low, compared with pumped-hydro systems, the technology could be attractive for developing countries. (A)
Index Keywords: power; Wind

Authors: Mitchell R., Noun R.J., Flaim T., Deutsch M., Jacobs E.
Title: Wind-energy program: FY 1982 second quarterly review.
Authors with affiliations: Mitchell, R.; Noun, R.J.; Flaim, T.; Deutsch, M.; Jacobs, E.
Abstract: Progress on the following tasks is summarized: program management and planning, WECS applications in nongenerating utilities; technical feasibility of standalone SWECS; WECS/storage assessment and options; WECS performance/value analysis; wind energy industry analysis; wind systems coordination; wind workshops; noise and television interference studies; and advanced and innovative wind energy concepts. (A)

Title: Heat-pump cool storage in a clathrate of freon.
Authors with affiliations: Tomlinson, J.J.
Abstract: The analytical description and preliminary technical assessment of a unique heat pump/storage system, in which the conventional evaporator of the vapour compression system is replaced by a direct contact crystalliser, is presented. The thermal storage technique requires the formation of a refrigerant gas hydrate (a clathrate) with an enthalpy of reaction comparable to the heat of fusion of ice. Operational benefits include cool storage at temperatures of 4 to 7 exp 0 C, and heat transfer rates afforded by the direct contact mechanism. In addition, the possibilities of using this technique to provide isothermal storage at higher temperature levels in discussed. Paper presented at the 17th Intersociety Energy Conversion Engng. Conf., (Los Angeles, U.S.A.: Aug. 8, 1982). (from author's abstract)
Index Keywords: Heat transfer

Title: Increased efficiency of hydroelectric power.
Abstract: The results of a project to study the potential for increasing hydroelectric generation efficiency at existing plants are presented. Physical factors studied included the uprating of turbines and generators, leakage control, and use of flashboards. The study concluded that excluding pumped storage, there is a potential for a 17% increase in capacity and approximately a 5% increase in energy from existing conventional plants. (A)
Index Keywords: database; hydraulic dam; intake; reservoir; trash rack

Authors: Dekisch A., Etzier G.C., Fritzsche A., Lorch G., Mueller M.
Title: Development of a 5.5 M diameter vertical axis wind turbine (Phase 3).
Authors with affiliations: Dekisch, A.; Etzier, G.C.; Fritzsche, A.; Lorch, G.; Mueller, M.
Abstract: Discusses some studies for the development of a 5.5 m diameter vertical axis wind turbine, in particular a one year field test supply to a small power grid under optimum conditions, independent of different wind speeds. Two Savonius rotors (2 m diameter) were mounted on the 3 blade version of the Darrieus rotor. Adjustable Savonius blades (3 blade version) were used to experimentally find the most efficient angular position. Modifications and optimization slope were evaluated. Describes adjustment of the blades of the Savonius rotor, gear lubrication variation of rotor speed, and simulation of a small grid with a large storage battery. Outlines guidelines for layout of low cost Darrieus wind turbines (n series) and associated control and energy conversion system. (from authors' abstract)
Index Keywords: power; Wind

Title: Wind generated electricity for isolated communities.
Abstract: This report on a study of electricity generation by wind power thouroughly examines the technical and financial aspects of various windmill types and generating schemes, including hybrid types such as wind/diesel systems, and systems with energy storage by batteries or hydraulic accumulators. The section on hydraulic energy storage describes available components such as pumps, motors, valves and accumulators. (K.R.)

Title: Geotechnical basis for underground energy storage in hard rock. Final report.
Authors with affiliations: Farquhar, O.C.
Abstract: Design and construction problems of large caverns in hard rock are discussed, with emphasis on underground pumped hydroelectric storage and compressed air energy storage.

Title: Compressed-air energy storage preliminary design and site-development program in an aquifer. Volume 1. Executive summary.
Source title: PALO ALTO, U.S.A., ELECTR. POWER RES. INST., JUN. 1982
Abstract: A study was performed to investigate the behaviour and suitability of an aquifer based compressed air energy storage (CAES) facility. The project was co-sponsored by the Department of Energy and Electric Power Research Institute as part of Phase II of a five phase programme to promote CAES and underground pumped hydro in the United States. The methodologies, descriptions, and results derived from the study were incorporated into a nine volume final report. Volume 1, entitled Executive Summary, provides the background, project organization, and summarization of all project work. (A) (Microfiche)

Authors: Bruce Tomas, Lindeberg Lennart, Roslund Stefan
Title: CENTRAL SOLAR HEATING PLANTS WITH SEASONAL STORAGE.
Source title: Document - Swedish Council for Building Research
Authors with affiliations: Bruce, Tomas; Lindeberg, Lennart; Roslund, Stefan
Abstract: The paper reviews heat and energy distribution systems by means of hot water in various countries and discusses basic assumptions for the heat distribution in a central solar heating plant with seasonal storage.
Index Keywords: BUILDINGS - Space Heating; Energy storage; STRUCTURAL DESIGN - Mathematical Models; HEAT DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS; Heating

Title: World energy supply: resources, technologies, perspectives.
Source title: World energy supply: resources, technologies, perspectives.
Affiliations: Scientific Director, Fuhrungsakademie der Bundeswehr, Hamburg, Germany., Germany
Authors with affiliations: Grathwohl, M., Scientific Director, Fuhrungsakademie der Bundeswehr, Hamburg, Germany., Germany
Abstract: Treats the problems of world energy supply for the future as a whole, and intends primarily to inform the reader by providing reliable data on the connection between aspects of the total energy situation. Chapters include discussions on primary energy sources as they relate global economics; the world energy potential from hydrocarbons, nuclear and alternative sources; energy supply systems and the role of secondary energy sources - specifying different types of nuclear reactor, methods of solar thermal conversion, and a variety of indirect secondary sources from renewable energy technologies. Gives a comprehensive summary of energy storage, supply and transport systems. The environmental impact and problems of safety of any energy release are discussed, detailing specific problems associated with different sources. Concludes with general predictions for, and consequences of changes in future demand.- after Author

Authors: Kinsella E., Vokaer D., Steemers T.C.
Title: Extended abstracts of final reports in the field of solar energy applications to dwellings ( EEC).
Source title: Extended abstracts of final reports in the field of solar energy applications to dwellings ( EEC).
Affiliations: Nat. Board for Science & Tech., Dublin, Ireland.
Authors with affiliations: Kinsella, E., Nat. Board for Science & Tech., Dublin, Ireland.; Vokaer, D., Nat. Board for Science & Tech., Dublin, Ireland.; Steemers, T.C., Nat. Board for Science & Tech., Dublin, Ireland.
Abstract: 'Solar energy applications to dwellings' project A, is one of the eight tasks which form the Solar Energy R & D Programme of the Directorate General XII, for Science, Research and Development of the Commission of the European Communities. It includes two types of actions: 1) the 'concerted actions', which are executed with a common programme in different countries, at the same time. These actions are dealing with: modelling of solar heating and domestic hot water systems, validation of these models with data from solar pilot test facilities, performance monitoring of solar houses, collector testing, passive systems and modelling of passive systems; 2) individual research programmes carried out within the frame of contracts with research institutes or private companies, and dealing with solar heat storage and solar cooling mainly. The present document contains 24 extended abstracts of the final reports of the research work, as they became available in the last two years.-Authors

Title: Available energy and environmental economics.
Affiliations: Oakland Univ., Rochester, Michigan, USA., United States
Authors with affiliations: Edgerton, R.H., Oakland Univ., Rochester, Michigan, USA., United States
Abstract: The objective of this book is to provide engineers and people making technological decisions with new techniques for dealing with energy and environmental situations. Quantitative methods and techniques of combining thermodynamic design and economic analysis are emphasised. An attempt is made to provide the basis of a thermodynamic accounting system for evaluating alternative futures in the energy, economic and environmental status of the world. Attempts to integrate qualitative descriptions of entropy into a quantitative measure defined as the 'available energy'. Examines energy transfer between systems, solar, bioenergetic and chemical-thermodynamic mix energy potential, plus a variety of other available energy sources. Energy dissipative and storage systems are also considered.-after Author

Title: Turbocompressor considerations in compressed-air-energy-storage plants.
Authors with affiliations: Vogt, R.L.
Abstract: Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) technology provides an efficient, environmentally compatible opportunity to increase the capacity factor of existing base load generating stations by storing off-peak energy, large, efficient turbocompressor systems are available now for CAES service. Well suited turbocompressors have accumulated a considerable performance history in the industrial sector. Axial, centrifugal, and barrel type compressors are desirable for CAES duty, and are compared here. Historical turbocompressor experiences having particular significance for CAES plants are summarized. (from author's abstract)
Index Keywords: axial compressors; barrel compressors; centrifugal compressors

Authors: Lukas H., Montogomery M., Schainter R.
Title: Recuperative heat exchangers in compressed air energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Lukas, H.; Montogomery, M.; Schainter, R.
Abstract: Finite element computer modelling was used to calculate thermally induced stresses in tube to tubesheet joints of recuperators considered for a compressed air energy storage plant. The areas of low temperature sulphuric acid corrosion and flow induced vibration were investigated. The conclusionof this study was that a recuperator can be designed and built at reasonable cost which will provide acceptable service life. This paper presents an overview of the project and reports some of the major highlights, conclusion,s and recommendations. (A)
Index Keywords: Heat exchangers; Heat transfer

Title: Buoyant plane jets in thermally stratified media.
Authors with affiliations: Jaluria, Y.
Abstract: Studies mixed convection flow in a laminar vertical plane jet discharged in a thermally stratified environment. Notes application to energy storage and heat rejection systems for solar power in particular. Discusses the predicted downstream variation of the centreline velocity and temperature, and the effect of stratification of the corresponding profiles. A linear ambient temperature distribution is assumed. Determines the local buoyancy level, the zero level bouyancy position, though the boundary flow treatment is not suitable for a study of the reverse flow region. Outlines the nonboundary layer effects near the source. Compares flow with plane thermal plume flow. (C.J.U.)

Title: Energy storage options for harnessing wind energy.
Authors with affiliations: Ramakumar, R.
Abstract: The inherent variability of the wind energy resource necessitates either an energy storage and reconversion system or a back-up unit to supply customers 'on demand'. A brief survey of the technical aspects of the various energy storage and reconversion options proposed for use with energy conversion systems is presented. Energy can be stored in mechanical, chemical, thermal, or electrical form. The schemes discussed include hydrofirming, compressed air, flywheels, hydrogen, secondary batteries, and thermal storage. (A)

Title: Feasibility of an underground pumped hydro storage in The Netherlands.
Authors with affiliations: van Lohuizen, H.P.S.; Halberg, N.
Abstract: Energy storage systems generally offer the utilities the potential of: a more effective use of fossil fuels, the long term potential of shifting from oil and gas, a more rational utilization of combined heat and power production and, theoretically, unlimited possibilities for using renewable alternative energy sources. The economic value of these benefits have to compensate for the costs of the storage system. As the Netherlands is a flat country, only relatively expensive storage systems, such as underground pumped hydro and low head pumped hydro, are feasible. Some aspects on locations and construction alternatives of an underground pumped hydro are discussed. (A)

Authors: Barnett J.H., Carter C.L., Buffett R.K., Todd D.E.
Title: EPRI/TVA PILOT ELECTRIC VEHICLE DEMONSTRATION PROJECT: PHASE I.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Barnett, J.H.; Carter, C.L.; Buffett, R.K.; Todd, D.E.
Abstract: This is the second and final report of the first phase of the EPRI/TVA Electric Vehicle Demonstration Project conducted at Chattanooga, Tennessee. The first report (EPRI EM-2095) included the strategy and methodology used in implementing an electric vehicle (EV) demonstration program which was conceived after an evaluation of prior worldwide efforts. It included the vehicle evaluation and selection process, demonstration planning, site preparation, facilities development, data gathering and design of on-board monitoring equipment. This part includes information gained from testing and evaluation of ten Volkswagen electric vehicles--five buses and five vans--operating in a ″real-world″ environment under controlled conditions. Real-time and other data were collected on the EVs during the eighteen month period from January, 1980 through June, 1981 and analyzed to determine their performance capabilities. Route and mission studies were conducted to determine EV applications within the TVA fleet and to develop an approach for identifying suitable missions for EVs within general utility fleet operations. Summaries of the operation of these vehicles are included along with evaluations of selected components. System energy efficiency, operating and maintenance data are presented for each vehicle. Failure analyses that were performed to determine vehicle and component deficiences and strengths are presented.
Index Keywords: MOTOR BUSES - Electric; ELECTRIC VEHICLES; VANS; STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES

Authors: Boyd D.W., Buckley O.E., Clark C.E.
Title: COMPRESSED-AIR ENERGY STORAGE: COMMERCIALIZATION POTENTIAL AND EPRI ROLES IN THE COMMERCIALIZATION PROCESS.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Boyd, D.W.; Buckley, O.E.; Clark, C.E.
Abstract: This report describes an assessment of potential roles that EPRI might take to facilitate the commercial acceptance of compressed air energy storage (CAES) systems. The assessment is based on (1) analyses of the market potential of utility storage technologies, (2) interviews with representatives of key participants in the CAES market, and (3) decision analysis synthesizing information about market and technology status. The results indicate a large potential market for CAES systems if the overall business environment for utilities improves. It appears that EPRI can have an impact in ensuring that utilities realize the potential of CAES by (1) continuing an aggressive information dissemination and technology transfer program, (2) working to ensure the success of the first United States CAES installation at Soyland Power Cooperative, (3) developing planning methods to allow utilities to evaluate CAES and other storage options more effectively and more realistically, and (4) supporting R&D to resolve residual uncertainties in first-generation CAES cost and performance characteristics.
Index Keywords: Compressed air

Title: ADVANCES IN ENERGY SYSTEMS AND TECHNOLOGY, VOLUME 3, 1982.
Source title: Advances in Energy Systems and Technology
Abstract: This book consists of three papers offering solutions to the problem of energy conservation. The first paper deals with the feasibility of utilizing unconventional sources of natural gas, such as tight gas, Devonian shales, coal seams and geopressured aquifers. The second paper shows how France, by pursuing a consistent nuclear power program, has become a leader in civilian nuclear technology. The first commercial-sized nuclear breeder reactor is being constructed and essentially all the elements of a complete nuclear cycle are now in place, including nuclear waste storage for indefinite periods. The description of the French program should serve as a valuable lesson to all students of nuclear energy. The third paper deals with ways of improving transportation energy efficiency in the United States, paying particular attention to power plant and other technologies for highway vehicles and to efficiency improvements for air transportation, but sadly neglecting the renewed use of railroads as a means of energy conservation.
Index Keywords: Energy resources

Title: ADVANCES IN HYDROSCIENCE VOLUME 13, 1982.
Abstract: The book contains 4 papers that present a review of simulation techniques for aquifer thermal energy storage; theory of thermal control and prevention of ice in rivers and lakes; hydraulic theory of alluvial rivers; and stochastic analysis and probabilistic prediction of random seas.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Hydrology; INLAND WATERWAYS - Ice Control; Thermodynamics; Water waves; Seawater

Title: EXAMINED FISSION PRODUCT ACCUMULATION PROGRAM USING ENDF/B-V DECAY DATA.
Source title: Atomic Energy of Canada Limited, AECL (Report)
Authors with affiliations: Walker, E.H.; Hebert, A.
Abstract: The CRNL fission product accumulation program, FISSPROD, has been revised and expanded. Output treatment has been completely revised by the use of random access data storage. After all time steps are completed for a given case various groups of data are recalled and listed by time steps. A standard output lists incremental and accumulated irradiation and decay time for each step, assorted parameters for each fissile nuclide and total fission product absorption, decay energy release, heat, radioactivity and mass.
Index Keywords: FISSION YIELD RATES; ISOTOPIC NUMBER; Nuclear reactors

Title: ELECTRICAL HEATING OF FORGING BILLETS.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Keith, R.E.; Weldon, W.F.
Abstract: Recent and ongoing research concerned with homoplar generators operated in a pulse mode and making use of kinetic energy storage principles has led to the application of these techniques to forging billet heating. Most forging billet heating is done using fuel-fired furnaces, but use of electric induction heating is increasing. The homopolar pulse billet heating (HPBH) process is described and its capabilites are evaluated relative to furnace and induction heating. Conclusions are that applications for this new process will most likely be in the heating of stainless steel and super-alloy billets, particularly if present research efforts are successful in reducing costs.
Index Keywords: Electric generators, DC; ELECTRIC HEATING, INDUCTION - Applications; FORGINGS - Heat Treatment; FORGING BILLETS; HOMOPOLAR GENERATORS; Rolling mill practice

Authors: Chaney S.R., Humphrey J.A.C., Shah A.
Title: FLOW AND HEAT TRANSFER OF A STABLY-STRATIFIED FLUID IN AN ENCLOSURE.
Source title: U.C. Report FM - University of California, Berkeley, Department of Mechanical Engineering
Authors with affiliations: Chaney, S.R.; Humphrey, J.A.C.; Shah, A.
Abstract: The flow rates of stratified fluid (thermocline) were investigated. Measurements of temperature and of the energy storage performance characteristics of the thermocline were made as a function of time. Predictions of these quantities based on the analytical solution of a simplified energy conservation equation, neglecting buoyant effects in the flow field, are in good agreement with the measurements.
Index Keywords: Heat transfer

Title: FEASIBILITY ASSESSMENT OF CUSTOMER-SIDE-OF-THE-METER APPLICATIONS FOR BATTERY ENERGY STORAGE.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Stolte, W.J.
Abstract: Reduction of peak demand in utility systems can be beneficial to both utilities and customers. One means of achieving peak demand reduction is the use of load-leveling batteries. This report describes an investigation of the techno-economic factors for customer-owned battery energy storage plants. Only current state-of-the-art lead-acid batteries were considered. The study has taken into account realistic battery and balance-of-plant (BOP) costs, current utility rates, and customer load profiles typical of those for which battery storage may be feasible. Battery storage system designs and costs were described and quantified through contacts with vendors and use of previous study results. Utilities with electric rate structures expected to favor customer load-leveling were selected and contacted to obtain the most current rates and customer load profiles. Using these data for generic applications, an economic analysis was conducted. A baseline application was described and evaluated using internal rate of return (ROR) and payback methods. Cost and performance parameters were varied parametrically to determine the sensitivity of the results to these parameters. An analysis of five specific customer applications was also made.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric utilities; Energy storage; Electric power systems

Title: Channel bars in gravel-bed rivers.
Authors with affiliations: Church, M.; Jones, D.
Abstract: Discusses features of channel bars sedimentary accumulation that represent major storage places for bed load sediments only sporadically moved and important flow resistance elements that may evolve in the short term. Distinguishes hydraulic element bars, storage element bars and bars produced by non-fluvial effects. Classifies bars and riffles and examines their stability. Analyses with the help of field observation the spatial organisation of bars the bar complexes of braided river reaches and their sedimentation zones (sedimentary megaforms). Discusses the function of bars as energy dissipators. Discussion of the paper, pages 325-338, includes notes on bed form classification, bar formation and shear stress channel geometry relationships. (C.J.U.)

Title: Buoyant plane jets in thermally stratified media.
Authors with affiliations: Jaluria, Y.
Abstract: Studies mixed convection flow in a laminar vertical plane jet discharged in a thermally stratified environment. Notes application to solar ponds. Discusses the predicted downstream variation of the centreline velocity and temperature and the effect of stratification on the corresponding profiles. A linear ambient temperature distribution is assumed. Determines the zero local buoyancy position though the boundary flow treatment is not suitable for a study of the reverse flow region. Outlines the nonboundary layer effects near the source. (C.J.U.)
Index Keywords: energy; Storage

Authors: Carling R.W., Bradshaw R.W., Mar R.W.
Title: Aluminide coatings for alloy protection in molten NaNO SUB 3-KNO SUB 3 at 600 DEGREE C.
Issue: (ed.), Warrendale, U.S.A., Am. Inst. Min., Metall., & Pet. Engrs. Inc., 1982, p.261-269. (ISBN 0-895
Authors with affiliations: Carling, R.W.; Bradshaw, R.W.; Mar, R.W.
Abstract: Molten drawsalt (NaNO SUB 3-KNO SUB 3) is being considered as the energy transfer and storage medium for many solar central receiver applications. In an effort to reduce the cost of the containment material while maintaining corrosion resistance, alloys with aluminide coatings were examined after immersion in molten drawsalt for up to 6000 hours at 600 DEGREE C. The alloys examined were 2 1/4Cr-1Mo, 5Cr-1/2Mo, and 9Cr-1Mo steels, and 316 stainless steel. The results show a steady, albeit slow, net weight loss over the course of the experiment. The weight loss was attributed to spalling of Al SUB 2O SUB 3 from the surface (the occurrence of AL SUB 2O SUB 3 is a result of the aluminizing process) and the dissolution of corrosion products NaA10 SUB 2 and/or NaFeO SUB 2 during post immersion handling. Scanning electron micrographs of exposed surfaces revealed little or no corrosion of the base metal. It was concluded that aluminide coated alloys can provide significant corrosion resistance for the alloys tested when in contact with molten drawsalt at temperatures up to 600 DEGREE C. (A)
Index Keywords: Coatings; Metals

Title: COOL STORAGE INSTRUMENTATION AND DATA VERIFICATION PROGRAM.
Source title: Electric Power Research Institute (Report) EPRI EM
Authors with affiliations: Bullock, C.E.; Reedy, W.R.
Abstract: Results of a residential cool storage instrumentation and data verification program are reported. The purpose of the program was to gather quantitative field performance data on operating systems and develop guidelines for the use and application of cool storage systems. The reuslts provide the electric utility industry with data to aid in the evaluation of cool storage impacts on utility load factors, revenues, operating costs, and capacity requirements. R&D needs and opportunities are identified. Program tasks included the monitoring and analysis of 18 cool storage experiments, development of mathematical models required for an analytical evaluation, and the conduct of parameter studies. Results of the field monitoring and analytical studies indicate that cool storage can be an effective means of shifting electrical load, and that the required refrigeration condensing unit capacity can be smaller than would be required for a conventional air conditioning system. However, the resulting seasonal energy use required for a state-of-the-art cool storage system is always greater than for a conventional system. The customer may need a significant additional capital investment. Electrical consumer interest in cool storage is therefore tied to the establishment of proper time-of-day electric rate schedules or other means of financing incentives to reflect the utility interests in improving electrical system load factors.
Index Keywords: AIR CONDITIONING - Energy Storage; HEATING - Energy Conservation; Electric power systems

Title: The aquifer compressed air field experiment at Pittfield, Illinois.
Authors with affiliations: Allen, R.D.; Doherty, T.J.
Abstract: Compressed air energy storage is a concept that may be used by electric utilities for load levelling. Off peak energy is used to compress air and store it in geologic reservoirs for use during peak demand. Aquifers can store natural gas economically and may be suitable for compressed air energy storage, but differences in geochemistry, cycling period, temperature and viscosity must be evaluated. A test site was identified near Pittsfield, Illinois to perform these evaluations. The reservoir is a gently inclined dome consisting of impervious dolomitic caprock overlying permeable sandstone. Temperature, pressure, liquid water content, relative humidity, and withdrawn mineral particles were monitored and analyzed to enable comparisons of reservoir behaviour with numerical and experimental models. Pre and post test cores were compared with respect to chemical composition, mineralogy, microstructure, and physical properties. Data from the field, laboratory, and numerical modelling studies were integrated to develop comprehensive stability criteria for compressed air energy storage within aquifer reservoirs. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Economic selection of a CAES facility for an actual power system.
Authors with affiliations: Menge, E.E.
Abstract: The purpose of this study was to evalute and compare various methods for supplying the peaking power capacity that Soyland Power Cooperative Inc. will need in 1986 and thereafter. Three alternative peaking power facilities were considered: simple cycle combustion turbines; combined cycle combustion turbines; compressed air energy storage (CAES). Non-peaking energy supply sources included in the evaluation of each alternative consisted of a 97 MW share of the Clinton 1 nuclear facility available in 1983, and a 450 MW (net) coal fired facility to be available in 1987. Energy purchases from both Central Illinois Public Service and Illinois Power Company are continued as required to meet projected load and reserve requirements. (from author's abstract)

Title: Ice maker heat pumps for energy storage applications.
Authors with affiliations: Somerville, M.H.
Abstract: The design of an ice making system for an off-peak air conditioning application is presented. The actual operational characteristics of the system, as well as some of the technical problems encountered during the installation and operation of the system, are discussed. Recommendations for changes in the rating codes and standards as well as changes to the design codes are made and discussed. (from author's application
Index Keywords: heat pumps

Title: The first U.S. CAES plant - a review.
Authors with affiliations: Ruzich, R.R.; Miller, J.B.
Abstract: Soyland Power Cooperative Inc. of Decatur, Illinois is building the first Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) power plant in the United States. Because of the nature of the technology, and its being the first application of its kind in this country, there have been very few well established procedures or patterns to follow in implementing the project. This paper describes the strategy and logic that shaped and defined the various steps that were needed to bring the project to its current state. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Energy storage in geologic media.
Authors with affiliations: Gustin, J.D.
Abstract: This paper synthesizes current design concepts for the storage of potential energy in geologic media utilizing compressed air energy storage and underground pumped hydro. These concepts have been refined through cooperative studies over the last 6 to 7 years by international utilities and by American utilities under the sponsorship of the Department of Energy and the Electric Power Research Institute. These studies indicate that energy storage in underground caverns and aquifers appears to be a technically and economically viable method of conserving off peak power generated by existing fossil and nuclear power plants. U.S. work in the field is reviewed. (from author's abstract)

Authors: Stange J.R., Gianuzzi L.F., Nakhamkin M., Anderson T.
Title: Heat rejection system optimization for compressed air energy storage power plants.
Authors with affiliations: Stange, J.R.; Gianuzzi, L.F.; Nakhamkin, M.; Anderson, T.
Abstract: A generic procedure for heat rejection system optimization for compressed air energy storage application is presented. The results of optimization and engineering of the heat rejection system for the Soyland Power Cooperative Compressed Air Energy Storage plant are given. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Evaluation of an air-bubble control technique for compressed air energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: McIntosh, D.A.
Abstract: The ability to contain a compressed air bubble in a confined aquifer with a horizontal caprock structure was investigated. A numerical model was developed to evaluate the use of injection and withdrawal wells to manipulate the pressure field of a confined aquifer such that it was suitable for compressed air storage. In addition, a Hele-Shaw model was used to provide a preliminary assessment of the proposed containment scheme and to afford a means for verifying the computer simulation technique. The results verified the technical feasibility of using injection wells to establish a pressure field that is conducive to compressed air storage. (from author's abstract)
Index Keywords: energy; Storage

Title: NASA REDOX STORAGE SYSTEM DEVELOPMENT PROJECT.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: This annual report (for the period ending approx Dec. 1980) describes the technical accomplishments pertaining to the development of Redox systems and related technology. Task elements discussed in this report are representative of Department of Energy (DOE) policies in existence during calendar year 1980.
Index Keywords: CHEMICAL REACTIONS - Redox; Electrochemistry; Electrolytic cells

Authors: Zaloudek F.R., Wheeler K.R., Marksberry L.
Title: An evaluation of thermal energy storage media for advanced compressed air energy storage systems.
Authors with affiliations: Zaloudek, F.R.; Wheeler, K.R.; Marksberry, L.
Abstract: Proposed designs of adiabatic and hybrid compressed air energy storage plants have utilized sensible heat storage systems to store the heat developed during the air compression phase of the operating cycle for subsequent use during the power generation phase. This study was performed to experimentally evaluate the performance and durability of several heat storage materials proposed for these systems. Materials considered were: 3/8 in. sintered iron oxide pellets, 1/2 in. Denstone spheres, 1-in. cast iron alloy balls, and crushed rock. The results indicated that, from the standpoint of performance and durability, Denstone, cast iron containing 27% or more chromium, or crushed rock (Dresser basalt) would be satisfactory. However, considering material costs in addition to performance and durability, crushed rock would probably be the most desirable heat storage material for these types of compressed air energy storage plants. (A)

Title: RESEARCH RESULTS AND APPLICATIONS 1982 EDITION.
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Thiry-five examples of those EPRI research projects results are presented that have been beneficially adopted by electric utilities. One hundred and six new near-term research accomplishments are also described that are ready for utility application. These examples cover the entire spectrum of electric R&D: 1) fuel processing, 2) electric power generation, 3) transmission and distribution, 4) energy storage and managment, 5) energy analysis, and 6) environmental assessment and control. A user's guide is attached which discusses how to access information and, once a document of interest is found, how to minimize time spent in interpreting that information.
Index Keywords: Electric power distribution; ELECTRIC POWER GENERATION - Energy Resources; Electric power transmission; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT - Control; Electric utilities

Title: TESTS OF AN ALTERNATING CURRENT PROPULSION SUBSYSTEM FOR ELECTRIC VEHICLES ON A ROAD LOAD SIMULATOR.
Authors with affiliations: Stenger, Francis J.
Abstract: Test results are presented of a breadboard version of an ac-electric vehicle propulsion subsystem designed and built as a part of the U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) Electric and Hybrid Vehicle Program. Steady-state tests were run to characterize the system and component efficiencies over the complete speed-torque range within the capability of the propulsion subsystem in the motoring mode of operation. Transient tests were performed to determine the energy consumption of the breadboard. The maximum steady-state subsystem efficiency observed for the breadboard was 81. 5 percent in the high-gear-speed range in the motoring mode, and 76 percent in the regenerative braking mode (low gear).
Index Keywords: STORAGE BATTERY VEHICLES; Propulsion

Authors: Ayers D.L., Baladi J.Y., Bonk J.S.
Title: Design of wells and piping for an aquifer CAES plant.
Authors with affiliations: Ayers, D.L.; Baladi, J.Y.; Bonk, J.S.
Abstract: The design of compressed air energy storage system for an aquifer reservoir requires that wells be used to move air into or out of storage. The design of such a well system depends upon the rate of air flow within the storage volume. A two dimensional mathematical model of transient, conmpressible air flow in an aquifer reservoir was developed. The model, coupled with characteristics of plant rotating equipment, is capable of predicting flow into or out of the reservoir. It was used to perform a design of a well system for an aquifer located near Media, Illinois. (A)

Title: Compact energy storage.
Authors with affiliations: Dooley, J.L.; Hammond, R.P.
Abstract: Recent improvements in air liquefaction plant efficiencies make it practical to consider liquid air as a medium for storing off peak power to handle peak load shaving in a utility grid. For power output the liquid is pressurized and heat by combusion with some fuel before expansion in turbines. Advantages are high storage density, good efficiency and response with benign environmental characteristics. (A)

Title: High pressure test facility for the resolution of the champagne effect.
Authors with affiliations: Pellin, J.
Abstract: EPRI initiated a research project to investigate the installation of a 50 bar compressed air energy storage champagne effect testing facility in Europe. This paper describes the site selection, compares various facility design principles, their technical characteristics, the related costs and depicts the optimum solution. (from author's abstract)
Index Keywords: gas-liquid

Title: Wind and tidal energy integration into an electricity network.
Authors with affiliations: Bossany, A.E.
Abstract: An electricity grid simulation model developed by G. Whittle has been run with and without tidal plant, various amounts of wind plant, and pumped storage to determine the fuel savings achieved by the renewable sources singly and in combination. The results demonstrate that the savings due to any renewable source are slightly reduced if the system already contains some renewable sources. The savings are greater if storage is available, particularly in the case of wind power.

Title: Only economic restraints are holding back world's fast flow to hydro.
Abstract: This paper discusses hydroelectric development which, it is believed, will have a very important role in the energy scene by the end of the century. It is also believed that the number of projects now being planned or developed would undoubtedly be much greater if it were not for the recessional constraints on capital expenditure. The Dinorwic pumped storage project is discussed in detail and shown to be a major engineering feat by any world stadards. Various other hydroelectric projects are also discussed. The paper concludes that for the future, government and utilities worldwide are actively considering hydroelectric possibilities and they can see sound economic reasons for choosing hydro against other forms of generation for power extraction programmes. However, when large projects can prove extremely expensive, it is becoming increasingly crucial for them to have an awareness of the significant advances in recent years in design, engineering and equipment technology. (A.B.)

Title: Advances in hydroscience. Volume 13-1982.
Authors with affiliations: Chow, V.T.
Abstract: Reviews the state-of-the-art modelling of aquifer thermal energy storage including (1) physical, chemical, and energy mechanisms, (2) mathematical treatment of transport mechanisms, (3) simulation techniques for permeable media, (4) techniques for analysing geochemistry, (5) applications, and (6) site-specific considerations. (165 refs.)

Authors: Boehman L.I., Anderson L.A., Bishop W.S., Strnat R., Egart M.K.
Title: The University of Dayton alternate energy hybrid research facility.
Authors with affiliations: Boehman, L.I.; Anderson, L.A.; Bishop, W.S.; Strnat, R.; Egart, M.K.
Abstract: A hybrid solar and wind energy system including a wind energy converter, solar photovoltaic array, storage battery and a computer for system monitoring and data acquisition is being used to identify cost-effective combinations of solar and wind energy components which satisfy a specific load in a given location. (P.M.T.)

Title: Compressed-air energy storage system analysis.
Authors with affiliations: Heilmann, W.J.
Abstract: A constant-volume, nonfired Compressed-Air Energy Storage (CAES) research system of about 100-kwh capacity has been built at Institut de recherche d'Hydro-Quebec. The thermodynamic efficiencies of the system were investigated experimentally and theoretically, closed and open system models are presented to derive the work potential and to simulate the thermodynamic processes observed. Solutions of instantaneous and cycle efficiencies of the subsystems and the total CAES system are presented graphically and numerically. Comparison of the isentropic and the isothermal process models shows that the latter gives a better efficiency approximation. (A)

Authors: Marinacci D.J., Bonk J.S., Bumgarner J.M., Schainker R.B.
Title: Optimizing the performance of Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) compressor and turbine trains.
Authors with affiliations: Marinacci, D.J.; Bonk, J.S.; Bumgarner, J.M.; Schainker, R.B.
Abstract: The potential future market for Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) systems is discussed. The savings realized by utilizing CAES power plants can be very attractive with the proper generation mix. Thermodynamic parametric performance studies were conducted to screen the various aquifer charging and discharging cycles. Equations are presented to calculate directly the optimum (minimum required total compressor work and air cooler heat rejection) intercooler(s) location for a compressor train utilizing one and two intercoolers. An equation is also presented which directly determines the reheat combustor location required to maximize the turbine train output. (from authors' abstract)

Title: Regenerative heat exchangers in compressed air energy storage.
Issue: (San Francisco, U.S.A.: Sep. 20-22, 1982), New York, U.S.A., Am. Inst. Aeronaut. & Astronaut., 1982,
Authors with affiliations: Lukas, H.; Schainker, R.
Abstract: Finite element computer modelling was used to calculate thermally induced stresses in tube to tubesheet joints of recuperators considered for a compressed air energy storage plant. The areas of low temperature sulphuric acid corrosion and flow induced vibration were investigated. The conclusion of this study was that a recuperator can be designed and built at reasonable cost which will provide acceptable service life. This paper presents an overview of the project and reports some of the major highlights, conclusions, and recommendations. (A)
Index Keywords: Regenerators

Title: Turbocompressor considerations in compressed-air-energy-storage plants.
Issue: (San Francisco, U.S.A.: Sep. 20-22, 1982), New York, U.S.A., Am. Inst. Aeronaut. & Astronaut., 1982,
Authors with affiliations: Vogt, R.L.
Abstract: Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) technology provides an efficient, environmentally compatible opportunity to increase the capacity factor of existing base load generating stations by storng off-peak energy. Large, efficient turbocompressor systems are available now for CAES service. Well suited turbocompressors have accumulated a considerable performance history in the industrial sector. Axial, centrifugal, and barrel type compressors are desirable for CAES duty, and are compared here. Historical turbocompressor experiences having particular significance for CAES plants are summarized, and the Sulzer compression systems for Huntorf and Soyland are reviewed. Thermodynamics and operational considerations are made regarding efficiency, starting, charging, dispatching and load uptake. (A)

Title: Feasibility of an underground pumped hydro storage in The Netherlands.
Issue: (San Francisco, U.S.A.: Sep. 20-22, 1982), New York, U.S.A., Am. Inst. Aeronaut. & Astronaut., 1982,
Authors with affiliations: Lohuizen, H.P.S.; Halberg, N.
Abstract: The possibility of using wind energy in underground pumped hydro storage in the Netherlands is considered. Locations and construction alternatives to U.P.H. are discussed. (P.J.B.)

Authors: Behrmann P., Hafner H., Speilkamp L.
Title: Use of waste water for supply water heating by use of heat pipe diodes.
Issue: (ed.), Oxford, U.K., Pergamon Press Ltd., 1982, p.235-244. (ISBN 0-08-027284-3)
Authors with affiliations: Behrmann, P.; Hafner, H.; Speilkamp, L.
Abstract: A hot supply water storage tank, which is heated by waste water heat, was developed by Dornier System GmbH under a Daimler-Benz AG contract. Copper heat pipes using water as carrier fluid were developed for this purpose, capable of transferring sufficient heat even at temperatures as low as 10 DEGREE C. Measurements indicated that up to 90% of the usable waste water heat can be recovered depending on the waste water flow rate and on the complexity of the system. Stratification within the tank allowed more than 75% of the stored energy to be drawn without a signficant drop in supply water temperature. (from authors' abstract)
Index Keywords: Heat pipes

Title: The turbomachinery for the compressed air energy storage plant of the Soyland Power Cooperative.
Issue: (San Francisco, U.S.A.: Sep. 20-22, 1982), New York, U.S.A., Am. Inst. Aeronaut. & Astronaut., 1982,
Authors with affiliations: Zaugg, P.; Haselbacher, H.
Abstract: In this paper, it will be shown which parameters of an air storage plant determine the design of the turbogroup. Then, after an overview of the Soyland machinery, the turbine, the high pressure combustion chamber and the compressor-group will be mentioned only to the extent necessary for the understanding of the turbo-group. The remaining sections will be devoted to the explanation of the operating behaviour of the turbogroup. (from paper)
Index Keywords: Turbomachinery

Title: Influence of Eddy Current on the Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage System
Source title: IEEJ Transactions on Power and Energy
Affiliations: Department of Eleetrical Engineering, Washeda University, Japan; Electrotechnical Laboratory, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ishiyama, A., Department of Eleetrical Engineering, Washeda University, Japan; Agatsuma, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Japan

Authors: Ishiyama A., Agatsuma K., Sogama T.
Title: Control Methods for the Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage System and Their Experiments
Source title: IEEJ Transactions on Power and Energy
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Waseda University, Japan; Electrotechnical Laboratory, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ishiyama, A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Waseda University, Japan; Agatsuma, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Japan; Sogama, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Japan
